fields.headline: Bolton fined £45,000 for poaching Allardyce
fields.trailText: Bolton were last night taking legal advice after being fined £45,000 by the Football League for poaching the then Notts County manager Sam Allardyce in October.
fields.body:
Bolton were last night taking legal advice after being fined £45,000 by the Football League for poaching the then Notts County manager Sam Allardyce in October.

Allardyce was also fined a lesser amount after being found guilty of breaching his contract.

Bolton appointed him five days after he resigned from County.

"Bolton spoke to him while he was still under contract, which is against regulation 20:1," a league spokesman said. "He had handed in his notice at Notts County but it had not been formally accepted, so he was still under contract."

 Manchester United, Arsenal and Chelsea have been given until the end of the month to open formal negotiations for Ruud van Nistelrooy. "If none of the clubs open discussions with PSV by the start of May, then I'll stay another year in Holland. I will sign the improved contract that they have put before me," said the 23-year-old national striker. "But if one can reach an agreement with PSV over my contract, which has three years to run, then I will leave for England."

 Middlesbrough have confirmed they will play in a May event in Libya to mark the official opening of the Great Man Made River stadium, although talk of a £1m package was dismissed as "grossly exaggerated".

 West Ham have paid the London Owls supporters club £140 to buy a replacement player of the year trophy for the one awarded to Paolo di Canio in 1998 but not returned after he joined the Hammers.

 Graham Poll will referee the FA Cup final between Aston Villa and Chelsea on May 20.

webTitle: MPs sound alarm on drug research

fields.headline: MPs sound alarm on drug research
fields.trailText: A parliamentary committee will sound a note of alarm today about the possibility that Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham could move their drug development operations overseas following their imminent merger.
fields.body:
A parliamentary committee will sound a note of alarm today about the possibility that Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham could move their drug development operations overseas following their imminent merger.

A report into the deal by the Science and Technology select committee will warn that the companies' long-term presence in Britain is conditional on the availability of good science graduates.

MPs on the committee are likely to tell the government that it must pour money into scientific education, to avert the risk of thousands of job losses.

One Labour member of the committee said: "The message is that the science base here in Britain is wonderful but if profits are to be made in Beijing, that's where they'll go."

The MP added: "They've no loyalty to this country and they're very powerful. They're effectively telling us they're bigger than the government."

Another committee member said: "These multinationals will go where the science is best. We must continue to nurture scientists - we need to keep university departments staffed with good quality teachers and well equipped with infrastructure."

The committee heard evidence on the merger from Glaxo's chairman Sir Richard Sykes and SmithKline's chief operating officer, Jean-Pierre Garnier. MPs were generally impressed with the two executives. One MP said: "They're two of the toughest cookies I've ever come across."

Today's report will give its support for the merger in principle, echoing the committee's conclusions two years ago when a previous attempt at a tie-up collapsed.

MPs accept that the two groups need greater critical mass to prosper in an industry which is consolidating rapidly. One said: "We think its right for both national and international interests."

Between them, Glaxo and SmithKline employ 21,900 people in the UK and unions fear up to 5,000 job losses. The committee is likely to express concern but conclude that some job cuts are "for the greater good in the long term".

The operational centre of the new group will be in New York with a head office in Britain to deal with "corporate" issues.

fields.headline: Emanuel Ax
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.body:
The Harrods International Piano Series is a showcase for the only breed of performer regularly to have the whole stage to themselves. Yet this does not mean that all the performers live up to the role of showman. Emanuel Ax does not hide behind the veneer of a stage persona - he shuffles on to the stage, smiles a lot, plays, then bumbles off again. His performances are all the more enjoyable for the resulting feeling of sincerity.

Seated at the instrument, Ax's affability gave way to a focused concentration. He appeared deceptively relaxed, even under the scrutiny of the camera shot of the keyboard that was projected above him throughout (more intrusive than useful, as it put paid to any sense of stillness around the performer). There was very little self-consciousness in his playing, and he managed to draw a wide spectrum of colour from the instrument without histrionics. Especially effective was his liberal use of the soft pedal, which made some of the more subdued passages recede into the distance.

The first work to benefit from this unaffected approach was Haydn's Sonata in A flat, Ax's performance belying the fact that this was one of the longest sonatas the composer wrote. His control over his tonal palette made for some striking moments - such as the muted, echoing repeat at the end of the opening section of the first movement, and the sense of stillness as the second movement returns to its home key.

It was Haydn who inspired the most interesting part of Ax's programme: three pieces written in homage, all based on ciphers of the composer's name. Many composers have used the technique of assigning a note of the scale to each letter of the alphabet, and it was fascinating to hear the different treatments that the five-note motif, spelling out Haydn's name, had been given. Ravel made it into a broad, almost rhapsodic theme, producing a Minuet that teetered knowingly along the tightrope between wistfulness and schmaltz. Debussy made the notes stand out starkly against a misty accompaniment, at times pugnacious, always insistent. George Benjamin's 1982 Meditation on Haydn's Name centred around clustered repetitions of the Haydn notes, ever present against angular phrases exploring the rest of the keyboard, and finally blossoming into a rippling series of arabesques.

Schumann's huge Carnaval is also partly based on musical ciphers. Ax's reading was colourful, though the feeling of struggle that the music demands during the final section made itself felt in one or two imprecise chords - not that they took away from an intense, thoughtful performance.

fields.headline: Luxurious and erotic
fields.standfirst:
LSO/Simon Rattle
Barbican Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
LSO/Simon Rattle
Barbican Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
Strauss fans are having a good time at present. Hard on the heals of the Royal Opera's outstanding Rosenkavalier come concert performances of Ariadne auf Naxos conducted by Simon Rattle, which scale similar heights of intensity and abandon. This is no mean feat, for of all Strauss's operas, Ariadne is perhaps the least suited to the concert format. In either of its versions, it's an opera about opera and also - in the 1916 edition which Rattle favours - a reflection on the power of theatrical performance to transcend the backstage tensions which go to create it (the better 1912 original posits a diametrically opposite view).

As such, it screams out to be staged, and there's a terrible danger that its impact will be blunted and the cut and thrust of its argument will be lost, when it's done with singers line up in evening dress clutching scores. Nevertheless, this was a superlative achievement, with Rattle visibly relishing every note of the piece and the LSO - apart from a couple of dodgy moments from the brass - playing as if their lives depended on it. There were plenty of sexy, translucent textures, gorgeous string and woodwind solos, and throughout an overwhelming sense of drive and energy.

Rattle's Ariadne is Anne Schwanewilms, making her London debut and taking over at short notice from the indisposed Katerina Dalayman (not an easy thing to do). A Barenboim discovery, Schwanewilms is big in Berlin, and, one hopes, will become so here. The sound is rich, opulent, all thrilling top notes and creamy low ones, and the role's colossal range is well within her capabilities. She cultivates a glamourous, statuesque hauteur on the platform - not at all inappropriate here - and suggests from the outset that Ariadne is a woman who has sublimated her sexuality into spiritual yearning. At the end of the opera she yields to Johan Botha's clarion Bacchus with tangible eroticism. She has outstanding potential - and one hopes she won't wreck it by doing too much too soon as some singers are wont to do.

As Zerbinetta, Christine Schafer proves a perfect foil. If Schwanewilms is unusually sexy, then Schafer is unusually serious. Anything but the stereotypical tart, she looks svelte and Dietrich-like in a tall coat and is by turns touchingly vulnerable and strongly proto-feminist. Her big aria, advocating equal rights to pleasure for men and women, is beautifully voiced - this is by far and away her best performance since her Lulu at Glyndebourne. Cult mezzo Angelika Kirchschlager is the Composer. The role lies a fraction high for her - you're occasionally aware of effort - but her passionate declamation is riveting. The rest of the casting - which includes Thomas Allen as the Music Master and Christopher Maltman as Harlequin - is luxurious beyond belief.

Ariadne auf Naxos is at the Barbican tonight. Box office: 0171-638 8891.

fields.headline: Investors wary as ARM sparkles
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: ARM Holdings, the Cambridge based microchip designer that became one of last year's stock market stars, beat market expectations yesterday to report a 157% jump in first quarter profits.
fields.body:
ARM Holdings, the Cambridge based microchip designer that became one of last year's stock market stars, beat market expectations yesterday to report a 157% jump in first quarter profits.

The sparkling figures were still not enough to convince nervous investors to mark up the price of ARM shares, which lost more than 40% of their value during the technology stocks sell-off of the past month.

Despite climbing 9% in early trading the shares closed down 57p at £39.58 after company executives told analysts not to raise their earnings estimates for the next two quarters. In early February ARM shares were trading as high as £50, up from around £2 a little over a year before.

In the three months to March 31, pre-tax profits jumped 157% to £8.2m, beating analyst forecasts of £5.2m to £7.2m. Revenues leapt 64% to £21.4m, while the total volume of microchips shipped under ARM licenses climbed from 51m to 72m.

Robin Saxby, the chief executive, said the jump in profits came from larger than expected royalties from manufacturers who build ARM technology into their electronic devices. Royalties increased threefold year-on-year and now account for 22% of total revenues. Margins climbed from 20% to 33% compared with a year ago.

"We are building momentum," Mr Saxby said. "We have more partners than before who are shipping more products than before and royalties are increasing all the time."

He added that ARM signed a further five new licensees in the period and extended a number of existing agreements.

Charles Elliott, an analyst with Goldman Sachs, summed up market reaction by describing the figures as "splen did" but cautioning that the shares, which trade at a heady 300 times 2001's forecast earnings, remain fully valued. "It would take another very big rise in profits to make the shares look inexpensive," he said.

Competition concerns, as much as the wider market sell-off of technology stocks, have weighed heavily on ARM's share price in recent weeks. Mr Saxby said he was not worried that the emergence of a number of new microchip design companies such as ARC Cores and Bookham would derail ARM's ambition of getting its technology into all mobile devices worldwide by 2010.

"We will never ignore the competition and will look and learn from what they do - but we have a 10-year headstart on many of our rivals and as long as we implement well I believe history will prove that a lot of their announcements were just noise."

ARM's growth has been driven by its exposure to the fast growing mobile phone industry; its technology is now in threequarters of all mobile phones worldwide.

Other devices such as set-top boxes for digital TV, digital audio appliances, games consoles and hard-disk drives are increasingly adopting ARM technology, Mr Saxby said. He believes cars could be the next big moneyspinner. ARM's technology is already used in airbags, braking systems and engine management and "the car will become the next big web access point after the PC," he predicted.

"You'll be able to watch TV, check your share prices, listen to digital music and book tables at local restaurants using global positioning technology. ARM designs can be used in all those areas."

ARM intends to open a new office in Taiwan, and has agreed to pay £375,000 for Infinite Designs, a Sheffield design firm which has previously acted as a consultant.

fields.headline: Love in the house
fields.standfirst:
Black Eyed Peas
LA2, London
***
fields.trailText:
Black Eyed Peas
LA2, London
***
fields.body:
It's strange what a tiny stage, some basic visuals and a couple of hundred fans can do for a band. For the Black Eyed Peas it takes a trio of well-meaning, if bland, rappers and turns them into hyperactive party animals.

Their debut album, Behind the Front, made stateside heroes of the Black Eyed Peas crew - Will-I-Am, Ap De Ap and Taboo - but here in Britain they're known only to those who still consider a backward baseball cap cool. Which is odd considering Behind the Front is the perfect background music for credible dinner parties, with it's mellow, unexciting grooves and inoffensive lyrics. Fear of a Black Planet, it ain't.

But having just finished a high-profile support slot on the Macy Gray tour, and with a new album, Bridging the Gap, Black Eyed Peas are out to get the respect and success they believe they deserve. From the moment they burst on-stage, they've got something to prove. Shedding their comfy coffee table image, they suddenly become bouncing arbiters of fun and flava. The sheer enthusiasm is amazing, as Will-I-Am, dressed in fetching waistcoat and tea-cosy hat, jumps up and down like a kid on Christmas Day. Taboo, all Rudolph Valentino head scarf and Bruce Lee moves, can hardly contain himself, while Ap De Ap does lunges towards the crowd in a hip-hop style, hyping the audience. "Word up," he cries, "love in the house."

And there certainly is. The crowd feeds off the exuberance of their heroes, while the band maintain their energy levels thanks to all those hands in the air. The Black Eyed Peas' mission is to show the good guy side of rap, banishing "all the negativity and bullshit rap that's out there", Taboo explains. The good time continues as the crowd parts to allow each member of the group to do a spot of breakdancing. As the head-spinning spectacle takes place, the Peas' backing band shines. And it is very much a band, rather than just hired hands, re-creating familiar samples note perfect.

When the irrepressible Will-I-Am forgets his words mid-rap, not once, but twice, it merely adds to the informal nature of the night. Backing singer Kimmy Kim tells us: "That's the beauty of hip-hop, you never know where it's gonna go."

fields.headline: Who do I put first?
fields.trailText: 11 April: My boss's secretary told me off the record that she has applied for another job. I feel in a bit of a dilemma: should I tell the senior managers?
fields.body:
The problem

I have recently started a job as an office manager but I worry whether I am becoming too matey with the other staff. My boss's secretary told me off the record that she has applied for another job, which offers a much better salary than our company could offer.

I feel in a bit of a dilemma. If she gets the position then I am concerned that senior managers may find out and ask why I didn't tell them. If I tell them, and she doesn't get the job, I may ruin her working relationship with her boss and turn the other office staff against me.

The solution

I don't think there should be any dilemma here at all. You were told something in confidence and therefore are not in a position to disclose it. It isn't something that is particularly important for the bosses to know, anyway. What would they do if they did know she was looking for another job? Fire her? Look for her replacement? Neither option is possible until she actually hands in her notice, so I don't really see that you have any reason to tell them.

If the senior management do complain that you never told them, explain how important it is for you to maintain good relationships with your staff - and this means keeping confidences where necessary. The fact that people feel able to confide in you demonstrates your excellent people skills - something that your managers should appreciate. You could also point out that you did not feel that the information would benefit them at that time.

So, stop worrying and congratulate yourself on doing well in your new job. To be able to get on with everyone and do the job well is a great achievement - don't let this little niggle spoil things!

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Secrecy jibe in PC row
fields.trailText: The John Lewis Partnership yesterday accused the office of fair trading of secrecy in an escalating row over the market for personal computers.
fields.body:
The John Lewis Partnership yesterday accused the office of fair trading of secrecy in an escalating row over the market for personal computers.

The chain of department stores issued an angry condemnation of the consumer watchdog, after it refused to re-open its investigation into PC sales.

The partnership said it was "difficult to test the OFT's decision because it keeps to itself the data it has collected".

John Lewis added that the OFT compared "unfavourably" with the US Department of Justice, which published all the evidence it considered in the recent Microsoft trial.

The dispute has erupted because of the emergence of exclusive supply agreements between two leading computer manufacturers and Dixons, the retail group which owns PC World and Currys.

Dixons maintains that Packard Bell and Compaq have chosen to restrict themselves to its stores because they offer knowledgeable staff and efficient distribution.

However, John Lewis claims that they exacerbate Dixons' already dominant position in the PC market. It cites independent market research showing that 57% of computers purchased in the high street are from Dixons' stores.

Dixons disputes this, saying that it only has 10% of the overall market, taking into account mail order and internet channels.

Packard Bell stepped into the row yesterday, defending its agreement with Dixons. Marketing director Graham Paterson said: "The lion's share of our business last year was through the Dixons group. The exclusive deal was a natural evolution of that."

He said there were extra costs involved in supplying smaller retailers, which were not worth paying.

Mr Paterson added: "We're having to sharpen our pencils on a regular basis to remain competitive. We certainly don't feel there are any grounds at all for declaring the market uncompetitive."

The OFT said vertical agreements between manufacturers and retailers were "commonplace and do not generally give rise to competition concerns".

However, a John Lewis insider said the partnership was "seriously considering" seeking a judicial review of the OFT's findings.

webTitle: Dolly's creators seek big league ally

fields.headline: Dolly's creators seek big league ally
fields.trailText: Cloning specialist PPL Therapeutics, which created Dolly the sheep, is on the brink of signing up a big pharmaceuticals corporation to commercialise its first medicines.
fields.body:
Cloning specialist PPL Therapeutics, which created Dolly the sheep, is on the brink of signing up a big pharmaceuticals corporation to commercialise its first medicines.

PPL's chief executive, Ron James, said talks were under way with three "global players" and five smaller, more specialised drugs companies.

The news sent PPL's shares up 24p to 157p.

PPL's partner will pay for development and marketing of AAT, a protein which the Scottish company has produced in the milk of genetically altered sheep.

AAT occurs naturally in the blood but some people are born with a congenital deficiency. They suffer from a form of emphysema which is often fatal. Cystic fibrosis patients also lack AAT. The total market for the substance could be £670m, PPL says.

"We said we were hoping for a partnering deal by the middle of the year and we're very much on track to deliver it," Mr James said.

PPL has taken AAT through phase two clinical trials but wants a partner to fund a phase three study, which would involve more than 100 patients. If this is successful, AAT could be filed with regulators next year.

PPL's full-year losses edged up 1% to £14.4m, the company reported yesterday. Capital expenditure fell from £3.6m to £1.1m, despite spending on a new farm in New Zealand and extra housing for sheep in Scotland.

The company has a large stock of genetically altered animals including cows, sheep, rabbits and mice.

PPL announced last month it had created the world's first cloned piglets. The company believes that through genetic modification it can develop "knockout pigs" with organs suitable for transplant into humans.

Mr James said that heart, lung or kidney transplants might be possible within seven years.

PPL was planning to charge about $20,000 (£12,500) for each organ - about equal to the cost incurred in human-to-human transplants. The total market worldwide could be worth $6bn.

The project received support recently from Christian Barnard, the surgeon who performed the world's first human heart transplant. He read in the press that PPL had named one of its piglets Christa to honour him. He has asked to visit the animal and indicated enthusiasm for the idea of transplanting pigs' organs.

Other PPL products under development include a fibrin sealant, used to make wounds heal faster, produced in sheeps' milk.

webTitle: Dot.com valuations put back in touch with reality

fields.headline: Dot.com valuations put back in touch with reality
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The tide of technology companies seeking capital via a stockmarket flotation could turn as instability in global markets causes panic among investors, a survey said yesterday.
fields.body:
The tide of technology companies seeking capital via a stockmarket flotation could turn as instability in global markets causes panic among investors, a survey said yesterday.

KPMG said initial public offerings found the number of companies seeking flotation on the main market had halved to 13 in the quarter ending in March. Even so, a large proportion of those 13 companies seeking £889m in capital, were technology-related like lastminute.com and Knowledge Support Systems.

In 1999 there were a total of 70 new issues raising £5bn. Neil Austin, KPMG corporate finance's head of new issues, said that up until two weeks ago the technology floats on the UK market looked set to continue.

"While business to consumer stocks had fallen out of favour in the US it wasn't until the disappointment of lastminute.com that this view was reflected in the UK," Mr Austin said. "With the recent fluctuations of Nasdaq and the Techmark 100 index there is significant uncertainty in the marketplace and unless it stabilises soon many flotations may have to be postponed."

Lastminute.com was issued at 380p a share, and ended yesterday down 10.5p to 203.5p. However, despite the concern about the volatility in technology stocks at least four internet related businesses applied for AIM listings yesterday. They were network solutions provider Metonni, online market agency iCommsMedia Group, CTRLP.com and inflexion.

AIM's popularity has seen some technology companies achieve capital raisings greater than those of companies joining the main market, Mr Austin said. Yes TV, which offers video-on demand services, is another company not deterred by the volatility with a listing planned for April 23. Spread companies had the group trading on the grey market at 320p to 330p yesterday, compared with its indicative offer price of 225p to 275p a share.

Dru Edmonstone, of Durlacher's institutional sales team, refuted suggestions of a slowdown in technology-related public offerings. "It's scaremongering really," he said. "On the surface there is no indication of it slowing down, though there may have been floats put on hold." He said insti tutional and small investors had become more cautious. "Gone are the days when new issues are going to double on their first day. Valuations are no longer losing touch with reality."

Mr Austin said despite concern about volatile trading, corporate advisory firms had a "very strong pipeline" of IPO's which would see them "working to capacity" until August.

webTitle: Stop this sex farce, I want to get off

fields.headline: Stop this sex farce, I want to get off
fields.standfirst:
The Threesome
Lyric, Hammersmith
*
fields.trailText:
The Threesome
Lyric, Hammersmith
*
fields.body:
In Eugène Labiche's 19th-century farce everyone has sex on his or her minds but nobody dare admit it. The word is unspoken, the act largely unconsummated, but the suggestion is everywhere. The entire play is like a frenzied unravelling of sexual frustration. Everyone is guilty but not for the right reasons. Their desires and their fantasies cause them panic, their fear of discovery leads to hysteria but nobody gives a toss about betrayal, friendship or deception.

The Marjavels' marriage is a model of suburban propriety. But there is something very strange about their household. The maid is constantly entertaining a fireman in the kitchen of their home on the outskirts of Paris, two Alsatians are imminently expected, and Ernest, the young man who lives in the summerhouse, is having an affair with Madame Marjavel, his best friend's wife.

In Gordon Anderson's ungainly production there are even unsubtle hints that there is some kind of homoerotic subtext to the relationship between Ernest and Monsieur Marjavel. The grim truth is that the Marjavels are one of those not so very unusual couples who need a third person in their relationship. Quite who is using whom is very much open to question. This revelation comes rather too late to salvage a play that makes a Brian Rix farce look sophisticated. For a farce to really work the audience has to experience the same fear of discovery that haunts the characters. For them the feeling is nightmarish. For us it is delicious. But not here, alas.

This is leaden stuff, weighed down by a translation that is full of the kind of end-of-the-pier double entendres that make you groan and that are almost impossible for the poor actors to deliver with any authority. It is hard to say lines such as "he'll be mounting my trellis at any moment" without sounding like Frankie Howerd. In this play such lines are laid end to end. It makes sex seem so dreary it might well put you off forever.

Things are not helped by a production that approaches the play at a stroll, not a gallop. You long for it to speed up, not least because it would then be over much more quickly. Like the blackmailed Marjavels and Ernest, I felt I'd been taken for a ride. But somewhere I'd rather not have gone.

To May 6. Box office: 0181- 741 2311

webTitle: Toon army in retreat with honour intact

fields.headline: Toon army in retreat with honour intact
fields.trailText: Martin Thorpe at Wembley sees Newcastle's dark days continue after the Blues extend their purple patch.
fields.body:
Over recent years the Toon army have suffered more despair than a leading character in EastEnders. There was the agonising way they lost the league title under Kevin Keegan, then back-to-back FA Cup final humiliations, insults from the club's directors over the quality of replica shirts and of their women, and last month they were forced to hand over prime seat positions at St James' Park to the corporate sit-down-dinner set.

Yesterday it was Chelsea's turn to inflict a blow to Geordie hearts and send the most loyal of loyalists back north with nothing but frustration for company.

For Chelsea, a third Cup final appearance in six years came courtesy of their third high-profile victory in nine days following the wins over Leeds and the epic against Barcelona.

As if by some devilish tradition, it looks far worse in black and white-Newcastle have not won at Wembley in a major competition since 1955 and Robert Lee's goal yesterday was their first at the old stadium since 1976.

"It was a result we didn't deserve," said Robson. "I feel sorry for the fans and our performance deserved something better. But at least we gave the supporters a football match today. We got the ball down, used the flanks and got shots at goal, though I'm heartily sick and disappointed that we haven't given the fans the result they needed."

Like their supporters, the Newcastle team gave everything, and their performance was a vast improvement on the capitulations which characterised their previous Wembley defeats at the hands of two other Premiership giants, Arsenal and Manchester United.

Each of those occasions were heralded as a new Newcastle dawn. But Kenny Dalglish and Ruud Gullit soon disappeared into the sunset. Robson at least seems to be a real messiah.

Yesterday he was deprived of the reward he deserved for inspiring such a renaissance on the Tyne, but there is little doubt that he has laid the foundations of a healthy Newcastle team. "We've lost unluckily to a very good team today which makes us very good," he said. "We've come a long way, so I'm happy about that."

There was very little reason for Gianluca Vialli to do anything but admit that his team were somewhat fortunate to win. "I'm happy because we've reached another final," he said. "We didn't play particularly well but sometimes it is the result that counts.

"I sincerely believe that for long spells they were the best team on the pitch and I feel sorry for them. They deserved more. Our problem was that we scored early and then thought too much about defending. We didn't create enough.

"We are a side who has got to play football, impose ourselves, otherwise something is bound to happen, which it did when Newcastle equalised. But the bright side was the spirit and resilience we showed after they scored."

Chelsea's double scorer Gustavo Poyet blamed his goals on two players being out of position-Warren Barton and himself.

"For the first one, Barton's position gave me the chance to hit the ball early," said the Uruguayan. "For the second, normally when Jon Harley crosses I should be in left midfield, but for some reason I was in the box. I don't know why."

It was a sense of mystery which extended to the whole of the Newcastle camp. How on earth did they fail to win at Wembley yet again? "The sooner they knock this place down, the better," said a dejected Alan Shearer.

fields.headline: Preston stutter
fields.trailText: Preston kept up their eccentric title-chasing with a second successive Saturday stalemate against desperate opponents from the relegation zone, adding a 0-0 stand-off at home to Cardiff to the previous week's at Blackpool - having beaten their closest championship rivals at Wigan in midweek.
fields.body:
Preston kept up their eccentric title-chasing with a second successive Saturday stalemate against desperate opponents from the relegation zone, adding a 0-0 stand-off at home to Cardiff to the previous week's at Blackpool - having beaten their closest championship rivals at Wigan in midweek.

 Wigan, with a game in hand, tightened their grip on the second automatic promotion slot with a 2-0 win at struggling Oxford, who with Scunthorpe and Chesterfield made up the three losers among the bottom five. A goal in either half from Wigan's Simon Haworth took his season's tally to 13.

 Bristol Rovers failed to win for the fifth time in a row and they needed a 50th-minute equaliser from Jason Roberts - his 20th goal of the season - to finish 1-1 at lowly Cambridge. United's Trevor Benjamin set a club record by scoring for the eighth match in succession.

 Millwall staked a firm claim for a play-off spot with a 3-0 demolition of Bury. First-half goals from Paul Moody, Joe Dolan and Neil Harris, his 19th of the season, decided the issue.

 Burnley's investment in Ian Wright paid a further dividend when he came off the bench to hit a last-minute winner in their 2-1 win over Notts County, whose play-off hopes now look dashed.

 Stoke leapfrogged Gillingham into the play-off zone with a 1-0 win over Brentford, Peter Thorne taking only eight minutes to score his fifth goal in three games.

fields.headline: York battle on
fields.trailText: The three teams in the automatic promotion places all drew for the second Saturday in a row, the top two being held goalless at home - and third-placed Darlington's 0-0 scoreline at York gave Terry Dolan's battlers their seventh game without defeat under his management.
fields.body:
The three teams in the automatic promotion places all drew for the second Saturday in a row, the top two being held goalless at home - and third-placed Darlington's 0-0 scoreline at York gave Terry Dolan's battlers their seventh game without defeat under his management.

 Southend had Steve Jones sent off in the 0-0 draw at the leaders Rotherham United, whose closest rivals Swansea City - without a win in six games - were held by the play-off candidates Peterborough at the Vetch Field.

 Northampton fell back in the play-off pecking order with a surprise 4-3 defeat at home to mid-table Halifax, their first win in nine games. Sixfields saw the home side fall behind after two minutes, hit back to lead twice but eventually emerge without a point after Steve Kerrigan grabbed the Shaymen's winner in the dying seconds.

 The League newcomers Cheltenham moved up to third with a 2-1 win at mid-table Lincoln. Jamie Victory and Martin Devaney gained them a comfort cushion before Steve Holmes gave the home fans something to cheer with 14 minutes to go. Town have now gone five games without defeat.

 Second-last Shrewsbury were within five minutes of a win at the play-off contenders Barnet, but Scott McGleish answered Stephen Jagielka's 57th-minute goal and cost the Shrews two points that would have intensified the pressure on Chester.

webTitle: Indian police seek British help as cricket probe widens

fields.headline: Indian police seek British help as cricket probe widens
fields.trailText: The South African government has demanded the release of the 'Cronje tapes'.
fields.byline: David Hopps and David Beresford in Cape Town
fields.body:
Indian police yesterday officially requested assistance from Scotland Yard in arresting the businessman Sanjiv Chawla as they stepped up their investigation into allegations of match-rigging that have left international cricket in uproar.

Chawla, a clothing business-man believed to be in hiding in London, allegedly took part in the tapped mobile phone conversations with the South African captain Hansie Cronje that police contend are central to evidence of a £320,000 sting during a limited-overs series in India last month.

A second businessman, Rajesh Kalra, who was arrested on Friday under suspicion as an illegal bookmaker, was remanded in custody in Delhi yesterday for a further four days. He faces questioning from tax officials regarding illegal foreign exchange transactions. He arrived for a half-hour court hearing flanked by a posse of policemen and with his face covered with a yellow towel.

It emerged yesterday that Indian police investigators have been despatched to three more cities: Cochin, the venue for the first one-day international; which along with the third match in Faridabad is under most suspicion; Mumbai, said to be the centre of India's multi-million pound illegal betting industry; and Bangalore.

Cronje and three other players - Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom - charged with fixing matches, are the first cricketers so charged after a decade which has smouldered with allegations of players' dealings with illegal bookmakers.

The players have vociferously protested their innocence and have received stalwart support in South Africa, both from the public and cricket authorities. Yet, in their haste to question the authenticity of the "Cronje Tapes", the South Africans may have leapt to some embarrassing assumptions.

South Africa's deputy foreign minister Aziz Pahad pronounced at the weekend that their High Commissioner in India, Maite Nkoane- Ramashada, had listened to the tapes and that the accents were not South African. "It's NOT our Hansie" headlined the Sunday Tribune yesterday. "Both voices on tape Asian."

However, Delhi police contend they have released only printed transcripts - edited highlights from 12 tapes of evidence which remain locked in a police safe. The tapes the South Africans have rubbished might well have been re-enactments of the transcripts broadcast on Indian radio.

The stand-off between India and South Africa is beginning to rival that between England and Australia in the infamous Bodyline series almost 70 years ago. Indian authorities have shunned South African requests to release the tapes so they can conduct their own voice analysis.

The South Africans, for their part, have not yet agreed to supply an official recording of Cronje's voice. Pahad has also assured Ali Bacher, the managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, that explanations will be demanded for the tapping of South African players' telephones.

However, Delhi police sources assert they did not tap Cronje's phone in room 364 at the Taj Palace hotel in Delhi but only mobiles belonging to Indians under suspicion.

Inspector Ishwar Singh, the Dehli officer in charge of the investigation, said: "We came to know that certain people are involved in match-fixing. And then we got three to four mobile numbers and kept monitoring those phone numbers. One of them was of Sanjeev Chawla. On that phone, which we tapped, we came to know he was having a conversation with the South African captain Hansie Cronje."

Jagmohan Dalmiya, the International Cricket Council president, said: "We at the ICC take the allegations very seriously." For the moment, though, the investigation is firmly in the hands of the police.

fields.headline: Poyet shows superior finish
fields.trailText: Newcastle 1 - 2 Chelsea
fields.body:
Goals, not performances alone, win football matches, which is why Chelsea will meet Aston Villa in this season's FA Cup final. Though Newcastle United dominated more than half of yesterday's semi-final and created the greater number of chances, Chelsea's superior finishing was the decisive factor.

A Uruguayan, Gustavo Poyet, scored both their goals and each at a time when his team was under severe pressure. A Peruvian, Nolberto Solano, wasted several chances for Newcastle, the best to bring the scores level shortly before half-time.

At least Gianluca Vialli, whose below-strength team responded with a below-par display, had the good grace afterwards to concede that Chelsea had got away with it. Another view would be that the victory confirmed the greater depth of Vialli's squad compared with the options available to Bobby Robson.

The Chelsea manager made six changes from the team that had roundly beaten Barcelona in the Champions League quarter-finals yet could still recall a wealth of well-rested experience in Roberto di Matteo, Frank Leboeuf, George Weah and, crucially, Poyet.

Gianfranco Zola, Chelsea's impish inspiration against Barca, was introduced only for the last 12 minutes. Should Chelsea make further progress in the Champions League Vialli's selection for Wembley on May 20, four days before the European Cup final, will make interesting reading.

No fair observer would have begrudged Robson the privilege of leading out Newcastle United for a Cup final against Aston Villa 22 years after his Ipswich side had won the trophy by beating Arsenal. As the Newcastle manager observed, Chelsea did enjoy those grains of fortune that so often make the difference between victory and defeat.

Poyet's opening goal followed a free-kick taken when the ball was moving. Not so long ago the referee, Dermot Gallagher, would have ordered it to be taken again, but these are liberal times. Again, when Poyet scored his second Kieron Dyer was lying injured in the Chelsea half following a tackle by Didier Deschamps.

Gallagher did not have to stop the game but Robson noted that when Di Matteo was down in the Chelsea goalmouth in the closing minutes play was halted before the ball had gone out. "Little things like that didn't go for us," Robson observed, "and those are the days when you lose."

Unlike in their supine performances in the past two FA Cup finals, Newcastle did not expect to be beaten. The longer the match progressed the more Chelsea owed to the defensive class of Marcel Desailly, backed by Ed de Goey, who tipped a shot from Dyer over the bar soon after half-time, a save as important to the result as Solano's miss.

Alan Shearer, whose burden at the head of Newcastle's attack was doubled once Duncan Ferguson had been forced off with a knee injury, was tireless in his harrying and hustling of Leboeuf but Desailly remained unmoved and im movable at the heart of Chelsea's defence.

Newcastle's best hope of reaching their third Cup final in as many seasons, and what would have been their third against Villa, lay in the extent to which they could exploit superior width. Early on the ease with which Solano was getting past Jon Harley on the right promised to hand them the initiative and later, after the speed of Didier Domi, Ferguson's replacement, had been added to Newcastle's left wing, Chelsea were in danger of being outflanked.

For a time in the first half Dennis Wise, Deschamps and Di Matteo controlled the pattern and tempo of the play, but eventually Robert Lee, Gary Speed and Dyer seized control of midfield and enabled Newcastle to maintain their pressure. Chelsea's attack was never so effective, even after a labouring Chris Sutton had given way to Tore Andre Flo for the second half.

By then, however, they had taken the lead with the best move of the afternoon. Just past the quarter-hour Wise's quick, if not entirely legal, free-kick took Newcastle by surprise. The ball moved swiftly from Poyet to Sutton to Weah and back to Poyet, who neatly flicked into the net over the advancing Shay Given.

Three minutes before half-time Solano, set up by Shearer chesting off a cross from Warren Barton, wafted the ball over the bar, but Newcastle's persistence was eventually rewarded, if only briefly. After 67 minutes Shearer beat Leboeuf near the right-hand corner flag and from his excellent centre Lee headed his first goal of the season.

The Geordie half of Wembley was ecstatic but within four minutes Harley's centre found Poyet easing his way between the centre-backs to nod Chelsea back in front. At the last De Goey saved feet-first from Dyer and that, for Robson, Newcastle and the Toon army, was sadly that.

webTitle: Fat lady warms up after late strike fells Chester

fields.headline: Fat lady warms up after late strike fells Chester
fields.trailText: Chester 0 - 1 Carlisle
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the Deva Stadium
fields.body:
It was a half-hearted message, born of misplaced optimism rather than harsh reality. "Never give up; there's always hope," implored Chester's public announcer. "It's not over until the fat lady sings."

With the air crackling with emotion, cameramen scrutinising the stands for tearful fans and a tangible feeling of foreboding engulfing this Lego-like stadium, his confidence was incongruous.

Battered and beleaguered, Chester are in dire need of some divine intervention. This defeat leaves the Football League's wooden-spoon club two points below Shrewsbury with five games remaining.

As those versed in football cliche can testify, playing against 10 men is never easy. To lose against nine, however, smacks of carelessness - especially when the opponents are 90th-placed Carlisle.

"There are still 15 points to play for," said Chester's director of football Ian Atkins. "We are very hopeful." But their supporters are not deceiving themselves. "Does anyone know where we can find a miracle?" hollered one.

The example of Jimmy Glass, the goalkeeper who rescued Carlisle from relegation with a 95th-minute goal on the final day of the 1999 season, proves that miracles do happen, but such events would not be the stuff of legend if they occurred regularly.

Here, amid overwhelming tension, there was more stoppage-time drama after an understandably tetchy affair that for the preceding 93 minutes had lived down to all expectations.

Peter Clark snuffed out one last attack from the home side and carried the ball upfield to the substitute Scott Dobie. His first touch carried him away from goal but the second more than made amends, a rasping drive that fairly whistled into the top corner from 25 yards.

"I just thought I'll hit it; after all it never did Bobby Charlton any harm," he said afterwards. Carlisle had just had Stuart Whitehead and Stephen Halliday sent off for second bookable offences; with a penchant for dramatic finales, this is not a club for those of a nervous disposition.

"Our supporters pretend not to, but they love these occasions really. It's another magnificent piece of nostalgia," said their chairman Michael Knighton, who has put the club up for sale, presumably with a health warning attached. He is struggling to find a buyer. "There just aren't many raving lunatics out there with chequebooks."

fields.headline: Taylor smart and Bassett smarting
fields.trailText: Barnsley 2 - 2 West Brom
fields.body:
The newly installed manager Gary Megson was so desperate to convince Bob Taylor he should return to the Hawthorns he offered the striker a three-year contract at the age of 33.

It is not a bad personal deal for the player but it could turn out to be an even better decision by the new Albion manager as he struggles to keep a club with such a rich tradition out of the Second Division.

Taylor is some sort of talisman after scoring 96 league goals for them, at just under one every two games, and he made it 97 at Oakwell with his first since returning from a two-year exile at Bolton.

Megson regards the signing as more than just a source of goals, believing the popular striker will also provide reassurance to fans disillusioned by boardroom squabbling and nine managers in 10 years.

Taylor, too, pointed out that he has been re-signed for the right reasons. "I'm here to work hard, give 100 per cent and try to keep the club in the First Division," he said. "I don't want people saying I don't care, because I do.

"I love the club and I never left the area. The fans have made me very welcome but they know it's not going to be easy."

Barnsley, top scorers in the Nationwide league, were aggrieved at two decisions by the referee Bill Jordan. The Tring official ruled out appeals as Darren Barnard tumbled under a challenge by Tony Butler in the area in the second minute but awarded a penalty when Albion's Fabian de Freitas was challenged by Chris Morgan in the 47th.

Richard Sneekes scored from the spot and it left Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett searching for an explanation. "I hope the referee watches the video and learns something," he said. "The players are furious but we were pleased to get a point in the end. It could be one that takes us up, who knows?"

Neil Shipperley equalised in the final seconds of normal time, after Barnard's dead-ball strike preceded Taylor's 55th-minute header.

fields.headline: Royle restores feel-good factor
fields.trailText: Man City 4 - 0 Crewe
fields.body:
Joe Royle was warned by the previous incumbent, Frank Clark, that there was something "rotten" at the club. A letter to the local newspaper counselled him that the job was "about as easy as nailing a piece of jelly to a ceiling".

But Royle took charge of Manchester City regardless and, a little more than two years later, is on the verge of a spectacular triumph.

He has led his team three points clear of the dreaded play-off zone after four consecutive wins. They have entered the season's final four weeks, when results are all that matters, playing the sort of football that has not been seen here for years.

Most amazing of all, however, is the fact that he has returned the feel-good factor to Maine Road.

Thirty years of woeful mismanagement and laughable under-achievement have taken their toll - even now supporters are careful not to sing about the Premiership - but morale is soaring to forgotten heights in this particular part of Manchester. Forget United's apparently irresistible drive towards world domination. City are back.

Even Royle, 51 on Saturday and his mobility hampered by a hip replacement operation, had a spring in his step after watching his side dismantle Crewe with such resilience and panache.

The nerves kicked in only briefly, during the 27-minute wait between Spencer Prior's headed opener and Paul Dickov's volley.

"Five hurdles to go, we're on the final straight and we can see the finishing line," he beamed with a tasty appreciation of the fact it was Grand National day. "I think we'd have settled for that back in August."

City traditionally pull up like Devon Loch, the royal horse that remains a byword for grasping defeat from the jaws of victory, but they seem to be made of stronger stuff these days.

Rather than putting their fans through the emotional mill by conceding at least one late goal, City added to their tally through Mark Kennedy and Dickov.

Crewe, impressive on the ball but at a loss without it, look in grave danger after five straight defeats. Whether they escape or not, it seems they have seen the last of City for a while.

webTitle: Referees make too much of a bad thing

fields.headline: Referees make too much of a bad thing
fields.trailText: Huddersfield 0 - 0 Birmingham
fields.byline: Martin Howey at the McAlpine Stadium
fields.body:
Between them, two referees managed to append an extra 10 minutes of torture to this excruciatingly miserable affair.

The original referee Graham Frankland lasted only 27 minutes before falling victim to a groin injury. Lucky man.

Unfortunately, he and his replacement Martin Robinson felt the game needed to be extended by another 10%. Not so lucky supporters.

A point for Birmingham was gratefully received. As their manager Trevor Francis said: "We had just 32 in the bag at the turn of the year and will have been very long odds indeed to have 70 at this stage and be looking good for the play-offs."

His opposite number Steve Bruce, quietly despondent, pointed to his team's home record in defence of a bad day at the office. "We've only lost two league games here this season," he said. "I thought we were excellent defensively, but we did lack a cutting edge."

Huddersfield's most promising attackers were Chris Beech, a midfielder, and Jamie Vincent, the left wing-back. Bruce's boys began with Alun Armstrong and Clyde Wijnhard up front and finished with Chris Hay and Michel Ngonge in their stead. Not one of them troubled Thomas Myhre all afternoon.

This was a dreadful advertisement for the Premiership's nursery. And, doubtless, Huddersfield fans in particular will have slept like babies afterwards. Waking up every half-hour and crying their eyes out.

webTitle: Nielsen's private mission proves good for Wolves

fields.headline: Nielsen's private mission proves good for Wolves
fields.trailText: Wolves 2 - 1 Blackburn Rovers
fields.body:
Perhaps it was the sunshine but until a penalty of dubious pedigree sparked this contest into life it appeared the players were thinking more of the beach than the play-offs - except, that is, for Allan Nielsen, who is hoping to spend at least some of his summer as one of Denmark's Euro 2000 squad.

In order to make it Nielsen has moved to Wolves on a month's loan from Tottenham Hotspur. "I need to play first-team football if I m to be in the Denmark squad," he said. "I don't know what my long-term future with Tottenham holds. I've got two years to run on my contract, so it's up to them."

His performance against Rovers will have done much to further his cause. With a range of astute passes he created a host of chances that were either saved or squandered but in the 72nd minute the Dane headed home Michael Branch's deft chip. It earned a win that keeps Wolves' play-off hopes alive and, according to the Rovers manager Graeme Souness, ends those of his side.

"If I was a gambling man I'd say we won't make the play-offs after this," said Souness after his first defeat since taking charge at Ewood Park.

Dismayed by the penalty that allowed Kevin Muscat to put Wolves ahead, he was delighted by Damien Duff's solo goal a quarter-of-an-hour later.

"We've got the nucleus of a very good squad. I don't think I ll have to spend a lot of money in the summer." Jack Walker, for one, will be delighted.

In order to make it Nielsen has moved to Wolves on a month's loan from Tottenham Hotspur. "I need to play first-team football if I m to be in the Denmark squad," he said. "I don't know what my long-term future with Tottenham holds. I've got two years to run on my contract, so it's up to them." His performance against Rovers will have done much to further his cause. With a range of astute passes he created a host of chances that were either saved or squandered but in the 72nd minute the Dane headed home Michael Branch's deft chip. It earned a win that keeps Wolves' play-off hopes alive and, according to the Rovers manager Graeme Souness, ends those of his side. "If I was a gambling man I'd say we won't make the play-offs after this," said Souness after his first defeat since taking charge at Ewood Park. Dismayed by the penalty that allowed Kevin Muscat to put Wolves ahead, he was delighted by Damien Duff's solo goal a quarter-of-an-hour later. "We've got the nucleus of a very good squad. webTitle: Kiddy see the future beyond Diamonds

fields.headline: Kiddy see the future beyond Diamonds
fields.trailText: Kidderminster 2 - 0 Rushden & Diamonds
fields.body:
Signs around Kidderminster proclaim cottage garden, grain store and farm shop. This is a county made for village cricket. But on Saturday, with the sun bearing down on fruit trees heavy with blossom, Worcestershire took a giant step towards embracing League football for the first time.

The athletic Harriers of their origin in 1886 have given way to a hawkish emblem and they picked off Rushden, their only remaining challengers. Victory puts them six points clear with a game in hand; and Rushden have only six to play.

Jan Molby, Harriers' manager, insisted: "We're not there." And Rushden's Brian Talbot said: "We've got to make them win as many games as possible." But he knows the game is as good as up. "They've got 1 hands on it now."

In the past two seasons Rushden have lost similarly in April to their closest rivals: Halifax, then Cheltenham. Their ambition was set out by Max Griggs, chairman of Dr Martens, when the Diamond Centre was opened in 1994: League football by 2000. A working party is considering letting two up and down and, if it was rugby union, Rushden would hold out hope of making it this season. But they look destined to wait another year.

Whether Talbot, ill-fated with strikers, will be there is open to doubt. Mark Darnell, managing director, said: "Sacking Brian is not in the frame."

Much of the play was not in the frame either, as fear rushed clearances out of the ground. The Harriers' defender Adie Smith may be well advised to remain a roofer. It took a rum referee's decision to release the deadlock and enliven the last half-hour.

Both sides can do better - the managers, playing rivals in the 80s, agreed as much at half-time; things are friendlier in the Conference. In August Diamonds had won 5-3, part of a grim start to Molby's managerial reign; his team lost four of their first five games, seven out of 15. But only Kettering have beaten them in 20 since. It is surely a roll into history, and six years overdue.

In 1994 they topped the Conference but were denied promotion because Aggborough did not meet League regulations. It put many League grounds to shame then, now more than ever. The club took five TV companies and a capacity crowd of 6,250 in its stride. But they will have to spend £250,000 to meet health and safety regulations. League membership comes at a price.

When Gary Brittain gave Harriers a penalty for pushing, even Molby thought it "harsh". Ian Foster hammered it in, sharp as a carpet tack. Until then Molby had shown the deftest touch himself, volleying the ball back into play in happy recall of his closing days at Anfield when, large as an Eastern potentate, he ruled play from the centre. Mike Marsh's sudden injection of pace made the second for Andrew Brownrigg.

In that respect it was a metaphor for Kiddy's season. Marsh, an Anfield team-mate of Molby, has lost once since arriving in November. Ian Clarkson came just before, from Northampton, stolen from under Rushden's nose. But neither can play in the League without forfeiting insurance payouts for injury.

Just before the end Engine 7325, plying its puffing business on the Severn Valley Railway, gave a final blast from the past. Stands the club clock at 10 to five and is there money in the hive? Thanks to Molby and a chairman Lionel Newton who made millions from furniture, the face of sport in the county is heading for a new future.

fields.headline: Dow boosts Dons stock
fields.trailText: Hibernian 1 - 2 Aberdeen
fields.body:
Hibernian, who last won the Scottish Cup when the Boer War was being fought, will have to wait another year to put the record straight. They lost a semi-final to Aberdeen, who are bottom of the Premier League after an horrendous season but who proved resurgent when it mattered.

The Edinburgh club gave themselves every chance and took the lead in the 56th minute when Russell Latapy, at the end of a 40-yard run, ignored his team-mates in support to shoot home a wonderful goal.

But Aberdeen, with tremendous grit, fought back with two goals of their own in a five-minute spell, largely the reward for the efforts of their Danish striker Arild Stavrum.

He knocked in a rebound in the 65th minute to equalise and then laid the ball back quite beautifully with the softest of feet for Andy Dow to shoot home the winning goal and take the Dons into their second final of the season.

Hibs had started the match not only as the bookmakers' favourites but also the people's choice. That view owed much to the fact that in a league largely populated by honest enough scufflers, the Edinburgh club possess a couple of genuine talents in Latapy and Franck Sauzée.

But semi-finals are notorious for suffocating even the best of them, and there was the additional factor that no fewer than 10 of the players had already received yellow cards and one more indiscretion would mean that they would be watching the final from the grandstand.

Hibs' two likely lads at least started well. When, in the seventh minute, Thomas Solberg could only half-clear Aberdeen's lines, Sauzée's shot, struck well although he was off balance, was well saved by Jim Leighton, whose experience had brought him well outside his own six-yard line to narrow the angle.

Latapy's first intervention came eight minutes later, when he broke forward and produced a teasing cross for Mixu Paatelainen to gain a sight of goal, but the Finn dragged his shot wide of the post.

In the dying seconds of the half Eoin Jess, set free by a Thomas Mayer pass, spurned the best chance for Aberdeen, and only a desperate touch by Derek White from a Kenny Miller pass stopped Hibs taking the lead at the other end.

fields.headline: Scottish round-up
fields.trailText:
Bad Ayr day
Among Dick Advocaat's more compelling traits is his doggedly serious attitude to life and football. Less intense managers would have fallen about laughing, writes Ian Archer. He was at his most stern after Rangers' embarrassing Scottish Cup semi- final that ended in a 7-0 win over Ayr United, Billy Dodds netting a hat-trick.
fields.body:
Bad Ayr day
Among Dick Advocaat's more compelling traits is his doggedly serious attitude to life and football. Less intense managers would have fallen about laughing, writes Ian Archer. He was at his most stern after Rangers' embarrassing Scottish Cup semi- final that ended in a 7-0 win over Ayr United, Billy Dodds netting a hat-trick.

"I would have liked to have taken the whole team off at half time," Advocaat thundered. "Thirty thousand Rangers fans had to pay for their tickets and my team forgot that." His side was three goals ahead at that stage.

 The Celtic captain Paul Lambert was sent off in the 33rd minute of their 1-0 defeat at Hearts, Gary McSwegan supplying the sucker punch three minutes later.

 Dundee's James Grady is unlikely to forget his contribution to his side's 4-1 win over Motherwell. He scored twice and was sent off.

 Kilmarnock eased their relegation concerns courtesy of an own goal from John McQuillan of Dundee United at Rugby Park.

 Clydebank's inevitable drop from the First Division became reality after their 2-1 home defeat by Livingston.

webTitle: Tigana prepares for life as Fayed's chosen one

fields.headline: Tigana prepares for life as Fayed's chosen one
fields.trailText: Tranmere 1 - 1 Fulham
fields.body:
The latest chapter in the managerial career of Jean Tigana began yesterday in the unlikely surroundings of Tranmere's Prenton Park.

The 43-year-old former French international midfielder sat in the stands there after agreeing to ply his trade in the First Division at Craven Cottage from July 1 on a five-year contract worth a reported £7.5m.

"He is the right choice for Fulham," enthused Karlheinz Riedle, the striker turned caretaker manager who cannot hand over the reins quickly enough. "He is a very high-profile manager, a high-profile person and a good choice for Fulham.

"You can only say after a while whether he will be successful. He needs time. He can't change everything in one day. But this is a good sign to the team and the fans.

"He came to the hotel this morning, the board introduced him to the players, and now everybody knows what is happening next year."

Tigana's most recent active experience of English football - as manager of Monaco when they eliminated Manchester United from the 1998 Champions League quarter-finals on away goals - may not have prepared him for this league.

This bruising and breathless encounter was typical of the fare he can expect next season. Only Andy Melville's 88th-minute volley earned Fulham a point and kept alive their faint chance of reaching the play-offs.

At least, as Tigana watched the game alongside Everton's John Collins, who was acting as interpreter for his former Monaco manager, he must have been impressed by the persistence Fulham's expensive team demonstrated.

Such qualities have not always been apparent in Fulham's play this season, a fact that ultimately cost the previous manager Paul Bracewell his job.

Once the initial awkwardness of yesterday's introductions has receded (Tigana speaks no English), Fulham will congratulate themselves on the appointment of one of Europe's most highly rated managerial talents.

A celebrated midfielder in the France side that won the 1984 European Championship, Tigana played at Lyon and Monaco, leaving the principality in January 1999 to take a coaching role at the French FA. He has been widely mentioned as the next national team manager should Roger Lemerre fail to live up to expectations.

For now, his interests are more modest and he will start by examining a goal poorly conceded yesterday after Gary Jones skipped past Terry Phelan and squared for David Kelly to shoot into an open goal.

Rovers had every right to feel hard done by when Andy Melville volleyed in a Lee Clark cross from 12 yards two minutes from time.

webTitle: Izzet the easy target of Everton's racist brigade

fields.headline: Izzet the easy target of Everton's racist brigade
fields.trailText: Leicester 1 - 1 Everton
fields.body:
It was a sickening sight, Everton fans glaring into the eyes of Muzzy Izzet and running fingers across their throats. Here was a chilling reminder that the campaign against racism is far from won. The anti-Turkish idiots probably tucked into a kebab to help the vitriol down.

From the away section boos greeted Izzet's every touch as if he had plunged knives into the Leeds' supporters killed in Istanbul. The midfielder's crime was deciding recently to play for Turkey, his father's birthplace. The supporters who booed should note that Izzet is no more responsible for Wednesday's tragedy than Merseyside was for James Bulger's murder. They disgraced their club.

Everton moved admirably quickly to dissociate themselves from the actions of a minority of their fans. Izzet, born in east London and yet to play for Turkey, sensibly declined to discuss the incident as he signed autographs and posed for pictures after the game.

"I can't really win whatever I say," he explained, "so it would be best to say nothing." Emotion is still running high and he must fear upsetting certain elements in his adopted country. He was described by a Leicester spokesman as "surprised and upset".

It may be some consolation to the 25-year-old to know that a letter of apology is on its way from Everton, as is a fax from their independent supporters' club. "I was extremely disappointed to hear some of our supporters acting in this manner," said Everton's chairman Sir Philip Carter.

He must have hoped the bigotry that saw bananas thrown at John Barnes had been flushed out or at least suppressed. A club spokesman added: "It wasn't an awful lot of our fans but that doesn't matter. Whether it was one or a thousand it shouldn't happen."

The guilty parties should consider themselves fortunate not to have been thrown out of a ground where "indecent or racist chanting" is described on signs as a criminal offence. Leicester's manager Martin O'Neill, who did not realise what the booing was about, called the scorn "uncalled for".

Stan Collymore went further. "What happened was disgaceful," said the Leicester striker, who watched as a radio pundit. "The Professional Footballers' Association have gone a long way with the campaign over the last few years highlighting the problem but it is still there. We can do without what we witnessed on Saturday."

Ian Macdonald, spokesman for the Independent Blues, said attempts were made to keep the culprits quiet. "They were getting shouted at: 'Grow up and shut up, the lad's got nothing to do with it.' But what do you do? Do you drag them down? You can't go that far. We apologise unreservedly to Muzzy Izzet and his family."

Izzet had the partial satisfaction of taking a corner, from next to the Everton fans, which Gerry Taggart headed in to give Leicester the lead. Don Hutchison equalised by nodding in an excellent cross by Nicky Barmby, whose performance in front of Kevin Keegan was solid rather than spectacular.

Otherwise the game meandered as anticipated, Everton having chances to win before Taggart headed over in the last minute. By then Izzet had been substituted. He deserves better treatment than this.

webTitle: Forest show their mettle to stall Charlton party

fields.headline: Forest show their mettle to stall Charlton party
fields.trailText: Nott'm Forest 1 - 1 Charlton
fields.byline: Adam Sills at the County Ground
fields.body:
Charlton are almost home and dry, with promotion one win away. Yet the nightmares of last season could be about to resurface.

It is a measure of the task facing Alan Curbishley's side that, when the Nottingham Forest manager David Platt was asked if he had expected an equaliser, he replied: "Not against Charlton I didn't."

Inferiority complexes do not exist in the battle to stay in the Premiership and, if Charlton are to prosper, a considerable psychological overhaul will be needed over the summer.

"I'm going to take a long holiday once the season's over and have a good think," said Curbishley when asked if Premiership survival plans were already in place. Sunderland would be an ideal destination.

Peter Reid's side have shown what can be achieved with money to invest and a lethal strike force. Curbishley has the former to achieve the latter and, should he reinforce his attack with a Premiership-proven striker, he may be able to secure Charlton's top-flight status. Andy Hunt has thrived in the First Division and scored his 24th goal of the season on Saturday. He managed seven in their Premiership campaign. Curbishley, though, believes that Hunt and his team-mates will benefit from that chastening experience.

"The club is in better shape for the Premiership and so is the squad," he said. "I will have money to spend in the summer but we also have some quality players here already."

After Hunt latched on to a mix-up in the Forest defence to give Charlton the lead, promotion beckoned. But the home side's equaliser nine minutes from time delayed celebration, possibly until Friday when Huddersfield are due at the Valley. For Forest there is still work to be done to ensure First Division status next year. The signs, though, are that a corner is being turned.

Earlier in the season Platt would not have fancied his side's chances of recovery from a one-goal deficit with 11 men, let alone 10. On Saturday Colin Calderwood's dismissal spurred Forest on. They deserved to equalise, albeit fortuitously, when Jim Brennan fell over Anthony Barness's challenge in the box. Chris Bart-Williams scored from the spot and only a save by Dean Kiely with his knee from Jack Lester prevented Forest from taking all three points.

"I don't think we are behind in terms of quality," said Platt. "But Charlton are where they are because, while they have been inconsistent in performance, they have been consistent in results."

It is something the London side will need if they are not to find themselves this time next season again staring the First Division in the face.

fields.headline: Venue verdict expected today
fields.trailText: European football's governing body is expected to give its verdict in the next 24 hours on whether the second leg of Leeds United's Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasary will go ahead on Thursday week at Elland Road or be switched to a neutral venue.
fields.body:
European football's governing body is expected to give its verdict in the next 24 hours on whether the second leg of Leeds United's Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasary will go ahead on Thursday week at Elland Road or be switched to a neutral venue.

A Uefa spokesman, Frits Ahlstroem, has already indicated his organisation appears set to back Leeds but the decision would seem to be in the balance.

The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has continued to urge Galatasaray supporters not to show up for the return leg. But Galatasaray have requested the game be staged away from Elland Road and have threatened to pull out if a supporter ban is enforced by Uefa.

fields.headline: Derby rest their woeful case
fields.trailText: Watford 0 - 0 Derby County
fields.body:
Derby County would appear to be safe at last, not that they have any right to be. Wimbledon's apparent eagerness to throw themselves on the Premiership's funeral pyre means Jim Smith's side actually climbed further away from the relegation zone after this awful match, in which Stefan Schnoor's missed penalty provided an apt summary of their disappointing season.

It became clear from the kick-off that Derby have virtually given up playing. They appear to assume - probably rightly - that either Bradford or Wimbledon will keep them up and to that end are conserving their energy for a fresh start next August. So much so that they cannot even be bothered to organise spot-kicks.

"I don't know who the recognised penalty taker is because we haven't been awarded one all season," said Smith after his 1,150th game as a manager.

"Schnoor shouldn't have taken it today but there was a misunderstanding. [Branko} Strupar was going out before the game and I said to him, 'Take the penalties' and Schnoor thought it was to him. Branko, being such a nice man, stepped away when he saw him arguing over the penalty and thought, 'I'll let you take it'." Schnoor proceeded to pass the ball dozily to the keeper Alec Chamberlain.

That the penalty was given away by the home captain Robert Page showed that incompetence was not confined to one side. "We're in cup final mode. Every time we walk on the field we have to win - single points are not enough now," Page had said beforehand, only to chop down Darryl Powell in the 70th minute in one of Derby's rare attacks.

Graham Taylor, who played in the same Lincoln team as Smith, conceded that his bottom-of-the-table side were as good as down. "If we win every game we can get 38 points. Is that enough?" he joked, before pointing to a run-in that includes Leeds, Manchester United and Arsenal.

Against mounting evidence to the contrary, however, he insisted there was still a place in the Premiership for clubs the size of Watford, even if their primary aim is to survive rather than cut a swath through the moneyed aristocracy.

webTitle: Crazy Gang comes apart but they look like staying in the show

fields.headline: Crazy Gang comes apart but they look like staying in the show
fields.trailText: Sunderland 2 - 1 Wimbledon
fields.byline: Trevor Haylett at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Wimbledon put in a typical afternoon's work, scored with a fluke before succumbing to a late winner, learned that their survival prospects had in fact improved and stayed not a minute longer in the north-east than was necessary.

Another big game looms large in two days' time when Sheffield Wednesday visit Selhurst Park and Egil Olsen thought it best to put distance between his team and this fourth successive defeat as quickly as possible. They have a six-point lead over Bradford - who are declining every invitation to exploit Wimbledon's short- comings - and if it applied at the other end of the table we would be saying that they are uncatchable.

But this is Wimbledon, the Crazy Gang who are no longer crazy and who do not resemble much of a gang any more. The whisperers insist that Olsen is not happy, that their Norwegian owners are not happy with him and that players are queuing behind the exit door. The latest rumour had it that Robbie Earle stayed behind in London in protest at not being part of the starting 11.

Who knows where it is all going to end but as long as they do not fluff their remaining lines disastrously it is hard to believe the Premiership production will go on without them next season. Wednesday's game gives them the opportunity to open up a margin that will require three wins and a draw - because Bradford's goal difference is markedly inferior - to bridge the gap.

Olsen maintained that they were unfortunate to lose this fixture but fate was definitely smiling when Michael Hughes shot with no great power and saw the ball divert in off Eric Roy for their equaliser. "Wednesday will be a cup final," Olsen said. "If we win that we are safe."

For an hour Wimbledon succeeded in frustrating Sunderland's attempts to make a game of it and threatened three times on the break through Walid Badir. It was heavy going and long before half-time thoughts were turning towards Aintree.

Peter Reid's team were more like themselves after the break and following another free kick Niall Quinn superbly gathered Alex Rae's low pass before teeing up a volley that flew past Neil Sullivan.

It put the Quinn-Phillips partnership on 40 goals for the campaign. With both in such prolific form few other players are permitted a glimpse of the scoresheet and it has taken Kevin Kilbane 15 appearances following his December move from West Bromwich to register his first for the Wearsiders. With eight minutes remaining he was in just the right place to put away Quinn's far-post header, though Wimbledon's claim that Quinn had escaped with a push on Kenny Cunningham appeared justified.

It lifted Sunderland to sixth overnight but Reid was guarded about the prospect of a place in Europe next season."The last time someone asked me about that," he said, "we went 12 games without winning."
