webTitle: Better world for Hoddle and Saints

fields.headline: Better world for Hoddle and Saints
fields.trailText: Bradford City 1 - 2 Southampton
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle may have a bit of a reputation for outlandish religious beliefs, but the placard-carrying zealot parading outside Valley Parade had not chosen the best time to persuade him that the end of the world was nigh.

In Premiership football the only end of the world that matters comes in the shape of relegation. As Southampton had just achieved the victory to safeguard their Premiership future, Hoddle was dreaming instead of a better world that lay ahead.

Had Southampton lost this match, Bradford City, the third-bottom club, would have closed the margin to five points. Instead it was stretched to 11 and, with only six matches remaining, only obsessive mathematicians would feel much inclined to doom-mongering.

Bradford must still entertain two more sides just above them - Wimbledon and Derby County at Valley Parade - but this defeat struck their manager Paul Jewell harder than most. "Effort probably isn't going to be enough to keep us up," he said, "but effort is our best ingredient, so we have to keep going."

Jewell also made reference to the need for a change of luck after Southampton had taken the lead 11 minutes into the second half through Chris Marsden's mis-hit 25-yarder, which deflected wickedly off David Wetherall and fell inside Matt Clarke's right-hand post as the goalkeeper failed to regain his balance.

"If he'd hit it well the keeper would have saved it, or it would have flown over the top," said Jewell, whose time observing Bradford's strikers has clearly made him forget that well-hit shots can occasionally end up in the back of the net.

In fact, Jewell has not exactly eased Bradford's goalscoring shortcomings by loaning out his strikers. Isaiah Rankin was brought back from Birmingham City because of injury to Dean Saunders, but Lee Mills remains at Manchester City after a careless public comment or two caused him to lose favour.

Southampton, the more composed side, added a second goal thanks to the crafty ploy of replacing Matt le Tissier with Marian Pahars, which amounts to not as much an injection of pace as a full-scale transfusion.

Pahars had been on the pitch only 25 seconds when he tore infield after Andy O'Brien's error, turned back inside O'Brien as the defender attempted to recover, and beat Clarke with a cracking finish. Le Tiss must have been exhausted just watching it.

Bradford did pull one back within a minute when Robbie Blake beat Neil Moss at the second attempt. That ensured a final assault, with Wetherall flung forward as an extra striker and it was entirely appropriate that their last chance saw Dean Richards diving in to block Blake's shot.

Richards, a former Bradford central defender and still a devoted fan, had been magnificent, repelling a stream of high balls with ease. But the loyal home-town boy need not concern himself that his colossal display might prove to be instrumental in sending Bradford down. For all their 17 corners and high energy count, this was a defeat of their own making.

webTitle: Berger puts Graham in firing line

fields.headline: Berger puts Graham in firing line
fields.trailText: Liverpool 2 - 0 Tottenham Hotspur
fields.body:
At a time when the Premiership has become a game of catch-up and Sir Alex Ferguson is putting the final preparations towards another open-top bus parade, it would be reckless to suggest the balance of footballing power is shifting back towards Merseyside.

However, for the first time this season Liverpool occupy runners-up spot, having leapfrogged Leeds with an ultimately simple victory over a tepid Tottenham side here yesterday.

Gérard Houllier's rejuvenated charges are now unbeaten in 11 games and looking good for their Champions' League inauguration.

"It's our best league position for a long time and I'm thrilled," said the Frenchman. "It feels brilliant, fantastic."

Compare that with George Graham's day at the office. Not only were Tottenham so comprehensively outplayed that the embarrassment bordered on the excruciating but his ignominy was to end with the travelling supporters demanding his removal from office.

If Graham's first season had induced aspirations of navigating a route back to the top, this term has been all wrong turns and cul-de-sacs. The inquest will be long and painful and the verdict will inevitably mean comings and goings at White Hart Lane.

Judging by the strains of "We want Graham out" from the travelling contingent, his departure would not prompt much heartache around the Seven Sisters Road.

"It's understandable I suppose. It's very rare you get cheered off when you lose. If you don't do well, you get booed. That's life in football," he said afterwards.

It was a match that started sluggishly before Liverpool found their momentum. All they could muster in a turgid opening 30 minutes was a free-kick from Patrick Berger that pinged off Steffen Freund and came close to deceiving Ian Walker.

But the next time Berger tried his luck, it produced a spectacular dividend. Controlling an awkward bouncing ball 25 yards from goal, the Czech swivelled in one motion, connected with the meatiest part of his left boot and billowed Walker's net as though it had been struck by a cannonball.

Within another five minutes Emile Heskey had conjured a left-foot shot that was still rising when it cracked the crossbar and Graham was wearing the type of anguished expression that followers of the London club have seen far too much of recently.

Houllier's team continued to exude an air of authority after the interval and David Thompson should have extended the lead after beating the offside trap from Berger's flicked pass only to be afflicted by a sudden bout of stage-fright when confronted by Walker.

But Liverpool did not have long to wait. Michael Owen's industry created the initial opening for Heskey and, when his shot ricocheted back to him off Walker, the New Kid on the Kop unselfishly laid off the ball for his strike colleague to poach his 12th goal of a campaign blighted by injury.

After that it was just a question of how many Liverpool would clock up. But Walker, one of the few visiting players to emerge with any credit, ensured that Tottenham retained a shred of dignity. At the other end Sander Westerveld could have done with another jersey to keep himself warm.

For Spurs, Chris Armstrong posed a few problems but there was precious little else and only Graham understood the reasoning behind deploying David Ginola as a centre-forward, with Steffen Iversen shovelled out on the right flank.

Iversen is an accomplished player but not a winger, while the biggest threat posed to Liverpool's defenders in marking Ginola was getting his hair caught in their eyes. The Frenchman was substituted 13 minutes from the end to provide further ammunition for the anti-Graham faction among Tottenham's perennial grumblers. It was one of those days.

fields.headline: Musical chairs for dead wood
fields.trailText: As the new county cricket season begins, more players than ever are on the move. But this greater freedom does little to help youngsters match their foreign counterparts.
fields.body:
When Andrew Harris, the sometime England A seamer, informed Derbyshire this winter that he would not be signing a new contract after all, his bosses were taken aback, not to say a little peeved.

Hackles were raised further when it emerged that the rejection had come via John Morris, ex-Derbyshire, Durham and England, newly established as an agent in a sports management company alongside Somerset's Peter Bowler, another Derbyshire exile. That Harris duly joined Morris at Nottinghamshire did nothing to quell the feeling at Derbyshire, who have seen 13 players depart since last season, that the move raised "serious ethical considerations".

Welcome to the wacky world of the winter sales, county cricket style, a world where players move ever more freely without a farthing changing hands but where time-servers continue to profit at the expense of the young blades.

The close season has witnessed, according to John Carr, the England and Wales Cricket Board's director of cricket operations, "a slight slackening" of the regulations. Counties were previously entitled to sign only two List One players (the most experienced and most sought-after professionals) over a five-year span, but are now allowed three, no more than one of whom may be under 25.

More significant is the introduction of a loan system. If approved by both clubs and the ECB, loan deals, confined to players under 25, will be for a minimum of six weeks but may only commence between June 1 and July 31, the borrower paying the wages for the duration.

The player concerned, moreover, is forbidden from representing two sides in either the NatWest Trophy or B&H Cup. The aim of this "slackening", stresses Carr, "is to ensure counties have a chance of hanging on to players they've developed. If there's no chance of that, there's no incentive to develop."

The changes are welcomed by some, such as the players' union. Others see it as a harbinger of doom. Bob Platt, Yorkshire's cricket chairman, says: "It's the thin end of the wedge which opens the way to poaching and is the first step on the downward spiral to a transfer system, agents and all the skulduggery that goes with it. We didn't vote for this idea. It is an ECB brainstorm and we will have nothing to do with it."

Carr denies that a formal transfer system is likely to emerge. "It's hard to see how it will happen," he begins, with tact befitting an ex-banker, let alone the son of a former England captain and Lord's mandarin. "It's hard to put a fee on somebody at the end of their contract. I don't see cricket going down that route in the foreseeable future. The counties don't have vast sums to flash about. A lot of thought, I'm sure, has been given to awarding compensation, but it's a very complex area. The problem is, unless it's very low, it's like a transfer fee, and then we get into restraint of trade."

Many fear that the new rules, with the two-division structure of the County Championship, will merely encourage clubs to swap has-beens and sort-of-weres, obstructing the could-bes and blocking the supply lines of young talent.

"There is something of a concern," Carr concedes, "that by raising the stakes you make it harder for counties to take a long-term view. One hopes the top young players will force their way in. I don't think you'll find Australian state sides playing youngsters for the sake of it, but it's a very valid point."

This winter's major movers were Paul Nixon, Rob Bailey, Darren Bicknell, Alan Mullally, Trevor Ward, Phil DeFreitas, Tim Munton and Morris, all 29 or over. Only Nixon and Mullally retain realistic visions of an international role. Discouraged from moving on, the 21- and 22-year-olds who make way are expected to work on their thumb-twiddling skills. And while the benefit system remains intact, inspiring loyalty through legitimised bribery, the time-servers will continue to thwart their ambitions on another front.

Mind you, there is another way of looking at all this. One likely to find favour, at least in principle, with those advocating leaner professional staffs. "Released" by Sussex after averaging 21.27 with the bat in 23 first-class outings over four seasons, Rajesh Rao, 25, has returned to university, leg-breaks long in mothballs. Last term, Tony Cottey, 33, whose arrival from Glamorgan barred his path, averaged 27.86.

Could this signify the start of a fiendish, top-secret culling operation? If only we could be confident that the parties concerned had the foresight to be so Machiavellian.

webTitle: Chastened Blair admits Welsh leadership blunder

fields.headline: Chastened Blair admits Welsh leadership blunder
fields.trailText: April 10 2000: Tony Blair has been forced to admit he made a spectacular blunder by blocking Rhodri Morgan from standing as leader of the Welsh Labour party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has been forced to admit he made a spectacular blunder by blocking Rhodri Morgan from standing as leader of the Welsh Labour party.

In a sign that he has been chastened by the downfall of his unpopular placeman, Alun Michael, the prime minister said he should have learnt to "let go".

"I got that judgment wrong," an unusually candid Mr Blair said. "You've got to exercise discretion. You've got to know the battles to fight and the battles not to fight."

His remarks, following his speech to a south Wales audience in which he wrapped himself in Labour's red flag, signalled that Downing Street is redoubling its efforts to reach out to the party's core supporters ahead of next month's local elections. Ministers fear massive losses but hope that rallying traditional supporters will lessen the damage.

The new-look prime minister made his first appearance in yesterday's Observer when he praised the old Labour Mr Morgan, who fought a bloody battle for the leadership of the party in Wales after Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on Clapham Common. Mr Morgan lost - after the leadership blocked him through union votes - but took over as Welsh first secretary earlier this year when Mr Michael was forced out.

Mr Blair, who was put off Mr Morgan by his chaotic approach when they worked together in opposition, said he was "doing a very good job" in his new position. The prime minister's remarks will be designed to win back thousands of party supporters who abandoned Labour in last year's Welsh assembly elections out of sympathy for Mr Morgan.

Mr Blair's admission that he should have "let go" in Wales will not apply in London, where Labour stepped up its attacks on Ken Livingstone yesterday. Frank Dobson, who won the Labour nomination in similar circumstances to Alun Michael, accused Mr Livingstone of performing a u-turn after he admitted his bond scheme for the underground would cost Londoners more in taxes.

Mr Dobson will attempt to reinvigorate his lacklustre campaign today when he unveils a 10-point plan for London.

Mr Blair will finally demonstrate his support for Mr Dobson later this week when they appear together to highlight Mr Dobson's transport plans. There has been speculation that Downing Street has delayed the prime minister's appearance because Mr Blair does not want to be too closely associated with what is likely to prove to be Labour's greatest failure in nearly a decade.

webTitle: Cronje 'in the dark' over match-fixing charges

fields.headline: Cronje 'in the dark' over match-fixing charges
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje says he will make his banking details available to the ICC if they decide to investigate the allegations of match-fixing against him.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje says he will make his banking details available to the ICC if they decide to investigate the allegations of match-fixing against him.

The South African captain claimed he was still in the dark about the origin of the allegations, which he said didn't make any sense.

"The only assurance I can give people is that I've never received any sum of money for any match that I've been involved in" Cronje told reporters in Durban. "I've never ever approached any of the players and asked them if they wanted to fix a game," he added.

The United Cricket Board of South Africa's managing director, Ali Bacher, said he had spoken to Cronje and fellow internationals Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom about the allegations made against them by the Indian authorities.

"All of them dogmatically insisted that they have never ever contemplated of being party to match-fixing. Never ever," Bacher said.

Earlier today, the South African high commissioner met senior Indian foreign ministry officials in New Delhi and asked them to hand over tapes, reportedly from bugged phone conversations, that allegedly incriminate Cronje.

Maite Nkoane-Mashabane told reporters the response from the foreign ministry was "positive." South Africa has also requested a copy of the formal police charges filed against the four players.

The charges are based on tapes and transcripts of a telephone conversation in which police say Cronje discussed payment for himself and others in return for throwing a match in the five-match series that India won 3-2.

Pakistan's Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Aziz Pahad said South Africa was surprised by the accusations but that the government did not regard the matter as closed.

webTitle: Ridsdale on Turks, Spurs on probation, and Boro on holiday

fields.headline: Ridsdale on Turks, Spurs on probation, and Boro on holiday
fields.trailText: RIDSDALE LAMBASTS 'OPPORTUNISTIC' TURKS
fields.body:
RIDSDALE LAMBASTS 'OPPORTUNISTIC' TURKS

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has criticised Galatasary for "a lack of respect" and acting in an "opportunistic" fashion after the murders of United fans Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus. Ridsdale has also accused the Turkish club of undermining his efforts to ensure fans' safety at the second leg.

"These were two people who were murdered. I saw the stab wounds and I never want to see anything like that in my life again," he said. "I just wish Galatasaray would realise the impact that the events of Wednesday have had and at least show some respect, which at the moment is lacking."

A Uefa decision on the second leg is expected this week, but European football's governing body seems certain to support Leeds' wishes and ban Galatasaray fans from Elland Road. "The Football Association have been very supportive and to the best of my knowledge Uefa are too," Risdale said this morning. "I would expect them to confirm that it is okay for is to go ahead at Elland Road without any Galatasaray supporters. Safety overrides every other decision."

Ten of the Turkish youths detained after the stabbings of the two Leeds fans were released earlier today. Prosecutors are still interrogating eight others, and are expected to charge four with the stabbing and the four others with involvement in the fatal fighting.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MOANER LOSER

Spring has finally arrived. The sun is shining, children are frolicking in the meadows and little chaffinches are poking their heads out from behind well-maintained guttering. Everything is bright, beautiful and tinged with the smell of blossom. Everything, that is, apart from White Hart Lane, home of the continually under-performing Tottenham Hotspur. It is covered with frost and smells of rotting vegetation.

Spring may have passed Spurs by, but everyone is keeping themselves warm by pumping out a lot of hot air. "That's life, you do well and the fans cheer you - if you don't, they boo you," said George Graham after Spurs fans began calling for his head during yesterday's league defeat at Liverpool. "That's fair enough, I can live with that," he added, foiling all those fans who hoped to bring him down with a couple of atonal sing-songs.

Inconsistent goalkeeper Ian Walker joined the moan-in today. "It was my turn [for stick] last Monday night because I made a couple of mistakes," he revealed not-at-all grudgingly. "The criticism seems to be going around at the moment," he added. Which would explain why Sol Campbell has described the club's progress today as like "getting engaged, then getting cold feet and not getting married".

Club captain Sol, who is tipped to leave the club in the summer, is still unsure where he should direct his moaning. "I don't know if it's finances or certain people's attitudes that are holding us back," he said with North Londoners immediately scratching their head as to the identity of this certain person. "There's a lot of red tape," Sol continued. "I'm sure most people realise how close we are to being a top team again. I just hope the right people here wake up and realise." Everybody say: "I love Tottenham in the spring time..."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FILM OF THE DAY

'Manchester United - the movie'. Mel Gibson's Icon Productions are to make a fly-on-the-wall movie following Manchester United around. As great and as totally different from that programme about Fergie as it sounds, Icon have yet to come up with a name for the 'project'. Apparently they're looking for suggestions at www.manutd.com. Why don't you help them out?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

GREAT MAN MADE MYSTERY

Football manager Bryan Robson has a few problems to ponder before tonight's Premiership encounter with Manchester United. Will Gary Pallister recover his fitness in time (some would say it has gone walkabout since 1998)? Will Robbo stick with the alternating 4-3-3/4-5-1 formation that worked so well against fantastic Spurs last week? Will he call for outward investment to bolster Libya's faltering economy?

Yes, that's right, football manager Bryan Robson is set to become an international man of peace after his club announced that they will take part in a post-season tourney in Libya. The mediocre Premiership side will meet mediocre Serie A side Bari, as well as local boys Tripoli, to celebrate the opening of the inspirationally-named Great Man Made River Stadium on May 17.

"Having been to Tripoli myself," said Boro's commercial director Graham Fordy today (he's not one to boast), "I've seen how passionate they are about football. Like anywhere else there's kids kicking balls about on the streets - but they haven't seen top European sides in Libya for many, many years." Make your own 'top European side' joke here, but it's great to see Boro ready to fly the humanitarian flag abroad. And any rumours that they've been paid £1m to take part in the tournament are just that.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Barcelona's De Boer brothers, Frank and Ronald, could join Arsenal in a swap deal with Marc Overmars.

Real Madrid are lining up a double raid on the Premiership. They will bid £7m for Emmanual Petit and £5m for Nolberto Solano in the summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Kieron Dyer is ready to commit his future to Newcastle for the next decade. "I can see me staying for 10 years just for the fans," he said. "They're absolutely brilliant, and I'm just gutted for them. They're the number one fans in the world."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Sports Show (11.30pm) This show has been on for years and still it's described as 'hard-hitting'. Has nobody ever watched it?

Champions League weekly (12.35am) A big week coming up in Big Cup, so thank goodness for this weekly magazine show.

Football Extra (1.05am) It's less important than Big Cup, even on a quiet week.

Sky Sports 1: World football show (6.30pm) Mund and fut go together in perfect harmony.

Monday night football - live (7pm) Boro v United, presented by Andy Gray and a man who looks like a monkey.

***'** ** *** ******! (10.35pm, 3.15am)

"Phil, you left the toilet seat up again!! That's it, I'm leaving you. Fiona." Do you have a relationship you'd like to end in a peremptory fashion? Why not mail the McCaff at the.boss@theguardian.com?

Football League review (2.15am) Like Football Extra, only buried even deeper in the schedules.

Sky Sports 2: Football League review (11pm) Unless you watch it now that is.

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10pm) And it's the countdown to the new Norwegian season.

Radio 5 Live: Skint - the Brighton and Hove Albion story (7.30pm) See they're not only Skint, they're sponsored by skint! Or should that be Skint?

Live football - Boro v United (8pm) Presented by Mike Ingham and a man who knows which way the wind's blowing.

TaLkSPOrt: Alvin Martin (7pm) Who says ancient pros don't necessarily make good broadcasters?

webTitle: No half measures in licensing shake-up

fields.headline: No half measures in licensing shake-up
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort on beer and Britain
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw today announced that pubs and bars would be allowed to stay open beyond 11pm, in the biggest reform of licensing laws seen since the first world war.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw today announced that pubs and bars would be allowed to stay open beyond 11pm, in the biggest reform of licensing laws seen since the first world war.

Unveiling a white paper to the House of Commons, Mr Straw argued that fixed closing times encouraged binge drinking and said that some venues could now open 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

Responsibility for issuing licences and determining opening hours would be transferred from magistrates courts to local authorities, subject to appeal to the crown court, said Mr Straw, giving local authorities and police "tough and uncompromising" new powers to deal with drink-related crime and disorder.

Mr Straw's proposals to end the 11pm closing time were welcomed by the drink lobby and by Tory spokesman Oliver Heald, who said it would "end the practice of drinking to a deadline".

Iain Loe of the Campaign for Real Ale said: "We've been pressing for a long time for opening hours to be more relaxed. It's about time licensing laws in England and Wales caught up with the rest of Europe."

Gordon Skates, secretary of the Licensed Victuallers Association, said: "The trade is in favour of flexi-hours or 24-hour opening.

"Longer opening hours means there won't be crowds spilling out into the street at 11.20pm. Some people will leave at normal closing time and others may stay on until midnight."

But Alcohol Concern, a national agency concerned with educating the public about alcohol, had reservations about the proposals.

Spokesman Lisa Leonard said: "Just because drinking hours are being extended, it doesn't mean those drinking large amounts won't be drinking large amounts for longer."

The Conservatives also attacked the plan to remove licensing powers from magistrates, arguing that such decisions should remain a "judicial responsibility", and not be a "political judgment".

Apart from the 1988 reform that allowed all-day Sunday opening, the licensing laws in England and Wales have changed little since 1915, when they were tightened to stop factory workers turning up drunk and harming the war effort.

Mr Straw's proposals also focus on "rationalising" the different rules that apply to pubs, clubs, restaurants and other licensed premises.

Alongside drinks licences for specified premises, a new system of personal licences allowing holders to sell alcohol from any building will be introduced.

But the home secretary's measures are unlikely to be implemented before the next general election in 2001/2 as the government will have to invite responses to the white paper before bringing a bill before parliament.

fields.headline: Ridsdale condemns Galatasaray's 'lack of respect'
fields.trailText: Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has condemned Galatasary for showing "a lack of respect" and acting in an "opportunistic" fashion after the murders of United fans Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus. He has also accused the Turkish club of undermining his efforts to ensure fans' safety at the second leg.
fields.body:
Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has condemned Galatasary for showing "a lack of respect" and acting in an "opportunistic" fashion after the murders of United fans Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus. He has also accused the Turkish club of undermining his efforts to ensure fans' safety at the second leg.

Ridsdale said: "These were two people who were murdered. I saw the stab wounds and I never want to see anything like that in my life again. I just wish Galatasaray would stand one step back and realise the impact that the events of Wednesday have had and at least show some respect, which at the moment appears to be lacking.

"The only thing that seems to be happening is to see every loophole and opportunity to get through to the final, whilst undermining everything Leeds United have tried to do, and I think that's unfortunate."

Ridsdale has campaigned since last Thursday morning for Galatasaray supporters to stay away from Elland Road for fear of reprisals. But Galatasaray officials have called for the game to be played at a neutral venue, while club spokesman Turgay Vardar has suggested the team will refuse to travel if the fans are not allowed to go to Elland Road.

When asked about Vardar's comments, Ridsdale replied: "I think that's the best thing they can do because frankly, since it happened, Galatasaray appear to me to have been opportunistic. They have been trying to find any means possible to get through to the final without kicking a football.

"We played a football match on Thursday in circumstances which nobody should have been expected to do so. We played it because I'm not prepared for people to feel that the only way to progress through to the final of a competition is to go out and murder innocent people.

"I've been criticised in some quarters for allowing that game to take place. With the benefit of hindsight I would still progress with that game because I never ever want to see violence override true sportsmanship.

"Galatasaray, from my perspective, would be best served by acknowledging there's a game to be played a week on Thursday. They should turn up as a team, with their officials. They will be afforded every respect and given every opportunity to savour the hospitality which is afforded to any visiting club, and whatever the result it should stand.

"But to try and undermine what we wish to have, which is a return leg at Elland Road without any risk to any individual no matter what nationality, I feel saddened by the response."

Uefa are expected to back Leeds' wishes later this week.

Earlier today eighteen Turkish men appeared before prosecutors to face formal charges over the deaths of the two Leeds fans.

Prosecutors freed ten suspects, including five juveniles, without any immediate indictment.But police are questioning eight others and are expected to charge four with stabbing and four with involvement in fatal fighting, according to NTV television.

Turkish newspapers are reporting that at least five of the suspects have criminal records for knife assaults, theft and selling tickets on the black market.

"We played a football match on Thursday in circumstances which nobody should have been expected to do so. We played it because I'm not prepared for people to feel that the only way to progress through to the final of a competition is to go out and murder innocent people. "I've been criticised in some quarters for allowing that game to take place. With the benefit of hindsight I would still progress with that game because I never ever want to see violence override true sportsmanship. "Galatasaray, from my perspective, would be best served by acknowledging there's a game to be played a week on Thursday. They should turn up as a team, with their officials. They will be afforded every respect and given every opportunity to savour the hospitality which is afforded to any visiting club, and whatever the result it should stand. "But to try and undermine what we wish to have, which is a return leg at Elland Road without any risk to any individual no matter what nationality, I feel saddened by the response." Uefa are expected to back Leeds' wishes later this week. Earlier today eighteen Turkish men appeared before prosecutors to face formal charges over the deaths of the two Leeds fans. Prosecutors freed ten suspects, including five juveniles, without any immediate indictment.But police are questioning eight others and are expected to charge four with stabbing and four with involvement in fatal fighting, according to NTV television. Turkish newspapers are reporting that at least five of the suspects have criminal records for knife assaults, theft and selling tickets on the black market.

fields.headline: Snap judgments
fields.standfirst: Say cheese - the paparazzi are back in business. Last week, the Mirror published intrusive pictures of Camilla Parker Bowles.  Roy Greenslade  asks: is the press going back on its promise to clean up its act?
fields.trailText: Say cheese - the paparazzi are back in business. Last week, the Mirror published intrusive pictures of Camilla Parker Bowles. Roy Greenslade asks: is the press going back on its promise to clean up its act?
fields.body:
Jason Fraser is a specialist photographer. Some people might call him a paparazzo. But Jason is a sensitive chap and he doesn't like being designated as a pap. So let's call him what he really is: a sneak photographer. He is, in fact, Britain's foremost celebrity stalker, the man who makes his living - and a very good one it is, too - by taking pictures of people without their knowledge.

He haunts the world's beaches, creeping through bushes, hiding behind windbreaks, sometimes hiring boats, so that he can train his long lens on the famous as they soak up the sun, oblivious to the watching snapper.

The results of Jason's latest coup were published by the Mirror last Wednesday: three pages showing Camilla Parker Bowles in a swimsuit on a beach in Mauritius headlined: "Camilla as you have NEVER seen her." For this portfolio of grainy, snatched pictures of a 52-year-old woman who thought she was enjoying a private moment on a private holiday, the paper paid Fraser £20,000. Doubtless he will pick up more from foreign syndication, so he is a happy man.

The benefit for the paper was an extra sale of about 30,000 copies, a reasonable return on its investment, and evidence that editor Piers Morgan's decision to buy the pictures was justified. Mirror sources indicate that there have been no complaints about the paper's use of the pictures though there were, supposedly, calls from people who thought the paper was "too kind to Camilla" in its coverage. So Morgan is happy too. But Camilla, according to St James's Palace, was upset when she was told about the Mirror's scoop. That's hardly surprising. No one likes to think they have been watched and photographed by a stranger, and few enjoy the resulting unposed pictures.

The Mirror tried to ease the pain, and deflect any possible criticism, by running deliberately hyperbolic copy: here's Camilla "showing off a shapely body which could easily belong to a woman half her age". This disingenuous fluff was calculated to excuse the intrusive nature of the exercise.

Hang on, says the Mirror, this wasn't intrusion and certainly no breach of the editors' code of practice. Clause 3 (ii) states: "The use of long-lens photography to take pictures of people in private places without their consent is unacceptable." But this was a public beach. There were plenty of other people around.

Even that isn't conclusive because there is an important addition to that clause: "Private places are public or private property where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy."

If Camilla wished to push it, she could make out a case based on her "reasonable expectation". I doubt that she will. Like so many of Fraser's other victims in the past couple of years - stretching back to his infamous shots of Princess Diana and Dodi Fayed together on a boat days before they died - she is likely to want to put the embarrassing episode behind her.

Gradually, as the months pass, the press is conveniently forgetting the pledges it made after Diana's death. Remember the promises not to use paparazzi shots by the Mirror and the Daily Mail? Remember the hue and cry against the tabloids' use of sneak shots led by Daily Telegraph editor Charles Moore?

Yet the Mirror, Mail and Telegraph are all routinely using paparazzi pictures again. (A dozen or so were published by the Daily Telegraph during its recent serialisation of the book by bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones). Fraser's income therefore seems assured for a long time to come. None of his victims has ever gone to the Press Complaints Commission, and papers are not merely happy to use his pictures: picture desks do all they can to please him. Though both Sun editor David Yelland and Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre turned down the Camilla pictures, judging that they might suffer from a negative reaction in "the court of public opinion", their picture desk executives were far from pleased.

The Sun's team were not only amazed but alarmed. One said: "You have to admire Morgan's bottle" and wondered whether, by rejecting the pictures, they would jeopardise their relationship with Fraser.

It's not as if the paper is against his sneaky form of picture-taking. On February 29, it showed Gwyneth Paltrow sunbathing. On February 2, it published Fraser's topless pictures of Star Wars actress Natalie Portman. Both the Sun and the Daily Mail ran his holiday shots of Rory Bremner, Tiggy Legge-Bourke and Claudia Schiffer. All of these people may have expected privacy at the time, but neither the papers nor Fraser were troubled by that little matter. Celebrities are considered "fair game".

Does Camilla come into the same league? Well, there is the argument that she is the mistress of the heir to the throne and the fact that the couple do not yet feel able to take a holiday together with his children (the princes are skiing in Klosters) is interesting enough to be brought to public attention.

More pertinently, executives at the Mirror point to a St James's Palace spin-doctoring initiative which, they maintain, is aimed at presenting Camilla in a positive light. They claim that they, along with one or two other papers, often receive calls informing them that if a photographer were to be in a certain place at a certain time, they might be able to take a picture of Camilla attending, say, an opera or a private party linked to a charity.

Therefore, it is argued, an orchestrated campaign to win the public to Camilla through manipulating the press entitles papers to take unsanctioned shots of her. In the words of one unrepentant Mirror journalist: "If you dance with the devil, you will be pricked by his horns."

If this is true - and a St James's Palace spokesman has described it as a "monstrous lie" - then it shows just why intrusion is such a grey area.

But does it justify the activities of Jason Fraser? With the greatest of respect to other photographers, he is unlike most of his breed: middle-class, articulate, bilingual, well connected and, according to one of his detractors, rather sophisticated.

When he discovered that Camilla was going to Mauritius (under a false name), he booked a first-class seat just behind hers. She, of course, was unaware that the personable 33-year-old on the British Airways flight was Diana's former photographic tormentor and soon to be hers.

Fraser will not reveal his source, of course, but vehemently denies that it came from someone in BA, though it is strange how well informed he is about the movements of celebrities around the world.

In Mauritius, Camilla was disturbed one afternoon by a helicopter hovering for 10 minutes above her hotel villa. Fraser says: "I categorically deny that I was in a helicopter." But I couldn't help recalling what he told a Daily Telegraph journalist in August 1997, when boasting of his prowess after his Diana-Dodi scoop: "I do get a buzz out of hanging out of helicopters."

The Camilla pictures were certainly taken at ground or sea level, and Fraser defends taking them on the grounds that her friendship with Prince Charles has "pushed her into the limelight". He also thought the pictures showed her in "a positive light".

This is one of his favourite responses when attacked about the surreptitious nature of his work. He once wrote: "It is possible to take candid photographs of famous people in public and remain within the bounds of good taste, humour and decency."

He has also talked of having a self-imposed moral code. "I would never do to anybody what I wouldn't want done to myself. By that I mean I don't do people who are in mourning or grieving; I wouldn't dream of photographing someone in hospital; I don't trespass on private property and I don't photograph on to private property."

Even more high-mindedly, he claims: "Although I get paid a lot for the work I do, I don't do it for the money: I do it for the precious moments every year when the adrenalin rush is massive."

He also stresses that his pictures are harmless. "Look, I'm not murdering people. I'm just taking pictures of people in as flattering a light as possible."

Maybe he is fooling himself. But unless anyone complains about Fraser and the papers which are eager to pay for his services, he will go on taking his pictures.

fields.headline: The great talent hunt
fields.trailText: It's called the prune juice effect, apparently coined by an appalled Alan Sugar when he first got involved with Tottenham Hotspur. Despite buoyant revenues from the gate, sponsorship and television the club had difficulty breaking even. The money, like prune juice, went straight through the club, almost without touching the sides, straight into the pockets of the highly-paid players. Better to be a footballer than a club owner, was the conclusion. The price of talent exercises broadcasters in much the same way.
fields.body:
It's called the prune juice effect, apparently coined by an appalled Alan Sugar when he first got involved with Tottenham Hotspur. Despite buoyant revenues from the gate, sponsorship and television the club had difficulty breaking even. The money, like prune juice, went straight through the club, almost without touching the sides, straight into the pockets of the highly-paid players. Better to be a footballer than a club owner, was the conclusion. The price of talent exercises broadcasters in much the same way.

I was reminded of how apt the prune juice metaphor is when reading a recent interview with Delia Smith in the Guardian. The feature revealed her desire to take a break from television cookery in order to concentrate on Norwich City football club, where she is an investor. But my eye was taken by a paragraph where Delia, wearing her football supporter's hat, lamented the "exorbitant players' wages". Let's hope the irony of the remark was not lost on Delia. She commands large television audiences on BBC2, unrivalled book sales, owns a best-selling magazine and earns well-deserved millions as a result. Genuine talent has a price, even if the prune juice recipe is not to everyone's taste.

The inflation in the cost of talent was part of the BBC's submission to the Davies committee. They argued for a bigger licence fee to help pay for it. In their analysis some presenter fees had increased by between 60 and 100% in just two years. The corporation's frustration was well exemplified when Alan Yentob publicly attacked the negotiating stance of Frank Skinner and his agent, shortly before the comedian's departure for ITV. Alan may have been the hippest, coolest controller of BBC2, but he was also the man who moved heaven and earth to hire Noel Edmonds a few years later when he switched channels from BBC2 to BBC1. So he is no enemy of talent.

Indeed, he recently launched the new initiative, BBC Talent, at a glitzy party in the City. Messrs Yentob and Bannister sat astride the bar like Smashie'n'Nicey as they explained this search for home-grown talent to a star-studded throng, among whom was the new director-general. Their performance can't have done them any harm since they both now have shiny new jobs. Alan Yentob's includes a key responsibility for talent. Already the BBC has put a network of "talent managers" in place - named individuals who are meant to look after particular presenters to improve the bond between them and the BBC.

In the meantime there has been a massive response to the BBC Talent campaign: getting on for half a million hits at its website, huge presenter auditions across the country, hundreds of scripts submitted to the sitcom event and 300 audition tapes sent in to the comedy awards. It has really caught the imagination of the next generation of would-be entertainers.

It is very important for the BBC to grow new talent, not least because talent inflation will intensify further as competition hots up between the growing number of channels. Whether it is Channel 4 or Sky One or Discovery Home and Leisure, they are all seeking faces to personify their channels. They will have to invest heavily in this branch of marketing and they will bid each other up, no doubt with some (entirely disinterested) help from the massed ranks of agents.

True, we have not yet seen deals of the sort that US networks have made for the likes of Friends and ER. These are classic squeezings of prune juice where the network pays more for the shows than it can possibly recoup in advertising. But they cannot afford not to have the show. Meanwhile, many of the greenbacks flow straight through the production company to the show's stars. In Britain, a number of our programme brands and formats remain stronger than the talent. So stars can come and go from EastEnders, Coronation Street or You've Been Framed and the shows still continue to prosper. But the signs are that we are edging closer to the US model.

There has been no more surreal moment in the past year than seeing how docusoaps are handled at awards ceremonies. The "real people" featured have been going up on stage to receive the accolades - collecting awards for being themselves! And now they have their own agents and series.

My advice to any young entrants to our industry is simple: whether in front or behind the camera, make sure you're the talent. Then, to paraphrase Oscar Wilde, you have nothing to manage but your own genius.

 Peter Bazalgette is creative director of GMG Endemol Entertainment, an independent production company part-owned by the Guardian Media Group

webTitle: Chastened Blair admits Welsh leadership blunder

fields.headline: Chastened Blair admits Welsh leadership blunder
fields.standfirst:
Devolution in Wales: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has been forced to admit he made a spectacular blunder by blocking Rhodri Morgan from standing as leader of the Welsh Labour party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has been forced to admit he made a spectacular blunder by blocking Rhodri Morgan from standing as leader of the Welsh Labour party.

In a sign that he has been chastened by the downfall of his unpopular placeman, Alun Michael, the prime minister said he should have learnt to "let go".

"I got that judgment wrong," an unusually candid Mr Blair said. "You've got to exercise discretion. You've got to know the battles to fight and the battles not to fight."

His remarks, following his speech to a south Wales audience in which he wrapped himself in Labour's red flag, signalled that Downing Street is redoubling its efforts to reach out to the party's core supporters ahead of next month's local elections. Ministers fear massive losses but hope that rallying traditional supporters will lessen the damage.

The new-look prime minister made his first appearance in yesterday's Observer when he praised the old Labour Mr Morgan, who fought a bloody battle for the leadership of the party in Wales after Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on Clapham Common. Mr Morgan lost - after the leadership blocked him through union votes - but took over as Welsh first secretary earlier this year when Mr Michael was forced out.

Mr Blair, who was put off Mr Morgan by his chaotic approach when they worked together in opposition, said he was "doing a very good job" in his new position. The prime minister's remarks will be designed to win back thousands of party supporters who abandoned Labour in last year's Welsh assembly elections out of sympathy for Mr Morgan.

Mr Blair's admission that he should have "let go" in Wales will not apply in London, where Labour stepped up its attacks on Ken Livingstone yesterday. Frank Dobson, who won the Labour nomination in similar circumstances to Alun Michael, accused Mr Livingstone of performing a u-turn after he admitted his bond scheme for the underground would cost Londoners more in taxes.

Mr Dobson will attempt to reinvigorate his lacklustre campaign today when he unveils a 10-point plan for London.

Mr Blair will finally demonstrate his support for Mr Dobson later this week when they appear together to highlight Mr Dobson's transport plans. There has been speculation that Downing Street has delayed the prime minister's appearance because Mr Blair does not want to be too closely associated with what is likely to prove to be Labour's greatest failure in nearly a decade.

webTitle: Shell to step on the gas

fields.headline: Shell to step on the gas
fields.standfirst: Anglo-Dutch oil giant plans £9bn bid for BG International
fields.trailText: Energy giant Shell is to accelerate its dash for gas with an approximately £9bn bid for the overseas interests of the former British Gas conglomerate, according to weekend press reports. The group yesterday refused to comment on speculation it was preparing to buy BG International.
fields.body:
Energy giant Shell is to accelerate its dash for gas with an approximately £9bn bid for the overseas interests of the former British Gas conglomerate, according to weekend press reports. The group yesterday refused to comment on speculation it was preparing to buy BG International.

Such a deal would highlight the steady shift of traditionally oil-based companies into gas activities as petroleum reserves run down and pressure grows around the world for cleaner energy generation.

Last summer, Karen de Segundo, head of Shell's gas and power division, said gas would account for more than 50% of the group's production within the first quarter of this century. The production gap of 67% oil to 33% gas would narrow, then disappear, she said.

While on current trends Shell's transformation into a gas company would take until 2022, one or two big projects, or deals, would speed up the process considerably.

According to reports yesterday, Shell has hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the US investment bank, to prepare for the bid. Shell is expected to try to buy the business for cash before BG completes its "divorce" into two parts - BG International and the domestic pipeline business, Transco.

Last month, Dick Giordano, who will chair BG International, said: "We would have to listen if a suitable company with a fat wallet (made a bid approach)".

Shell's group treasurer, Steve Hodge, said: "They have assets that any oil company would be interested in. We would be derelict in our duty if we did not look at them and at what price we could get them for."

BG International has assets around the world, including in the West Indies, South America, Indonesia, Egypt, India and the Mediterranean.

But some of these rich gas reserves are kept from potential customers by inadequate facilities. fields.headline: Brands hatching
fields.standfirst: The new Skoda ads are trying to change our view of a product that was famously naff. So what gives a car its image, asks  Stephen Bayley, and do the makers and marketers have any control over it?
fields.trailText: The new Skoda ads are trying to change our view of a product that was famously naff. So what gives a car its image, asks Stephen Bayley, and do the makers and marketers have any control over it?
fields.body:
There are about 18 major passenger vehicle manufacturers on the planet, although the number will soon drop. Between them they have about 50 brands or what, in more innocent stringback-glove-and foaming-pint days, used to be called marques. As the industry consolidates into almighty conglomerates, the most urgent creative task is to understand what these brands mean. How did they acquire their value? How can this value be exploited and extended? If you haven't got it, how can you get it?

Today anybody with machine tools and access to cheap labour can make a car. If someone gave me the money I could start tomorrow. This is why the smarter automobile makers are already contemplating a future when they subcontract dirty manufacturing, leaving themselves with the most precious commodities and vital disciplines of the information age: design, marketing and distribution. At the same time, for many individuals the car has ceased to be a viable means of transport: legislation and congestion mock the spirit of democratic mobility that inspired the first makers of automobiles. Equally, technical distinctions are thinning and today there are very few positively bad cars on sale.

Competitive advantage used to come from the simple ability to manufacture, now it comes from something infinitely more subtle and mysterious: image. Unlike a production line, which is predictable, the image a car possesses is volatile, transient and difficult to control. Here we are in intellectual territory, surroundings that until now have been alien to the motor industry. Manufacturers may have total control over the design and content of the cars they sell, but they cannot control their afterlife. It's the same with paintings that acquire meanings which the artist may never have intended.

Although advertising can help build a brand image, it doesn't always work. Some things are beyond the opinion research, brainstorming, and cost-per-thousand figures that dominate this pseudo-science. It is really more snake oil and sorcery. Despite what the agency might say, you can't help who buy the cars. Maserati, for example, always attracted the wrong sort of people: men who wear those woven shoes and have a disinclination to do up their shirt buttons. Now Maserati is owned by Ferrari, but these old impressions stick: it's a truism of marketing that image endures long after the reality that brought it about. Even BMW has its problems. In the 80s there were discussions about buying-in used cars to prevent them falling into the wrong hands. Certainly, BMW does a marvellous job of fetishising cupidity, but recent embarrassments with British investments have led to an unfamiliar image crisis. It will be some time before wholesome estate agents stride into wine bars and flash their 3-series key fobs. To add to a basket of positive associations, largely justified by a tradition of refined design and superb engineering, BMW now has to tackle less welcome associations including arrogance, indecisiveness, ruthlessness and a certain reluctance to be straightforward. Still, there are some who say that an air of menace is a significant part of the BMW brand proposition.

General Motors invented brand strategy in the 50s when that wizard of kitsch, Harley Earl, defined car design as giving the customer a "visual receipt" for his money. But a brilliant strategy that clearly defined Chevrolet, Oldsmobile, Buick, Pontiac and Cadillac so that every nuance of US taste was not just catered to, but anticipated, has gone astray. Now General Motors has the unfortunate reputation of owning five brands that even Americans won't buy. The Chevrolet Vega and Chevette were recently described by the New York Times as among the worst cars ever made. It always used to be described as social suicide to be seen driving a Chevy off the Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard ferry.

Some of this rubs off on Vauxhall, General Motors' local product. Many people would rather walk than use one. As a brand it represents an almost fathomless black hole. Far better be in a Skoda than a Vauxhall. With roots deep in the European engineering tradition, Skoda never deserved its comedic reputation: the cars were in themselves fine. Their only problem was that the Czech factory was crippled by under investment and as late as the 80s they were still producing a car that was no more technically advanced than the 1936 Volkswagen. And of course corrupt Comecon supply chains meant Skoda had shabby materials and irregular ancillaries. But they were cheap and where brands are concerned cheap doesn't necessarily mean good. Skodas were bought by low income individuals and this set up a resonant chain that said "I am poor" and as a result of that robbed downstream Skoda owners of sexual allure and social prestige to a disturbing degree.

Then Volkswagen bought Skoda to have a brand for Eastern Europe and things got better. Except the advertising, which was as dismaying as the jokes. As a careless shortcut to credibility, explicit associations made people scratch their heads and wonder why buy a Czech Volkswagen when you could buy a German one? That problem has now been solved by some fine cars, although Skoda does still have its difficulties with names. Felicia sounded like a sexual practice with your teeth misisng.. Now there is Fabia, but it is a car that can be bought without a keen sense of irony. Fallon McElligott's latest television ads attempt to change our view of the brand. The current one has a British dignitary enthusiastically touring the factory in the Czech Republic before asking if they also make "those funny little Skoda cars" as well. It is cleverly conceived and beautifully executed, and although the Skoda brand still has a mountain to climb, it is well up the lower slopes.

Machines have life and they tend to betray the preoccupations and beliefs of the people who make them. Skoda is now making well-designed cars so its brand will continue to increase in value. Those people are really committed. Maserati, on the other hand, was not: the Maserati brothers never actually wanted to make road cars, they were only interested in racing. And this is why Vauxhall has the allure of a dead cat : there is nothing to believe in.

Again, nobody's heart was in Rover: the whole misadventure was like Goldsmith's line about toiling pleasure sickening into pain. This is why BMW will be fine: everybody knows they are fanatical about the product. Jaguar is exemplary too. It just gets better and better. Jaguar's image is so strong it can even survive close association with John Prescott.

But the biggest brand problem of all? It is Rolls-Royce and Bentley. Instead of rock solid associations of aristocratic privilege, luxury and graciousness, images of scrap metal dealers float into view. Anyway, things can only get better: Dirk van Braeckl, the designer who did so much to improve Skoda, has gone to work in Crewe. The way things are now, Rolls-Royce can only benefit from association with Skoda.

Cars that ended up with the wrong image

Citroën 2CV
Designed in 1935 by André Citroën as a replacement for the French peasant's horse and cart, the ungainly 2CV has been adopted by sandal-wearing teachers and liberals across the UK. No gite-loving Francophile would be content without one.

Ferrari
Once an aristocrat's plaything Enzo's work of art is now the quintessential flash footballer's run-about. In fact the players' car park at Old Trafford easily passes for a Ferrari showroom.

Ford Mondeo
Tony Blair's Mondeo man stereotype had the marketing men crying into their espressos. The car is now indelibly associated with the middle-England mediocrity of estate agents, school runs, and 2.4 children.

VW Camper
Hijacked by tie-dyed hippies and bronzed Californian surf bums, the 1960s saw the VW Camper transformed from family recreation vehicle to mobile den of iniquity.

Ford Escort XR3i

Conceived in 1982 at the height of Thatcherism, this beast was soon snapped up by boy racers and equipped with fluffy dice and matching his'n'hers name stickers in the window. As soon as the sun set in Essex, every one way system became an unofficial XR3i racetrack.

webTitle: Me and my motor: Howard Slater

fields.headline: Me and my motor: Howard Slater
fields.trailText: Howard Slater was once a professor of microbiology. Now he is boss of Frog Tours in London.
fields.body:
Howard Slater was once a professor of microbiology. Now he is boss of Frog Tours in London.

What the hell's that?

It's a Frog Tours bus - an amphibious vehicle that travels around London and then goes into the Thames. It's based on the DUKW landing craft, designed and developed to facilitate European landings in the second world war.

Where did you get the idea from?

While I was on holiday in Boston in the US I saw something similar. My daughters pushed me to try it out and it was huge fun - so I decided to replicate it in London.

Where do they go?

We run adventure tours called Around London in 80 Minutes, which take in all the tourist attractions including Buckingham Palace, Piccadilly Circus and Hyde Park continuing into the Thames and going past the Houses of Parliament.

Do you think tourists really want their bus to drive into the river?

Absolutely; they're overwhelmed by it.

How many are there?

Three running currently with a view to adding two a month. I've taken on option to buy a total of 32, each one coming into service once a renovation and re-service has been completed.

Do they have names?

Mistress Quickly, Beatrice and Titania.

Have you ever driven one?

Yes, but not on the road as I don't have the appropriate licence. You need a PSV (Passenger Service Vehicle) licence and a boatsman's licence from the Port of London. It's the most regulated method of transport.

Who has travelled on it so far?

Fare-paying tourists of all sorts of nationalities. The personalities that helped to launch it were Stirling Moss and Jenson Button. We asked them because they represent the old and the new - as the Frog does.

What do passers by think?

People continually stop and stare with mouths dropped open. The older folk mouth "duck" because they know how the vehicle was originally used. On one occasion, football fans at Trafalgar Square sang We Love Mr Froggie and then Yellow Submarine at it. If we travel down The Mall, more people look at the Frog than at the Palace.

Is there anything you don't like about it?

No. It's deeply endearing and adds a new dimension to London. It has a major historical role and is given a new lease of life.

What do you normally drive?

A dark blue BMW 323

 Frog tours: 020 7928 3132

fields.headline: Now or never
fields.standfirst: There are plenty of Rover bargains out there, but is it wise to go for one, asks  Richard Simpson
fields.trailText: There are plenty of Rover bargains out there, but is it wise to go for one, asks Richard Simpson
fields.body:
Last weekend Rover launched a media blitz to persuade us to buy their new cars, and in such desperate circumstances they have to appeal to buyers' baser instincts with cut-price offers.

The deals certainly do look tempting. First there are price cuts, with £1,000 "cashback" on a Rover 25, £1,500 on a 45 and £2,000 off the big Rover 75. On top of that there's two years' 0% finance with a 40% deposit, plus three years' free servicing. And because of the uncertainty about the future, Rover also claim that they'll ensure the serviceability of all their cars for at least 10 years. So is buying a new Rover still too much of a gamble, no matter how good the price may seem?

Mark Norman is editor of the influential CAP Monitor trade-price guide, and he's confident that we should take Rover at their word. "All future values hinge on parts supply and availability of service points, and I don't expect problems with either. When the Rover sell-off was announced, there was a strong suspicion that Rover's residuals would collapse, but they didn't. In fact the cars have performed well so far, and even for future residuals we've only marked Rover down slightly."

I won't bore you with the figures, but Norman confirms that he expects new Rover residual values to decline from middling to slightly below the market average, while most older Rovers won't be affected significantly. That's very important of course, because the price you get for a car when you sell it is just as important as what you pay now - since depreciation is the key motoring cost. So with some informed reassurance that your new Rover won't collapse in value, should you now take Rover up on its generous offer?

In a way, their own press advertisement provides the most likely answer to this question, since they use some worked examples of financing a new Rover through a personal contract purchase (PCP) package. Choose a relatively inexpensive car, like the £9,395 Rover 25 1.4 i, and under Rover's new deal you put down £499 and then pay just over £150 a month to drive the car for three years. At the end you can pay another £3,961 to buy the car outright, although if Rover's residual values are in the dog-house by then, you can simply walk away.

That deal looks like decent value, because running a new car for just over £150 a month isn't bad, especially with servicing thrown in. But move up to the Rover 75 and things start to look less attractive. If you fancy the 75 1.8i Classic you're going to have slap down £999 as a deposit, and then pay over £250 a month to drive the car for three years. And in the current market, I wouldn't bet that a three-year-old Rover 75 will beat Rover's guaranteed value of £8,984.64, suggesting that you'd be unlikely to get much cash back to put towards your next deposit. (Although even if the car's final value is much less than Rover predict, you wouldn't be a total loser, because any over-estimate by them will actually reduce your monthly payments.)

It's also worth bearing in mind that car supermarkets are offering some staggeringly cheap deals on new Rovers at the moment, largely because there are plenty of unsold cars about. For instance Derby-based Motorpoint (01332 347357) is offering new Rover 75 1.8 Club SEs for just £14,999 and Rover 25 1.4 iS at £8,499 - savings of £4,881 and £3,496 respectively.

In the end I'd only buy a new Rover if I really liked the car anyway, and the smaller, cheaper 25s do look like the range's best-buys. But what about the award-winning Rover 75? Sadly Rover's image problems are almost certain to hit the range-topping 75 harder than the workaday 25s, so despite their various incentives, it's hard to see the 75 as an ideal private buyer's car. But as the Rover spokesman commented, with what must have been a distinctly wan smile, with a likely maximum of 100,000 75s ever being produced, this model may eventually become a collectors item.

fields.headline: Mind your language, British politicians warned
fields.standfirst: Attempts by both the Tories and Labour to 'outgun' each other on the asylum issue have backfired, writes Guardian political correspondent Nicholas Watt
fields.trailText: Moderate Tories who still cling to the hope that William Hague will one day return to the centre ground were exasperated last week when the Conservative leader decided to play politics with Britain's asylum crisis.
fields.body:
Moderate Tories who still cling to the hope that William Hague will one day return to the centre ground were exasperated last week when the Conservative leader decided to play politics with Britain's asylum crisis.

In a powerful echo of Margaret Thatcher's infamous warning that Britain was being "swamped" by immigrants, Mr Hague complained of a "flood" of bogus asylum seekers.

The use of such emotive language has sparked a furious debate, prompting the non-partisan United Nations High Commission for Refugees to take the rare step of rebuking the Tories.

But the UNHCR's criticisms, echoed by the Liberal Democrats in a complaint to the Commission for Racial Equality, were not confined to the Tories. The home secretary, Jack Straw, was also upbraided for breaking an all-party agreement to avoid stirring up divisions among different racial groups by using hostile language.

The government dismissed the criticisms over the weekend and ministers attempted to turn the spotlight on the Tories by condemning them for "playing the race card". Downing Street insisted yesterday - in carefully crafted terms - that there was a serious problem of "not genuine" asylum seekers, a situation which has been hampered by the Tories' failure to reform the system when they were in office.

Moderates from both parties will be hoping the row will provide a moment for the Tory and Labour leaderships to reflect on the wisdom of trying to outgun one another on populist issues such as asylum.

One of Tony Blair's great successes has been to rob the Tories of their claim to be the party of law and order, by staking a claim on territory which was traditionally the property of the right.

This has seen Mr Straw condemn homeless people as "winos" and round on the "squeegee merchants" who wipe motorists' windscreens at traffic lights. Not to be outdone, the asylum minister, Barbara Roche, recently described aggressive beggars who use children to aid their cause as "vile".

Mr Straw has been careful not to use such language about asylum seekers. But his response to the Afghan hijack crisis earlier this year, in which he informed the Commons that refugees on the plane would be returned home before he had considered their cases, strayed into highly-sensitive territory.

"The prime minister's view is that in this area you do have to be very, very careful about the language you use and the way you deploy that language," Downing Street said yesterday.

A sensible conclusion for all concerned, including the government.

webTitle: The new activism (fire in the belly) (IV)

fields.headline: The new activism (fire in the belly) (IV)
fields.trailText:
Part one: Culture jamming
Part two: The Manchurian consumer: are you authentic?
Part three: Posthuman: life in cyberspace
fields.body:
Part one: Culture jamming
Part two: The Manchurian consumer: are you authentic?
Part three: Posthuman: life in cyberspace

You may already be a culture jammer. Maybe you're a student who does not want a career working for corporate America. A graphic artist tired of selling your soul to ad agency clients. A vegan. A biker. A maverick professor. An Earth Firster who liberated a billboard last night.

We jammers are a loose global network of artists, activists, environmentalists, Green entrepreneurs, media-literacy teachers, downshifters, reborn Lefties, high-school shit disturbers, campus rabble-rousers, drop-outs, incorrigibles, poets, philosophers, ecofeminists. We cover the spectrum from the cool intellectual middle to the violent lunatic fringe, from Raging Grannies who chant doggerel at protests to urban guerrillas who stage wild street parties. We are ecological economists, TV jammers, ethical investors. We paint our own bike lanes, reclaim streets, "skull" Calvin Klein ads, and paste GREASE stickers on tables and trays at McDonald's restaurants. We organize swap meets, rearrange items on supermarket shelves, make our software available free on the Net, and generally apply ourselves to the daily business of getting consumer culture to bite its own tail. We're idealists, anarchists, guerrilla tacticians, hoaxers, pranksters, neo-Luddites, malcontents and punks. We are the ragtig remnants of oppositional culture - what's left of the revolutionary impulse in the jaded "fin de millenium atmosphere of postmodernity" in which revolution is said to be no longer possible. What we share is an overwhelming rage against consumer capitalism, and a vague sense that our time has come to act as a collective force.

On the simplest level, we are a growing band of people who have given up on the American dream. Here are a few samples of the way we think:

 Instead of treating vegetative, corporate-driven TV culture as something to be gently, ironically mocked, it's time to face the whole ugly spectre of our TV-addicted nation, the savage anomie of a society entranced and entrapped and living a lie. It's time to admit that chronic TV watching is North America's number one mental health problem, and that a society in which citizens spend a quarter of their waking lives (more than four hours a day) in front of their sets is in serious need of shock therapy.

 We recycle our beer cans, newspapers and vodka bottles; we join car pools and food co-ops; we turn our thermostats down at night. We do all the right things. So why do our environmental problems just keep getting worse? Maybe it's time we stopped expending our energies on small do-goody gestures and faced the fact that many of the paradigms within which we live cultural, social, economic - are outdated and dysfunctional. Most of our environmental "solutions" are red herrings. They deflect energy from the essential work at hand. What we need is not just fewer cars on the roads but new cities designed chiefly with pedestrians, bicycles and public transport in mind. Not just new ecofriendly products, but new consumption patterns and new lifestyles. Not just a carbon tax, but a global across-the-board pricing system that tells the ecological truth. Not just new measures of economic progress more accurate than the GDP, but a radical rethinking of the neoclassical paradigm we've been teaching in Economics 101 for the past few generations.

 Ours is a society filled with exceptional individuals, affluent communities, efficient businesses, top notch universities and exciting cities. But that is no longer enough. The concept of excellence must now be applied to the whole culture. We have never been afraid of getting tough with the other broken systems in our lives; we retrain workers, dump governments, and eagerly, completely revamp entire corporate cultures such as IBM's when they lose their sense of mission. Now let's apply that sane sense of focused urgency to the repair of our culture.

Let's rethink our vital components - our information delivery systems, our basic ideas about nutrition, transportation and economics. Let's commit, totally, passionately, to reducing our ecological footprint, to learning how to measure progress accurately, to countering the information viruses spreading in our midst. Instead of resisting this kind of fundamental change, let's embrace it. Let's cheer on our cultural rebels even as we fear them. Let's revel in (or at least not shy away from) the life and death of our paradigms.
