fields.headline: More trouble...
fields.standfirst: Since the cameras from BBC's Trouble Between the Covers left Sally O'Sullivan's publishing house, Cabal, rumours suggest that all is not well. Two weeks ago, O'Sullivan's founding partner, Andy Sutcliffe, quit.  Maggie Brown  investigates
fields.trailText: Since the cameras from BBC's Trouble Between the Covers left Sally O'Sullivan's publishing house, Cabal, rumours suggest that all is not well. Two weeks ago, O'Sullivan's founding partner, Andy Sutcliffe, quit. Maggie Brown investigates
fields.body:
"In publishing", says Andy Sutcliffe with a sigh, "you can be too small." He speaks with first-hand knowledge. Until two weeks ago, he was managing director of Cabal, the magazine company he founded with Sally O'Sullivan in August 1998 in a blaze of defiance and optimism. "When you are small, you need luck," he observes. "Competing with IPC and Emap is not the easiest thing in the world. It's true that 'All's fair in love and war'. It was very hard."

Sutcliffe, the second - and highest profile - of the four founding directors to quit, is speaking from his girlfriend's house in Highgate. He is sitting out his notice and pondering his next move, diplomatically vague on details such as what to do with his Cabal share options.

In its short but intensely scrutinised life, Cabal, which now publishes two successful monthly glossies - lads' mag Front and lifestyle read Real Homes - has generated more media interest than all its big established rivals put together. Proof of how we love a tale of David taking on Goliath? Perhaps. But also because we like to see big egos with big plans colliding with reality.

Sutcliffe acted camera-shy during the episode that really propelled Cabal into the wider public eye - Trouble Between the Covers. This four-part BBC2 business series, screened in January, was hijacked by Front's editor, Piers Hernu, but painted an extraordinary, partial portrait of life within Cabal's squashed offices on the Euston Road, central London, during its first year.

It included the departure of another founder director, Helen Brocklebank, when the company failed to land a big contract magazine for Boots, losing out to one of the sector's titans. But, since filming stopped last August, it also failed to update with some better news. There were good audited circulation figures for the monthlies in February and an increase in turnover to around £10m a year. Front is selling 141,000 copies a month, and Real Homes 131,000.

A compensatory move into internet publishing is also under way. Cabal has won the contract to supply the editorial content for a food and drink site for Sainsbury's - although the launch may be affected by the supermarket's new management - and has a clutch of other internet projects in hand.

On the surface, then, O'Sullivan's declaration that the TV series did more good - in terms of publicity - than harm has proved correct. But then there's Sutcliffe sat in his girlfriend's front room. Jonathan Rose, the company's new media specialist publishing director, has also left suddenly; and Hernu's scene-stealing screen charisma has, over the past few weeks, led him to be connected with practically every job going; from the Loaded editorship to a six-month development contract with independent producers Bazal and a number of TV presenting roles.

Sutcliffe parries questions about why he left with the reply: "I felt very close to Cabal. But I also feel very close to my career." His former partner O'Sullivan says, "He was absolutely fundamental and instrumental in starting the company. You have to adapt to the life-stage of a company." He is not being replaced.

Leaving, he says, was his decision. "I felt there was a great big world out there: the internet, a million and one opportunities. One problem with working for a small company is that there were fairly limited opportunities. Yet it is a time when there is almost a once in a lifetime opportunity for editorial people who know about content. I didn't want that to pass me by."

A new company clearly has to be very selective, because there is no margin for error. A key moment of truth arrived last year, when advanced plans for a big weekly crime magazine were hastily ditched, as IPC threatened a spoiler. It also led to observations in the specialist press that the big publishers have delighted in ganging up to bully the upstart.

To get any presence with a new magazine on overcrowded news stands, Sutcliffe muses, sales need to be around 100,000, the mags have to carry "cover mounts" (free gifts) and cut prices. The cost, including marketing, is likely to be somewhere between £3-£4m.

"The problem is that you have to invest something to get something," says Sutcliffe. Had Cabal, with its slender start-up funds, underestimated the problems? "I don't think we went into it naively," he says, but he clearly found the small scale business difficult. "One day you are doing very executive-ish sorts of things, next unblocking the toilets or taking a midnight call saying that the company is being burgled. In bigger companies your role is more precisely defined."

When O'Sullivan launched, she talked big, as one does to cause a stir. Not just of starting a range of perhaps a dozen titles, but producing them in a magazine utopia, by a family-style team who would even be allowed to take days off - called "mental health days" - when wanted. There were few job titles, and an atmosphere of informality.

She was also leading a breakaway from IPC, at a point when a successfully negotiated management buy-out had stopped short of including the key editorial figures. Sutcliffe had worked alongside her at IPC for seven years, rising to group editor, music and sports (he was originally editor of Cycling Weekly and brought two cycling titles to Cabal).

Rose, who helped set up the deal with Sainsbury's and set up Cabal's Pro-Cycling website, says the fact the chain chose Cabal rather than its rivals was a big coup and reflected the fact that O'Sullivan has the editorial teams to supply content. (Sarah Bravo, former editor of Real Homes, is spearheading the team).

He remains sympathetic to Cabal's trials. "I don't think Sally's been given the credit she deserves," he says. Insiders say that it has all been much more difficult than expected, putting O'Sullivan under huge pressure, although she has clearly adapted her plans to new conditions. Even the BBC film-makers said that they wished they had time to make an extra film, to describe what happens when the utopian dream collapses under 12-hour days.

Where does Cabal's future lie? From outside, Rose thinks it has a definite niche as an independent publisher: "There is space for all sizes, the future is good. They are very good at designing, things." Meanwhile, Sutcliffe outlines other options: Cabal can go it alone, or it may be acquired because of the good people it employs. The problem for a publisher of just two or three titles is that it's not the way to strike the best printing and paper deals. "Most of the major publishers have very broad portfolios," he concludes.

But O'Sullivan continues to fight on. A resilient media player (described by Sutcliffe as having "limitless contacts"), she says that if she's made one mistake it was by not concentrating all efforts on the big two titles, rather than trying to add smaller titles as well. "It is difficult being small. I agree with Andy," she says. "You have to move more slowly. In an ideal world, I'd like to launch titles every week." But she has a new male lifestyle magazine, Mondo, "a sort of 21st century Face" due for September launch, and another women's lifestyle magazine planned.

Plus, she sees websites as the "natural progression" for the company, although it was not something she foresaw two years ago. "I see a big future there. We are small enough to do it. In future we will launch new magazines and websites together."

The truth about Cabal, it seems, is that its day-to-day struggles have turned it into a standard small commercial operation, living a rather banal existence - a long way from the glamorous image the magazine world tries to project. And different too from what its young metropolitan media types expected. Trouble between the covers indeed.

They let the cameras in... and regretted it

Royal Opera House
Jeremy Isaacs, a former TV executive, assumed that BBC2's The House would be a showcase for such Covent Garden talents as Darcey Bussell, convincing the audience that his huge Arts Council subsidy and Lottery grant were well spent. Instead they saw ineptitude, bitching and an underling being sacked with apparent relish.

L!ve TV
Nightmare on Canary Wharf began with the cable channel's launch by Janet Street-Porter as an experimental yoof station, gleefully sat in as her bête noire Kelvin MacKenzie was installed by David Montgomery as TV chief, and recorded her inevitable exit - followed by L!ve's transformation into a porn-and-sport channel. Street-Porter, Montgomery and MacKenzie no longer work in the TV industry.

Graham Taylor
Followed by Channel 4's Cutting Edge as England manager during the qualification campaign for the 1994 World Cup, Taylor broke existing TV records with 37 four-letter words, made "Do I not like that!" a nationwide catchphrase, and raged at officials as his team lost the key game against Holland. Resigned after this defeat.

Bath Rugby Club
Before letting the cameras in, virtually invincible and indisputably England's top club. During filming, humiliated in games with big rivals, out of contention for all trophies, split by feuding.

The Independent
Looking for positive publicity three relaunches ago, during the brief reign of Rosie Boycott. Tony O'Reilly gained control during filming - and Boycott swiftly departed for the Express - so that instead of a paper which had found its direction, viewers saw one in constant turmoil.

Bosses on the Beeb
Business series Trouble at the Top, Back to the Floor and Dangerous Company (don't they notice these titles before saying yes?) spawned high-profile casualties including Dino Adriano, ditched as chief executive of Sainsbury's, and ex-BA boss Bob Ayling.

Sutcliffe had worked alongside her at IPC for seven years, rising to group editor, music and sports (he was originally editor of Cycling Weekly and brought two cycling titles to Cabal). Rose, who helped set up the deal with Sainsbury's and set up Cabal's Pro-Cycling website, says the fact the chain chose Cabal rather than its rivals was a big coup and reflected the fact that O'Sullivan has the editorial teams to supply content. (Sarah Bravo, former editor of Real Homes, is spearheading the team). He remains sympathetic to Cabal's trials. "I don't think Sally's been given the credit she deserves," he says. Insiders say that it has all been much more difficult than expected, putting O'Sullivan under huge pressure, although she has clearly adapted her plans to new conditions. Even the BBC film-makers said that they wished they had time to make an extra film, to describe what happens when the utopian dream collapses under 12-hour days. Where does Cabal's future lie? From outside, Rose thinks it has a definite niche as an independent publisher: "There is space for all sizes, the future is good. They are very good at designing, things." Meanwhile, Sutcliffe outlines other options: Cabal can go it alone, or it may be acquired because of the good people it employs. The problem for a publisher of just two or three titles is that it's not the way to strike the best printing and paper deals. "Most of the major publishers have very broad portfolios," he concludes. But O'Sullivan continues to fight on. A resilient media player (described by Sutcliffe as having "limitless contacts"), she says that if she's made one mistake it was by not concentrating all efforts on the big two titles, rather than trying to add smaller titles as well. "It is difficult being small. I agree with Andy," she says. "You have to move more slowly. In an ideal world, I'd like to launch titles every week." But she has a new male lifestyle magazine, Mondo, "a sort of 21st century Face" due for September launch, and another women's lifestyle magazine planned. Plus, she sees websites as the "natural progression" for the company, although it was not something she foresaw two years ago. "I see a big future there. We are small enough to do it. In future we will launch new magazines and websites together." The truth about Cabal, it seems, is that its day-to-day struggles have turned it into a standard small commercial operation, living a rather banal existence - a long way from the glamorous image the magazine world tries to project. And different too from what its young metropolitan media types expected. Trouble between the covers indeed. They let the cameras in... and regretted it Royal Opera House Jeremy Isaacs, a former TV executive, assumed that BBC2's The House would be a showcase for such Covent Garden talents as Darcey Bussell, convincing the audience that his huge Arts Council subsidy and Lottery grant were well spent. Instead they saw ineptitude, bitching and an underling being sacked with apparent relish. L!ve TV Nightmare on Canary Wharf began with the cable channel's launch by Janet Street-Porter as an experimental yoof station, gleefully sat in as her bête noire Kelvin MacKenzie was installed by David Montgomery as TV chief, and recorded her inevitable exit - followed by L!ve's transformation into a porn-and-sport channel. Street-Porter, Montgomery and MacKenzie no longer work in the TV industry. Graham Taylor Followed by Channel 4's Cutting Edge as England manager during the qualification campaign for the 1994 World Cup, Taylor broke existing TV records with 37 four-letter words, made "Do I not like that!" a nationwide catchphrase, and raged at officials as his team lost the key game against Holland. Resigned after this defeat. Bath Rugby Club Before letting the cameras in, virtually invincible and indisputably England's top club. During filming, humiliated in games with big rivals, out of contention for all trophies, split by feuding. The Independent Looking for positive publicity three relaunches ago, during the brief reign of Rosie Boycott. Tony O'Reilly gained control during filming - and Boycott swiftly departed for the Express - so that instead of a paper which had found its direction, viewers saw one in constant turmoil. Bosses on the Beeb Business series Trouble at the Top, Back to the Floor and Dangerous Company (don't they notice these titles before saying yes?) spawned high-profile casualties including Dino Adriano, ditched as chief executive of Sainsbury's, and ex-BA boss Bob Ayling.

fields.headline: My media: Fiona Allen
fields.trailText: Newspapers: I'm not actually a great newspaper reader. I like the Times, because it gives you good coverage of the news. On Sunday, I just get the News of the World, because I love pictures of B-list celebrities looking awful.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I'm not actually a great newspaper reader. I like the Times, because it gives you good coverage of the news. On Sunday, I just get the News of the World, because I love pictures of B-list celebrities looking awful.

Magazines: Vanity Fair, Marie Claire, Vogue, Q and the Beano. The Beano and a big glass of Vimto are a very important part of my life. I have read the Beano since I was little.

Books: At the moment I'm reading Angela's Ashes, which I'm really enjoying. Some friends have said that it's fake Irishness, but I was brought up by a Catholic so it all rings true. My niece Phoebe, who is seven, keeps talking about Harry Potter, so that's my next read. I have got a childhood favourite, which is The Folk of the Faraway Tree by Enid Blyton. It is a great book for making kids use their imagination, allowing them to be a little bit odd.

Film: I'm really into Almodóvar films, and Jamon Jamon is my favourite of all time. I like low-budget British films, like The War Zone and Secrets and Lies. There's no need to spend masses unless you need big explosions. Pretty Woman is a disgusting film.

Television: I can watch anything from an old black and white movie on a Sunday to Italian football to Corrie. All my friends watch Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? while I'm screaming at people for using up lifelines. I love watching comedy of any kind - League of Gentlemen is fantastic.

Radio: I like to listen to any music station, depending on what mood I'm in.

Ads: Beer ads are really cool, the trendy bottled beers and the Guinness ads. You could join them together and watch them like works of art.

Multimedia: I have just got a new graphite i-Book - it is so beautiful, I just put it out and look at it. My favourite game at the moment is email. I'm mental without my mobile but the internet just bores the pants off me.

 The second series of Smack the Pony begins on Channel 4 on Friday

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: Agony aunts are so angry they may soon need counselling themselves. Friends of Suzie Hayman, who has for seven years seen the readers of Woman's Own through thick and thin, say she has been ditched - in favour of Vanessa Feltz.
fields.body:
Agony aunts are so angry they may soon need counselling themselves. Friends of Suzie Hayman, who has for seven years seen the readers of Woman's Own through thick and thin, say she has been ditched - in favour of Vanessa Feltz.

Hayman trained with Relate and conscientiously answers unpublished letters in her own time. But a big, blonde, brassy celebrity she is not. Claire Rayner, mother of all agony aunts, is outraged at the slight to her profession. "It shows contempt for agony aunts, and above all, for readers. A column is not there for titillation, but as a genuine service," she rages. What's more: "How can they put in someone whose TV show abused people's trust, and think she's suitable for the job? You wouldn't put Feltz in to run financial pages, or as sports editor, so why this one?" But perhaps Feltz's own highly publicised problems - broken marriage, career fightback, battle with her weight and turbulent relationship with her father - might give her an ability to empathise with troubled readers? "It's no substitute for training," snaps Rayner.

Greg Dyke's sketchy reorganisation plans have left parts of the BBC in turmoil. There is disbelief that arch-Birtist Matthew Bannister has been handed director of marketing and communication, over the corporation's marketing supremo, Sue Farr. Farr has now been mentioned in connection with the (still) vacant chief executive post at ITV. Meanwhile, those confirmed in charge of the new divisions have been given until June to come up with plans for hirings, firings and departmental structuring, but no one knows how to get one of the top jobs left unfilled - heading all factual and learning programming. Will the post be advertised? Or will the two new acting heads, Lorraine Heggessey and Michael Stevenson, simply be placed in a padded ring with weapons until a victor emerges?

The organisers of last week's Newspaper 2000 Awards - gongs for newspaper production, renowned for such strange categories such as "best implementation of computer-to-plate technology" - showed their commitment to progressive thinking appropriate to the new millennium by relying on an all-male jury. One decision of this blokeish cabal prompted an outbreak of uncynical and uncontained delight, when Cage & Aviary Birds beat such illustrious titles as the TLS and THES to win the special interest newspaper of the year award. "This is just like being on Have I Got News For You," winked compere Clive Anderson, before wondering whether the editor won a year's supply of millet along with the handsome plaque.

The misery continues at the once-great Scotsman, still haemorrhaging staff apace under Andrew Neil, the Barclay brothers' press supremo. In the last few months, the paper has lost (or sacked) an editor, a deputy editor, an assistant editor (politics), an associate editor (pictures), a news editor, a features editor and a business editor. It has not replaced the home affairs correspondent after the incumbent was promoted, and the environment correspondent and Europe correspondent are also heading for the door as of late last week. The Dundee and Stirling district offices had already been closed. New appointees have either made their names in television or south of the border. "It seems the qualification for a new job at Scotland's national newspaper is to be English or know bugger all about newspapers - preferably both," said our man in a kilt.

 You can contact Maggie Brown at maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Tommy Hilfiger
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about Ali G's favourite designer
fields.trailText: 1. Tommy Hilfiger's stock is on the wane.
fields.body:
1. Tommy Hilfiger's stock is on the wane.

2. The fashion designer who sold hip-hop style to the masses in the 1990s is finding 2000 tougher going.

3. On Friday, Hilfiger's share price plummeted by 30 per cent to a five-year low on the New York stock exchange.

4. Hilfiger recently tried to buy the Calvin Klein label, but failed. Sales of his clothes are also on the decline.

5. In the 1980s, the unknown designer launched an ad campaign declaring him one of the four great American designers for men, alongside Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Perry Ellis.

6. Hilfiger became huge in the designer world after gangsta rapper Snoop Doggy Dogg appeared on Saturday Night Live in March 1994 sporting a red, white, and blue Hilfiger rugby shirt. Followers of the hip-hop culture adopted Hilfiger and, as, the rap industry grew and began to appeal to white as well as black audiences, so did the designer's fortunes.

7. Tommy was rumoured to have told talk show host Oprah Winfrey that if he had known black people would take to his clothes so much he "would not have made them so nice" but the allegation proved to be an email hoax.

8. Today, in class-ridden Britain, Hilfiger's aspirational casuals are fast becoming associated with 13-year-olds in sink estates. And Tommy seems helpless to prevent his clothes becoming the shellsuits of the new millennium. After an ill-advised fashion foray into Highlands chic, Hilfiger's creative consultant, Lloyd Boston, claims Tommy's more familiar colours of red, white and blue, "are back for the first summer of the new millennium".

9. "Guys," he advises, "should turn to the Hawaiian print shirt for summer 2000". Apparently, Tommy thinks the "bold floral prints on bright colorsare sure to attract the ladies."

10. It is the kind of comment which has led Ali G, the man who mercilessly apes the "Wigger" attitude, to endorse Tommy Hilfiger at every turn - a sure sign the designer's cultural credibility is virtually exhausted.

fields.headline: Brontë letter up for sale
fields.trailText: A two-page letter by Charlotte Brontë has surfaced after almost 150 years, telling how her father's frailty confined her to their bleak rectory on the Haworth moors
fields.body:
A two-page letter by Charlotte Brontë has surfaced after almost 150 years, telling how her father's frailty confined her to their bleak rectory on the Haworth moors.

It was written in 1851, four years after publication of Jane Eyre, to John White, who some years before had employed her as governess.

The letter was an apology for not replying to an invitation to visit: "I regret that it is not in my power to leave home at present. My father is now advanced in years and I feel it my duty to leave him as little as possible." She ends: "Give my regards to Mrs White and also to [the children] Jaspar, Robson and Sarah Louisa - though I would hint to that young lady that she seemed pretty well to have forgotten me when I saw her a few years ago..."

The letter was inherited by White's great great granddaughter, Jane Welch, 64, a retired teacher from Caversham, Berkshire. She has put it up for auction at Bonhams in London on May 23, and is estimated to fetch £10,000.

Mrs White is also selling a book entitled Stories in Natural History for Children, which Charlotte Brontë gave to Jasper in 1841 when she was the family governess. Potential bidders for the two items include the Brontë Parsonage Museum, which once paid £50,000 for a letter giving details of the deaths of Charlotte's sister Emily and her brother Branwell.

fields.headline: Myth of Franco takes pounding
fields.standfirst: In a Spain still nervous of coming to terms with its past, a historian claims the country's former dictator was no great military commander
fields.trailText: A book published in Spain to coincide with the 25th anniversary of the death of General Francisco Franco has shattered the myth that the dictator was a great military strategist.
fields.body:
A book published in Spain to coincide with the 25th anniversary of the death of General Francisco Franco has shattered the myth that the dictator was a great military strategist.

In The Military Incompetence of Franco, Carlos Blanco Escola suggests that Franco, who overthrew the Republican government in the 1936-39 civil war, committed several key errors and prolonged the war unnecessarily.

By contrast, Escola - a military historian and army colonel - praises General Vicente Rojo, who became commander-in-chief of the Republican forces. "Franco does not merit a pass mark while Gen Rojo proved himself worthy of the highest rating."

The book delivers a blow to the lingering legend of the generalissimo - who continued to dress in military attire after the war - as the finest of commanders.

The author traces Franco's military career, which began with Spain's colonial war in north Africa. Stories of his cruelty there are legion. He is said to have shot a soldier at point-blank range for refusing to eat his rations because the food was so poor.

Col Blanco accuses Franco of allowing political factors to override military concerns during the civil war. Of the battle for the Ebro river, he said: "General Rojo carried out a brilliant manoeuvre, much studied by the military academies of the former Soviet Union; he crossed the river and established himself on the right bank, achieving in one day what it took Franco four months, and vast amounts of ammunition, to achieve."

The author argues that Franco fell for many of the traps laid for him by Rojo. "Franco was often surprised by the enemy and unsure in his strategic thinking."

His clumsiness was all the more marked, according to Blanco, because his troops were better organised, and more disciplined than the Republicans. He also counted on backing from elite German and Italian units.

Hugh Thomas, a British historian who wrote The Spanish Civil War, has also highlighted Franco's military mistakes.

"His deficiencies were less organisational than errors of judgment," he said. "Time and again.. he insisted on fighting for the few miles that had been lost rather than cut his losses or seek to turn the enemy's flank."

After Franco's death on November 20, 1975, Spaniards decided to leave the past alone rather than reopen the wounds caused by the civil war and the subsequent brutal repression of the vanquished.

Even 25 years on, Spaniards remain reluctant to look at that period, and the marking of the anniversary later this year promises to be muted.

When he died millions of Spaniards filed past his coffin as it lay in state. But each year fewer people have attended ceremonies organised by rightwing groups to mark the anniversary.

The book's publication had aroused expectation. "It will contribute to the necessary demystification of the military image of Franco - an essential task still pending 25 years after his death," wrote Miguel Angel Ajuilar, a commentator for the leftwing daily El Pais, after reading the manuscript last March.

But any discussion of Franco remains so sensitive that it took more than a year for the book to appear.

A Barcelona paper, La Vanguardia, has given most prominent coverage to its publication. Franco's repression of Catalonia's culture, language and tradition are still well remembered there.

"Carlos Blanco Escola has effectively destroyed one of the last remaining myths about Franco; that of his talent as a military strategist," wrote Miguel Angel Trenas.

So far, no voice has been raised in the general's defence.

webTitle: The laddish letters of Kingsley Amis

fields.headline: The laddish letters of Kingsley Amis
fields.standfirst: Correspondence reveals novelist's thoughts on sons, sex, Thatcher and his wife
fields.trailText: "My little son," the novelist Kingsley Amis wrote of his firstborn, "has a face like that of an ageing railway porter who is beginning to realise his untidiness means he'll never get that ticket-collector's job he's been after for 28 years."
fields.body:
"My little son," the novelist Kingsley Amis wrote of his firstborn, "has a face like that of an ageing railway porter who is beginning to realise his untidiness means he'll never get that ticket-collector's job he's been after for 28 years."

That was about his son Philip. About the birth a year later of his son Martin he was at first more benign.

"Less horrifying in appearance," he told his friend Philip Larkin, but with "one of the most protesting faces I ever saw".

These affectionate gibes continued as Martin rose to fame as a writer almost 30 years later. "Did I tell you Martin is spending a year abroad as TAX EXILE?" Amis asked Larkin in May 1979. "Last year he earned £38,000. Little shit. 29, he is. Little shit."

In 1981 he was critical of Martin's narrative technique: "Young Martin's new novel [Other People] is out. Tough going, I find. You see, there's this girl with amnesia... so she's forgotten what a lavatory is and thinks the cistern and pipes are statuary. But then how does she know what statuary is?"

By 1986 it had become political. "Talking of Martin... he has gone all lefty and of the crappiest neutralist kind .... in fact going on like H Pinter does these days, I hear... the worse, far worse, for having come to it late - nearly 37, not 17."

These fatherly barbs, from a man who took care to cultivate his image as the "Old Devil" of English literature in the late 20th century, are disclosed in 700 of his selected letters to be published on May 15 in a 1,200-page book.

The book also includes his reaction to Margaret Thatcher's first election victory in 1979: "Bloody good, eh? Not only that she got in but that those who were pushed out were pushed out... that shouting bully Pardoe [John Pardoe, senior Liberal MP] and that tousle-haired totalitarian Shirley Williams.

"I bet she rued the day she turned up on the Grunwick picket line."

The letters will appear almost simultaneously with Martin Amis's autobiography, Experience: a Memoir, to be serialised exclusively next month in the Guardian.

Martin Amis, now 50, has published nine novels and two collections of short stories. Sir Kingsley Amis, who died aged 73 in 1995, published 23 novels including the classic Lucky Jim. He said: "I would like to be remembered for making people laugh."

Letters that the Mail on Sunday began serialising yesterday are almost all to Larkin, a lifelong friend. Close followers of his work are likely to take some of the harsher views in them with a pinch of salt.

Amis and Larkin were adolescent companions at Oxford, drawn together by a mutually iconoclastic sense of fun, a taste for jazz and alcohol and Amis's gift for mimicry. Both got first-class degrees.

As adults, they met infrequently but kept up the bond with weekly letters, vying to encourage and outdo each other in rightwing politics and with laddish remarks about women in their lives.

Some of their letters are seen as of vintage quality, but another close friend of one of them has used the phrase folie à deux about the way they egged each other on to extreme views. They wrote and spoke differently, often more humanely, to other friends.

While he was still at Oxford in 1946, Amis wrote laddishly to Larkin about his future wife, Hilary Bardsley, then 17 years old. fields.headline: Korea's historic summit
fields.trailText:
Who is meeting whom?
President Kim Dae Jung, of the Republic of Korea, is to fly north to meet President Kim Jong Il, of the People's Democratic Republic of Korea. The meeting is scheduled for June, and will be the first such summit since the peninsula was partitioned by the USA and the Soviet Union in 1945.
fields.body:
Who is meeting whom?
President Kim Dae Jung, of the Republic of Korea, is to fly north to meet President Kim Jong Il, of the People's Democratic Republic of Korea. The meeting is scheduled for June, and will be the first such summit since the peninsula was partitioned by the USA and the Soviet Union in 1945.

Why has it taken so long?
The two parts of Korea went to war with each other in 1950. A truce was agreed in 1953, but they are still working on a peace treaty. Technically, the war continues, and north-south relations have rarely been warmer than frosty.

Is the timing of the latest diplomatic initiative significant?
It will fall half a century, to the month, since North Korean troops crossed the 38th parallel into the south. Also the announcement of the summit is timed rather usefully for Kim Dae Jung, coming as it does just four days before the south holds parliamentary elections. It should boost the chances of the ruling Millennium Democratic party.

What do the two leaders hope to achieve?
According to the southern government, the summit will "promote national reconciliation, unity, exchanges and peaceful unification". The Korean Central News Agency, the tongue-tied mouthpiece of the north, talks only of "a preliminary contact to discuss procedural matters".

What do the two men have in common?
Language. Culture, in the historical sense. Otherwise, nothing. Kim Dae Jung is a veteran dissident, who has frequently been imprisoned and persecuted for pro-democracy campaigning. Kim Jong Il is a rigid authoritarian and Stalinist ideologue, known officially as the Dear Leader. His only qualification for the job is that he is the son of North Korea's founding dictator, Kim Il Sung, aka the Great Leader.

What significance does the summit have for the wider world?
Enormous. North Korea is a pariah state with a shattered, barely functional economy - but it is said to have nuclear weapons technology. The regime in the northern capital, Pyongyang, is desperate to get itself off Washington's list of terrorist-sponsoring nations, and resume normal international trade relations. The US, for its part, would welcome any chance of reducing or even removing its military presence from the south, where it currently has 37,000 troops.

What's in it for the Koreans?
For the north, a glimmer of hope of greater political freedom, and maybe even some economic improvement. Pyongyang has been reduced to pleading for international food aid: its people, struggling with poverty, flooding, and chronic mismanagement, have faced recurring famines. For the booming, prosperous south, reconciliation means stability, and an end to the periodic scares sparked by northern incursions by land and sea. In both parts of Korea, national reunification is a passionately desired long-term goal.

Why does the long-ago war cast such a long shadow?
It was a long, bitter, bloody affair, involving both world superpowers, and devastating most of the peninsula. The Chinese also intervened, and the Americans came close to using nuclear weapons. In the ebb and flow of the conflict, hundreds of thousands of lives were lost. At least 16 member-countries of the United Nations, Britain included, sent contingents of troops to aid of South Korea's corrupt and dictatorial ruler, Synghman Ree.

Why do they call it "the forgotten war"?
Every war is called that, nowadays. In fact, Korea is remembered vividly. Among the dozens of websites devoted to keeping the memory fresh, for example, is an immensely moving one by a Korean witness. Others testify to the bravery of the men who fought - and the pig-headed stupidity of many of their leaders.

Other useful links
Korea Times
Korean Herald
Yahoo! coverage of North Korea
Yahoo! coverage of South Korea

fields.headline: Furious SACB demand 'Cronje Tapes'
fields.trailText: The South African Cricket Board are demanding Indian police hand over the tapes on which the allegations of match-fixing against Hansie Cronje and three of his team-mates are based - so they can subject them to independent voice analysis.
fields.byline: Cricket Unlimited staff and news agencies
fields.body:
The South African Cricket Board are demanding Indian police hand over the tapes on which the allegations of match-fixing against Hansie Cronje and three of his team-mates are based - so they can subject them to independent voice analysis.

Although transcripts of the conversation which allegedly took place between Cronje and London-based bookmaker Sanjay Chawla have been circulated throughout the media, the actual tapes still remain in the possession of the New Delhi crime branch.

Cronje and the SACB have furiously defended their position, even though the Indian police today revealed they have more evidence against the quartet, made up of Cronje and fellow internationals Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom.

However, doubt has been cast as to whether the voice on the tapes is actually that of Cronje, and the SACB say they cannot act until it has been analysed.

"We have requested the tapes but so far this has been refused," said SACB communications manager Bronwyn Wilkinson.

"The matter is being dealt with at government level and we are hoping that a meeting between the South African department of foreign affairs and the Indian High Commission later today will provide us with further information."

Apart from their obvious distress at the accusations which have been levelled over the one-day series between March 9-19, which India won 3-2, the SACB are also livid that Cronje's telephone was tapped.

"You can only imagine what the response would have been if Sachin Tendulkar had received similar treatment in South Africa," said Wilkinson.

"Hansie takes something like 50 telephone calls a day in his hotel room when he is on tour and he has no recollection of any conversation of this nature."

New Delhi Crime Branch chief Pradeep Srivastava said the police were in possession of evidence besides tapes of purported conversations between Cronje, Chawla and his associate Rajesh Kalra, who is currently in police custody.

"The continued association between Chawla and Cronje began long before their contacts in New Delhi," said Srivastava.

"We have more than just the tapes which are now sealed but what we have are not for discussion. Whatever evidence we have will be produced in court in due course."

fields.headline: Virgin territory
fields.standfirst:
When it came to relationships, Maggie O'Farrell thought she had little to learn from her mother and grandmother. Then she sat down to write a novel about love and realised for the first time how the choices of one generation resonate in the next

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: When it came to relationships, Maggie O'Farrell thought she had little to learn from her mother and grandmother. Then she sat down to write a novel about love and realised for the first time how the choices of one generation resonate in the next
fields.body:
Three years ago, I'd have been the last person to claim that there was any connection between my love life and that of my mother. When it came to sex, I would have put us at complete polar opposites. She was a virgin until her wedding night which, to me, is an insane, preposterous idea. To enter into a lifelong legal and emotion bond with someone you've never slept with... I mean you try on shoes before you buy them.

My own experiences are different. I've had long-term, live-in relationships with two men and, like most other women in their late 20s, slept with others. Virginity is something I dimly remember from my teens. And marriage? Marriage doesn't even occur to me as an option; it's something women used to have to do, like wear corsets and learn embroidery.

To her credit, my mother isn't as disapproving about my life as I am about hers. Whatever she may think, she's always been there at the end of the phone whenever I've been heartbroken, elated, disappointed, bored, moving in, moving out.

But if you think the disparity between the sexual politics of my era and that of my mother's is a symptom of late-20th-century emancipation, you'd be far wrong. In her early 20s, my grandmother received two marriage proposals, by letter, from two trainee Methodist ministers. She hadn't so much as kissed either of them. Unsure about which to accept, she went to her mother, who in turn went to visit the head of the training college. This man gave the matter his consideration, then suggested the man who became my grandfather. This is as alien and arcane to my mother as the concept of virgin brides is to me.

When, three years ago, I set out to write a novel, I had a clear idea in my head. I wanted to write about love. I wanted to create a precise account of exactly how it feels to fall in love with someone and lose them. I had it all planned, but when I came to setting fingers to keyboard, a strange thing happened. I found I was unable to write about my heroine's love life until I had gone into those of her mother and her grandmother. I discovered that it was impossible to explain her without discourse to her mother. This was where the germ of my novel lay. How the actions of one generation can reverberate in the next, and how a woman's life is affected by her mother's choices in love were ideas I came to recognise as the ones I wanted to follow. It meant that I had to admit to myself that, as removed from me as my mother's life may seem, it had had more effect on me than I had been prepared to acknowledge - and not only in producing a rebellious reaction against what she'd taught me.

Once I'd recognised this correlation, I became fascinated, obsessed: I sought out books to read, I quizzed my friends for information, I eavesdropped shamelessly on conversations at cafe tables, I demanded secrets and details from near strangers. What I found out was that no woman is exempt from the influence her mother's choices can exert.

It was about this time that I found myself in the doorway of my then boyfriend's study, opening my mouth to demand, "Do you have to work all the time?", when a strange feeling of displaced déjà-vu crept over me. I could hear the words in my mother's voice. I took a mental snapshot of myself and saw a familiar stance: hands on hips, head on one side. I suddenly saw that no matter how much I'd gone out of my way to choose a man that went against my upbringing, here I was, in a situation from which I'd begun.

My mother and I are more similar than I have ever thought. We both have easily ignited and just as easily appeased tempers. And we both like a laugh. But it's not just parts of her personality that I am programmed with. What your mother teaches you about relationships and love is your first exposure to the concept, and anything she says or tells you will irrevocably shape your views. If my mother brought up my sisters and I with any kind of maxim it was, "never, ever hurt anyone's feelings". Although this hasn't always stood me in good stead in today's more cut-throat sexual climate, to this day I am paralysed with guilty horror if I think I have upset someone I love.

How much or how little your mother is prepared to disclose depends on how old you are. The biggest realignment in the mother-daughter relationship, it seems to me, occurs when the daughter reaches her late 20s. The mother's done the difficult bit, while the daughter has established her own life.

I am getting to an age I can remember my mother at, which, I've discovered, is an unsettling milestone. What I'm seeing happening around me to friends and colleagues of a similar age is mothers who are coming out with the truth about themselves. The mother maybe thinks her daughter is old enough, or maybe she's just asking, quite justifiably, for a return on 30 years of parenting. And, for many, the past that is uncovered isn't as innocent as they had assumed.

I had lunch with someone recently who arrived white-faced and stunned. After being plied with wine, she admitted she'd been moaning to her mother about how she was feeling jaded with the man she's been with for five years. Her mother, rather briskly and uncharacteristically, advised her to "go off and have an affair", relating how, 10 years into her marriage, she'd slept with a colleague several times. "I couldn't believe it," my friend said. "She said it made her realise how much she loved my father. The worst of it is my father never knew. Still doesn't know. How can I ever look him in the eye again?"

Someone else was cooking dinner when her mother, recently reunited with her former husband after a second marriage apiece and a gap of 15 years, shyly asked her how you should go about... you know... giving a blowjob. What did you say? I asked, aghast. My friend shrugged and smiled: "I showed her, of course. She taught me to read and write, after all. It's a fair trade." You showed her? "Yeah. We used a courgette." She glanced at me: "We peeled it first."

 Maggie O'Farrell's novel, After You'd Gone, is published by Headline Review, £12.99

webTitle: Five Turks charged with Leeds murders

fields.headline: Five Turks charged with Leeds murders
fields.standfirst: Full background
fields.trailText: Five Turkish youths have been charged with the murder of two Leeds United fans during last week's football violence in Istanbul, the Foreign Office confirmed tonight.
fields.body:
Five Turkish youths have been charged with the murder of two Leeds United fans during last week's football violence in Istanbul, the Foreign Office confirmed tonight.

Information from the British Consul General in the city, where Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight died the night before last week's Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds and local side Galatasaray, indicated the five would face trial in about 10 days' time.

"We have had confirmed that five are going to be facing trial and a further three have been released," said a Foreign Office spokeswoman. The names of the charged men were not available, she added.

webTitle: Zimbabwe farmers in new legal moves to halt land grabs

fields.headline: Zimbabwe farmers in new legal moves to halt land grabs
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's besieged farmers are braced for more invasions, as a union goes to court today for the second time to try to force war veterans off more than 800 farms they have occupied.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's besieged farmers are braced for more invasions, as a union goes to court today for the second time to try to force war veterans off more than 800 farms they have occupied.

The Commercial Farmers Union, which represents Zimbabwe's 4,500 commercial farms, has already obtained a court order banning squatters from the farms. But the legal ruling failed to move the veterans, and police said they did not have the resources to enforce it.

Local farm representatives expect the court will issue a new restraining order on the veterans, but have little hope that it will prove more effective than the first.

The invasions are widely seen as an attempt by President Robert Mugabe to garner popular support for his ruling Zanu-PF party before elections due next month.

"We are expecting massive invasions this week. They are moving in force," a farmer in central Mashonaland said. Several farmers around Harare are reported to have packed their bags and moved to the city for safety, while others have signed over large tracts of their land in fear of their lives.

New skirmishes have been reported on communal land north of Harare between veterans and farm workers who fear they could lose their jobs if farms are redistributed.

Topper Whitehead, a supporter of the fledgling opposition group the Movement for Democratic Change, said: "The president has pressed the country's self-destruct button for personal gain."

Meanwhile Britain is seeking European Union support for pressure on Zimbabwe to end the occupations and to permit EU monitoring of elections due in May.

"We are looking for a strong declaration that there must be a return to the rule of law and an end to the illegal occupation of the farms," foreign secretary Robin Cook said.

webTitle: Government looks desperately for way out from Shayler affair

fields.headline: Government looks desperately for way out from Shayler affair
fields.standfirst: David Shayler site
fields.trailText: The government is desperately looking for a way out of the David Shayler affair, with a growing number of Labour MPs warning ministers of the dangers of a re-run of the Spycatcher fiasco when attempts by the Thatcher administration to prevent journalists disclosing information about MI5 collapsed after an expensive and futile court battle.
fields.body:
The government is desperately looking for a way out of the David Shayler affair, with a growing number of Labour MPs warning ministers of the dangers of a re-run of the Spycatcher fiasco when attempts by the Thatcher administration to prevent journalists disclosing information about MI5 collapsed after an expensive and futile court battle.

Court injunctions have failed to prevent a stream of embarrassing allegations from Mr Shayler, the former MI5 officer living in Paris, notably about MI6 involvement in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.

The security and intelligence agencies have been unable to suppress information on the internet, including a MI6 report on the Gadafy plot and the names of MI6 and MI5 officers.

The Metropolitan police special branch is now being blamed for raising the ante by threatening the Guardian and the Observer with prosecution under the Official Secrets Act for publishing information from Mr Shayler. Robin Cook, foreign secretary, and Peter Hain, Foreign Office minister, have let it be known they were horrified by the action.

With both newspapers challenging the decision by Martin Stephens, an Old Bailey judge, to order them to hand over any emails or notes they may have relating to Mr Shayler, Jack Straw and MI5 are distancing themselves from the police action. The newspaper have made it clear they are ready to take the case to the European court of human rights.

MPs are also uneasy about the arrest of Julie Ann Davies, a student at Kingston University, in south west London, in connection with the Shayler affair.

The government's attempt to extradite Mr Shayler was dismissed by a French court two years ago on the grounds that its motive was political.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group, Liberty, and Mr Shayler's lawyer, has sought private meetings with ministers and the attorney-general, Lord Williams, but has so far been rebuffed.

MI5, meanwhile, is bracing itself for sharp criticism by the parliamentary intelligence and security committee for "usurping" the role of the government's law officers by deciding not to prosecute Melita Norwood, who was unmasked as a former KGB contact.

fields.headline: North-south divide gapes ever wider
fields.standfirst: As a new report shows increasing disparities in regional wealth, Guardian analysis editor David Walker calls for an energetic revival of subsidies
fields.trailText: As a new report shows increasing disparities in regional wealth, Guardian analysis editor David Walker calls for an energetic revival of subsidies.
fields.body:
It's Kilfoyle's revenge. Since the Liverpool MP resigned in January a succession of reports and surveys have confirmed that there are hard, enduring and structural differences in the prosperity of the English regions, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. The Cardiff report on competitiveness, released today, is the latest. What distinguishes it - and probably makes it all the more dismaying to read in Manchester, Swansea or Gateshead - is its future orientation. The northern regions, Wales and Northern Ireland are losing out in precisely those technologies and areas of knowledge from which the jobs and incomes of the 21st century are to come.

Peter Kilfoyle accused the Blair government of neglecting its "heartlands" - the parts of the United Kingdom from which it draws its traditional support. Blair's response was that within every region there are successful towns. He is right but it is a politically weak answer. The poverty and lack of opportunity on Merseyside and Tyneside are too physically apparent to be wished away by reference to growth in Chester or Newcastle's undoubtedly successful revival as a tourist destination.

What Kilfoyle has managed to do is put "regional policy" back on the map. He has revived an issue that had been consistently downgraded during the Tory era, on which Labour too had been none too keen when it took office. Whitehall is now hurriedly listing all the ways in which regional assistance is provided and Blair has become a convert to the possibility of transforming John Prescott's regional development agencies into embryonic democratic assemblies, allowing the regions to assert themselves.

Yet the Cardiff report is a chilling reminder of the size of the gap between north and south. Central intervention on a huge scale is going to be needed to boost productivity and introduce the new communications technology into the economic bases of Wales, Yorkshire, Humberside and the northeast. The report also shows that the government is going to have to swim against the economic tide which is washing so luxuriously around London's towers.

But there are ways in which the government can channel investment: if it invests in skills and infrastructure even the most southern-oriented company directors can be persuaded to relocate or set up a new shop in the north.

First, however, the government is going to have to concede the truth of the Kilfoyle critique. Labour's heartlands are suffering and only the most energetic revival of regional subsidy is going to help.

webTitle: Bad week gets worse for Barca

fields.headline: Bad week gets worse for Barca
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle reports on the latest developments in Europe's top leagues
fields.trailText: SPAIN
fields.body:
SPAIN

After starting the week as favourites for the Primera Liga and the Champions League, Barcelona are in danger of winning neither. They followed Wednesday night's 3-1 defeat at Chelsea, with a humiliating 3-0 home loss against mid-table Real Mallorca - and are now five points behind leaders Deportivo La Coruña.

Barcelona started lethargically, and Cameroonian striker Samuel Eto'o took full advantage, opening the scoring for Mallorca in the 14th minute. In the second half Louis Van Gaal replaced Rivaldo and Patrick Kluivert, but Barça's brittle defence once again crumbled. Eto'o made it 2-0 in the 73rd minute, outpacing the defence before firing it past Ruud Hesp, and just a minute later Luis Carreras made it 3-0.

Leaders Deportivo increased their lead at the top with a convincing 4-1 win at home to Athletico Madrid. Turu Flores started the rout, poking the ball past Molina after 19 minutes, and before the break Dutchman Roy Makaay grabbed a second. Athletico pulled one back when Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink scored his 23rd goal of the season, but two late goals from Makaay put the game beyond reach.

Deportivo can now afford to lose one of their last six matches and still come away with their first title - but they will not be celebrating yet. The northern side have a reputation for being chokers, after twice surrendering the title when leading at the start of the last day of the season in the 1990s.

Valencia continued their recent goal-scoring spree with a 6-2 thrashing of Oviedo, with Argentinian Claudio Lopez grabbing the first two goals. Real Madrid moved into fourth place - eight points behind Deportivo - with a 1-0 home win.

Leading standings: Deportivo p32 pts 61; Barcelona, p32 pts 56; Real Zaragoza p32 pts 55; Real Madrid p32, pts 53; Alaves p32 pts 51.

ITALY

Juventus seemed on the brink of dropping another two points in the race for the Scudetto - but two late goals snatched a much-needed 2-0 win away at Bologna.

Former Sheffield Wednesday striker Darko Kovacevic broke the deadline in the 89th minute, and Massimo Paganin's injury time own-goal sealed the points for Juve.

Lazio kept up the pressure with a 1-0 win at Perugia after a goal from Attilio Lombardo. They remain three points behind, but have the much easier run in - with Juventus facing tough games away to Inter and Parma.

Parma's run of five straight victories came to a halt as they could only draw 2-2 against Torino at the Stadio Delle Alpi. Torino took a surprise lead through Vicenzo Sommesse, but second half goals from Hernan Crespo and Amoroso looked to have brought Parma all three points. But former Forrest flop Andrea Silenzi levelled the match fifteen minutes before time.

Elsewhere Udinese kept up their chances of a Uefa cup place with a 3-0 thrashing of increasingly erratic Inter. Roberto Carlos Sosa, who has struggled to find his form this season, put them ahead after two minutes and added a second just before the break.

AC Milan remain in third place after a 1-1 draw against Fiorentina in the San Siro. Angelo di Livio gave the visitors the lead after 70 minutes, following good work from Predag Mijatovic, but Milan equalised five minutes later with Leonardo's sublime lob. Visiting keeper Francesco Toldo ensured his side would not go home empty handed when he made an amazing save from Alessandro Costacurto in injury time.

Leading standings: Juventus P29 pts 62; Lazio P29 pts 59; Milan P29 pts 50; Parma p29 pts 50; Inter P29 pts 49.

GERMANY

Bayer Leverkusen stay two points clear at the top of the Bundesliga - despite conceding a goal after just 100 seconds at home to struggling Borussia Dortmund.

Billy Reyna put the visitors ahead, silencing the capacity 22,500 crowd at the BayArena. But Brazilian-born player Paulo Rink netted twice to put Leverkusen in front before Thomas Brdaric wrapped the game up with a third in injury time. After a brilliant performance, Rink, who holds a German passport, hopes to get his cap by Germany's team manager Erich Ribbeck.

Bayern Munich kept up the pressure with an easy 4-0 win over struggling SSV Ulm, with goals from Scholl, Sergio, Jancker and Wojchiechowski.

And afterwards they sounded confident they would win the title. Keeper Oliver Kahn claimed: "Let us have six more matches and after that we will end up on top of the table again." His sentiments were echoed by captain Stefan Effenberg, who said: "The day will come for Leverkusen not to win and then we will be there.

Bayer boss Christoph Daum sounded less convincing in response. "I really wish Bayern well in Europe. I hope they give Germany victory in the Champions League. As for the title, they should be kind enough to leave it to us," he said. "They've been there before. Even their cleaning lady has won 10 titles already."

Hamburg stay third after their 1-0 win over Hansa Rostock, but remain six points behind Bayer.

Leading standings: Bayer Leverkusen P28 pts 60, Bayern Munich P28 pts 58; Hamburg P28, pts 54; Werder Bremen P28, pts 43; Kaiserslautern P28 pts 43.

fields.headline: A Balkan precedent
fields.standfirst: The case for an international court growsWar crimes in the former Yugoslavia: special report
fields.trailText: Slowly but surely, the men principally responsible for mass murder, terror, and ethnic cleansing in the Balkans during the early and mid-1990s are being brought to justice. Momcilo Krajisnik, a Bosnian Serb leader allegedly involved in planning some of the worst atrocities visited upon Bosnia's Muslims, last week became the biggest scalp to be claimed so far. Mr Krajisnik was seized during an early morning raid on his home in Pale, the once impregnable Bosnian Serb stronghold, by the Nato-led stabilisation force. Within hours he was on his way to the Hague to join 38 others who are currently in detention or on trial.
fields.body:
Slowly but surely, the men principally responsible for mass murder, terror, and ethnic cleansing in the Balkans during the early and mid-1990s are being brought to justice. Momcilo Krajisnik, a Bosnian Serb leader allegedly involved in planning some of the worst atrocities visited upon Bosnia's Muslims, last week became the biggest scalp to be claimed so far. Mr Krajisnik was seized during an early morning raid on his home in Pale, the once impregnable Bosnian Serb stronghold, by the Nato-led stabilisation force. Within hours he was on his way to the Hague to join 38 others who are currently in detention or on trial.

Mr Krajisnik's capture was a signal triumph for the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. Since its creation by the UN in 1993, the ICTY has publicly indicted 94 individuals of all ethnic backgrounds, accusing them of responsibility for war crimes or other serious violations of international law. Additional warrants have been issued under seal. Only 28 of the named indictees remain at large. They include the "big three" - the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, and the former Bosnian Serb leaders Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic. These last two have fled to Serbia. But Mr Krajisnik's detention should help to convince them all that the ICTY is not giving up the chase. They must know by now that for them there is, ultimately, no hiding place. The chief prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, had further cause to celebrate last week after she secured the full cooperation of Croatia's new president in her quest for justice.

The ICTY's success underlines the desirability of a permanent UN International Criminal Court, as already envisaged by a treaty approved by Britain and 119 other countries in Rome in 1998. Whereas the ICTY only has jurisdiction in former Yugoslavia, the ICC could, in theory, prosecute serious breaches of international law wherever they occur - in Chechnya, for example, or Sudan, East Timor or Iraq. The government described the ICC as "a major advance in international justice" at the time of last November's Queen's Speech, a position which places it at odds with the US and a few others. Washington believes the ICC will infringe its national sovereignty and inhibit the actions of its armed forces overseas. Some might consider that a welcome outcome. Britain should lead the way by ratifying the Rome treaty without further delay.

fields.headline: Bernie Grant
fields.standfirst: Passionate leftwing MP and tireless anti-racism campaigner
fields.trailText: Passionate leftwing MP and tireless anti-racism campaigner.
fields.body:
Bernie Grant, the Guyanese Labour MP for Tottenham since 1987, who has died of a heart attack aged 56, was a red rag to the bulls of rightwing politics. A black man with a leftwing trade union background, he was also an anti-apartheid campaigner, a supporter of revolutionary governments, feminist causes, black studies and a multi-racial school curriculum.

He became the figurehead and tireless activist in cases of official harassment or misconduct, notably the Joy Gardner case, where a black woman died after immigration officers entered her house and put her under restraint. And In 1985 when a riot exploded on Tottenham's Broadwater Farm estate and a policeman, Keith Blakelock, was murdered, Bernie commented that the youths on the estate felt that the police had received "a bloody good hiding." The remark made him a notorious hate figure in the pages of the tabloids.

Bernie Grant was born in 1944 in Georgetown, Guyana, His parents, Eric and Lily were schoolteachers, and he attended St Stanislaus College, a Jesuit-run secondary school. The family arrived in England in 1963, and he attended Tottenham technical college, before doing a degree course in mining engineering at Heriot Watt University in Edinburgh.

We met in 1970 while working for the Post Office at the International Telephone Exchange, in King's Cross. His radical engagement in student politics had already made him well known throughout the network of black students. It turned out that we'd both lived within a hundred yards of each other in Georgetown. He had a confident, humorous manner which made him instantly likable. We didn't discuss politics and spent most of our time larking around, practising our French and Spanish by trying to chat up the continental operators, or reminiscing about Guyana.

He talked from time to time about going back to Heriot Watt or somewhere else and resuming his studies, but when the Post Office strike of that year began, and Bernie became one of the chief organisers in our branch, it was obvious that he was happy and excited by the challenge of trade union politics and organisation.

Bernie stayed on as the exchange representative for the telephonists, attended union conferences, pursued a number of trade union courses, and wound up as chair of the branch.

With a typical mixture of passionate commitment and shrewdness, Bernie had recognised one of the few industrial areas where the colour of his skin would not be a disability. At the beginning of the 70s, Powellism was still a force in workplace attitudes, but the Post Office was more or less a multiracial enclave where there were black supervisors and union officials. During that period his politics took on a sharper edge, and he began to forge long-term alliances on the radical and anti-racist left.

He then became a full-time official for the National Union of Public Employees. Haringey, where he had lived and been a student, was an almost inevitable port of call. The borough's growing ethnic population was confronted by hardline racist organisations. He became a local councillor and then leader of the council.

His election coincided with a period of intense conflict between the Conservative government and a variety of municipal authorities. The tabloid press, dubbed him Barmy Bernie, and Haringey council was the subject of an endless stream of negative stories.

His notoriety and support for controversial projects such as the campaign for black sections in the Labour party, made the Labour establishment nervous and distant, and his survival as a political figure was due mainly to the respect and affection that large segments of the local electorate felt for him. In 1987 he won the Tottenham Parliamentary seat, ousting Norman Atkinson, who had been the MP for 20 years.

He entered Parliament dressed in African robes, and his career entered a new more internationally-oriented phase. His sympathies were pro-Arab and he made several visits to Colonel Gadafy in Libya. At the same time he became an important resource for developing world governments. When the volcano erupted in Monserrat a row broke out about British aid and policy towards the refugees. Typically the Monserratian chief minister immediately telephoned Bernie Grant and invited him to plead the island's case.

Bernie caused some embarrassment by arriving on the island before the government's own fact-finding mission, but he was never reluctant to break ranks, frequently going against some of the most deeply held beliefs of his leftwing allies. For instance, he defended Harriet Harman's decision to send her children to a selective school, arguing that his own children had suffered from their education in the public sector. However, during the last 10 years his chronic diabetes had begun to disable him, which in turn gave him relatively little time to attend the House of Commons.

Even those who characterised him as rash and hasty acknowledged that he was likeable, charming, generous to friends and enemies, and relentlessly honest. Those closest to him understood that he had never accepted the dogmatic positions of faction and party. He had a passionate devotion to an ideal of justice, and he believed that politics was about these notions.

He is survived by his three children from his first marriage and by his wife and devoted assistant, Sharon.

webTitle: Seizing power is easy. Knowing how to use it isn't

fields.headline: Seizing power is easy. Knowing how to use it isn't
fields.standfirst: Pakistan's coup master is forever in no-man's-landPakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: Statistics are daunting. Pakistan has had only four elected prime ministers through its 53 years of independence. One was assassinated, one hanged for conspiracy to murder; one lives in exile avoiding corruption charges - and one is a convicted terrorist beginning a life sentence. A record to make the Borgias blush.
fields.body:
Statistics are daunting. Pakistan has had only four elected prime ministers through its 53 years of independence. One was assassinated, one hanged for conspiracy to murder; one lives in exile avoiding corruption charges - and one is a convicted terrorist beginning a life sentence. A record to make the Borgias blush.

And yet, of course, that is not quite the whole of the story - for the infamous four come interleaved with long periods of military dictatorship and chaps in braid promising elections of a kind; but not just yet. It is a pretty dismal record for a nation of 150m souls which boasts world class poets, pilots, engineers, doctors - and nuclear scientists. They ought to be able to do better than this. The question now is whether the moment to do better has finally arrived.

Pakistan is world-class, too, in the arts of spin; full of honours graduates from the Alistair Campbell Academy. Thus the sentencing of Nawaz Sharif, the latest in the line of disgraced premiers, is spun as no great shakes. Do ordinary people take to the streets to protest his fate?

On the contrary, as I wandered through the alleyways of Lahore's Anarkali bazaar on sentencing day, the bustle of humanity was utterly normal. Nobody seemed to care that this once supreme son of the Punjab might spend the rest of his natural behind bars. From there, it is only the smallest propaganda stride to seeming enthusiasm for General Pervez Musharraf and his coup. The army, yet again, has "rescued" Pakistan.

It's a lovely smooth song. But it is also tremendous tosh. Of course the streets aren't alive with a roar of dissent. Why should they be? Nawaz Sharif fought and lost his ultimate battle for power far away from them. This is the dreadful routine as usual. The elected ones depart, the generals take over - and the people have seen it all before. They keep their heads down and just get on with earning a living. They have no faith and precious little interest in a system they can neither influence nor change. But don't confuse indifference with approval - or resignation with enthusiasm.

This time round, though, there is a difference. Something, it is slowly dawning, has changed. Nawaz Sharif will not hang, as Bhutto was hanged by the general he trusted. He will live because a judge - juggling some thinnish evidence and hearing whispers, perhaps, from behind the arras - says that he must. But is the essential judge in this supreme court Mr Justice Clinton?

Let's be brutal about a brutal equation. While Sharif survives, Musharraf can never sleep easy. There can be no easy transitions to real democracy - because real democracy would surely put the latest "chief executive" at risk for his own survival. These gents may drive big Mercedes and wear the smartest of suits: but the essence of the struggle is pure ancient Rome. Et tu Brute?

On this thesis, the merest hint of mercy is weakness and the right of Sharif to live is the beginning of the end for an unimposingly hesitant Gen Musharraf. The former prime minister may, of course, always suffer some fatal mishap in prison. The game is by no means over. But, failing such desperations, consider the wider logic. Whatever he tells a visiting Clinton, the chief executive can never blithely relinquish his grip. The failure to dispose of Sharif, as expected, has already enfeebled him. It signals that he may not be around for too long.

Pakistan, like other pawns in the cold war, is only now beginning to sense how the contexts have been transformed. General Zia could hang Bhutto and reckon that America would keep him safe for Afghan service rendered. Pakistan could cuddle up to Washington as Delhi flirted with Moscow. But none of that works any longer. The only superpower left turns out to be rather keen on democracy (except in spots like China, too touchy to squeeze). It certainly isn't going to spoil that pitch by embracing another Islamabad military coup master.

Where does that leave Musharraf? In no-man's-land. His basic quarrel with Sharif in 1999 was over Kashmir (should the army withdraw, at American prompting, from some captured Indian positions?). He has, unsurprisingly, set a Kashmir settlement at the heart of his foreign policy. The Indians endure so much bloody trouble in the vale. Surely - in the wake of Kosovo and East Timor - the fabled international community will bring them to the negotiating table at last?

A fundamental miscalculation. Who on earth, outside the Pakistan general staff, thinks that Clinton, Blair and the rest will intervene to assist the transference of Kashmir from Indian democracy to Pakistani military dictatorship? The proposition is absurd. Musharraf's perch at the top denies him the prize he seeks most fervently. His continuing presence automatically increases India's influence. These are the policies of the cul-de-sac. The chief executive shuttles round the Islamic world trying to win friends and woo people, but even autocrat democrats like Malaysia's Dr Mahathir see no point in encouraging him. Why hang your hat on such a passing peg?

We may, in sum, have reached a crucial phase in sub-continental history. On the surface, this is governmental shuttlecocking as usual. The braids move in. The venal politicians retreat. But seizing power is easy in a country in thrall to the army anyway. Plotting a coup is a piece of cake. It is knowing what to do with the power, once seized, that is more difficult.

I should be clear where I stand. I think, 35 years after I first set foot here and fell a little in love with its wonders, that Pakistan is a terrific country of immense potential. The people are - universally - kind and welcoming. The streets are safe; the motorways and ring roads of Lahore - one Sharif legacy - put London to shame. The hunger for education is ravenous.

This is the third world knocking at the door of the first - then, without answer, slinking away again because it can find no ruling stability in freedom to match its dreams. Does it matter that Sharif was a seedy chancer as well as a technocratic visionary? Perhaps in practice - but never in principle. Democracy depends on weathering the lows and well as scaling the heights. Democracy is the stuff for all seasons.

General Musharraf, waking up to his bleak inheritance, may be realising that now: and his international critics, from the White House to the commonwealth secretariat, have a duty to keep spelling it out to him. This time, the traditional army assumptions are caught by a painful new logic. Next time, the elected Pakistani prime minister needs to look forward to a happy old age.

webTitle: Bafta award choices scorn the Oscar line

fields.headline: Bafta award choices scorn the Oscar line
fields.trailText: The Americans may do it better, but for the second year in a row the Baftas proved that the Brits think they know better. Last year they resisted the steamroller of hype behind Shakespeare in Love in favour of The Truman Show, and this year they honoured many films ignored by the Oscars.
fields.body:
The Americans may do it better, but for the second year in a row the Baftas proved that the Brits think they know better. Last year they resisted the steamroller of hype behind Shakespeare in Love in favour of The Truman Show, and this year they honoured many films ignored by the Oscars.

Although Sam Mendes' American Beauty went one better than its Oscar tally of five - including the Bafta for best film - best director went to the flamboyant Spaniard Pedro Almodovar for All About My Mother, a tragi-comedy in which a nun gets Aids from a transsexual prostitute.

Being John Malkovich - possibly the most surreal, and possibly the only, adult puppet comedy ever to become a Hollywood hit - won best screenplay, and Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow, made in Britain, won Baftas to make up for lost Oscar glory.

Maggie Smith was a surprise winner of best supporting actress for Tea With Mussolini, a film which has not been overburdened with praise.

Annette Bening, who many had expected to win the best actress Oscar for her part as a manically self-improving suburban wife in American Beauty, finally got her due with a Bafta best actress.

Jude Law, who had been similarly disappointed in Los Angeles, won best supporting actor for playing a wastrel heir in Anthony Minghella's The Talented Mr Ripley. Overall though, it was a bad night for Minghella, who many had thought was due for at least a few consolation awards after his film was snubbed by the Oscars.

There was even less to cheer for another much-tipped British film, The End of the Affair, which despite 10 nominations left with only one Bafta, for its screenwriter Neil Jordan. Mike Leigh might have had more to smile about too, but Topsy-Turvy, which took two Oscars, won only one Bafta: best make-up for Christine Blundell, one of the behind-the-screen heroines of the British industry.

But there was joy for East is East, the rip-roaring low-budget comedy set in a Salford fish and chip shop which last month became the most successful fully-funded British film ever. It won, with touching historical symmetry, the Alexander Korda award for the outstanding British film.

The film's producer, Leslee Udwin, said that when the father of the film's writer - Ayub Khan Din - came to Britain from Pakistan in the 1950s he worked for a short time as a film extra on one of Korda's films, where he got his first taste of racism. "When he went to have some lunch, the other extras with him would not eat with him. So Korda came over himself and ate with him." East Is East features a character called George who is based on Khan Din's father.

Michael Caine won a Bafta fellowship for his special contribution to British film. Another fellowship was awarded posthumously to American director Stanley Kubrick, maker of 2001: A Space Odyssey and A Clockwork Orange, who only emerged from his Hertfordshire estate to make films.
