fields.headline: Child's play
fields.standfirst: Missiles for the under-fives, speed-learning, a non-revival and feathered fiends
fields.trailText: Missiles for the under-fives, speed-learning, a non-revival and feathered fiends
fields.body:
Nursery nukes

These are not good times for Britain's intelligence community. First an M15 operative inadvertently mislays his laptop computer. Then an Ml6 agent gets drunk and does exactly the same. Now a top-secret Ministry of Defence CD-rom has ended up in the art department of a Warwickshire nursery school. It was one of a bundle of CDs donated to Chipping Warden primary school by a parent who works at the nearby Army school of ammunition. All the other discs had been wiped clean. But one, snappily titled UK Restricted Ammunition and Explosives Regulations, was picked up by three-year-old Helen Fitchett, who incorporated it into a toy clock she was making. When she took the clock home, her father became suspicious. Dismantling his daughter's creation, ran the CD-rom on his computer, where he discovered classified information about rockets, surface-to-air guided missile systems and chemical weapons.
The offending object has since been returned to the MoD, and the experience seems to have had no adverse effect on young Helen. "She's as bouncy and imaginative as ever," said one insider. "Yesterday she made a lovely low-density neutrino cluster bomb out of a toilet roll and some gerbil bedding. It really was very realistic."
Daventry Express

She's learning fast

Hypocrisy or research? That's the question hanging over the recent activities of psychologist Lisa Dorn, who has spent 15 years researching what makes motorists drive too fast and was this week had up for - you guessed it - speeding. Years of analysis by Ms Dorn, who lectures at De Montfort University in Leicester, have convinced her that stress and a tendency to ignore road signs cause drivers to break the speed limit.
This revolutionary theory was borne out by her own experiences. "I was in a hurry, slightly stressed, and didn't realise what the speed limit was along that road," she explained. "I didn't realise I'd done anything wrong till the ticket arrived out of the blue in the post. It was a bit of a shock." Although she was only doing 1mph over the limit - 41mph in a 40mph zone - she is now liable for a £40 fine. She had been on her way to present a class on road crime when she committed the offence. "In a way I envy her the chance to experience first-hand the subject she's researching," said one colleague. "I'm currently writing a book on sex orgies, but have never managed to get beyond the theoretical stage."
Milton Keynes Citizen

Rave from the grave

One of the least successful tribute concerts of recent years took place this week at the 1,216-seat Her Majesty's theatre in London, where an evening in memory of the Welsh singing legend Dorothy Squires attracted just 176 people. And half of them left during the interval. Squires was the Britney Spears of her day. A native of Llanelli, and a former wife of the actor Roger Moore, she was a household name in the 40s and 50s, with songs such as Red the Rose and Where Can I Go.
Sadly, her popularity has waned, and the concert to mark what would have been her 85th birthday was a flop, despite advance publicity claiming Barbara Windsor, Tom Jones and Shirley Bassey would all be attending (they didn't). The show only featured one performer: a 20-stone Yorkshire pianist named Mike Terry, who spent three hours impersonating his diminutive seven-stone heroine.
"He neither looks or sounds even remotely like Ms Squires," fumed theatre critic Patrick Newley. "The only word that comes to mind to describe his performance is 'grotesque'." Undeterred, Mr Terry, who also organised the event, is taking his show on tour. He can at least take comfort from the comments of one 97-year-old audience member. "It was so good to see her again," enthused the woman. "She's put on a bit of weight, but deep down it was the same old Dorothy. And there's me thinking she was dead."
South Wales Evening Post

Watch the birdie

Kashmir, Chechnya, Kosovo, the Congo - some of the most perilous places on earth. And now, it seems, a new name must be added to the list: Kirkaldy. While it's humans that are causing the problems in the world's other hotspots, in Kirkaldy the danger comes from a different source: birds. Residents and businesses in the Fife town are being terrorised by flocks of delinquent pigeons and seagulls.
"It's like something out of an Alfred Hitchcock movie," said one man. "They're everywhere. Each morning I come out and it looks like someone's poured paint all over my car. The whole town is covered in crap." And it's not just the droppings that are causing concern. There have been numerous reports of birds attacking people. "They get very aggressive when they're nesting," explained one local ornithologist. "If you get too close they'll go for you."
Local authorities are considering a variety of schemes to get rid of the feathered fiends, including bringing in a professional hawker to scare the birds away, although to date no definite action has been taken. "They say it's good luck if a bird dropping lands on you," commented one woman. "On which basis I ought to be winning the Lottery at least 20 times a week."
Fife Free Press

Letter of the week

"MP Eric Illsley is quoted in the Chronicle as saying that a lot of his constituents have written to him complaining that Britain is spending too much on refugees.
He ought to be telling them that a total of 0.33% of income tax, or a third of a penny in every pound collected from income tax, is spent by the British government on refugees.
He ought to be telling his constituents that the reason new Labour cannot properly fund the NHS or education is because it will not increase taxation on the rich, and has nothing to do with refugees.
He ought to be telling them that Britain takes fewer refugees per head of the population than Germany, Switzerland, Holland, Finland, Belgium, Norway, Sweden, Irelland and Denmark.
In 1997 Britain provided for just 0.05% of the total world refugee population of 13m.
He ought to be telling his constituents that in 1999 the "big four" countries whose citizens sought refuge in Britain were Yugoslavia, Somalia, Sri Lanka and Afghanistan, all of them war, or civil war zones.
He ought to be telling them that new Labour's asylum act will force refugees to live below the poverty line.
And he ought to be arguing that refugees are not to blame for what is wrong in British society but rather that the problems lie with the very nature of the capitalist system we live under.
As a socialist he ought to be doing all these things, but then that would put him in conflict with his position as a Labour MP.
D Gibson, secretary, Barnsley District Socialist Workers party
Barnsley Chronicle
fields.bodyText: Nursery nukes These are not good times for Britain's intelligence community. First an M15 operative inadvertently mislays his laptop computer. Then an Ml6 agent gets drunk and does exactly the same. Now a top-secret Ministry of Defence CD-rom has ended up in the art department of a Warwickshire nursery school. It was one of a bundle of CDs donated to Chipping Warden primary school by a parent who works at the nearby Army school of ammunition. All the other discs had been wiped clean. But one, snappily titled UK Restricted Ammunition and Explosives Regulations, was picked up by three-year-old Helen Fitchett, who incorporated it into a toy clock she was making. When she took the clock home, her father became suspicious. Dismantling his daughter's creation, ran the CD-rom on his computer, where he discovered classified information about rockets, surface-to-air guided missile systems and chemical weapons. Essex

National League Div 2

Last year Champ 12th; NatWest R3; Super Cup n/a; NL9th (D1)

Coach Keith Fletcher

Captain Ronnie Irani

Import Stuart Law (Aus)

In Tim Mason (Leics), Mark Pettini, Zoheb Sharif

Out Jamie Grove (Som), Jonathan Powell, Tim Hodgson, Tim Walton, Stephen Brown, Robert Rollins

Prospects The popular Ronnie Irani is the new skipper but Nasser Hussain is still club captain and will continue to lead the side in the B&H Cup. The bowling looks good enough, with Ilott, Cowan and Irani backed up by young quicks Anderson and Thompson and the grizzly off-spin of Such. But the good days will not return to Chelmsford until the batsmen stop relying on the stupendous Law. Last season he scored almost 1,000 more than his nearest rival.

Odds Champ 8-1; NW 20-1; B&H 14-1

One to watch Ricky Anderson

Rating Hopefully no change in the Law

PW

Glamorgan

National League Div 2

Last year Champ 14th; NatWest QF; Super Cup n/a; NL 4th (D2)

Coach Jeff Hammond

Captain Matthew Maynard

Import Matthew Elliott (Aus)

In Matthew Elliott, Alex Wharf (Notts)

Out Ismail Dawood, David Harrison

Prospects Hammond, formerly of South Australia, may have his work cut out here. In Mike Powell (bat), Darren Thomas (ball) and Mark Wallace (gloves) he has some ripening fruits at his disposal. Robert Croft and Elliott, 1997 Ashes opponents, are now united in a quest to revive flagging careers, and their response will determine whether Hammond keeps his new organ in tune.

Odds Champ 9-1; NW 20-1; B&H 25-1

One to watch Mark Wallace

Rating Up, up and away

National League Div 1

Last year Champ 18th; NatWest Winners; Super Cup Winners; NL 4th (D1)

Coach John Bracewell

Captain Mark Alleyne

Import Ian Harvey (Aus)

In Tom Cotterell, Damian Forder, Imraan Mohammed, Chris Taylor

Out Matthew Church, Bobby Dawson, Nick Trainor

Prospects Peerless in the sprints, parlous in the marathon, Alleyne and Co secured a seventh championship wooden spoon , but when you've enjoyed a summer Wally and WG could only dream about, who cares? Alleyne's likely absences on England one-day duty are a worry.

Odds Champ 20-1; NW 28-1; B&H 20-1; NL

One to watch Tom Cotterell

Rating Carry on slumming

National League Div 2

Last year Champ 16th; NatWest R3; Super Cup n/a; NL 7th (D2)

Coach Mike Gatting

Captain Justin Langer

Import Justin Langer (Aus)

In Robin Weston (Derbys), Alex Edwards (Sussex), Ed Joyce, Jamie Dalrymple

Out Ian Blanchett, Alastair Fraser, Richard Kettleborough, Neil Martin

Prospects The old sweats who engineered the demise of coach John Buchanan, now crowing with Australia, are at last beginning to see the error of their ways. Langer will bring some Aussie know-how to the dressing room and Angus Fraser, who supported Buchanan, is an interesting pick as vice-captain. With Mark Ramprakash centrally contracted this could be the year for Owais Shah.

Odds Champ 4-1; NW 16-1; B&H 12-1

Rating More hard times ahead

Captain Matthew Hayden

Import Matthew Hayden (Aus)

In Darren Cousins (Essex), Adrian Rollins (Derbys), Michael Strong (Sussex), Robin Sutcliffe, Robert White

Out Rob Bailey (Derbys), David

Follett (ret), Kevin Curran, Dale Iniff

Prospects Will old man Devon keep rolling along? Will Mal Loye's winter in Perth help restore mislaid confidence? Did David Sales really learn self-denial in Bangladesh? Has that fine for oversleeping in South Africa taught Graeme Swann humility? Yes, yes, hopefully, and hopefully not.

Odds Champ 16-1; NW 33-1; B&H 40-1

One to watch David Sales

Rating On the (slow) mend

Nottinghamshire

National League Div 2

Last year Champ 17th; NatWest R4; Super Cup n/a; NL 5th (D2)

Coach Clive Rice

Captain Jason Gallian

Import Shoaib Akhtar (Pak)

In Shoaib Akhtar, Darren Bicknell (Surrey), Andrew Harris (Derbys), Giles Haywood (Sussex), David Millns (Leics), John Morris (Durham)

Out Vasbert Drakes (WI), Tim Robinson (ret), Matt Dowman (Derbys), Alex Wharf (Glam), Graeme Archer, Richard Bates, Kevin Evans, Noel Gie, Jamie Hart

Prospects Clive Rice's playing career at Trent Bridge made him a folk hero but his return as coach was more taxing. He has responded by slashing the staff, buying time with two batting veterans, John Morris and Darren Bicknell, and relying upon the turbulent talent of the Pakistani fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar. He will expect better this time around.

Odds Champ 14-1; NW 33-1; B&H 33-1

One to watch Giles Haywood

Rating Signs of improvement

DH

Sussex

National League Div 1

Last year Champ 11th; NatWest Rd 4; Super Cup SF; NL 1st (D2)

Coach Peter Moores

Captain Chris Adams

Import Michael Bevan (Aus)

In Paul Havell, Will House (Kent), Dominic Clapp, Michael Yardy

Out Michael Di Venuto (Derbys), Giles Haywood (Notts), Alex Edwards (Middx), Michael Strong (N'hants), Rajesh Rao

Prospects Sussex feel mildly miffed to find themselves in the Second Division after gathering more points last season than the year before, when seventh. Promotion is the main aim but will be difficult with the likes of Warwickshire and Notts around. Captain Adams had a shocking winter with England but county bowlers should feel the force of his frustrations. The bowling looks good if fitness is maintained. Bevan is back and will be a wow in one-days.

Odds Champ 12-1; NW 40-1; B&H 40-1

One to watch Robin Martin-Jenkins

Rating Promotion material

PW

Warwickshire

National League Div 2

Last year Champ 10th; NatWest R4; Super Cup SF; NL 7th (D1)

Coach Bob Woolmer

Captain Neil Smith

Import Allan Donald (SA)

In Ryan Sierra

Out Michael Edmond, Tim Munton (Derbys), Gladstone Small

Prospects Donald's suspect fitness has tempered expectations but Ed Giddins will be giddying up with extra urgency after missing out on South Africa. Alan Richardson's progress will be keenly monitored. Not one batsman averaged 40 in 1999, yet several could rectify that with application, not to mention fewer dastardly tracks. Woolmer's innovations - portable pitches, email communiques, groundsharing with Villa - will keep all on their toes.

Odds Champ 15-8; NW 6-1; B&H 7-1

One to watch Ian Bell

Rating Bears to escape pit

RS

Worcestershire

National League Div 1

Last year Champ 15th; NatWest R4; Super Cup n/a; NL 2nd (D1)

Coach Bill Athey

Captain Graeme Hick

Import Glenn McGrath (Aus)

In Glenn McGrath

Out Phil Newport (ret), Nathan Batson, Bobby Chapman, Jason de la Pena, Abdul Hafeez, Tom Moody (Aus)

Prospects Local businessman Cecil Duckworth has financed McGrath's summer by the Severn. Support, though, is slim ( Richard Illingworth eked out 15 wickets last term), the loss of Moody and Newport painful. Vice-captain Steve Rhodes will deputise capably for Hick, but if Vikram Solanki (above) is poised to bloom, that will be a mixed blessing for a club with such a skinny order.

Odds Champ 100-30; NW 14-1; B&H 8-1

One to watch Vikram Solanki

Rating New Road, old potholes

National League Div 2

Coach Colin Wells

Captain Dominic Cork

Import Michael Di Venuto (Aus)

In Michael Di Venuto, Rob Bailey (N'ants), Matt Dowman (Notts), Tim Munton (Warks), Luke Sutton (Som), Cian Wharton, Zubair Khan, Rawait Khan, Kasir Shah

Out Ian Blackwell (Som), Phil DeFreitas (Leics), Andrew Harris (Notts), Adrian Rollins (N'hants), Michael Slater (Aus), Robin Weston (Middx), Vince Clarke, Michael Deane, Michael May, Mark Newell, Glenn Roberts, Tim Tweats, Anthony Woolley

Prospects Derbyshire have felt the brunt of the transfer activity brought about by the new two- division structure, leaving the county spluttering about the disruptive effects of agents - primarily their former batsman John Morris. The mass exodus, most regretted in Ian Blackwell's move to Somerset, has been offset by the arrival of Tim Munton and Rob Bailey. Dominic Cork did well to steal First Division status last summer and even if he and Kevin Dean bowl like demons, batsmen look in short supply.

Odds Champ 28-1; NW 33-1; B&H 33-1

One to watch Trevor Smith

Championship rating Run shortage to prove fatal

Durham

National League Div 2

Last year Champ 8th; NatWest R3; Super Cup n/a; NL 9th (D2)

Coach Norman Gifford

Captain Nick Speak

Import Simon Katich (Aus)

In Simon Katich, Ian Hunter, Graeme Bridge

Out David Boon, Mark Foster (retired), John Morris (Notts), Steven Chapman

Prospects In achieving First Division status, David Boon proved just how much good sense can be cultivated in a few sentences. At the end of June, Durham were bottom of both Championship and National League and had lost to Holland in the NatWest Trophy. That Boon's walrus moustache would bristle with satisfaction on his retirement three months later seemed inconceivable. Durham's strength again lies in their attack, with the know-how of Simon Brown, the awkward bounce of Steve Harmison and the underrated Neil Killeen. However, it is hard to see where the runs will come from, even allowing for the hunger of Boon's replacement, the Western Australian Simon Katich.

Odds Champ 66-1; NW 100-1; B&H 100-1

One to watch Simon Katich

Rating Boon shortlived

National League Div 2

Last year Champ 7th; NatWest R4; Super Cup QF; NL 8th (D1)

Coach Jimmy Cook

Captain Robin Smith

Import Shane Warne (Aus)

In James Adams, Iain Brunnschweiler, Alan Mullally (Leics), Lawrence Prittipaul, Charlie van der Gucht, Shane Warne

Out Kevan James (ret), Thomas Hansen, Matthew Keech, Steve Lugsden, Nixon McLean

Prospects With a Brunnschweiler, a Prittipaul and a Van der Gucht joining a trio of Tykes in a crew coached by a South African and spiced by Australia's main contribution to late 20th-century art, Cosmopolitans seems an apter nom de plume than Hawks. Cook sees no reason why his new charges should not bid farewell to Northlands Road in style before moving to their new ground - and why not? The batsmen harvested more points than any last summer. Bolstered by a fit Alex Morris and a piqued Mullally, as well as Warne, the attack may be lethal. A pennant for the first time since the theme from Van der Valk hit No1? There's a memory worth erasing.

fields.body:
The Mirror Barcelona's De Boer brothers could be on their way to Arsenal if Marc Overmars completes his much-touted move to the Nou Camp this summer. Frank, a central defender, and Ronald, an attacking midfielder, remain unsettled in Catalonia.

The Independent Gianluca Vialli was spotted in "deep and meaningful conversation" with Patrick Kluivert after Chelsea's Champions League clash with Barcelona. Kluivert last week restated his desire to play in England sooner rather than later.

Teamtalk Liverpool have joined the hunt for Alvaro Recoba. Internazionale's sometime striker is set for talks with coach Marcello Lippi this week and Manchester United, Real Madrid and Juventus are all ready with bids should they fail.

Planet football Athirson, full name Athirson Mazolli de Oliveira, is the latest young South American talent to be linked with a move to England. The Brazilian under-23 international currently plays for Flamengo, but Arsenal and Barcelona have both expressed an interest. Athirson would cost either club £15m.

Spanish international Ismael Urzaiz claims that Arsenal want to sign him this summer. The striker, who has only scored four times in La Liga this season, is still an even bet for a place in Spain's Euro 2000 squad.

webTitle: Nice one Jack, but Brits will still get drunk

fields.headline: Nice one Jack, but Brits will still get drunk
fields.standfirst:
Modernising the licensing laws is a start, but the home secretary will not change Britain's drinking culture that easily, says Guardian food and drink editor Matthew Fort
No half measures in licensing shake-up
fields.trailText: Monday, 12.45pm: Modernising the licensing laws is a start, but the home secretary won't change Britain's drinking culture that easily, says Guardian food and drink editor Matthew Fort
fields.body:
"'What two ideas are more inseparable than Beer and Britannia?' said the Reverend Sidney Smith. In fact Smith should not have been so specific. It is not just beer and Britannia that are inseparable; it is Britannia and alcohol of any kind. Two hundred years on Jack Straw is again pondering the nature of this relationship.

The unhappy fact is that we Britons, in common with most other northern nations, like getting drunk. We have always liked getting drunk. We get drunk in private and in public. More civilised southerners have been remarking our inclination to get drunk for at least eight hundred years. Writers and artists have recorded the contexts and consequences of drunkenness of all levels of our society since alcohol was first recognised as a means of warding off the dreariness and boredom of daily life.

Somehow we have never discovered the secret of civilised drinking as the French, Italians, Spanish and Greeks have. In spite of public exclamations and bureaucratic meddling, drunkenness is not only tolerated in this country, it is celebrated. There is no social censure at being seen to be drunk. It is glorified through advertising, media coverage and public example.

It isn't really a matter of the licensing laws, which, it is true, are not such as should be tolerated by an civilised society. You can tinker with the licensing laws as much as you like, it won't stop people getting drunk. Young drinkers drink because they like the hit. Alcohol makes life more fun. Old drinkers drink because they are used to it. Alcohol makes life more pleasant.

In fact, what is at issue isn't a really a matter of drink at all. Bars are open in most European countries longer than they are over here, and most European nations drink much more than we do. It's just that they behave differently when they do so. Public exhibitions of drunkenness are frowned on, not tolerated. Oafishness, laddishness, lassie-ishness, loudness, drinking to get sick, drinking for the sake of drinking are not seen as socially admirable habits.

Jack Straw is setting himself to change the habits of the nation. Good luck to him. If he succeeds it will make England a more civilised (not the same thing as cultured) country. But it seems to me that such deeply ingrained patterns of cultural behaviour are not going to be rooted out because the pubs can stay open all day, too popular pubs get shut down and because children are only going to be exposed to the evils of alcohol until they are testosterone or progesterone laden teenagers with money to drink.

fields.headline: We also do TV
fields.standfirst: So you thought CNN was just a US TV channel? Think again. David Teather on the companyÕs plans to spread into Europe, Africa and the Middle East through the web
fields.trailText: So you thought CNN was just a US TV channel? Think again. David Teather on the companyÕs plans to spread into Europe, Africa and the Middle East through the web
fields.body:
You know how it works. YouÕre on a business trip, you get to the hotel, switch on the TV for some background noise and there it is. The reassuringly big-haired American tones of CNN, the 24-hour news channel playing in comforting 30-minute loops.

Mention that to executives of the Time Warner-owned business, though, and hear the groans. In the past few years, CNN has ploughed millions into building news channels with local partners and content to establish a less transient global audience. The latest addition was a Turkish-language joint venture with Dogan Media Group, CNN Turk, launched amidst the countryÕs devastating earthquakes at the end of last year. Nan Richards, president of Turner News Networks, describes the strategy as putting down CNN tentacles worldwide.

Now the company, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary, is turning its attention to the internet through CNN Interactive.

The business will today announce the appointment of David Brewer, one of the founders of the award-winning BBC News Online, to spearhead the development of websites across Europe, the Middle East and Africa, all tailored for local markets.

He aims to recruit a team of 30-40 journalists who will be based in CNNÕs anonymous European hub in Soho. BrewerÕs appointment is described by Mitch Lazar, who runs business development of new media for Turner, as a "beachhead" in Europe. "Expansion will be rapid," he says.

Like its sister TV business, CNN Interactive has a powerful core website in the US which reaches far beyond its domestic market. CNN.com, which launched in 1995, gets 700m hits a month, of which some 30% come from overseas eyeballs. As well as coverage of domestic events, sport and entertainment, the website offers news and analysis drawing on the wider groupÕs 4,000 staff working in 35 bureaux around the world. A version for Wap phones was launched in February.

But, as with the TV business, CNN Interactive is keen to get in closer on the ground with local language sites and a stronger emphasis on local content. "We want to be as locally relevant as we can," enthuses Lazar. "Content produced by people in the region for users in the region is a much more compelling offering. We are taking it down to the next level."

CNNÕs first local language website was launched in Sweden in May 1997 in partnership with Scandanavia Online. The company is now eyeing EuropeÕs biggest markets for development, Britain, France and Germany. Advertising sales people in CNNÕs London offices have already been hired to prepare the way.

The model so far in both TV and on the internet has been to go into markets with local partners. CNN InteractiveÕs latest launch last week was a Japanese site, its seventh local language site so far, which uses content from Asahi.com as well as original material from CNNÕs headquarters in Atlanta and the organisationÕs local bureau. Like its CNN.com cousin, it will also carry features from the Japanese version of stablemate Time magazine.

The group claims that its interactive division is one of the few internet businesses worldwide that is making a profit Ð although it declines to back up the boast with figures. Revenues come chiefly from advertising, with some additional income from licensing and e-commerce. One in four people employed by CNN are now in new media.

Richards says the key strength of CNN on the internet is the trust associated with its brand. "Being the first-ever 24-hour news channel gave us a real leg up. If we didnÕt have such a strong core brand we wouldnÕt be in a position to launch all these new services or to attract such strong partners. You would be hard pressed to find anyone throughout Europe who is not aware of CNN."

Brewer says the only place he would have left the BBC for was CNN. "When we were setting up BBC News Online three years ago we were looking at what else was out there and saying we want to be as good as CNN.com and deliver content as well they do." He seems to be taking the evangelical line. In response to the obvious question on share options he raises eyebrows. "We havenÕt even discussed that sort of thing yet," he comments, somewhat affronted.

Disingenuous or not, Brewer clearly thinks that hackery and mammon make uneasy bedfellows. Does he think it will be difficult to hire people without the kind of options on offer that start-ups are waving around? "We donÕt want that sort of person," he replies. "We want committed journalists who have a passion to deliver content as succinctly and accurately as possible."

In Britain at least, CNN will face some tough competition to make itself the first port of call on the web. As well as the BBC, it faces beefed-up operations from the likes of Sky News which is adding 30 staff to its online service and ITN New Media which also announced plans for expansion last week. CNNÕs not so secret weapon could be Time WarnerÕs proposed merger with America Online which can only underline its presence on the web.

Part of the task is to change the perception that CNN is still US-centric. "Anyone who still has the perception that we are just a US channel probably hasnÕt watched us in a couple of years," says Lazar. "ItÕs not the product people remember from the Gulf war, when we first really came onto the scene in Europe. "Our TV started out as a US service, which then became international and is now regionalised." CNN was split in 1997 into four separately scheduled channels, Asia Pacific, Europe, Latin and North America and the Middle East and Africa. In the US, CNN is available in more than 77m households while across Europe it is in 86m. Its first foreign language channel was CNN en Espanol, launched as a companion to CNN International Latin America. Richards says there are "a couple" of markets in the works for local TV stations, although a specifically tailored UK service is not one of them.

"We are not going to change perceptions overnight," says Lazar. "But the internet especially is a global medium by its very nature and as we bring in more local people we will change that perception. We are an American company but these are not American products." ThatÕs the plan, anyway.

CNNÕs not so secret weapon could be Time WarnerÕs proposed merger with America Online which can only underline its presence on the web. Part of the task is to change the perception that CNN is still US-centric. "Anyone who still has the perception that we are just a US channel probably hasnÕt watched us in a couple of years," says Lazar. "ItÕs not the product people remember from the Gulf war, when we first really came onto the scene in Europe. "Our TV started out as a US service, which then became international and is now regionalised." CNN was split in 1997 into four separately scheduled channels, Asia Pacific, Europe, Latin and North America and the Middle East and Africa. In the US, CNN is available in more than 77m households while across Europe it is in 86m. Its first foreign language channel was CNN en Espanol, launched as a companion to CNN International Latin America. Richards says there are "a couple" of markets in the works for local TV stations, although a specifically tailored UK service is not one of them. "We are not going to change perceptions overnight," says Lazar. "But the internet especially is a global medium by its very nature and as we bring in more local people we will change that perception. We are an American company but these are not American products." ThatÕs the plan, anyway.

webTitle: Tory MP to quit over Fayed job

fields.headline: Tory MP to quit over Fayed job
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Charles Wardle, the former Home Office minister who has accepted a £120,000 directorship from Mohamed Al Fayed, is to stand down from parliament after fierce opposition in his constituency.
fields.body:
Charles Wardle, the former Home Office minister who has accepted a £120,000 directorship from Mohamed Al Fayed, is to stand down from parliament after fierce opposition in his constituency.

In a letter to the Bexhill and Battle Conservative association, Mr Wardle expressed his "deep regret" over his decision not to contest the next election, despite having been reapppointed as candidate.

Mr Wardle, 60, is understood to have made the decision after Mr Fayed told him that he could increase his workload at Harrods if he abandoned the "low life and half men in Westminster".

The former minister, who turned down Mr Fayed's application for British citizenship in 1993, also threatened to sue the Daily Telegraph after it lampooned his decision to accept a £120,000 non-executive Harrods directorship.

Mr Wardle believes he was libelled on Wednesday when the newspaper printed a cartoon of him diving into a giant brown Harrods envelope stuffed with £50 notes. "I may be obstinate but I am not corrupt," he told the Sunday Times.

Mr Fayed is understood to have assured Mr Wardle that he will underwrite his legal expenses.

Mr Wardle's appointment, which was cleared with the Tory whips and with the parliamentary standards commissioner, horrified many Tories.

fields.headline: Marketing has trouble deciphering dot.coms
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Our core business is fundamentally simple: we will give young people the ability to shop securely online without the need for a credit card.
fields.body:
Our core business is fundamentally simple: we will give young people the ability to shop securely online without the need for a credit card.

Acting as an online debit facility, money will be deposited into a teenagers' online account. This will then be used to fund purchases from a network of partner Internet retailers, the actual transaction being carried out in much the same way as existing payment methods such as credit or debit cards.

The concept is simple to us, but we've been amazed at how many times we've been asked exactly what it is that we are doing.

It isn't just elderly relatives who have never used a computer that are struggling to understand what we are up to.

This question has been asked by people that you would expect to be a little more clued-up, including friends that use the Internet every day at work and, more surprisingly, professional services companies that are pitching for our, and no doubt other, dot.com business.

OK, so we are exaggerating a little, but it does serve to illustrate a wider point. When we have introduced our business to people they have shown, either directly or indirectly, a lack of understanding about what we are doing.

In a broader sense, many people are genuinely struggling to make sense of what is going on in the world of interactive media.

Take some of the marketing agencies we have spoken to. Several have appeared bewildered by the demands from new dot.com businesses.

Many have been unable to demonstrate a deep understanding of our needs and ambitions. This is despite the fact that the industry, particularly advertising, has had an integral role in launching numerous new online businesses. It has also been of the one of the ultimate beneficiaries of the venture capaital money pouring into the Internet space at the moment.

We have also found that some agencies are understandably wary of the potential downside of working in a relatively volatile and immature market.

With the spotlight focused firmly on dot.com businesses at the moment, professional services companies that have spent years building a great reputation within their industry risk destroying it in a very short space of time if something happens to go wrong.

Morgan Stanley has been criticised in some quarters for its handling of the lastminute.com flotation, for example.

The lack of understanding, both in the commercial and in the consumer worlds, stems from a number of factors; the speed of changes underway, the array of technical platforms available (Internet, WAP, digital TV) and the massive hype surrounding the industry.

It can also be difficult for people to make sense of pure online businesses that have no physical presence.

Working in a relatively insular world with high levels of usage and involvement with the Internet, it is important for us to be aware that some consumers are confused about what is going on.

It is sobering to remember that for all the hype, the Internet has still not touched the lives of a significant proportion of the population. Even some teenagers, members of the most wired generation so far, do not yet know how to use the net.

We face huge challenges in effectively communicating to these people what it is that we offer. But we believe that we now have a strong team of agencies on our side that can help with this. Critically, these agencies do fundamentally understand what we are about and genuinely share our excitement for the months ahead.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com

webTitle: The dark side of the Moon

fields.headline: The dark side of the Moon
fields.trailText: The Who's late drummer, Keith Moon, is the subject of a film being developed by director Brad Silberling (City of Angels) with cooperation from the band's remaining members - Pete Townshend, Roger Daltrey and John Entwistle. Moon died in 1978, aged 31, of an overdose of sleeping pills.
fields.body:
The Who's late drummer, Keith Moon, is the subject of a film being developed by director Brad Silberling (City of Angels) with cooperation from the band's remaining members - Pete Townshend, Roger Daltrey and John Entwistle. Moon died in 1978, aged 31, of an overdose of sleeping pills.

The Who, who are still touring, also may contribute to the soundtrack of Silberling's next film project, Baby's in Black, inspired by the 1989 murder of his fiancee, 21-year-old actress Rebecca Schaeffer, who was killed by a stalker.

The Keith Moon project is based at Warner Bros., but it is unclear whether the involvement of Sinclair - a longtime Who fanatic - extends to his financing and production company.

Still, a film about the life and times of Moon, the madman drummer who died in 1978 of an overdose of an anti-alcoholism medication, could prove a magnet for leading Hollywood talent.

Upon hearing of the potential Who picture, Nicolas Cage, who starred with Meg Ryan in the 1998 Silberling-directed City of Angels, was quoted as saying, "I am Pete Townshend!''

fields.headline: The debate rumbles on
fields.standfirst:
David Thomson, one of the world's leading film critics, reacts to Wisden's
Five of the Century in this e-mail to Tim de Lisle, editor of wisden.com
fields.trailText: The wisdom drummed into me from the late 1940s onwards was that Don Bradman and Jack Hobbs and Wally Hammond were the greatest players of all time. I think Garry Sobers was the best player I saw a lot of - though I know that's because he was an all-rounder and I was raised on some very good all-rounders, like Keith Miller, Trevor Bailey. England doesn't really make all-rounders any more. And I can easily understand how Shane Warne and Viv Richards get in. But when you're playing a game like this you can easily get into difficult situations. For example, if we believe that Bradman was the greatest ever, with a greatness that would have prevailed in any era, then I think you have to allow that several other figures from his era, or earlier - Hobbs, Frank Woolley, Hammond and Wilfred Rhodes (he above all maybe) - have to rise with Bradman.
fields.body:
The wisdom drummed into me from the late 1940s onwards was that Don Bradman and Jack Hobbs and Wally Hammond were the greatest players of all time. I think Garry Sobers was the best player I saw a lot of - though I know that's because he was an all-rounder and I was raised on some very good all-rounders, like Keith Miller, Trevor Bailey. England doesn't really make all-rounders any more. And I can easily understand how Shane Warne and Viv Richards get in. But when you're playing a game like this you can easily get into difficult situations. For example, if we believe that Bradman was the greatest ever, with a greatness that would have prevailed in any era, then I think you have to allow that several other figures from his era, or earlier - Hobbs, Frank Woolley, Hammond and Wilfred Rhodes (he above all maybe) - have to rise with Bradman.

It's so hard reconciling statistics when, long ago, batsmen in England had so many more innings, and Test cricket was played so much less often. Hobbs played 61 Tests in a 29-year career. Assuming he played now, and was an ever-present, he would play 200 times for England. His average for his 61 Tests was close to 57 - so, if he plays 200 times and has say 300 innings (as opposed to 100) he could have 17,000 runs in Tests, which is about twice what any other Englishman can claim.

Or take Hammond - 85 Tests in a 31-year career at an average of 58.45. And he gave up several years to the war; plus in his time there was a relative lack of games against weak teams - in the generation or two after him, English players fattened their figures on series with India, Pakistan and New Zealand.

Finally, Bradman played a mere 52 Tests (and only 80 innings - what does that tell you?). In those he made nearly 7000 runs at 99.94. Graham Gooch made 2000 more runs in 215 Test innings - average 42.58.

I think Frank Worrell may be rated a little high on the list. Worrell was a fine man and captain who surely drew West Indies into the modern age, but as a batsman he was less effective than Everton Weekes and several others. Also, Dennis Lillee - a great bowler, a great character and fresh in the memory, but was he better than Ray Lindwall? Lindwall in 1948 demolished and demoralised a pretty good English batting line-up.

I don't know how to make the comparisons. Except that Bradman, say, made his runs against some pretty good bowling. It would be very interesting to ask the question: which were the most competitive Test series of all time Ð ie. those in which there was true excellence on both sides?

His latest book is In Nevada: The Land, The People, God, and Chance (Little, Brown, 1999). Born in London in 1941, Thomson has lived in San Francisco since 1981.

fields.headline: Damien Hirst: drugs and me
fields.standfirst: Read the Guardian interview with Damien Hirst
fields.trailText: Damien Hirst was reduced to a "babbling wreck" by his prodigious consumption of drugs and alcohol, the original enfant terrible of Britart admits in an exclusive interview in the Guardian today. The Turner prize winner, better known of late as a celebrity restaurateur than as an artist, says he began suffering from blackouts after mixing cocaine and drink.
fields.body:
Damien Hirst was reduced to a "babbling wreck" by his prodigious consumption of drugs and alcohol, the original enfant terrible of Britart admits in an exclusive interview in the Guardian today. The Turner prize winner, better known of late as a celebrity restaurateur than as an artist, says he began suffering from blackouts after mixing cocaine and drink.

"There's a balance I was after between a certain amount of this and a certain amount of that, like an alchemist," he says. "But I started to blow gaskets and pop rivets."

Hirst says he has been experiencing "a difficulty with art" for four years, during which he has produced no significant new work. "I haven't done anything because until now I've not felt it was any good."

He hopes a series of new works to be exhibited in London this month and later in New York will refocus attention on his art. Already one of them, a 20ft anatomical figure called Hymn, has stoked the requisite controversy after the revelation that it was copied from a children's toy. Speaking to the writer Gordon Burn in his most revealing interview to date, Hirst is unapologetic about his inspiration for the sculpture, which was bought by Charles Saatchi for £1m, revealing that he got the idea after seeing his five-year-old son, Connor, playing with one of the toys. "I might even get sued for it. I expect it."

Hirst's new works seem certain to court as much outrage and attention as the pickled animals that made him famous. They include a giant fishtank containing a submerged gynaecologist's examination room, entitled Lost Love.

Hirst's last major exhibition was in 1996. Since then he has been involved in the opening of restaurants, released a record and produced a book.

Now he says the restaurant business was more trouble than it was worth. "It just wasn't art at the end of the day. You end up getting involved in aprons, knives and forks, all the shit of life that you don't really want to get involved in."

Hirst's new self-awareness does not seem to have eroded his talent for bad behaviour. He reveals that he is facing legal action after he dropped his trousers in the restaurant of a Dublin hotel last month and inserted a chicken bone in the end of his penis.

webTitle: Friedkin's military thriller topples Erin Brockovich from top of box office

fields.headline: Friedkin's military thriller topples Erin Brockovich from top of box office
fields.trailText: Exorcist director William Friedkin's military thriller Rules of Engagement has brought to a halt the three-week winning streak enjoyed by Julia Roberts' Erin Brockovich. Studio estimates yesterday put the film at the top of the US box office on its opening weekend.
fields.body:
Exorcist director William Friedkin's military thriller Rules of Engagement has brought to a halt the three-week winning streak enjoyed by Julia Roberts' Erin Brockovich. Studio estimates yesterday put the film at the top of the US box office on its opening weekend.

Stars Samuel L. Jackson and Tommy Lee Jones helped Rules of Engagement gross an estimated $15.3m in its opening weekend. The courtroom drama about friendship involves a tough Marine colonel (Jackson), who is court-martialled after a mission he leads to free a besieged US embassy fails. His Vietnam War buddy (Jones), now a mediocre military attorney, defends him at his trial.

The US critics have found it a less exciting prospect. "This thing is cut, dried and creatively dead on arrival. No surprises," declared the Washington Post, while Entertainment Weekly found it tame and unchallenging: "It backs off each time there's an opportunity for us to be challenged by ambiguity the drama ultimately retreats to safer, duller, more illogical, and more reactionary impulses and stereotypes."

Elsewhere in the US box office, DreamWorks' animated The Road to El Dorado fell a notch in the rankings, pulling in $8.9m for a total $25m in its second week of release. The movie features the voices of Kevin Kline and Kenneth Branagh in the quest for the legendary city of gold.

New romantic comedy Return to Me weighed in at No 4. The movie's plot involves Minnie Driver and X-Files star David Duchovny falling in love, only to find out Duchovny's dying former-wife donated her heart to Driver.

fields.headline: In at the shallow end
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we ask a county cricketer what he's been up to in the close season. This week we talk to Somerset's Tasmanian captain Jamie Cox, who began the season with a nice easy game against Oxford University
fields.trailText: Jamie Cox, a right-handed Australian batsman, joined Somerset as captain last season. He steered them to the NatWest final and fourth place in the Championship, scoring over 1600 first-class runs in the process. Last winter he replaced David Boon as captain of Tasmania.
fields.body:
Jamie Cox, a right-handed Australian batsman, joined Somerset as captain last season. He steered them to the NatWest final and fourth place in the Championship, scoring over 1600 first-class runs in the process. Last winter he replaced David Boon as captain of Tasmania.

"I spent most of the winter playing for Tasmania which is a totally different sort of cricket from over here. We play 10 games in a season, which gives us a lot more time to train and prepare. Generally we get a couple of weeks in between games so there's time to get involved in Grade cricket as well. I play for Lindisfarne and it's a pretty serious competition. There isn't a lot of time to relax or do anything outside of cricket. If I'm not playing cricket then generally I'm doing something involved with it. That's the way I prefer it really. Whether it's training or planning for a game.There's certainly three or four hours taken up every day with that.

Once the season gets underway over here you're really looking at body maintenance. You spend a lot of time stretching, and doing light aerobic and weights work. Most of it is done in the gym because there's not much time to do any cricket work on the road.

We had a couple of weeks off over Christmas because there was no Grade cricket during that time. I just had a quiet one with my family up in Wynard on the north-west coast of Tassie. It's lovely up there, really peaceful and stuff. My girlfriend was there with me which was nice.

I'm really keen to stay here in England and I've thoroughly enjoyed it so far. I only got back a few days ago and haven't had a chance to do any pre-season stuff but we were playing Oxford over the weekend and that went pretty well [Somerset won by 404 runs and Cox scored a second-innings 100]. But they were a fairly ordinary side to be honest.

fields.headline: Obituary: Claire Trevor
fields.standfirst: Actress famous for a series of 'wanton women' roles in 40s noir films
fields.trailText: Claire Trevor, who has died aged 91, will be remembered mainly for playing blondes with tough exteriors that hid her vulnerability. In her best films, she was not only a woman who had kicked around the world, but who had been kicked around by the world.
fields.body:
Claire Trevor, who has died aged 91, will be remembered mainly for playing blondes with tough exteriors that hid her vulnerability. In her best films, she was not only a woman who had kicked around the world, but who had been kicked around by the world.

In John Ford's Stagecoach (1939), which raised the western genre to artistic status, she was "saloon girl" Dallas, who has been forced out of town by puritanical women. When the Ringo Kid (John Wayne) proposes to her, she says, "But, you don't know me, you don't know who I am." "I know all I want to know," he says. Seeing a glimmer of hope, she asks the drunken doctor (Thomas Mitchell), "Is that wrong for a girl like me? If a man and woman love each other? It's all right, ain't it Doc?" Typical as the role was, Stagecoach was one of the few films that sanctioned her happiness.

She was born Claire Wemlinger in in New York of a French father and Northern Irish mother. When her father lost his clothing business during the Great Depression, she went out to work to help the family. Later she managed to attend Columbia University and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, before starting her acting career in stock in the late 1920s. By 1932, she had starred on Broadway opposite Edward Arnold in The Party's Over, which brought her to the attention of 20th Century Fox, who gave her a five-year contract in 1933.

At Fox, she played Shirley Temple's mother in Baby Takes A Bow (1934), supported Spencer Tracy in Dante's Inferno (1935), and made six films directed by veteran craftsman Allan Dwan, but they were mostly inconsequential programmers. She left Fox hoping for better roles and immediately landed one from Samuel Goldwyn in William Wyler's Dead End (1937) as hoodlum Humphrey Bogart's ex-girlfriend, reduced to streetwalking and ravaged by illness. Although she is barely on screen for five minutes, in a memorable seriers of close-ups, she made enough impact to be nominated for a supporting actress Oscar. "I'm tired. I'm sick," she tells Bogart. "Can you see it? Look at me good. You've been looking at me like I used to be."

Dead End set her off on a series of roles as wanton women: gangsters' molls in thrillers and saloon bar gals in westerns. In The Amazing Dr Clitterhouse (1938), she played Bogart's moll who betrays him, and in I Stole a Million (1939), she helps her mobster husband George Raft. However, Trevor had to wait for the rise of 1940s film noir to become one of the leading women of the genre. With her long, blonde hair whisked up above the broad-shouldered gowns and a seen-it-all look in her eyes, she was able to hit her stride.

In Street of Chance (1942), she misleads amnesiac Burgess Meredith by telling him he is wanted for murder, though she is the real killer. As the sexy, two-faced Mrs Grayle in Edward Dmytryk's Murder My Sweet (1944), she tells Philip Marlowe (Dick Powell), "You shouldn't kiss a girl when you're wearing a gun. It leaves a bruise." In Born to Kill (1947), she is "a silken savage," a mercenary divorcee with a fatal attraction for a man who has already killed two people. "You're strength, excitement and depravity," she is told. Anthony Mann's Raw Deal (1948) was one of the rare noir movies in which the narration was supplied by a woman, in this case Trevor as the betrayed girlfriend of a racketeer.

In the same year, in Key Largo, for which she won an Oscar for best supporting actress, Trevor played Gaye Dawn, the fading alcoholic mistress of sadistic gangster Johnny Rocco (Edward G Robinson). "She's a lush," says Robinson's fat henchman (Thomas Gomez). "After she bends the elbow a few times, she begins to see things - rats, roaches, bats, you know. A sock in the kisser is the only thing that will bring her out of it." Pathetically singing Moanin' Low to please Rocco, Trevor revealed the character's touching dependence on the brute.

During the next decade, Trevor's image continued to be "strength, excitement and depravity", especially in two films of 1951: Best of the Badmen as Robert Preston's angry and disillusioned wife, and Hard, Fast and Beautiful as the greedy ambitious tennis mother determined to live off her daughter's earnings. In 1954, she gained another Oscar nomination for The High and the Mighty (1954), this time as a loose woman among imperilled airline passengers. Ironically, Charles, her only child by the second of her three marriages died in an air crash in 1978.

In Vincente Minnelli's Two Weeks in Another Town (1962) as Edward G Robinson's "worn out, dry, old hag" of a wife, she rants and raves, drinks and smokes. "Don't take an overdose," Robinson tells her. "You know how ill it makes me." Like most of her later roles, such as the man-hating harridan in How To Murder Your Wife (1965), it was a reference to many of the parts she had played in her black-and-white movie past.

She not only enjoyed a Hollywood career spanning five decades, but performed in hundreds of radio and television shows - including an Emmy-winning role in Dodsworth. She retired from acting in 1987 and became a patron of the arts.

 Claire Trevor (née Claire Wemlinger), film actress, born March 8 1909; died April 8 2000

webTitle: 'It's great having your own network - you should try it'

fields.headline: 'It's great having your own network - you should try it'
fields.standfirst: Zad Rogers  on how TV producers can have all the power on the net
fields.trailText: Zad Rogers on how TV producers can have all the power on the net
fields.body:
Cable giant NTL's recent attempts to woo the independent production sector with a £25m spend on original content underlines the precarious position of the once dominant British broadcaster. New media is continuing to erode the viewer base and broadcasters are continuing to see the fragmentation of their audience, but is bad news for the broadcaster bad news for all? Not necessarily so.

For too long the power of distribution has rested in the hands of too few, but now new technologies should free up the stranglehold that broadcasters have on the distribution of media, and open up the revenue potential that the right to broadcast carries with it.

As a producer I am eager to have direct access to our audience and to be able to fund our own output. At Ideal World we see the web as a way of doing just that. Developments in technology are helping to transform the internet into a distribution system that rivals traditional broadcast methods, but brings with it none of the baggage. The internet will soon simply be another delivery system, and in a converged world all delivery systems will be capable of delivering all media.

In simple terms the internet will allow anyone to post near TV quality programmes on the web, but with the added advantage of those programmes being fully interactive. The enabler of all of this is broadband. Broadband offers speeds of hundreds of thousands of bits per second, as opposed to the 56K modem that is the norm on most PCs. These high-speed data transfer rates allow con tent providers to combine two-way, interactive communication with television-quality, full-motion video.

What does this mean for the producer? The right to broadcast has historically been the preserve of an elite group who have been protected from competition by the high entry cost and lack of bandwidth. Broadband is an affordable alternative to traditional means of terrestrial distribution which will allow producers to distribute their own output.

Some UK terrestrial broadcasters are fighting a rearguard action and trying to minimise the impact of the opportunities that new media represents by demanding the rights to the programmes they commission across all platforms and via all distribution systems. It is an attempt to neutralise new technology by demanding ownership of everything that is carried on it. This is a high-risk strategy that has only worked in the past because of the near monopoly that broadcasters have had over the distribution system. Not any more.

Independent producers now have a number of options. Besides being able to post programmes direct online there are a range of other potential broadcasters appearing on the scene who will pay for the idea if the traditional broadcasters are not willing to share in its exploitation. NTL's recent announcement of a £25m pot to fund programming is just one example of how radically the media landscape is changing. Other potential programme buyers - the likes of BT, Open and online broadcasters such as Broadcast.com - can distribute content via their own systems and platforms.

This freedom from the need to have an idea sanctioned by a broadcaster is already having a huge impact on the breadth of content available online. There are the serious sites such as On2.com, positioning itself as a major online broadcaster, and more leftfield sites such as the children's animation site Rumpus.com. On2.com, which launches in April, promises to be a world leader in delivering full-motion, full-screen, television-quality pictures using the latest technology (TrueMotion VP3) to deliver video with all the interactivity you expect from the web.

The internet is not about replicating TV online, but about the democratisation of distribution. By bringing down the cost of distribution it blows away the hierarchy that has controlled the dissemination of media for all time. Anyone can launch a label, and soon anyone can have a channel - it is this whiff of revolt that has sent the old regime running for cover. Brad Foxhaven of Top Cow Comics is a typical example. His attempts to get his work produced for broadcast via a studio were unsuccessful, so he launched his own site, Eruptor TV, which has become a big hit in the US.

As Brad Foxhaven's experience suggests, where broadcasters can't take the risk, the internet can. With risk comes experimentation which, in the long run, can only lead to more interesting programmes.

If broadcasters are no longer the gatekeepers of distribution it begs the question, what role do they have? As large organisations with an understanding of broadcasting rather than niche fulfilment, they are proving poor at judging the interests of the net audience. The innovation is not coming from the likes of the BBC, but from maverick talent like Brad Foxhaven or the pre-existing niche broadcasters such as MTV whose MTV.com is one of the most successful entertainment sites around.

But don't count the broadcasters out yet; in the UK they are in an unassailable position as long as they stay smart and stay open to developing new relationships to exploit new opportunities. Broadcasters are hugely valuable benign brands with absolute penetration throughout the UK. In an unstructured media environment with unlimited options, the broadcasters' brand can be trusted and, perhaps most important of all, they offer a quality-control mechanism that will become more important as access to online distribution becomes easier and easier.

The broadcasters' future must lie in partnerships with more savvy new media organisations, using the broadcasters' brand to bring in the traffic. Ideal World has formed such a joint venture with Channel 4 called 4car. 4car benefits from all the production experience of Channel 4 and its hugely valuable brand, whilst offering a much more direct link to the viewers.

Through partnering with producers and new media entrepreneurs, the broadcaster gets to keep the integrity of its own terrestrial brands whilst developing a relationship with the web. When video streaming becomes a reality, sites such as 4car can develop into sub brands, catering to niche audiences. These sub brands could offer a full range of interactive services that would not be available via the TV. As broadband sweeps all before it, sites grown in partnership with the broadcasters can migrate onto TV, where broadband will ensure continued interactivity.

An example of a company which realised the value of distribution via the internet is Broadway Video, one of the most respected independent production companies in New York. Tired of endless pitches to the US networks they acquired a college cable channel - called Burly Bear Network which now also transmits on the web. Burly Bear is now big business with e-commerce activities such as selling beer to thirsty students generating significant revenue and giving the company a huge value. But, equally important, it is also a very effective R&D department allowing Broadway Video to break new talent that the networks would never have considered.

This is a perfect example of the benefits of online distribution offering opportunities to new talent, developing fresh ideas and yet building alternative revenue streams out of reach of the traditional broadcaster. Burly Bear's output would never have found its way onto US network TV, but by zoning in on its young college audience, Burly Bear is building up a massive following and a very healthy balance sheet. It makes for a very exciting life since the mixture of big business and cutting-edge creativity is exhilarating. As the 28-year-old director of Burly Bear Networks said, "It's great having your own network, you should try it."

 Zad Rogers is a director of independent production company, Ideal World

fields.headline: Hague aides join 'quit EU' group
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague faced fresh embarrassment last night when it emerged that two of his most trusted aides have signed up to a rightwing group whose leaders want to force Britain to withdraw from the European Union.
fields.body:
William Hague faced fresh embarrassment last night when it emerged that two of his most trusted aides have signed up to a rightwing group whose leaders want to force Britain to withdraw from the European Union.

The Thatcherite John Whittingdale, the Tory leader's personal aide in the Commons, and the shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, are vice-presidents of Conservatives Against a Federal Europe, which is campaigning against Mr Hague's stance on the single currency.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, last night seized on their membership of the group - known as Cafe - to claim Tories were "moving relentlessly in an anti-European direction".

He said: "Almost a third of Conservative MPs have now signed up to an organisation that campaigns openly on a platform of renegotiate [British membership of the EU] or withdraw. The fact that this includes William Hague's PPS shows that he is either unable or unwilling to tackle extremists in his own party."

Cafe is supported by the leading rightwinger, Lord Pearson of Rannoch, who recently introduced a bill in the Lords to examine the options for British withdrawal from Europe.

The group believes that Britain should permanently rule out membership of the single currency. Mr Hague has just about held his party together by arguing that Britain should remain outside the euro for the lifetime of this parliament and the next.

Cafe has proved an embarrassment to the Tory leadership, which insists that its "In Europe, not run by Europe" message is not extremist. The group is supported by five frontbenchers, and John Redwood joined up as soon as he was removed from the frontbench earlier this year.

Pro-European campaigners believe Mr Hague has privately encouraged Cafe, as part of secret moves towards a more extreme position on Europe. They point out that the driving force behind the group is Mike Penning, who now serves as one of the most senior press officers at Central Office. Mr Penning is the former organiser of the anti-European Tory MPs who lost the whip under John Major.

Simon Buckby, campaign director for Britain in Europe, said: "It is shame that some people who ought to know better are still wasting their time in groups like Cafe when 3m British jobs and a third of our trade depends on our place in Europe."

Mr Whittingdale is a powerful force behind the scenes in Tory circles, where his formal role as Mr Hague's "bag carrier" belies his influence. A former PPS to Lady Thatcher, Mr Whittingdale is said to play an important role in "bridging" the Thatcher and Hague camps.

Anti-Europeans were delighted with Mr Whittingdale when Lady Thatcher hijacked last year's party conference with her claim that all Britain's problems came from continental Europe. Pro-Europeans were dismayed, believing Mr Whittingdale had allowed Lady Thatcher to demonstrate how the Tories were unelectable.

Mr Whittingdale is a strong supporter of Cafe's five-point plan, branded by pro-Europeans as "madly extremist". The plan's points are: never agree to economic and monetary union; revoke the powers of European courts over Britain; regain control of fisheries and agricultural policies; Britain to make its own foreign and defence policies; and reform of the European Parliament.

They point out that the driving force behind the group is Mike Penning, who now serves as one of the most senior press officers at Central Office. Mr Penning is the former organiser of the anti-European Tory MPs who lost the whip under John Major. Simon Buckby, campaign director for Britain in Europe, said: "It is shame that some people who ought to know better are still wasting their time in groups like Cafe when 3m British jobs and a third of our trade depends on our place in Europe." Mr Whittingdale is a powerful force behind the scenes in Tory circles, where his formal role as Mr Hague's "bag carrier" belies his influence. A former PPS to Lady Thatcher, Mr Whittingdale is said to play an important role in "bridging" the Thatcher and Hague camps. Anti-Europeans were delighted with Mr Whittingdale when Lady Thatcher hijacked last year's party conference with her claim that all Britain's problems came from continental Europe. Pro-Europeans were dismayed, believing Mr Whittingdale had allowed Lady Thatcher to demonstrate how the Tories were unelectable. Mr Whittingdale is a strong supporter of Cafe's five-point plan, branded by pro-Europeans as "madly extremist". The plan's points are: never agree to economic and monetary union; revoke the powers of European courts over Britain; regain control of fisheries and agricultural policies; Britain to make its own foreign and defence policies; and reform of the European Parliament.

fields.headline: Look what's landed in Brum
fields.standfirst: The gloom of Birmingham's Bull Ring centre is about to be lifted by an amazing new Selfridges store, writes  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: The gloom of Birmingham's Bull Ring centre is about to be lifted by an amazing new Selfridges store, writes Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
List six architectural landmarks in central Birmingham (readers from the West Midlands are excluded from this part of the article). The Rotunda. The Town Hall. Spaghetti Junction. St Chad's by Pugin - the first Roman Catholic cathedral built since the Reformation. And, erm, the aqueduct? I'm sure there's an aqueduct somewhere between Birmingham and the dams of the Elan Valley.

I'm not trying to be cynical. Despite a lacing of fascinating Georgian and Victorian buildings, and brave attempts to make its canals into new urban arteries and its central squares hotbeds of new public art, Birmingham's architecture remains strangely unmemorable. The centre, the Bull Ring, was blitzed in the war and then rebuilt dismally, save for the Rotunda, and is being rebuilt again in a trashy, flashy way, as if the city were determined to be known for its philistinism.

Help, however, is at hand from an unlikely source: Future Systems, the studio of radical architects fronted by Amanda Levete and Jan Kaplicky, who designed the gloriously original new press pavilion at Lord's cricket ground in London.

Future Systems has been commissioned by Selfridges to design its new Birmingham store as part of the Bull Ring redevelopment. Work begins this autumn, and should be completed in 2002. What it will offer Birmingham, aside from sophisticated shopping, is what we have learned to call a "landmark" building, one that cannot be missed and helps define the image of a city centre.

This martian spaceship-like building will be visible from the exit of Birmingham New Street, one of Britain's most wilfully banal railway stations. It is guaranteed to catch the eye of locals and visitors alike: a soft, organic form billowing seductively above the rooftops of existing shops and offices and acting as a foil to the spire of St Martin's church.

Central Birmingham is being remodelled along two new principal streets - one of which will be covered and will form part of a massive new shopping mall. This will house the main entrance to the Selfridges store. Apart from this, the building will be accessible only by a pedestrian bridge designed by Future Systems, leading from a multi-storey car park.

The blue store will thus help define the new-look Birmingham. It makes sense that this image will be dominated by modern buildings that are, effectively, air-conditioned covered markets, for the city has always been a great centre for getting and spending. It's a little sad, though, because while Birmingham is better known today for its conferences and summit meetings, its trade shows and its orchestra, it was also the working home of Boulton and Watt (and thus the steam engine); of Joseph Priestley, who discovered oxygen; and John Baskerville and his peerless typeface. Here, too, the X-ray was discovered, together with cotton wool and Cadbury's Creme Eggs. If New York is the Big Apple, Birmingham is the Mountainous Chocolate Egg.

In designing Selfridges, however, Future Systems has reconciled commerce, art and science in a building that reflects many of this landlocked city's virtues and inventions. The design is a fairly simple five-floor building penetrated by two amoeba-shaped atria and topped with a curvaceous roof-top garden and an ultra-modern restaurant. What makes the building so distinctive is its skin, a kind of architectural chain-mail, which will flow sinuously around the building. This is to be made from thousands of ceramic or coloured-aluminium discs in many shades of blue.

The new Selfridges will seem to be windowless, except for one large eye-window that peers out from behind the chain-mail and another that glides open and leads on to a balcony. If the building is all but hermetically sealed, this is because the area it is sited in is really no place to walk. The Bull Ring area is a kingdom for cars, with some of the fastest urban traffic in Europe.

Selfridges' chain-mail, says Kaplicky, was inspired by the metal fabrics devised by fashion designer Paco Rabanne, who, incidentally, trained for 12 years as an architect. The clever thing about this second skin is that it allows a loose fit over the building. If an additional curve were required in the building's jellyfish-like profile, it would be easy to add some more discs curving up and over it. As a result, the building will appear to be softly structured, a design that should appeal across the board. It is so distinctive, however, that, in theory at least, Selfridges agrees with Levete and Kaplicky that the store will need no name. Everyone will know it is Selfridges as surely as shoppers do the great neo-classical store in London's Oxford Street.

While the architects will be able to shape the main restaurant and cafes, what they cannot do is control the shops inside the new store. These will be given over to individual brands and outlets, each with its house style - from the preppy New England look of Ralph Lauren to the slick European modern of Giorgio Armani.

The store will not have a conventional entrance. Instead of a wall of glass interrupted with a row of doors, customers will enter through nothing more than a screen of steel mesh, inspired again by the fabrics of Paco Rabanne. Security is hardly a problem inside these new malls: they seem to boast more CCTV cameras per square foot than the headquarters of the CIA.

If we must have these giant shops, they should at least be interesting as works of architecture. Future Systems has pulled off the trick, doing for Birmingham what Sir John Burnet did 90 years ago for London's Oxford Street with his original Selfridges store - a wonderful steel-framed structure that remains the one great building in a mile-long corridor of commercial schlock. Can you name five others?

webTitle: Heads warn of parents' revolt on class sizes

fields.headline: Heads warn of parents' revolt on class sizes
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A headteachers' leader yesterday urged the government to extend its class size pledge to older children or risk facing "a middle class revolt" among parents.
fields.body:
A headteachers' leader yesterday urged the government to extend its class size pledge to older children or risk facing "a middle class revolt" among parents.

Figures due on Wednesday are expected to reveal a further substantial fall in the size of infant classes, showing that the government is edging closer towards meeting its 1997 manifesto pledge. Tony Blair went to the polls promising to reduce class sizes for five, six and seven year olds to 30 or below by the next election. The statistics due to be published this week will confirm that class sizes are continuing to fall.

But teachers' leaders are deeply worried that the reduction has been secured at the expense of larger classes at the top end of primary school and at the bottom end of secondary.

Figures published in January showed that by last autumn, 171,000 children aged under seven remained in over-sized classes. Across the entire primary school sector, the pupil-teacher ratio had fallen to 23.5 from 23.7 in 1998. But class sizes in secondary schools had edged up, with 21.8 pupils per teacher, compared with 21.7 in 1998.

Yesterday David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said the plight of older children in large classes could no longer be ignored. "The government has reduced class sizes among younger primary children, as it said it would," he said. "But if it really wants to secure the middle class vote at the next election, it had better do something about the older age group. By tackling class sizes for younger primary children, the government has only bought itself a period of peace. Parents will revolt if they don't see equal progress being made elsewhere."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, agreed and called on the government to provide a detailed breakdown of the situation in secondary schools. "Larger class sizes mean pupils will do worse, not better, at Key Stage 3 tests, GCSE and A-level", he said. "Even the chancellor's Budget windfall will not help, as schools will spend the money on leaking roofs and new computers, not extra staff to reduce class sizes.

Meanwhile, teachers will challenge the government this week overplans to force staff to "inform on colleagues" by supplying information to external assessors concerning those teachers who apply to go onto a higher pay scale. On Wednesday an application by the National Union of Teachers for a judicial review of the government's handling of the proposal will be heard at the high court. On the same day, MPs will be lobbied at Westminster by NUT members protesting at the broader plans for performance-related pay, due to start in September.

An early day motion condemning the plan and calling for a re-think is being tabled today by Phil Willis, the Liberal Democrat education spokesman, saying teachers will be put in an "invidious position" by being required to supply information on colleagues who apply to go onto a higher pay scale, linked to classroom results.

Doug McAvoy, NUT general secretary, said: "The government is imposing on all teachers a new duty which requires them to inform on their colleagues who apply to cross the threshold. Government attempts at damage limitation do not detract from the fact that this requirement will be placed on all teachers by statute unless the courts order the government to pursue the issue through full consultation.

"This nasty little scheme will divide teacher against teacher. it will not promote high quality teaching or education of pupils."
