webTitle: Caine gives Bafta tributes a cutting edge

fields.headline: Caine gives Bafta tributes a cutting edge
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: After his star turn at the Oscars, quite a lot of people now know Michael Caine is the king of acceptance speeches. But last night the man who made his name playing working class outsiders dominated the Baftas by confessing that for much of his life he did not feel welcome in his own country.
fields.body:
After his star turn at the Oscars, quite a lot of people now know Michael Caine is the king of acceptance speeches. But last night the man who made his name playing working class outsiders dominated the Baftas by confessing that for much of his life he did not feel welcome in his own country.

There was a distinct edge to Caine's wit as he accepted a lifetime's achievement award. "I am getting used to these standing ovations and I like it," he said before taking a swipe at the British film industry. "It's very difficult to win an award round here ... They do make some strange choices. Jesus, I've made 85 movies and one only has won [a Bafta]. For most of my career I've felt like The Spy who came in from the Cold, that I did not belong in my own country or profession ... It has been cold out there. Maybe I feel a little more welcome in my own country now."

Caine, who was a tax exile in the 1970s, became emotional as said that as a south Londoner with a "duff accent" he felt excluded and from the charmed circle of drama school graduates who dominated British stage and screen. He also chided the judging panel for not giving him a Bafta for The Cider House Rules for which he won an Oscar for best supporting actor.

For the rest, the night went almost to Oscar form. Although American Beauty went one better than its Oscar tally of five, including the Bafta for best film, there was nothing for its British director Sam Mendes. Instead that award went to the flamboyant Spaniard Pedro Almodovar for All About My Mother, a tragi-comedy in which a nun gets Aids from a transsexual prostitute.

Being John Malkovich won best screenplay, and Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow - which was made here - also won Baftas to make up for lost glory. But the biggest shock of all was Maggie Smith's winning of best supporting actress for Tea With Mussolini.

Just as at the Oscars, Pedro Almodovar provided the colour on an otherwise drab night. Picking up his second award for best foreign film, he said: "Thank you for not cutting me short with music [as happened at the Oscars] ... this feels like the beginning of my honeymoon with British audiences and I'm feeling horny."

Christina Kubrick, daughter of director Stanley Kubrick, accepted a posthumous Bafta fellowship on behalf of her father who died last year just before his last film, Eyes Wide Shut, was released. She said she doubted whether her father, the maker of 2001: A Space Odyssey, and a Clockwork Orange, would have accepted the Bafta himself even if he were alive. "He was not one for public things like this."

Annette Bening was best actress for American Beauty and Jude Law won best supporting actor for her role in Anthony Minghella's Talented Mr Ripley.

There was joy for East is East, the low-budget comedy set in a Salford fish and chip shop which last month became the most successful fully-funded British film ever. It won the Alexander Korda Award for the outstanding British film.

fields.headline: Softly, softly
fields.standfirst: Evidence of the clandestine activities of military intelligence in Northern Ireland is being suppressedThe Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: British army documents passed to the Bloody Sunday inquiry allege that an IRA informer accused Martin McGuinness of firing a shot from a submachine gun that sparked the shootings by British soldiers. The informer, codenamed Infliction, appears to have made the allegation in 1984, more than 12 years after the event.
fields.body:
British army documents passed to the Bloody Sunday inquiry allege that an IRA informer accused Martin McGuinness of firing a shot from a submachine gun that sparked the shootings by British soldiers. The informer, codenamed Infliction, appears to have made the allegation in 1984, more than 12 years after the event.

Sinn Fein has dismissed it as a dirty trick, an attempt to embarrass its chief negotiator. We do not yet know whether this is part of the army's sinister agenda. We may never know despite the inquiry's stated determination to get to the truth.

Meanwhile, another investigation is under way. It is not entirely unrelated, though it appears to be rather less thorough. Indeed, if the ministry of defence has its way, it will be suppressed.

Martin Ingram - not his real name - is a former member of the army's force research unit (FRU), a clandestine cell within the intelligence corps set up to handle informants in the IRA and loyalist paramilitary groups. Last year, he revealed that a "covert methods of entry" team - another undercover cell in military intelligence - burned offices occupied by Sir John Stevens, the new Metropolitan police commissioner, at Carrickfergus, near Belfast.

At the time, Stevens was deputy chief constable of Cambridgeshire and investigating allegations of collusion between military intelligence and loyalist terrorist groups. He was preparing to arrest Brian Nelson, one of the FRU's key agents who was acting as an intelligence officer for the Ulster Freedom Fighters. Nelson was jailed in 1992 on a number of counts of conspiracy to murder.

The attack on Stevens' offices took place during the night of January 10 1990, a few hours before Nelson - FRU's agent number 6137 - was due to be arrested. According to a classified army file, "6137's appointment enables him to make sure that sectarian killings are not carried out but that proper targeting of PIRA [Provisional IRA] members takes place prior to any shootings".

According to Ingram, Nelson's handlers thought that burning down Stevens' offices would give them "a little bit of time to construct an alternative cover story". Hours before his arrest, Nelson was tipped off by the FRU who had in turn been tipped off by the RUC special branch. Though he was eventually arrested, none of the files suggesting that the army recruited him to refine the targeting of UFF murder squads emerged during his brief trial.

Ingram has also disclosed information about the death of Neil Clarke, a private in the 2nd battalion the Queen's regiment, who was killed by a sniper during an attack on an army patrol in Derry in 1984.

Clarke was allegedly killed by a rifle from an arms stockpile controlled by an FRU informer within the IRA. Shortly before Clarke's death, the FRU informer is said to have told his handlers that an IRA go-between had asked for rifles from the stockpile. It would have been possible for the army to sabotage the weapons, but senior officers decided not to act for fear of blowing the informer's cover.

Last November, days after Ingram's disclosures first appeared in the Sunday Times, Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary, obtained a court in junction banning the newspaper from publishing any information from Ingram. Hoon's attempt to prevent repetition of information that had already been published, and even to reveal that it had been gagged, was dismissed by the courts.

"When I confronted the truth about certain operations I was privy to as a member of a specialist military unit, including an illegal arson attack by army personnel in 1990 to destroy incriminating evidence in a police headquarters", Ingram wrote later, "Hoon's reaction was to seek an injunction. The aim was clear: to prevent material of an embarrassing or sensitive nature, sourced from a former security force member, entering the public domain".

He told the Sunday Times: "As a young man in my early 20s, I had a different view of life than I do now. Today I feel uneasy with my involvement in a unit that was responsible for all human intelligence gathered by army agents in Northern Ireland".

In December, the police, apparently acting on instructions from the Ministry of Defence, arrested a former army intelligence officer in its search for the whistleblower. The man was held for about 40 hours but never questioned about the fire in Stevens' offices.

As Britain's top policeman, Stevens is formally in charge of the hunt for Ingram. He is also heading an inquiry into the murder of Pat Finucane, a solicitor allegedly killed by the UFF with the collusion of the FRU. He is said to be reopening the investigation into the fire that burned down his offices in 1990.

Ingram has offered to give evidence about the fire. He has also offered to give evidence to the Bloody Sunday inquiry if he is allowed to testify anonymously. He has said he has seen intelligence files which showed the IRA was ordered on that day not to open fire, contradicting claims by the army that it expected its soldiers to be attacked.

The injunction, meanwhile, prevents newspapers from publishing any information he has about Bloody Sunday.

It would have been possible for the army to sabotage the weapons, but senior officers decided not to act for fear of blowing the informer's cover. Last November, days after Ingram's disclosures first appeared in the Sunday Times, Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary, obtained a court in junction banning the newspaper from publishing any information from Ingram. Hoon's attempt to prevent repetition of information that had already been published, and even to reveal that it had been gagged, was dismissed by the courts. "When I confronted the truth about certain operations I was privy to as a member of a specialist military unit, including an illegal arson attack by army personnel in 1990 to destroy incriminating evidence in a police headquarters", Ingram wrote later, "Hoon's reaction was to seek an injunction. The aim was clear: to prevent material of an embarrassing or sensitive nature, sourced from a former security force member, entering the public domain". He told the Sunday Times: "As a young man in my early 20s, I had a different view of life than I do now. Today I feel uneasy with my involvement in a unit that was responsible for all human intelligence gathered by army agents in Northern Ireland". In December, the police, apparently acting on instructions from the Ministry of Defence, arrested a former army intelligence officer in its search for the whistleblower. The man was held for about 40 hours but never questioned about the fire in Stevens' offices. As Britain's top policeman, Stevens is formally in charge of the hunt for Ingram. He is also heading an inquiry into the murder of Pat Finucane, a solicitor allegedly killed by the UFF with the collusion of the FRU. He is said to be reopening the investigation into the fire that burned down his offices in 1990. Ingram has offered to give evidence about the fire. He has also offered to give evidence to the Bloody Sunday inquiry if he is allowed to testify anonymously. He has said he has seen intelligence files which showed the IRA was ordered on that day not to open fire, contradicting claims by the army that it expected its soldiers to be attacked. The injunction, meanwhile, prevents newspapers from publishing any information he has about Bloody Sunday. richard.norton-taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: 85 N-plants 'needed to meet CO2 target'
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: At least 85 nuclear power stations must be built in Europe - including four in Britain - over the next 20 years if targets on emissions of carbon dioxide are to be met, according to a European Commission report.
fields.body:
At least 85 nuclear power stations must be built in Europe - including four in Britain - over the next 20 years if targets on emissions of carbon dioxide are to be met, according to a European Commission report.

The EU is committed to carbon dioxide reductions of 8% by 2010 and they are expected to be reduced further after that date in order to combat the threat of global warming - but as nuclear power is phased out, this will become increasingly difficult.

The report compiled by the London-based consultancy ERM Energy so alarmed the EC's energy and transport directorate at first that it was kept confidential but now officials have decided it should be released shortly to "stimulate debate" on the future of electricity generation in Europe.

Although the report concludes it is "highly unlikely" that the public will accept new nuclear stations being built in Europe, it says that without them legally binding targets to reduce emissions will be very difficult to maintain.

Electricity generation produces one third of all carbon emissions in Europe but nuclear power produces none. However, it is extremely expensive, according to the report, and has the side effect of producing nuclear waste and large quantities of plutonium which is a security threat.

The alternative energy sources which produce no carbon dioxide - renewable sources like solar and wind power, biogas from landfills, and crops to burn in power stations - are being developed too slowly. In some countries, notably the UK, there is great potential for these alternatives but lack of political will to harness them means they are unlikely to fill the gap.

The report says that despite increasing public and political opposition to nuclear power, particularly in Germany, it is important to keep them in production to meet the Kyoto target for the EU of reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 8% by 2010.

Most nuclear stations were designed for 25 to 30 years but the report says they should be retained for 40 years. Some in Britain have already been given licences to run for 45 years.

Europe can meet its 8% reduction target on 1990 levels by 2010 by keeping existing nuclear stations open and continuing the switch from coal generation of electricity to gas. Modern gas stations produce half the carbon dioxide of older coal plants to provide the same amount of power.

After 2010, as nuclear stations are switched off and electricity demands rise, targets will not be met, says the report. The options to switch to gas will have mostly run out and renewables will not be able to meet the shortfall.

In 1995, the base year for the report, 23% of the EU's power came from nuclear sources. By 2025, without building any new nuclear plant, but keeping existing stations going, the nuclear share will have dropped to 9%. By shutting stations earlier as Germany and Sweden wish to do, the nuclear share would drop to 1%, the report says.

The UK produces around 20% of its power from nuclear stations now; and this will drop to 7% in 25 years. Four new stations the size of Sizewell B in Essex at 1,200 megawatts would be needed to make up the shortfall but the electricity would be too expensive.

If no nuclear power stations are built, then the targets would be exceeded by 15% in 2025.

webTitle: Can the food trucks get there in time?

fields.headline: Can the food trucks get there in time?
fields.standfirst:
International neglect, war and three years of drought have left refugees in Ethiopia at the end of the aid queue

Ethiopia 2000: special report
fields.trailText: In a dusty compound on the outskirts of the Ethiopian desert town of Gode, 300 women and children are squatting in the dirt. There is no shade so the mothers hold their faded robes over their listless children.
fields.body:
In a dusty compound on the outskirts of the Ethiopian desert town of Gode, 300 women and children are squatting in the dirt. There is no shade so the mothers hold their faded robes over their listless children.

Occasionally an aid worker distributes water from a plastic bucket. When the queue moves forward, the shuffling feet raise clouds of red dust.

The queue ends at a pair of scales and a large ruler fixed to the wall of a hut. Here, workers from the Ogaden Welfare Society (OWS) - a local relief agency working for British and US aid groups - weigh and measure every child.

The more lively children hang laughing from the hook of the scale as if on a playground swing. Others, with the hollow eyes and distended bellies of malnutrition, dangle limply in its harness.

The statistics stack up in the register: Fadumo Sabdi is 75% of the normal bodyweight for her age, Xamdi Abdi 60% and Shagri Abdi 55%. Alis Mandid Aqasdir is one year old, and at 4.4kg, just over 9lb, 46% of normal bodyweight.

These are the lucky ones. They will be given high-energy porridge and biscuits three times a day until they are strong again.

The United Nations says 8m people in Ethiopia and another 8m elsewhere in East Africa are threatened with starvation. Gode is in the centre of Ogaden, the region worst affected by the current crisis. For tens of thousands that threat is already a reality.

"It is a very, very serious situation," said Mohammed Ugo Mohammed, the local director of OWS. "People are dying every day and unless we get substantial supplies quickly things will deteriorate fast."

Relief is beginning to trickle through. Last week 30,000 tonnes of food unloaded in Djibouti - the independent port state to Ethiopia's north - had reached the distribution centre of Combolcha, near the eastern town of Dire Dawa.

The aid had been sent by the UN World Food Programme (WFP) was yesterday being transported by trucks chartered by the Ethiopian government towards Ogaden. A second ship carrying 30,000 tonnes will arrive in 10 days and an American ship with 85,000 tonnes of food on board by the end of the month.

"There are trucks heading everywhere," said a WFP spokesperson. "The ships are being unloaded in record time and we are getting the relief out to the people who need it."

One problem is that no one knows how bad the famine is. Most of those affected are semi-nomadic pastoralists who wander the arid areas of the south and east of Ethiopia and surrounding countries, in search of grazing land.

The death toll could be 'only' in the hundreds nationwide, or it could be several thousand in Ogaden alone. Aid workers have visited a few more remote settlements. Some are deserted. In others people are holding on even though most of their cattle are dead. The surrounding desert is littered with animal carcasses.

There are reports of worse problems in war-torn Somalia. And the WFP is very concerned about pockets in southern Borena district close to the Kenyan border and northern Welo province, near the area hit by major famines in 1984.

So far at least this famine is on a far smaller scale than its predecessor. In 1984 a million people are thought to have died. Now it seems there is still time to avert a major disaster.

The question is how many people will perish before sufficient aid reaches them. The Ethiopian government's emergency food stocks have been allowed to run low and the shortfall has caused serious problems in the early stages of the relief effort.

Burhane Gizaw, the deputy commissioner of the government's Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Committee, blames the shortfall on western donors who have failed to deliver promised aid.

"They told us to hand out our own stocks and they would replenish them... but they never did," he said. "We are now down to less than two weeks supply."

The WFP has admitted to delays in delivering 52,000 tonnes that were promised early last year and the European Union and the US government - though they have now pledged more than 800,000 tonnes - owe the reserves huge quantities of aid.

The Ethiopian prime minister, Meles Zenawi, last week criticised the international community for ignoring repeated requests for assistance.

In turn, the Ethiopian government has been attacked for distributing food without proper targeting. The government is unpopular internationally for continuing a costly war with Eritrea. The war has no clear cause. Ethiopia granted Eritrea its independence seven years ago, ending more than two decades of conflict.

But in 1998 fighting flared again after mutual accusations of border violations. It is costing both countries a great deal of money that neither can afford. Addis Ababa recently imposed restrictions on foreign exchange after it became clear that it was running out of hard currency. It is believed the money was spent on weapons.

Privately, western diplomats in both countries say the war is a key reason for the recent delay in aid reaching the region. According to aid officials in Gode, only a major airlift will get enough food in fast enough to prevent hundreds more deaths.

The WFP is hoping to bring in at least two flights of aid early this week. Much of the food will be destined for Dana - a village 50 miles south of Gode. More than 9,000 refugees are camped on the arid plain on its ouskirts. It has not rained for three years.

The refugees have all left their homes in the Ogaden interior and walked for days in the hope of finding food. Aid agencies have been stretched to the limit by the influx. Water tankers run by Save The Children deliver only enough for a litre for each refugee a day and WFP has been able to distribute food to only a third of the families. The rest lie in the shade of their huts, waiting for help. Every day a dozen or so corpses are buried on the fringe of the camp.

Ahmed Hashi, a 40 year-old farmer, walked 80 miles to Danan from his village of Palaap with his family. Six of his 10 children have died and two others are too weak to stand. "I am begging God to help me," he said.

Aid workers fear the lack of water will lead to outbreaks of disease. Already tuberculosis is rife among the younger children. Mohammed Ugo Mohammed said: "If the rains do not come this year there will still be a catastrophe. Whole regions of the country will need feeding. They have no animals and no crops."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The man on the door of Zimbabwe's parliament confirmed that this was the day its members would lay to rest the worst legacy of British imperialism. Black honour would be restored, he opined. For too long Zimbabweans had been forced to do things the white man's way. But he insisted that a collar and tie was still obligatory for anyone wanting to watch. It wasn't so much a debate as a competition to see who could most fervently endorse President Robert Mugabe's proposal to amend the constitution so his government can seize white-owned farms and demand that Britain meet the cost of compensation to the flotsam of empire.
fields.body:
The man on the door of Zimbabwe's parliament confirmed that this was the day its members would lay to rest the worst legacy of British imperialism. Black honour would be restored, he opined. For too long Zimbabweans had been forced to do things the white man's way. But he insisted that a collar and tie was still obligatory for anyone wanting to watch. It wasn't so much a debate as a competition to see who could most fervently endorse President Robert Mugabe's proposal to amend the constitution so his government can seize white-owned farms and demand that Britain meet the cost of compensation to the flotsam of empire.

The speeches by the "honourable comrades" were full of fury at the legacy of British rule. Cecil Rhodes came in for particular venom. The land grab by white settlers 110 years ago was the "unfinished business" in Zimbabwe, they said. Then the MPs burst into a revolutionary war song and ululated in front of the mace until Comrade Speaker beckoned for order. In many respects Zimbabwe's parliament has changed little from colonial days. It's MPs sit on the same Westminster-style benches that once housed Ian Smith and his illegal regime after its unilateral declaration of independence.

Today the MPs are "honourable comrades" and their dealings with each other are a model of civility by the standards of Westminster. But then the government front bench stares straight into the faces of the government front bench. There are only three opposition MPs among the 150 members and they are consigned to the very back. If you want to hear criticism of the government, go to the Anglican cathedral next door. "Prayer meetings" include robust talk about Mr Mugabe.

Parliament's civility extends to portraits of Britain's Queen hanging in the corridor. One was painted shortly after her coronation when Zimbabwe was the colony of Southern Rhodesia. The other is from the 60s when Mr Smith still insisted on his loyalty to the crown. Before Mr Mugabe elevated himself to president he was a prime minister and self-declared Marxist revolutionary who must have wandered past the paintings almost daily. But they remained securely on the wall.

When it was suggested to Comrade Speaker, Cyril Ndebele, last week that perhaps the portraits of the Queen were outdated, and should come down, he was genuinely astonished. Nobody had ever said that before. He wouldn't hear of it. Perhaps the real surprise is that Margaret Thatcher wasn't similarly honoured. She is viewed with great favour by Zimbabwe's leaders. One MP called her a woman of honour whose promise to pay for land redistribution had been broken by that treacherous Tony Blair. He wondered how the British could have let such a fine woman slip through their fingers.

When it came to the vote on confiscating white land, those who supported the bill were told to shuffle to the right side of the house. The left stood empty. Mr Mugabe needed 100 votes to amend the constitution and that's exactly what he got. Or did he? Furious counting by Zimbabwean and foreign reporters in the press gallery could manage to account for no more than 98 MPs. But no one could be sure of the accuracy of this informal count because voting in Zimbabwe's parliament is an artful affair in which names are ticked off a list while the members mill around making it very difficult to check.

The Honourable Comrade Minister for Industry and Commerce, Nathan Shamuyarira, led the government's charge in the debate so he seemed a logical person to seek out of comment. He announced he had "written for the Guardian when it was a good newspaper, when it told the truth about Zimbabwe". The MPs celebrations over the land issue were tempered by the realisation that it also marks the end of another era. On Tuesday, parliament will be dissolved ahead of elections next month. The opposition are expected to do well. For the first time in years, the government front benchers will finally get to look their opponents in the face.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what our top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what our top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
 Paul Maidment (editor, FT.com) in New Media Age www.nma.co.uk

Online is the future of news journalism in the UK, but it's the present in the US. Ask an American student if they get their news online and they'll say yes. Ask which sites they use and you'll probably hear Yahoo!, MSNBC, CNet or CNN.

That's not to say traditional publishers don't have a future online. But they must embrace publishing's new ground rules. These turn the basic assumption of print publishing on its head: that a publication aims to be the primary news source for its readers, and that, to tie in those readers, it creates its own content and distributes it exclusively.

It's the other way round on the web. A publication is but one news source among many: no news site can be an island. News sites have to create and aggregate. Yahoo! and other search engines-turned-portals may originally have aggregated content as they had none of their own, but whether traditional publishers like it or not, it established a format for news online.

[That means] publishing to others' sites - including competitors' - as well as one's own. Publishers must go where the customers are. That's keeping a brand alive, not diluting it. E-media is now arriving at the last battleground - that for being the trusted, reliable and authoritative guide through our information-saturated culture. It's the battle traditional newspaper publishers should still win - if they can just turn up in time.

 Rupert Staines (of ValueClick) in Revolution www.revolution.haynet.com

Why are people suspicious of online advertising - or should I say, the falling click-through ratios of banner campaigns? Or, put another way, when was the last time you jumped through a poster and discovered a whole world of information at your fingertips? Internet advertising is just that - it's immediate, it's instant.

However, those of us in marketing and advertising are barely past the internet "gestation" period, and to add to the confusion along comes a new "protocol" kid - Wap - relax, there's an incubator near you! There's no point getting carried away with the baby analogy, but the pace of change can be likened to a child's first years, only the pocket money buys you a lot more than sweets.

It's true that the online audience still does not resemble your typical A to E filled supermarket aisle, but this, we believe, will be the biggest transformation over the next two years as net accessibility becomes cheaper (or free!) and more widely available. With predictions of 19m internet users in the UK by the end of 2000, that represents a substantial marketing opportunity.

However, those of us in marketing and advertising are barely past the internet "gestation" period, and to add to the confusion along comes a new "protocol" kid - Wap - relax, there's an incubator near you! There's no point getting carried away with the baby analogy, but the pace of change can be likened to a child's first years, only the pocket money buys you a lot more than sweets. It's true that the online audience still does not resemble your typical A to E filled supermarket aisle, but this, we believe, will be the biggest transformation over the next two years as net accessibility becomes cheaper (or free!) and more widely available. With predictions of 19m internet users in the UK by the end of 2000, that represents a substantial marketing opportunity.

fields.headline: Lock up your mobile phones
fields.standfirst: Imogen O'Rorke  meets the new media ad team who want to take over your Wap and teach us all about online digital advertising
fields.trailText: Imogen O'Rorke meets the new media ad team who want to take over your Wap and teach us all about online digital advertising
fields.body:
There is trouble afoot in loaferville. Traditional advertising agencies - the companies who in the 90s prided themselves on being at the cutting edge of creative thinking - are increasingly under threat from a new breed of new media upstarts, who claim they are better equipped to service a market that is changing and subdividing at a frightening rate.

Last month, the newest branch of the new media economy won a PR victory when it produced the first Wapvert in Britain. It was a 60-character-long text message that popped up in the middle of regular Fonedata services and directed fans of Manchester, Liverpool and Newcastle to the WML site of Football 365, where they could get all the latest footie news.

It was a blip on the landscape, hardly a creative epiphany. The 100,000-odd UK Wap phone owners probably hardly noticed the two-second teaser before it was lost on the airwaves (which wouldn't have mattered since it was intended for the more advanced Scandinavian market), but it was a significant step towards the future.

The 'vert in question was a collaboration between Media 21, a media buyer turned online ad agency, in conjunction with 24/7 Europe, a new media ad sales and strategy bureau. It is companies like these, working out of Clerkenwell and Shoreditch, the heartland of London's new media community, who are poised to clean up in this fast-growing economy.

Many of them were founded by frustrated employees of traditional agencies, who, even if they do have interactive departments, are finding it increasingly difficult to keep staff. The brain drain is not just confined to publishing.

Media 21, which has a staff of 17 and an average age of 28, has just celebrated its first birthday. One of its first clients was Sky, and since then it has worked for Emap, QXL, Bol and upmystreet.com - all sizeable brands. Next month, it is moving out of the offices of Deepend (another shape-shifting "digital solutions" agency which serves roasted vegetables and feta salad in its kitchen) into its own and is planning to recruit 50 new staff next year.

"The phones have not stopped ringing," confirms Pete Robins, 28, who not too long ago was a media planner at Modem Media. His co-founders are Nick Suckley, 30, formerly content manager at McCann-Erickson and Rick Sareen, 43, who came from Lowe-Spink.

"We realised the companies we worked for didn't have a clue about online digital advertising - they were stuck in the analogue world," says Suckley. "They were either ignoring interactive technology or they weren't structurally equipped to deal with it." Like Razorfish, Xceed, Agency.com, Deepend, erstwhile design companies who now offer "total marketing" from design through to brand consultancy and e-commerce, Media 21 have positioned themselves at the forefront of the market.

The agencies are panicking. While they hold board meetings to decide how to move forward and dispatch reps off to interactive TV conferences with such titles as "Challenging the way we view advertising", the new kids on the block are picking off their loyal clients, one by one.

So what exactly are the new challenges facing advertisers? Is it just about diversification or does their whole approach have to be reappraised? "They have to look at the market from the 30,000ft level," suggests Stephen Griffiths, manager of M-business at Agency. "Adverts are an ancillary thing. Agencies have to look at their clients' infrastructure holistically - it's about integrated marketing strategy."

A visit to Agency's website is a crash course in the new organic marketing. It offers to "deepen customer relationships online", adopting a "philosophical approach to strategic planning". It is not enough, they claim, for companies to simply assert their brands online, they have to "live it!"

Advertisers want to be taken in hand and guided. In response to a slew of inquiries about wireless advertising, digital consultancy firm Ovum has commissioned a report on the subject, out in May. Eden Zoller, Ovum's senior consultant, believes the future "is advertising which is dressed up not to look like advertising"; in other words value-added services such as discounts, offers, coupons, loyalty schemes and 100% sponsorship. Stick to the Yellow Pages model and you will be OK, is the message.

Not enough research has yet been done to ascertain whether consumers will permit advertising on their personal mobile service. Ovum's statistics suggest that professionals are fairly open-minded about receiving advertising - if it means a reduction in the service costs. But in America, SkyTel's advertising experiments with pagers produced an adverse reaction - consumers complained.

Mark Nall, sales director at 24/7, believes that wireless will not be a viable media market until third generation technology and the "always on" service. "With GPRS [general packet radio system - the next step after Wap] customers are going to have to pay to download data packets. The question that advertisers have to answer is, how are they going get customers to pay for the privilege?"

The opposite is true of interactive TV where broadcasters are looking into paying customers to download their adverts, but essentially both models will follow the Permission Marketing model, a phrase coined by the marketing guru of the moment Seth Godwin, courting the customer's attention with a raft of "value-added" services.

The current issue of Revolution magazine, which carries a special online advertising report, drives home the basic message that interruptive advertising - analogue TV and radio adverts and click-through banner ads - is a thing of the past. The way forward is vertical and targeted.

The future for wideband is Rich Media advertising - banner ads which enable the visitor to transact without leaving a site, or, say, a beauty site which works like a Cosmopolitan quiz, giving personalised answers and tips back in return for information.

"From the PC-based internet onwards, it is only going to get more complicated. From above the line advertising right the way through to virtual retailing, advertising will be service driven - content is king," says Mark Nall. "A sophisticated digital audience is emerging who are sitting at home accessing information, entering into commerce relationships."

Saatchi and Saatchi is one of the few old agencies which has its online act together - as a multinational it has no choice. "We don't separate our online and offline arms - in new media communication and commerce are the same thing," says Nick Kojey-Strauss, the agency's MD of e-commerce. They are currently working on short message service (SMS), Wap and interactive TV ads for clients. "We transform brands - companies that exist offline, online and start-ups."

Back at Media 21, they're raring to go. "We haven't got to the starting line in the race yet - but we wanted to set a precedent," says Robins. They accept that part of the learning process will involve "experimenting and pissing off a few customers on the way".

Behind a barrage of multiple new formats they are working in, which include Wapverts, splash screen, text messages on Amstrad's new email phone and interactive TV, there is a simple logic: "The creative message is less important online than who it is sent to, when, how, when, how often and in what medium," says Robins.

It is the difference between the second world war blanket bomb campaign and the smart bomb - the ultimate killing application of the 90s. Companies have paid a heavy price in the past for what is known as the "ready, shoot, aim" approach to above-the-line online advertising. Advertising executives are now talking about "through the line" and "one to one".

In an industry that is estimated to be worth hundreds of billions of dollars in commerce alone within four years, can the traditional advertising agencies afford to lag behind?

webTitle: Barb has lost its stinging power

fields.headline: Barb has lost its stinging power
fields.standfirst: View from Cannes
fields.trailText: View from Cannes
fields.body:
If you go down to the MIP TV programme market at Cannes today, you could be in for a big surprise. The suits can usually be seen marching between meetings in a swirl of borrowed Gauloises chic, but this year you might find them thrashing around in the sand, shouting at the sea. They are the King Cannes-utes of television, fighting back the waves of internet invaders.

The internet will have the same revolutionary impact on the TV industry as television had on cinema, both as a commercial space and a source of entertainment and information. It will help to get rid of wasteful, pointless television, but it will not replace it. This is a very exciting prospect for everyone who believes in the box as a positive cultural force. It is also a very worrying time for those who have cynically (and boringly) exploited the distribution monopoly of mainstream media.

The main reason for this is advertising. Ever since TV became the public's favourite trivial pursuit, advertisers have been working on ways of creating space between the programmes - hence ad-friendly formats such as soap and sitcom, which soon replaced the broadcast of full-length plays in the 50s as the staple diet of commercial TV.

The problem was, and is, that most adverts miss the mark. Not because there is anything wrong with them, but because of the wastage involved in conventional schedules and breaks. For every one person who wants to know about your product, there are thousands, if not millions, who would rather put the kettle on, or stare at the cat. Even though, in some cases, they may not own either. All this, on the internet at least, is set to change.

The television ratings compiler, Barb, is a crumbling currency. The more fragmented the media world becomes, the more inappropriate and irrelevant a panel-based system appears to be. In the digital age, buying ratings with Barb is a bit like purchasing a car with a bag of sweets, time-consuming and a bit creepy.

Advanced picture compression and streaming technology on the internet, precipitated by an ongoing battle for supremacy between Microsoft Media Player, Apple Quicktime and Real Player, has opened up a global portal for the broadcasting of quality sound and pictures. It has created an alternative world of distribution and consumption, in which viewers choose content in their own time and place - at home, work or on their mobile phone.

The commercial potential of streaming technology is enormous. After establishing a relationship with a viewer (using old-fashioned entertainment and inspiration), the internet broadcaster can stream relevant adverts into the programme content when viewers give them permission to do so. Meanwhile, the web server picks up who is watching and for how long they are on line. This information is then added to a vast database and processed for individual programme reports. For the first time, ratings will be accurate; advertisers will get exactly what they pay for and viewers will have a say in what, when and how they view programming - for free.

Independent producers should therefore think carefully about selling exclusive internet rights to their programmes before studying all the options available to them. They may want to develop broadcast distribution channels of their own, either exclusively or in partnership with internet platforms.

Cable, satellite and digital terrestrial TV channels are all excellent means of delivering millions of hours of enhanced content to the world, especially for "event" programming. However, access to the delivery "pipes" is limited to a few owners and distribution is either expensive (multi-channel TV is still a luxury) or restricted to a few free terrestrial channels.

The beauty and strength of the internet is that nobody and everybody owns it. If you are an independent producer with quality content, the cost of encoding and distributing your content for distribution on the internet is exactly the same as it would be for a major Hollywood studio. So why bother getting lost in a library where you can't make any noise?

My company, ichooseTV.com, is in Cannes with a warning to producers and content-owners not to limit the distribution opportunities of their programmes. Beware the exclusive licence deal unless it offers unlimited access to people who want to view your work in a controlled, accountable environment.

With personalised schedules, "smartcasting" and streamed commercials via the internet, cost-effective programme distribution for everyone is possible at last.

So there is no need to fight them on the beaches - the ISPs and TV portals are allies of old media. Streamed sound and picture quality is improving every day and with it our chances of working together to change the future of television. Just don't wait and see - or someone else will do it first.

 Richard Kilgarriff is CEO at ichooseTV.com, which unveils its plans for a free personalised internet television service at MIP TV this week

fields.headline: Need to know: Dick Hopple
fields.trailText: Age: 53.
fields.body:
Age: 53.

Who's he? CEO of Unicast, which pioneers superstitial internet advertising technology. Former president of advertising agency Wells Rich Greene and US president of DMB&B.

What's the clever idea? Superstitials are a new way of advertising on the net. Before superstitials, advertisers used banner ads, with outdoor billboard-like visuals. Advertisers want more intrusive formats, but the websites can't degrade the user experience by anything that will, for example, slow down the load time. Superstitial solves that problem by loading ads when you have already loaded a page and are reading it. The modem is idle, so we don't slow down page loads. When you click from one page to another, that's the trigger for the ad to play. Because it's all loaded in your machine, it doesn't take ages to load like a web page. So while banners play as part of the page, a superstitial plays between pages.

What's the thinking behind it?

The internet gets a large audience, but in terms of creative flexibility it doesn't score highly. Banner ads are a limited message, and the consumer is doing other things while reading. Because we came out of the advertising world as opposed to the technology world, we refused to believe that banners were the endgame, and believed we could develop technology that provides advertisers with the kind of experience they want, without interrupting the experience users want.

What are the advantages? The main benefit is in creative flexibility. It is another dimension, a medium more like TV. Secondly, there is a standard definition of an impression. There are no standard formats for banners, so an advertiser buying 10 websites will have to do four or five versions of an ad. We standardise all that. The average banner ad click-through is 0.3%; on a superstitial it's about 7.5%, and some will get 40%. The advertising is more prominent, because you can close the ad once it starts playing, but you can't stop it playing. The ads are more interesting, too. It's a comment on how effective advertisers can be on the internet.

Any disadvantages? It doesn't yet play on Macs, but will do within 30 days. As bandwidth increases and websites sell more advertising, and as agencies plan how to make ads more effective on the net, the ads will get better, but we don't see that there are a lot of drawbacks to the technology. It's still light-years ahead of anything else.

What's next? We need to make sure that the superstitial is established as the standard in Europe, the way it is becoming in the US. As bandwidth increases the quality we offer will rise. At the moment superstitials are being used on most of the major specialised vertical portals, such as CBS Sportsline and Bloomberg, but it's not yet widely used on the big general portals like Yahoo! and Lycos. We see that as a challenge.

webTitle: Sharif set for grilling on wealth

fields.headline: Sharif set for grilling on wealth
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan's new regime says the deposed prime minister bought Park Lane apartments with stolen money

Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: Pakistan's jailed former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, is to be interrogated this week over claims that he stole hundreds of millions of pounds during his time in power, depositing much of the money in offshore accounts based in Britain.
fields.byline: Luke Harding  and  Rory McCarthy  in Islamabad
fields.body:
Pakistan's jailed former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, is to be interrogated this week over claims that he stole hundreds of millions of pounds during his time in power, depositing much of the money in offshore accounts based in Britain.

Sharif, who last week received two life sentences for hijacking and terrorism, will be asked how he was able to purchase four Park Lane apartments. Investigators have discovered that the Mayfair properties are registered to two offshore companies in the British Virgin Islands.

At the weekend officials accused Sharif of concealing ownership of the properties at the time of his 1997 election victory and formally registered a corruption case against him. He faces four other corruption charges, with at least seven more cases pending.

In a sign that General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military leader, has not finished with the man he toppled, Sharif is expected to appear in court again this month and faces the prospect of several lengthy corruption trials stretching over several years.

"Sharif was involved in evasion of taxes, money laundering, circumventing procedures and railroading legislation specifically to benefit family concerns," Farouk Adam Khan, the chief corruption prosecutor, said. "We would like to confront him with information we have collected."

Sharif's six co-defendants, who were last week acquitted in the hijacking case, have been arrested again. His brother Shahbaz, a former chief minister of Punjab, has been moved to the Attock Fort jail, pending a corruption trial. Mr Sharif is expected to appeal against his terrorism conviction today.

Investigators have been attempting to trace his assets since he was detained following the military coup in October. They claim that he siphoned off "hundreds of millions of pounds" from Pakistan throughout his politcal career, hiding the money in Jersey, Guernsey and Switzerland.

Sources at Pakistan's national accountability bureau say that Mr Sharif concealed ownership of his Park Lane apartments by registering them in the name of two British Virgin Island offshore companies.

The flats are managed by a firm of British solicitors. The companies have two Swiss bankers as nominees.

"We believe the money used to buy these apartments was stolen from the people of Pakistan," Mr Khan added.

Sharif, who is 50, allegedly bought the properties with money borrowed from state-run Pakistani banks, and failed to repay it. Although technically bankrupt, he is one of Pakistan's richest men. He owns an estate, several townhouses and a lucrative steel, sugar, textile and paper empire. All these are registered to his wife Kulsoom, daughter Mariam and other relatives. They deny impropriety.

"Having property is not illegal. The Sharif family is not at all corrupt and insh'allah (God willing) we will prove it one day," Mrs Sharif said recently. "The Park Lane flats were bought because the children were studying in London."

For the past six months investigators have been piecing together how Sharif's wealth increased by 800% since his appointment as Punjab chief minister in 1985, and between 1990-1993, when he first became prime minister.

He is accused of failing to pay tax on a Russian Mi-8 helicopter, not declaring income tax and defaulting on two loans worth £24m.

webTitle: Prescott seeks £2bn 'quick fix' for rail network

fields.headline: Prescott seeks £2bn 'quick fix' for rail network
fields.standfirst:
Transport in Britain: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott has promised to pump up to £2bn into the railways in advance of the next general election if the industry can produce immediate improvements.
fields.body:
John Prescott has promised to pump up to £2bn into the railways in advance of the next general election if the industry can produce immediate improvements.

The deputy prime minister's offer to the shadow strategic rail authority would require it to invest in "quick fixes" such as relieving rail bottlenecks, improving track and making more trains run to time.

The offer has been made to Sir Alastair Morton, the SRA's chairman, who was anxious to help. But he has told Mr Prescott that it is difficult to come up with solutions which would make an impact soon enough.

Mr Prescott still has to obtain Treasury approval for the deal, and industry sources last night suggested that Sir Alastair would resign if he did not get the financial backing he is being offered.

Sir Alastair, a key member of Mr Prescott's railway team, and the architect of a new strategy for the railways, is also ill and is frequently working from home to produce a strategy which will be published in the summer.

Industry sources last night said that he may resign from his part-time job if he fails to convince the Government that more money is required to underpin the railways, whose expansion has confounded critics.

The railways have grown by at least 25 per cent since privatisation, are still growing and are carrying more passengers than in the years after the second world war.

Mr Prescott could ill afford the departure of such an important player as Sir Alastair before the next election. It would leave the industry rudderless at a time when it needs a coherence and leadership which has been lacking since privatisation.

Sir Alastair, who was brought in by Mr Prescott after advising the government on the Channel Tunnel rail link rescue bid, wants to negotiate at least two key franchises before the election and unveil a new strategy for the industry this summer.

While pleased at Mr Prescott's offer, Sir Alastair wants to ensure that it is not scuppered by the Treasury, as the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is forced to draw up his priorities for the election, of which health will be at the top of the list.

At the moment the Government is subsidising rail to the tune of £1.3bn this year, a figure which will reduce to £900m by 2002, and is then due to disappear altogether.

A senior industry source said: "Mr Prescott is very anxious to demonstrate that the railways have improved under his leadership. He would be delighted, and so would the SRA, if the authority could come up with an eyecatching project or two. But this is not an industry which can perform like that. It takes a long time to turn things around."

Train operating companies have been warning the government that unless their subsidies continue, they will not be interested in renewing their franchises.

webTitle: UK refuses to back plan for Europe car-free day

fields.headline: UK refuses to back plan for Europe car-free day
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Britain was last night at the centre of a row for being the only senior member of the European commission to reject plans for a Europe-wide car-free day on September 22.
fields.body:
Britain was last night at the centre of a row for being the only senior member of the European commission to reject plans for a Europe-wide car-free day on September 22.

France, Italy, Portugal and Spain have welcomed the idea but the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has indicated that the government will not back it. The Department of Transport said last night: "We are not supporting the plan, but local authorities in the UK will no doubt be running with their own events." It claimed people would quickly forget "one event on one day".

So far five local authorities are known to be backing the scheme: Camden in north London, Dover, Edinburgh, Newcastle and Poole.

Sir Richard Branson said Virgin would run free trains on the day if Mr Prescott relented.

fields.headline: Playing the race card
fields.standfirst:
The UN's rebuke to the Tories is justifiedTories in opposition: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservative party is under attack for making life worse for asylum seekers. Its manifesto for next month's local elections talks of the country being "flooded" by bogus applicants, manipulated by racketeers. The British representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees fears the language here is inflammatory and a breach of an undertaking which all party leaders have given not to incite or exploit prejudice for political gain. The party says this is nonsense and some of its adherents state it much more strongly than that. On Saturday the Daily Telegraph complained of "moral McCarthyism". "The race relations industry," it declared, "is rapidly becoming one of the greatest threats to British liberties."
fields.body:
The Conservative party is under attack for making life worse for asylum seekers. Its manifesto for next month's local elections talks of the country being "flooded" by bogus applicants, manipulated by racketeers. The British representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees fears the language here is inflammatory and a breach of an undertaking which all party leaders have given not to incite or exploit prejudice for political gain. The party says this is nonsense and some of its adherents state it much more strongly than that. On Saturday the Daily Telegraph complained of "moral McCarthyism". "The race relations industry," it declared, "is rapidly becoming one of the greatest threats to British liberties."

Whose liberties are they thinking of here? Clearly not those of the young black man, partner of a white woman, who was racially abused and then sprayed with petrol and set alight in Berinsfield, Oxfordshire on Friday. Nor those of the relatives of Errol and Jason McGowan, the two black men found dead in mysterious circumstances in Telford, Shropshire, who for weeks failed to convince West Mercia police that they might have been victims of a racial killing. Scotland Yard has become involved, and now there has been an apology and a pledge to carry out a thorough investigation. Nor those of Stephen Lawrence, or his friend Duwayne Brooks, or Michael Menson. It is not as if the UNHCR representative had tried to close down free speech by demanding a blanket ban on any mention of the asylum issue in political speeches. All Mr Hague is asked to do here is to remember and honour a pledge which he freely gave.

We need to remember why the "race relations industry", as its critics sneeringly call it, came into being. Though it sometimes seems hard to credit it, the climate before it started to operate was far worse than it is today. A conspicuous case is housing, where before the "industry" came into being it was standard practice for landlords to advertise property with the requirement "no blacks". People who in those days thought like the Telegraph now did not condone this practice. Indeed, they had a positive remedy for it: what we needed to do was deplore it. Fortunately the politicians were not content with that. They did not merely deplore; they legislated.

No one would claim that the performance of this "industry" has been faultless. But objective evidence - especially that of the annual British Social Attitudes survey - has over the years shown sign of heartening change, of old gut prejudice flaking. Professor Richard Berthoud of the Institute for Social and Economic Research, according to reports yesterday, has shown that Britain has the highest rate of interracial relationships in the world. That is a trend which no amount of racist revenge will reverse. People change: so do perceptions. Who would ever have dreamed that the death of the black MP Bernie Grant, once denounced by a Tory home secretary as "the high priest of race conflict", would bring a warm and even affectionate tribute from the chairman of the Conservative party?

Politicians have a duty to articulate people's fears, but they have to do so in ways which do not endorse or authenticate raw and dangerous prejudice. What they say helps create a climate. Liberty is not such an easy issue as some like to pretend. Freedom for the pike, as Tawney said, may mean death for the minnow. When the political right starts appealing to liberty, it is frequently up to no good. That is certainly so in this instance.

webTitle: Labour and Tories reported for 'inflammatory' asylum language

fields.headline: Labour and Tories reported for 'inflammatory' asylum language
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and William Hague are to be reported to the commission for racial equality for using inflammatory language to whip up hostility to asylum seekers.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and William Hague are to be reported to the commission for racial equality for using inflammatory language to whip up hostility to asylum seekers.

As the government unveiled plans to increase the number of detention centres, the Liberal Democrats lodged a formal complaint with the CRE condemning the Tories and Labour for exploiting the issue ahead of next month's local elections.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman, said: "There is growing concern that the struggle by the Conservative and Labour parties to be seen to be tough on asylum and immigration issues is motivated by short-term party political advantage. We pander to hostility to immigrants at our peril."

Mr Hughes has handed the CRE the Tories' local election manifesto, which talks of a "flood" of bogus asylum seekers, and speeches on the issue by ministers. His move came after the United Nations high commissioner for refugees censured Labour and the Tories for breaking an all-party commitment, organised by the CRE, not to stir up prejudice.

The UNHCR highlighted Mr Hague's local election manifesto, which complains of racketeers "flooding our country with bogus asylum seekers". Labour was criticised for using harsh language that ran against the spirit of the CRE commitment in which political leaders agreed not to "incite hostility" between racial groups.

The rare intervention by the non-partisan UNHCR sparked a furious debate over the weekend. Describing the Tories' language as "appalling", the Home Office minister Barbara Roche said: "They are, quite clearly in my view, attempting to play the race card. To play politics with this is a very dangerous thing to do."

However, Ms Roche underlined the government's determination to be seen to be acting in a tough manner against asylum seekers when she unveiled plans to set up more detention centres. As part of an attempt to prevent claimants from "melting away," ministers are examining plans to open new walled camps.

Her criticism of the Conservatives was condemned by the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe. Making clear that the Tories would stand by their controversial manifesto, Miss Widdecombe said: "No amount of abuse is going to divert us from speaking out on behalf of the millions of people in Britain who have been let down by Labour's failures."

However, there were signs of a shadow cabinet split when one of Miss Widdecombe's colleagues voiced unease about the harsh language being used about asylum. In an attack formally directed at the media, the shadow international development secretary, Gary Streeter, said: "We're talking about human beings, many of them being persecuted and fleeing for safety, and this country has a tradition of tolerance for genuine asylum seekers. Let's treat them like human beings and not like cattle."

Ms Roche also said she had been given pledges by Italian ministers that they would step up efforts to stop illegal immigrants hiding on trains and using Europe's rail network to enter Britain.

fields.headline: The art of power
fields.standfirst: Sky1's new series The West Wing creates a convincing US President in Martin Sheen. No easy task, says  Mark Lawson. And what's more, it even manages to tackle some some intelligent ideas
fields.trailText: Sky1's new series The West Wing creates a convincing US President in Martin Sheen. No easy task, says Mark Lawson. And what's more, it even manages to tackle some some intelligent ideas
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher was a problem for writers of political fiction. Until her rise, the prime minister in a novel or screenplay would be some generalised grey-hair, played by a character actor in late middle-age. But during the decade of Thatcherism, a male prime minister made the story seem dated or futuristic. And a female one would be identified directly as Thatcher, edging the fiction towards libel or satire.

In the 80s, James Bond found himself under the political control of the Thatcher-impersonator Janet Brown. Michael Dobbs, in his House Of Cards trilogy, deliberately set the stories far ahead, when Thatcher had handed over to a ruthless man, an instinct which turned out to be wrong politically but right dramatically. Sometimes a politician so changes the perception of the role that a fictional stand-in seems a pale impersonation.

Two American presidents have stalked the imagination in this way. After Nixon, viewers and readers wondered whether each fictional White House occupant had a dirty tricks team in the back room. Post-Clinton, any invented president who likes sex or lying is taken as a contemporary commentary, while any White House paragon on page or screen is assumed to be a corrective fantasy. American TV responded to Nixon with Behind Closed Doors - Watergate with the names changed. Its Clintonian equivalent has - perhaps fittingly - a more complicated relationship with the truth.

The West Wing (tonight, 9pm, Sky1) follows the story of President Josiah Bartlett, Democrat president of vast charm and dangerous evasions. In some ways it is a roman à clef, but one in which, in the manner of computer encryption programmes, the key has received maximum scrambling.

Clinton has already inspired more fictional impersonations than any sitting president. Michael Douglas in The American President played Clinton as the White House seducer he might legitimately have been if Hillary had conveniently died young. Gene Hackman in Clint Eastwood's Absolute Power dramatised the long-rumoured Clinton dark side - Arkansas gossip about rape, murder and drug-running - which moved from innuendo to constitutional crisis during the Lewinsky affair.

In The West Wing, Martin Sheen as President Bartlett is visually a post-Clinton dreamed-up leader (grey-haired, red-faced, sexually energetic), with useful hints of a past commander-in-chief. Sheen played JFK in the mini-series Kennedy and seems to use some of those famous Bostonian inflections here.

Writer Aaron Sorkin also seems to have drawn on those two stories. Bartlett is distanced from recent presidential history by having a loving, apparently faithful relationship with his wife, although she maintains a separate career as a doctor - a fantasy about the tolerance of the American electorate which would probably irritate Hillary Clinton more than anything else in this drama.

But Bartlett does possess a politically lethal secret. He ran for election while hiding a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. This works as a metaphor for Clinton's duplicity - avoiding the viewer asking "which one is Monica?" - yet also draws on the way Jack Kennedy hid a degenerative kidney condition which might in time have done the work of Oswald's bullet.

If identification is one problem in political fiction, the other is ideology. The reason that audiences are much higher for dramas than for news shows is that the majority of the population is bored by the theories and techniques of politics, though occasionally turned on by its personalities.

The West Wing addresses this focus-group resistance by placing in the foreground the urgent and gossipy surface of politics. The President collapses with a fever (a hint of his hidden medical condition) on the eve of the State Of The Union address, while a Washington website has just reported that the White House chief of staff is a recovering alcoholic and drug-abuser. These crises are interspersed with comedy from the Rosencrantzes and Guildensterns of the administration - bitchy and ambitious aides who aspire to running the country but can't organise their own love lives.

If it merely consisted of these scenes, The West Wing would still be re-elected unopposed most Monday nights by those with Sky. It would, though, be Reaganite drama: all jokes and smiles and no hard choices. What's so impressive about The West Wing is that it's genuinely informative about politics - although a few of its policies prevent it from being entirely a dream ticket. Even Sheen can't manage to save the obligatory scene in which he quotes from the Constitution with soaring strings behind.

It would be good one day to have a Clinton-Lewinsky Behind Closed Doors, but, until then, The West Wing is smart, tough stuff. With the exception of the 1970s Trevor Griffiths series Bill Brand, about a Labour MP, British TV drama has usually treated politics as comedy (Yes, Minister, House Of Cards) or fantasy (A Very British Coup.) Americans are more solemn about politics, but The West Wing achieves the difficult feat of dramatising the nuts and bolts of office while also showing you the screws.

If it merely consisted of these scenes, The West Wing would still be re-elected unopposed most Monday nights by those with Sky. It would, though, be Reaganite drama: all jokes and smiles and no hard choices. What's so impressive about The West Wing is that it's genuinely informative about politics - although a few of its policies prevent it from being entirely a dream ticket. Even Sheen can't manage to save the obligatory scene in which he quotes from the Constitution with soaring strings behind. It would be good one day to have a Clinton-Lewinsky Behind Closed Doors, but, until then, The West Wing is smart, tough stuff. With the exception of the 1970s Trevor Griffiths series Bill Brand, about a Labour MP, British TV drama has usually treated politics as comedy (Yes, Minister, House Of Cards) or fantasy (A Very British Coup.) Americans are more solemn about politics, but The West Wing achieves the difficult feat of dramatising the nuts and bolts of office while also showing you the screws.

fields.headline: Pensioners refuse to wither away
fields.trailText: Penny Toynbee is utterly wrong that the state pension is a benefit (Showing age concern, April 7). It is and always has been an entitlement to those who have paid the required numbers of contributions.
fields.body:
Penny Toynbee is utterly wrong that the state pension is a benefit (Showing age concern, April 7). It is and always has been an entitlement to those who have paid the required numbers of contributions. Those are paid in proportion to earnings and it is only right that the pension should be paid in proportion to earnings too. It is means-tested, because every pensioner is liable for income tax; hence the poorer may have no tax to pay, but the rich will pay at the top rate.

The problem for government is that no accumulated fund exists so often tax revenue may have to be used to pay the pension liabilities. That's tough on a government that is trying to cut taxes or to spend heavily on the NHS or some aeroplane that will never fly. Denigrating the pension entitlement to the status of a benefit, or hand out, is government's way of making the harsh uprating of the pension easier to defend.
Tony Ward
Loughborough, Leics
A.S.Ward@lboro.ac.uk

 Polly Toynbee did much to restore balance to what has been an often ill-informed debate. One of the reasons 700,000 pensioners do not claim benefits is because they are stigmatised by their fellow pensioners who claim to be acting on their behalf. The campaigners constantly refer to some magical difference between the state basic pension they have "paid in for" (in fact a myth) and everything else which they refer to as "handouts". In fact all benefits to pensioners (contributory or otherwise) are supported to varying degrees by current taxpayers. Very many pensioners also claim housing and council tax benefit, which is means tested.
Richard Bourne
Colchester

 Ms Toynbee tells us "the basic pension is withering away because it goes to growing numbers of newly retired people who are well off". I retired three years ago after 16 years of full-time work, having previously fulfilled my family commitments of bringing up children and looking after elderly relatives without pay or the help of nannies. My state pension is £48.50pw and I have an occupational pension of £4,000pa. If this is Ms Toynbee's idea of wealth, we have a very different understanding of what it means. Ms Toynbee maintains every poor pensioner was always means tested and "topped up". Many pensioners would rather starve than ask for "topping up". Pensioners learn to live without the trappings of wealth and even without their daily Guardian telling them they never had it so good. Just let them keep their dignity.
Name and address supplied

 Polly Toynbee wants us to reject the principle of a national insurance pension, whereby all at work pay and all receive an adequate pension when they retire. Although this is a pay-as-you-go scheme in which people in employment pay for today's pensioners, each generation benefits. Most workers understand and accept the national insurance principle, and it is why the TUC and all the trade unions are in favour of the approach. The Royal British Legion, Help the Aged and Age Concern also accept that the basic pension is far too low. Today's surplus in the national insurance fund can readily provide a return to the average wage index.
Jack Jones
President, National Pensioners Convention

 As a 79-year-old pensioner, I cannot understand people like Jack Jones not including the £100 fuel payment in their assessment of the pension increase. Perhaps Gordon Brown should designate the £150 we are going to receive next time round as a cost of living allowance plus £3 per week.
H Evans
Warrington, Cheshire

 Pensions is emerging as the defining issue for the New Labour government. Recently Polly Toynbee has stoutly defended the universalism of both the NHS and child benefits, which also go to the rich as well as the needy, on the grounds that to use a means test excludes some of the poorest and universalism spreads the risks. If these arguments are correct for the nation's health and the financial security of children, what makes pensioners different? This is the conundrum that Labour's heartlands cannot fathom. Older people do not want to be patronised by price concessions on fuel and TVs, they would rather have a decent income to spend as they choose.

I have seen no evidence that the costs of restoring the link with earnings are unsustainable - far from it, because the basic pension is still one of the lowest in Europe. Nor is there any evidence that the missing 700,000 who do not claim the means-tested minimum can be encouraged to do so. As a veteran of take-up campaigns in the 1970s, I know that it is very difficult to persuade proud people that a means test is a right. Meanwhile how many will die in poverty? The nation can afford to abolish poverty in old age as well as childhood.
Prof Alan Walker
University of Sheffield
A.C.Walker@sheffield.ac.uk

 Waiting lists grow longer, taxes favour younger families, costs rise against the meagre 75p pension rise. Banks are closing rural branches and now we learn pensions are to be paid into bank accounts which will lead to inevitable post office closures. Do the elderly count? Come the next election, Mr Blair...
Tony Martin
Eastwood, Notts

webTitle: The poor and 20,000 undelivered leaflets in Runcorn

fields.headline: The poor and 20,000 undelivered leaflets in Runcorn
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Wheatcroft says there are not enough poor people any more (Comment, April 8). How many poor people are enough then, before a political party can be bothered to represent their interests? That sort of talk looks like the application of Barclays bank-type thinking to democratic theory and values.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Wheatcroft says there are not enough poor people any more (Comment, April 8). How many poor people are enough then, before a political party can be bothered to represent their interests? That sort of talk looks like the application of Barclays bank-type thinking to democratic theory and values.

I thought a political system such as ours was supposed to be able to take into account the views of minorities and govern in the interests of all, not merely to govern in the interests of the majority, no matter how affluent. Size has got nothing to do with it.

There may no longer be an industrial working class composed of the poor and uneducated, but we now have something far worse - a scapegoat group of the invisible and the dehumanised, composed of assorted dispossessed people - the unemployed, the aged, single parents, the disabled, black people, the sick, crims, druggies, beggars and asylum seekers, all of them poor.

That there is no political party prepared to champion their cause and represent their assorted points of view is a disturbing new departure, not a cause for congratulation and seems more likely a symptom of a political system that is sick and unable to cope with the 21st century than one that is going anywhere.
Sue Lord
Hull
susan@albanystreet.freeserve.co.uk

 The poor may not now be "most of the British people" but they constitute much more than the minority Geoffrey Wheatcroft asserts. Most of the army of part-time workers and pensioners would certainly regard themselves as poor, and where does he get the idea that only the so-called majority must pay tax to the poor? I have to pay income tax on a small occupational pension and each time that I buy anything I, in common with most other poor people have to pay 17.5% VAT.
Eddy Bruce
Cardiff
eddybruce@pop.ntlworld.com

 Geoffrey Wheatcroft suggests that the New Labour project will become No Labour, as much voting is no longer driven by social class. Since he correctly suggests that the rise of class-based voting stemmed from universal suffrage, then an obvious solution is available to those who deplore such social division. Since the poor, homeless and unemployed clearly make no contribution to society, why not disenfranchise them? That would leave all of us in the middle ground, freeing all politicians to play to our greed.
Michael Pidd
Lancaster
m.pidd@lancaster.ac.uk

 The working class now have no political party to speak for them, if indeed they ever did. Mr Blair thinks it is "fantastic" that middle-class business people support the Labour party. Twenty thousand Labour party election leaflets remain undelivered in Runcorn so perhaps we will see these new supporters on our streets some time in the next three weeks. Or perhaps not.
Ronald Williams
Runcorn, Cheshire

fields.headline: Fit for pigs
fields.trailText: Your leader (April 7) urging the government to consider the US model of food welfare, which gives tax incentives to companies to donate unsold food, is short-sighted. I have visited food banks in US, Canada and Australia and both workers and recipients have made it clear that once companies are enticed into using the poor as surplus removers, there is no turning back.
fields.body:
Your leader (April 7) urging the government to consider the US model of food welfare, which gives tax incentives to companies to donate unsold food, is short-sighted. I have visited food banks in US, Canada and Australia and both workers and recipients have made it clear that once companies are enticed into using the poor as surplus removers, there is no turning back. A crisis response quickly becomes institutionalised. Food banks experience immense difficulties - too big a supply of inappropriate foods, storage, staffing, morale. They are the ultimate in food control, removing choice. What once was fed to pigs is now given to a sub-class of consumers. This is not the Third Way but neo-mediaevalism.
Prof Tim Lang
Thames Valley University

 The cost of wasted food is already included in the prices charged by supermarkets. Why should they have tax rebates so they can make higher profits?
Tim Lobstein
Food Commission
