fields.headline: The nearly men
fields.standfirst: Cold comfort for political hot favouritesTories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The decision of the former Conservative defence secretary, Tom King, to leave the Commons at the next election allows us to add his name with some finality to the long and distinguished list of future Conservative prime ministers who never made it. Very few saw Margaret Thatcher coming before she displaced Edward Heath in 1975: a more popular tip was Edward du Cann, a former party chairman to whom, understandably as it now seems, Mr Heath had refused ministerial office. Not many spotted John Major long before his accession: he was certainly a less obvious contender than, say, Michael Heseltine. William Hague from the time he made his famous conference speech while still a schoolboy was widely tipped as a future leader. But he too, of course, may never make premier.
fields.body:
The decision of the former Conservative defence secretary, Tom King, to leave the Commons at the next election allows us to add his name with some finality to the long and distinguished list of future Conservative prime ministers who never made it. Very few saw Margaret Thatcher coming before she displaced Edward Heath in 1975: a more popular tip was Edward du Cann, a former party chairman to whom, understandably as it now seems, Mr Heath had refused ministerial office. Not many spotted John Major long before his accession: he was certainly a less obvious contender than, say, Michael Heseltine. William Hague from the time he made his famous conference speech while still a schoolboy was widely tipped as a future leader. But he too, of course, may never make premier.

Early in Lady Thatcher's reign before the Falklands war made her popular, close observers agreed that if she had to be dropped, her most likely successor was Francis Pym. Then he lost her confidence, and that was the end of him. Another popular tip was her protégé John Moore, whom she put in charge of health and the social services - reduced, after the job proved too much for him, to social security only. His career was effectively finished when he was barely past 50. There were those who without attracting ridicule backed the bright young ministers who are now Lord (Kenneth) Baker and Lord (Cecil) Parkinson. More recently, there was Jonathan Aitken.

Some, like RA Butler or Chris Patten, who lost his Commons seat at just the wrong moment, were felled by events. Others were never much more than fantasy. Tom King never seemed a realistic contender, though some shrewd Tories backed him as an unusually safe pair of hands. On the whole, the record suggests that the strongest apparent candidates are the ones least worth backing. That Michael Portillo is now generally judged to be ahead of the field suggests he may never make it.

fields.headline: A load of multiple goals
fields.trailText: Andrew Sullivan's article was an honest account of the feelings that testosterone produces in men (Mainlining manhood, April 8). It is important, though, that both sexes recognise and respect the strengths of the other.
fields.body:
Andrew Sullivan's article was an honest account of the feelings that testosterone produces in men (Mainlining manhood, April 8). It is important, though, that both sexes recognise and respect the strengths of the other. Women do not lack motivation and drive because they are not aggressively competitive. What women experience is motivation in terms of goals, often multiple goals, frequently quite complex and distant. This can be just as effective and productive as male behaviour rooted in winning "this" fight.

For example, a man may write a letter to the Guardian with the view of winning an argument. I am writing because I want to communicate an idea. Neither of these motives is right or wrong, just different and either may succeed (or fail) in producing a letter which is worth reading.

What I would like to see is female long-term, goal-directed behaviour financially as well rewarded as male short-term competitive behaviour.
Alison Page
Coventry

 Andrew Sullivan extrapolates from his own experience to conclude that naturally lower levels of testosterone in women make them less brave, impulsive and energetic and, by implication, less witty and intellectually sharp. The women Andrew Sullivan knows sound awfully dull. Perhaps he should take advantage of his new-found love of life to cultivate a wider circle of friends.
Nick Rogers, Amanda MacLean
Glasgow

 It appears that Andrew Sullivan uses his testosterone injections for the same reason that middle-aged men use prostitutes: to make him feel like a man. What a pity he didn't like or respect his normal self.
Kathleen Hines
Washington, Tyne & Wear

 I thought April Fools Day was the previous Saturday - or has lack of testosterone dulled my wits again?
Dawn Gill
Lydbrook, Glos

fields.headline: Still angry, still fighting
fields.standfirst: Helena Kennedy has come all the way from a Glasgow tenement block to the heart of the new Labour establishment. But, says  Sally Weale, that doesn't stop her giving the government a hard time
fields.trailText: Helena Kennedy has come all the way from a Glasgow tenement block to the heart of the new Labour establishment. But, says  Sally Weale, that doesn't stop her giving the government a hard time
fields.body:
For a woman whose career has been built on her credentials as radical outsider and passionate critic of the status quo, Helena Kennedy - the best-known female lawyer in the land, apart perhaps from Cherie Booth - these days finds herself in a curious position.

As a member of the House of Lords, a QC and chair of that august but slightly obscure body called the British Council, Baroness Kennedy of The Shaws, who next month celebrates her 50th birthday, would appear to be at the very heart of the New Establishment.

She might have been brought up in a council tenement building in Glasgow, the third of four daughters of a newspaper print worker, but today Helena (pronounced He-lay-na) Kennedy lives in Hampstead and counts half the British cabinet among her personal friends.

On the day of our interview, she is still capable of a pretty convincing impression of the angry young radical. She is a small but sturdy woman, with a powerful oblong face, steady eyes of Mediterranean blue that hold yours unwaveringly and an unfashionably prominent, Charlotte Brontë-like nose.

We meet in the Old Bailey where she is defending in a murder trial. She appears first in "civvies" - smart browns and beiges, carefully applied make-up and well-groomed, burnished-copper hair. She wears strong, silvery jewellery - thick bands on her fingers and bangles around her wrists which jangle on the canteen table. She looks like she's dressed by Principles, maybe a bit more expensive - then changes into her gown and tufty, talcum-powdered wig ready for court.

Criminal law continues to be her greatest passion and despite her myriad commitments, she still manages three-quarters of a full-time practice. We manage to squeeze our interview between family life (she has three children aged 16, 13 and 10); court work; writing and broadcasting; a trip to Ireland to pick up an honorary degree (Gregory Peck will also receive one) and a visit this week to Ukraine on behalf of the British Council.

There is something typically lawyerly about the way she articulates - for the most part she is measured, careful, deliberate - but her observations are peppered with excitingly angry, unlawyerly adjectives. She is "appalled", "shocked", "horrified", "disgusted"; she finds things "scandalous" and "outrageous". She feels a "swell of anger" at injustices, she listens to her "inner voice" and it matters to her that she listens to her conscience and can face herself in the mirror. All very un-Blairite - especially when much of her criticism is targeted at government itself.

In the past, Kennedy has described her relationship with the government she worked so hard and long to get elected as one of a "critical friend"; she has come in for a certain amount of flak from her own side for speaking out, but she has picked her arguments carefully and they concern the issues about which she knows and cares most - human rights and civil liberties

That same inner voice propelled her to speak out most recently over Jack Straw's proposals to limit the right to trial by jury, which were defeated in the House of Lords earlier this year after a vociferous campaign in which Kennedy acted as the chief Labour opponent of reform.

She is genuinely appalled by the proposal. It's "invidious", she says, that citizens will lose their fundamental right to choose a jury trial for middle-ranking offences and it will be left to magistrates - largely white, middle-class and legally unqualified - to choose who goes to crown court and who doesn't.

But her harshest words are reserved for suggestion that lawyers like herself were driven by self-interest and were only opposed to the changes because it might reduce their workload in the crown court. "The idea that that should be pushed out to the press and public as being the reason why lawyers might stand up and say 'hold on a minute' was disgusting. It was outrageous that people would even suggest it."

Kennedy suspects the amended but still controversial bill will be voted down again when it returns to the Lords, but because both Jack Straw and Tony Blair are committed to it, it will inevitably be forced through in the end. "One of the great follies of the last government was that it did not listen. I just hope we aren't going down that road."

Kennedy's early interest in the law was partly shaped by an incident when she was young, growing up in an Irish-Catholic working-class family on the south side of Glasgow. Her mother was injured when a slate fell off a roof and hit her, but suing was unthinkable. "The idea of setting foot over a lawyer's step was clearly very intimidating," Kennedy has said. "And I think a lot of working-class people feel fear and horror at the idea of being involved with the law. But the law should be there to help them as much as anyone else."

It is her family background - a million miles from the world inhabited by most of her colleagues in the Lords and the Inns of Court - that has inspired her deep sense of justice and which makes her such an effective advocate and powerful critic.

There are, of course, plenty of government achievements with which she's delighted - the minimum wage; recent changes to the way in which rape trials can be conducted; devolution; the economy; the return of unionisation to GCHQ; the money being ploughed into further education, particularly for people who missed out first time around.

Even Pinochet was a bit of a triumph in her book. "I thought it was wonderful that we arrested him and went through those steps. I thought the House of Lords judgment was a seminal decision which is going to affect human rights law worldwide." The outcome of course was disappointing. The Chilean dictator is probably "turning somersaults" in the streets of Santiago, but given the evidence, Jack Straw made the right decision.

"If it's true there's evidence he would have difficulty in presenting a proper defence, your human rights have to extend even to monsters who have no concern for the human rights of others. We have to live by different rules."

Where she parts company sharply with the government is on single parents and the reduction of the special child allowance ("It's absolutely incredible we got it so badly wrong" - though things have improved since, she concedes); freedom of information ("It's absolutely unsatisfactory that ministers should be deciding what is secret and what is not"); reform of the legal aid system ("It's not about attacking the abuses, it's about really reducing the budget"), and asylum. Particularly asylum.

"The Labour party for me has always been the party of minorities. In the face of uglier emotions in the public, Labour has always been prepared to take the courageous stand in protecting minorities. I'm very, very concerned about what's been happening over asylum.

"I don't like the voucher system." (introduced earlier this month to replace cash benefits for asylum seekers) "And this new business that you don't get change is scandalous. Or that you can't buy your child a toy. Who are we?" She pauses, her disbelief robbing her of words. "Who could be suggesting such a thing?

"Our role has always been to comfort the afflicted. I feel there's been too much succumbing to the notion of a bogeyman - a hostile middle Englander. I don't believe that person really exists, not in any great numbers anyway.

"What I think is so regrettable is we are seeing some really good things that are being done being overshadowed by some really bad things. Unfortunately what's likely to be remembered are the really bad things."

Would she ever be interested in a government job? She says not. "I'm an independent woman. That's how I like it." With that she's on her way, back to court and on to the Lords, scene of the next battle. "I've still not quite got them to have machines for tampons in the ladies loos. But we'll win that one too." Undoubtedly.

fields.headline: Crowning glory (with squiggles)
fields.trailText: Whether the new Community Legal Service will or won't bring access to justice to millions suddenly seemed irrelevant to the delirious masses waiting for its official launch last Monday. As the scheme was formally unveiled, so, dramatically, was its logo. One moment there was a blank bit on the wall, the next there it was. There was not so much a storm of applause as a hushed quizzical silence. Then a spontaneous roar - OK, a polite whisper - arose from the assembled multitude. "What is it?," it cried as a single voice. It is a virulent shade of green, the same shade as Kermit the Frog, the well-known Muppet.
fields.body:
Whether the new Community Legal Service will or won't bring access to justice to millions suddenly seemed irrelevant to the delirious masses waiting for its official launch last Monday. As the scheme was formally unveiled, so, dramatically, was its logo. One moment there was a blank bit on the wall, the next there it was. There was not so much a storm of applause as a hushed quizzical silence. Then a spontaneous roar - OK, a polite whisper - arose from the assembled multitude. "What is it?," it cried as a single voice. It is a virulent shade of green, the same shade as Kermit the Frog, the well-known Muppet.

But what does this tell us about the logo's symbolic relationship with the CLS? Search me. The rest is easier. The four white thingies on top, I'm told, represent the Crown, though why that's in the act I'm not sure. And then, my visual interpreter explained, reading from the top down, there's a C, an L and an S. I'm beginning to catch on. But surely the whole represents the flow of justice, a river restlessly trying to enter every inlet of legal need; or, alternatively, (squint and look at it from the bottom up), the smoke of justice billowing and reaching for the stars (four of them), or possibly Isadora Duncan's scarf, just before it was caught in the wheels of her car and strangled her.

There is even a school of thought that the logo is a symbol of Cherie Booth, depicting the unity of government - her husband - and the law. Those four white blobs are her barrister's wig, with the C below standing for Cherie and - this is the clincher - the next thing down, what else can it be but an advanced pregnancy? The lowest swirl is of course her judicial gown. The only flaw in this interpretation is that the logo will need redesigning as soon as the youngest Blair is born. But never mind the logo, look at the CLS web site - www.justask.org.uk - which is terrific.

I was puzzled by the libel case won by Marco Pierre White against the New York Times and the International Herald Tribune. He won £75,000 damages over a profile containing untrue allegations of past drug-taking and drinking. Why did the papers fight the claim? They accepted that they'd been factually wrong and their defence that the allegations weren't defamatory seems absurd.

The reason for the New York Times going to court, I understand, is that, as a matter of policy, it always does. And apparently it had never before lost a libel suit brought against it. In America, though, White's claim wouldn't have stood a chance. White is a public figure, so he would have had to prove malicious intent. This is an impossible hurdle where, as in this case, the writer makes a mistake in good faith. In England, we're inching towards giving the media a defence if they mistakenly libel a politician, provided they'd taken steps to verify the story.

But I'm not convinced that this should be extended to all celebrities and, anyway, such a crass mistake does not deserve the protection of the law.

You may have missed this exchange in a House of Lords debate recently on Section 28. Lord Moran: "For example, necrophiliacs, transvestites and sado-masochists who have been living together for some years might argue that they are in stable relationships and may be surprised to find that they are regarded by the government as forming "key building blocks of community and society". Earl Russell: "My Lords, is the noble Lord suggesting that necrophiliacs have relationships?". Lord Moran: "My Lords, I believe the noble Earl knows more about that than I do."

Within an hour of seeing that in Hansard I learn the government's sex offences review is proposing that necrophilia become a criminal offence. I thought it already was. Though on one view a victimless crime, it is, I agree, in the utmost bad taste. But must it be a crime? And will there be a defence of silence indicating consent?

webTitle: CIA takes rap for embassy attack

fields.headline: CIA takes rap for embassy attack
fields.standfirst: Sack for agent whose error led to Belgrade raid that killed three Chinese citizensKosovo: special report
fields.trailText: One CIA officer was sacked and six others reprimanded yesterday as the American intelligence agency finally took the rap for the US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade last year at the height of the Nato conflict with Yugoslavia over Kosovo.
fields.body:
One CIA officer was sacked and six others reprimanded yesterday as the American intelligence agency finally took the rap for the US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade last year at the height of the Nato conflict with Yugoslavia over Kosovo.

George Tenet, the CIA director, acted against the seven employees last week after two internal agency reviews on the bombing, on May 7, which killed three Chinese citizens and injured more than 20 others. The attack plunged US-China relations into deep freeze and renewed doubts about the Nato campaign in several European nations.

Mr Tenet's decision, which was announced in an unusual public statement from the agency, follows 11 months of public and private Chinese government pressure for "severe punishment" of those responsible for the bombing.

The action has immediately sparked allegations in the US that President Bill Clinton's administration has used the agents as scapegoats in an effort to smooth relations between Beijing and Washington after Chinese officials refused to let the matter die.

The agents against whom action has been taken have not been identified. However, reports in the US yesterday said that the sacked agent was a mid-level career officer whose targeting error was blamed for the incident.

The others, said to include one senior official and four supervisors, received punishments varying from spoken admonitions to suspended promotions and pay awards.

The US has already apologised to Beijing and agreed to pay $28m (£17.5m) in compensation to the Chinese government, as well as $4.5m (£2.8m) to families of those who were killed and injured.

The CIA confirmed yesterday that its internal inquiries had concluded that the intelligence officers had intended to target the Yugoslav military supply headquarters, but wrongly identified the building housing the embassy.

"The evidence shows that this was clearly a tragic accident," spokesman Bill Harlow said in a statement.

Although Chinese - and, from time to time, some western sources - have claimed that the American attack was a deliberate act, the official Washington version of events which emerged within days of the attack has not substantially changed in the ensuing months.

The CIA says the bombing was caused when the now sacked officer mistakenly identified the military supply HQ on a street map on the basis of its address, 2 Bulevar Umetnosti, which was in fact several hundred yards away from the building housing the Chinese embassy.

The map on which the target was identified was a 1997 map that showed the Chinese embassy located at its earlier address in the centre of Belgrade.

After the location was wrongly fixed, it was discussed during three meetings among CIA officials, none of whom questioned the targeting procedure that had been used. The target details were then passed to the Pentagon and Nato, but were not queried there either.

The whole saga is particularly embarrassing for the CIA because this was the only one of 900 targets struck by Nato planes during the 78-day campaign that was wholly selected by the agency.

"The CIA lacked formal procedures for preparing and forwarding target nomination packages to the US military," Mr Harlow admitted.

However, as reported in the Guardian last year, in the week preceding the embassy bombing another mid-level CIA officer did voice doubts and objections to the identification of the target.

This agent called colleagues at the US military mapping agency in Washington with his doubts and also discussed the matter with the Nato taskforce in Naples, Italy, which was responsible for issuing instructions to B-2 stealth bomber crews about their night missions. No senior official intervened, however, and the strike went ahead. The officer who raised the concerns was officially praised - though not identified - by Mr Tenet in his official statement.

A lawyer for one of the reprimanded officers said yesterday that it was "manifestly unjust" to blame individual CIA officers when "the failure was systematic".

Roy Krieger said: "It's shameful that the CIA caved in to political pressure to provide scapegoats. The agency has already publicly admitted that the map provided to the officers contained errors without which the Chinese embassy would not have been mistakenly bombed. These officers were asked to improvise and did the best with the materials provided to them."

webTitle: Israel and US clash over spy plane sale to China

fields.headline: Israel and US clash over spy plane sale to China
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel is being told to walk away from the most lucrative arms deal ever on offer to the country's air force industry, or risk jeopardising relations with its main ally, the United States.
fields.body:
Israel is being told to walk away from the most lucrative arms deal ever on offer to the country's air force industry, or risk jeopardising relations with its main ally, the United States.

Washington objects to the sale to China of a sophisticated airborne radar system which Pentagon officials say is similar to America's own airborne warning and control system (Awacs). Israel claims that the system does not contain American technology.

The sale of the Phalcon radar system is the latest in a series of alleged transfers of military technology which have angered Washington.

The confrontation comes into sharp focus this week. Tomorrow, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the US president, Bill Clinton, will meet in Washington. US officials say their talks will almost certainly include US concerns that the system would give China a dangerous new advantage in a potential confrontation with Taiwan.

Two days later, the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, will arrive in Israel to inspect the first Russian-made plane to be fitted with the sophisticated Israeli avionics. The visit, the first by a Chinese head of state, underscores the importance for Israel of strengthening its ties with one of the biggest customers in the arms market.

Israeli officials had hoped China would sign up for as many as eight planes, which are worth at least £150m each, but last week the stakes increased.

"It is a question of a long-term erosion," said Gerald Steinberg, a political science professor at Bar Ilan University. "If Israel is perceived in the US - particulary by those who have always supported Israel - to be supporting the current enemy number one, which is China, militarily, that could erode political support for Israel in the long term which could affect aid and co-operation."

The force of American objections to the sale have been growing more pronounced. On Thursday night, a Republican congressman with control over aid spending said he would withhold some $250m of Israel's annual $2.82bn in aid if the deal goes ahead.

Sonny Callahan, the chairman of the house of representatives appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, said he was issuing the threat to reinforce a similar warning from the US defence secretary, William Cohen.

During a visit to Israel last week, Mr Cohen argued that the sale would alter the strategic balance in the Taiwanese straits by beefing up Beijing's capability to intercept and shoot down Taiwanese and US aircraft.

Mr Barak promised to review the matter. "We are aware of the sensitivity in the United States with regard to China," he said. But he added: "We of course are aware of our commitment in the contracts that we have signed."

At the weekend, state department officials distanced themselves from Mr Callahan's threat.

"We do not think conditioning aid is an effective way to address this issue," said a statement. "At the same time, both the administration and congress have concerns regarding Israel's arms transfer and the deepening defence relationship with China."

Israeli arms deals with China stretch back 15 years, and the strength of the US objections to the sale of the Phalcon appear to have caught the Israelis off-guard - particularly as Washington has been aware of the deal for four years.

The change in Washington's own policy towards Beijing has compromised Israel's position. fields.headline: Coffee with the enemy
fields.trailText: About 280 years ago, Lord Hervey had trouble with his mother. He called her Mount Vesuvius, because "from her mouth poured fire and rubbish". I must say I sympathise. My mother erupted last week.
fields.body:
About 280 years ago, Lord Hervey had trouble with his mother. He called her Mount Vesuvius, because "from her mouth poured fire and rubbish". I must say I sympathise. My mother erupted last week. For some odd reason she has turned against Rosemary. At the sound of the R-word, out pours a molten flow of bitterness-speak. It is difficult, under these conditions, to invite Rosemary round for tea, so I have taken to visiting her in her small apartment.

"Where are you going?" roars my Mother. "Out!" I am 15 again. I cannot say R... and risk another tremor.

But on Saturday Rosemary braved it, visiting for the first time since her traumatic departure from our road. Down in the kitchen we were out of the glare of my mother's fury. But Rosemary is not one to cower or suck-up. She, too, likes to express her opinions in a loud, clear voice. And both she and my mother are highly skilled grudge-bearers. The air prickled with hatred.

Rosemary and I battled on with our coffee break. No sound came from my mother's room. Did she know I had a visitor or was Rosemary's voice drowned out by the sound of the Walton's on telly? I do hope so. Rosemary is not the only one. Over the years many of them have blotted their copy somehow. Some ate too much dinner, some didn't wash up, some answered back, some wore horrid clothes, some were rowdy and worst of all, some had taken advantage. Only a very few have spotless records.

But as I like to assert that I am a grown-up, I press on, entertaining chums regardless, although the mood in our house is not always as mellow as I would like. I party on a knife edge. Will there be sulks, glares, insults, a fight? Then gradually the temperature cools. Life simmers along. And there is at least one thing about living here in Temper Towers that my Mother appreciates. It is rarely dull.

fields.headline: Superwoman and her perspiring pants
fields.standfirst: Emma Warren on the tyranny of underwear
fields.trailText: Knickers, you'd think, would be pretty resistant to the persistent forces of beauty technology. Unless you are an Olympic swimmer and you need your briefs specially designed to reduce trawl and cut those vital milliseconds from your breast-stroke, of course. But no.
fields.body:
Knickers, you'd think, would be pretty resistant to the persistent forces of beauty technology. Unless you are an Olympic swimmer and you need your briefs specially designed to reduce trawl and cut those vital milliseconds from your breast-stroke, of course. But no. In the name of technology, advancement and the marketing of women's anxieties about their bodies, come elastic-less knickers, created to - wow! - eliminate visible panty line.

The smalls, made by French manufacturer Scandy, cling to the skin by transferring perspiration from an inner layer of fabric to finer fibres on the outside (sounds nice, girls) and are made from Tactel, a fabric more frequently used to make hard-wearing sportswear. Whether it's knickers that mould into your skin, anti-cellulite tights (recently launched by Aristoc) or a spray-on bra (a heavily marketed YSL firming gel) beauty and cosmetic manufacturers are focusing on ever-smaller parts of the female anatomy to sell their wares.

Emma, a 27-year-old trainee lawyer, is unconvinced. "Underwear is something to be a bit sexy in, and none of this sounds at all sexy. Who is it made by? Who's it for? You can't quite take it seriously."

There's no denial that semi-surgical cosmetics are big business: millions are spent each year in research and development of products designed to multi-task us into shape - an Elizabeth Arden lipstick that freshen the breath being just one of the latest. "There's a whole side of cosmetics that is just ridiculous," says Manchester-based fashion journalist Sarah, 26. "They hit you with science and tell you that you need it, but at the end of the day it's bullshit that panders to women's paranoia about their self-image."

It's not just gym culture that is exerting pressure: women of all ages and shapes are being exhorted to adopt the American model of external beauty. And being expected to spend more time, effort and money on attaining the one specific, large-breasted, slim-hipped model of beauty that our culture deems lovely.

We already have the longest working hours in Europe, and now women and girls are being pushed to spend any free time on the expensive, here's-the-science-bit equivalent of having a wash. Louise, a 28-year-old Australian who works in publishing, agrees: "The pressures are enormous. My mother spent years doing ridiculous exercises and using millions of different creams to make her breasts larger. I've spent years wearing various padded, push-up and underwire bras to make myself look bigger. Not only is it demeaning - it's bloody uncomfortable too."

Sarah makes another point: "Products like the spray-on bra are just wordplay. It's so typical of the really hardcore marketing that cosmetic companies are doing at the moment."

Look on the stacked shelves of any beauty counter, and you'll find a staggering range of creams, gels and sprays, which, if you believed the hype, would be able to turn the average gal into a lush, fleshy-in-the-right-places, tight-everywhere-else, ultra-model. In reality, they are more likely to relieve you of cash than they are of natural (womanly) body shapes.

"A lot of these products are marketed at women in their late 30s who are worried that their bodies are sagging but don't want plastic surgery," reckons Sarah. "I think a lot of people were scared by Lola Ferrari's death - plastic surgery seems really scary and creams seem like a safer option."

Either way, every day, women are confronted with more evidence that natural slippage is bad and hiked-up silicone souls rule. Body beautiful is not about beautiful bodies, it's about beautiful clothed bodies. Real bodies are shapely and soft, while Wonderbodies are probably covered in plant gels and bio-technology, clothed in perspiring (but seamless) pants, and plastic with uplift. Which would you prefer to hold in bed?

webTitle: Motorist changes law by fighting clamping

fields.headline: Motorist changes law by fighting clamping
fields.trailText: A motorist who twice took her case against wheel-clampers to the court of appeal has won back the £105 she paid to have her car released and clarified a grey area of the law for tens of thousands of other drivers.
fields.body:
A motorist who twice took her case against wheel-clampers to the court of appeal has won back the £105 she paid to have her car released and clarified a grey area of the law for tens of thousands of other drivers.

Marina Vine thought she had been so unfairly treated when her car was clamped on private land that she enlisted the backing of the Automobile Association and sued in the county court to get her money back. She lost there, but appealed.

Although the claim was for only £105, it was to tax the brains of five appeal court judges before the judgment in Mrs Vine's favour was delivered. Unusually, the two judges who dealt with the original appeal could not agree and it had to be reheard by a second panel of three senior judges.

The east London borough of Waltham Forest, which employed the clampers through a contractor, now faces a "substantial" legal bill for the three-year battle.

Its head of legal services, Philip Jackson, said clampers would be given new guidance following the case.

Lords Justices Roch, May and Waller ruled, in a judgment that sets a clear precedent for other cases, that Mrs Vine was not liable to pay the unclamping fee because she had not seen the clampers' warning sign.

Mike Watkins, head of legal services at the AA, said: "What we are trying to do is to clarify the law as a motorists' champion. We have been inundated with complaints about wheel-clamping on private land.

"It's a motorist's nightmare. Firms can do what they want. A lot of them don't even put their fees on their notices."

Mrs Vine, 64, of east London, was returning from a hospital appointment in March 1997. She suffered from a stomach complaint and was upset after learning that she would have to undergo an urgent operation. Feeling ill and worried that she was a danger to other drivers, she pulled over on to land owned by Railtrack in Leytonstone.

She parked at East London College and left her car for three to four minutes while she went to vomit. When she returned the car had been clamped and she was told she would have to pay a £105 fee to have it released. She had no choice but to pay by credit card, which cost her an extra £3.68.

Mrs Vine sued the council in the county court, asking for her money back plus £5,000 exemplary damages. The recorder who heard the case accepted that she had not seen the sign warning that cars could be clamped. There was no sign on her side of the bay and the sign on the other side was obscured. But he still dismissed her claim.

Last week, the three judges ruled that since Mrs Vine had not seen the sign, she had not consented to the risk that her car would be clamped. Therefore the clampers had committed a trespass to her car. They awarded her the £105 fee, the £3.68 credit card charge, £5 for being deprived of the use of her car for 15-20 minutes, and £17.64 interest.

Darryl Greer, Mrs Vine's solicitor, said motorists who were clamped could now take cases to the small claims court, citing Mrs Vine's precedent, and have them decided simply and cheaply by arbitration without the need for a lawyer.

"People ought to be able to go along themselves and the district judges ought to now know it's not just open and shut."

But the case still leaves open a vexed issue the AA had hoped to clarify - how much can clamping companies charge to release a car they were entitled to clamp?

Since Mrs Vine won the case outright, the judges had no need to rule on that point.

"Many people have been caught by clampers relying on this being a grey area and thinking this is a licence to print money," said Mr Watkins.

webTitle: Blair council's poor record for recycling

fields.headline: Blair council's poor record for recycling
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's constituency is the worst for recycling rubbish among those represented by cabinet ministers - nearly six times below Britain's national average, according to figures released today by the environment campaigning organisation, Friends of the Earth.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's constituency is the worst for recycling rubbish among those represented by cabinet ministers - nearly six times below Britain's national average, according to figures released today by the environment campaigning organisation, Friends of the Earth.

Sedgefield council is almost the worst performing in Britain, recycling only 1.4% of rubbish. It is only beaten to bottom place by Wansbeck in Northumberland (0.9%), Durham (1%) and Corby (1.3%). The average figure is 8.9%, according to figures collected by the audit commission, which polices local government.

The Downing Street policy unit is poring over the final draft of the government's waste strategy, which John Prescott, deputy prime minister, wants to release before next month's local elections.

The minister whose constituency includes the top performing local authority is Clare Short. Her council, Birmingham, recycles 13.8%, just beating Derby, represented by Margaret Beckett, leader of the house, which recycles 13.2%.

The Ashfield constituency of Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, manages 1.5%. The council in chancellor Gordon Brown's Fife constituency manages 1.8%. Environmnet minister Michael Meacher's Oldham constituency only recycles 2.9%.

Only four cabinet ministers represent areas where recycling exceeds the national average, including Blackburn represented by Jack Straw, home secretary.The Dewsbury constituency of chief whip Ann Taylor also exceeds the average.

The best authorities - the Isle of Wight with 41.7%; Bournemouth 37%; Castle Morpeth 36.6%; Dorset 32.7% and Poole 27.6% - are represented by backbench MPs.

Mike Childs, senior waste campaigner for Friends of the Earth, said: "Britain has one of the worst recycling records in Europe.

"Most councils have failed hopelessly to meet the target set more than 10 years ago, of recycling a quarter of their rubbish by the year 2000."

fields.headline: Development plan arouses opposition
fields.trailText: A plan to slice a third off the only inner city park created since the Victorian era, and build an upmarket urban village, has incensed residents in Liverpool.
fields.body:
A plan to slice a third off the only inner city park created since the Victorian era, and build an upmarket urban village, has incensed residents in Liverpool.

The North Liverpool partnership, a regeneration arm of the Liberal Democrat-controlled city council, wants to develop part of the 150 acre Everton park, claiming there is a need to encourage people to come and live and invest in the depopulated city centre.

The proposal has the backing of the Prince of Wales. He has taken a personal interest, and promised support from his trust.

The locality was rundown housing estates, until between 1983 and 1987 under the personal stimulus of Derek Hatton, the council's deputy leader when Labour controlled the city, the buildings were demolished, and lawns and trees planted. Mr Hatton objected to the new development, and said the park should be "cherished and improved" for future generations; it was wrong to substitute upmarket homes with panoramic views of the Mersey. "It is good to see disused properties developed, but that is not an argument for building on Everton park."

In the 1950s, the area had 10,000 homes and a population of 50,000, but today that figure has fallen to 3,600 inhabitants in 1,100 homes. Bob Ponting, director of the partnership, said that it had been wrong to move people out. "This takes the customers out of the shops, the children out of schools, and causes an area like Everton to become a derelict wasteland. I am trying to reverse the damage done by Hatton and his predecessors."

Under the partnership, private developers would buy parcels of land for homes and businesses from the council, and build schools, shops and community facilities. The money raised would go into improving the remainder of the park and its surrounds.

George Knibb, a local Labour councillor, disputed the claim, and said: "I am from a family of 12, born and bred in Everton, and I know what people here want. This is the people's park, and we will not be forced into selling it off."

fields.headline: Quality of motorway food 'scandalous'
fields.standfirst:
Critic demands competition to raise standards and cut prices

www.egonronay.net
fields.trailText: The food critic Egon Ronay today launches a blistering attack on the "scandalous" quality of meals and drinks available at the vast majority of Britain's 72 motorway service areas.
fields.body:
The food critic Egon Ronay today launches a blistering attack on the "scandalous" quality of meals and drinks available at the vast majority of Britain's 72 motorway service areas.

He and a colleague describe the food that they sampled on their tour round the motorway system as being mostly "mass-produced, unspeakable rubbish".

They complain bitterly of coffee that smelt of washing-up water, rigid and tough bacon, a disgusting fried egg, ridiculous chips, a mess of goulash, and chocolate mousse that was "a joke".

Mr Ronay, whose withering criticisms have made restaurateurs tremble for more than 40 years, notes that 91% of franchises are owned by three companies - Welcome Break, Granada and Road Chef - and says that an absence of competition does away with the need to raise standards.

"Tragically, much of the improvement experienced until a very few years ago has sunk back until now it is even below the previous, largely unacceptable standards," he comments on his website.

"What makes it worse is that many food and beverage prices are too high in spite of the immense turnover, outpricing equivalent items in the high street, and motorists being captive have to accept them."

A pot of tea could cost cost 50p more than the average high street price, a cooked breakfast £1 more and mineral water up to 50p more, he says.

Welcome Break's Membury services on the M4 near Swindon, where neither critic appears to have tasted anything they found acceptable except the cold quiche, comes in for special attack.

The fried fish is given a particular battering. It had an "impenetrable coating", they say, and "smelt very nearly 'off' but wasn't quite 'off' (both my colleague and I smelt it carefully)".

In contrast, considerable praise is heaped on two independent service areas. Magor on the M4 near Newport in South Wales has a beautiful view of green fields, hot food that is freshly made on the premises, and a managing director who helps clear tables.

Westmorland on the M6 at Tebay can boast of a country-house feeling, Cumbrian produce, a lake with ducks, and staff who are helpful. It is "a unique service area, showing up all the others".

Westmorland's operations manager, John France, said that he was delighted that his service area had been praised. "We try our best. Around 98% of our food is manufactured in-house, to local recipes using local ingredients. It is a genuine team effort."

Mr Ronay adds that, 40 years ago, he had said that no more than one service area should be owned by each operator, as was the case at that time on the German motorways.

"That battle has been lost with a vengeance, but it would still be perfectly possible to create very much more competition, [which is] the only way to improve food and beverages, as proven by standards at Heathrow and Gatwick for example, where competition within terminals was introduced eight years ago.

"Why on earth shouldn't the number of service stations be doubled?

"Millions of motorists must be assured not only of fair price deals, but must be given the chance of consuming simple and really enjoyable food and beverages... I passionately believe that no food or beverage, however humble, has the right to be anything but excellent."

"I fervently believe in free tipping, in rewarding good service generously - and in not tipping at all if I don't feel like it," says Mr Ronay.

Welcome Break Membury, M4

Coffee: scandalously bad, sourish smell, watery, no strength or substance, like black, watery ink.

Cheese sandwich: no cheese flavour whatsoever (of the cheese itself). At a blind tasting it might have been thought to be soap and it did not contain butter or mayonnaise-type spread.

Ham baguette: gigantic-sized with totally flavourless wet ham. Blind - it could have been anything.

Cold meat pie: quite horrible, pressed together, goodness-knows-what. I had to spit it out.

Westmorland Tebay, M6

Westmorland country ham soup: obviously home-made, excellent flavour, though a trifle overcooked ingredients.

Westmorland ham: marvellous, thick-cut, flavoursome, moist.

Ham sandwich: almost Ritz quality, with fresh white bread, well-filled, excellently mayonnaised; very good ham.

Tea: brilliantly clean, fragrant, flavoursome.

Fried fish: really outstanding, crisp batter.

Walnut gateau: first-class, farmhouse type.

fields.headline: Dolphins 'starving to death'
fields.trailText: Scotland's only resident colony of bottle-nosed dolphins are starving to death in the ice-cold waters of the Moray Firth, according to a top naturalist.
fields.body:
Scotland's only resident colony of bottle-nosed dolphins are starving to death in the ice-cold waters of the Moray Firth, according to a top naturalist.

The group of 129 dolphins is steadily deceasing as a result of pollution, human interference like jet skis and speed boats, and the lack of fish.

The fact that these marine animals now cannot find food is a new development which is worrying conservationists.

Tony Archer, manager of the Moray Firth wildlife centre in Spey Bay, near Garmouth, in Moray, said yesterday: "This colony seems to be disappearing at a rate of about 6% a year." He pointed to lack of food as the chief reason.

"The other problem is that if the dolphins are under threat then so are the other mammals like whales which come into the same category. The only way forward is for experts to investigate what is going wrong."

He called for "any possible threats" to be eliminated. "For example we think that dolphins get caught in nets being set illegally in the sea by salmon poachers."

The dolphin colony in the Moray Firth is estimated to be worth millions of pounds to the local economy in tourism terms.

Boats carrying thousands of sightseers during the season operate from a number of ports, including Inverness, Cromarty and Nairn.

fields.headline: Stonehenge project called off
fields.trailText: A project to solve the mystery of Stonehenge was called off yesterday for want of volunteers.
fields.body:
A project to solve the mystery of Stonehenge was called off yesterday for want of volunteers.

Historians have been given a £100,000 national lottery grant to discover how giant stones were transported from west Wales to the site in Wiltshire.

A three tonne slab of rock was loaded on to a wooden sledge for a team of volunteers to drag it all the way by rope.

They aimed to cover three miles-a-day and finish their 240-mile journey from Pembrokeshire to Salisbury Plain by September.

But only 40 people turned up and the huge slab was transported just one mile.

A spokesman for the organisers said: "We are very disappointed - we needed a lot more people to shift the stone three miles. But we will be back next weekend and we still think we can do it."

Experts have identified the type of rock in the inner ring at Stonehenge as Welsh bluestone from the Preseli mountains of Pembrokeshire. But how the huge stones were transported 4,000 years ago has always been a mystery.

fields.headline: Nightmare of lost '£2m ticket'
fields.trailText: John Igo, an unemployed Geordie, claims his lottery win has turned into a nightmare. Believing he had scooped £2m, he posted the winning ticket to Camelot - and it has gone missing.
fields.body:
John Igo, an unemployed Geordie, claims his lottery win has turned into a nightmare. Believing he had scooped £2m, he posted the winning ticket to Camelot - and it has gone missing.

Camelot said it had not received any jackpot tickets, but confirmed a £2m win remains unclaimed for the midweek draw when Mr Igo claimed his numbers came up.

Mr Igo, 42, of Newcastle upon Tyne, said he matched numbers 7, 12, 25, 28, 30 and 40 on Wednesday, March 15.

He said: "I sent my ticket off but haven't heard anything since. People have heard that I have won and they won't leave me alone. I have been threatened and people won't believe me when I say I haven't received a penny of it.

"I've got myself into debt because I splashed out on a new telly and video when my numbers came up."

He added: "I couldn't believe it when I saw my six numbers come up on the telly. I just started crying and my brother was jumping up and down."

A Camelot spokesman said: "Without a ticket you can't claim a prize."

 Four ticket holders shared Saturday's £13.7m national lottery jackpot, each scooping £3,425,000. The numbers were 18, 23, 30, 46, 47 and 49, with 31 the bonus.

The £250,000 Thunderball top prize was unclaimed. Wednesday's superdraw jackpot is a guaranteed £15m.

webTitle: Parents told not to shun MMR jab

fields.headline: Parents told not to shun MMR jab
fields.trailText: The department of health yesterday urged parents not to turn their backs on the mumps, measles and rubella - MMR - vaccine after a report linked it to chronic diseases, including autism, in children.
fields.body:
The department of health yesterday urged parents not to turn their backs on the mumps, measles and rubella - MMR - vaccine after a report linked it to chronic diseases, including autism, in children.

A study of children who developed the brain condition after an apparently healthy infancy found that 24 out of 25 had the measles virus in their gut.

Researchers said the virus could have come from the combined mumps, measles and rubella vaccine, given to hundreds of thousands of children in Britain every year.

John O'Leary, of the Coombe women's hospital in Dublin, and Andrew Wakefield, of London's Royal Free hospital, presented their research to the United States Congress last Thursday and said there was "compelling evidence" linking autism with MMR.

But the department of health rejected the study and said parents should continue to trust the vaccine.

"This is a highly selective sample carried out with incorrect and inappropriate controls and unverifiable by usual scientific means," a department spokeswoman said.

"As such it is uninterpretable. It does not prove anything and there remains no evidence to suggest there is any link between the MMR jab and autism.

"It would be a disaster if children were to die of vaccine-preventable diseases [because of] unfounded vaccine safety scares."

The research is the latest scare over the MMR vaccine, which has been linked to a number of health problems, although other studies have given it the all-clear.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Suicide fears among young
One in eight young people has considered or attempted suicide, a survey published today reveals.
fields.body:
Suicide fears among young
One in eight young people has considered or attempted suicide, a survey published today reveals.

A third of 15- to 34-year-olds think they have suffered from depression and 45% know someone their age who has contemplated, attempted or committed suicide. Suicide accounts for a fifth of all deaths in the age group.

Hard worker quits 14 jobs
Seamus McSporran, 62, thought to have the most jobs in Britain, is to retire from all 14 of them.

His jobs include being policeman, fireman, postmaster, shopkeeper, ambulance, school bus and taxi driver, registrar of births, marriages and deaths, rent collector, and undertaker on the west of Scotland island of Gigha.

Anti-racists arrested
Five Anti Nazi League supporters, including a local councillor, have been charged with public order offences and with assaulting a police officer following clashes with police at the weekend when they protested against a National Front march against asylum seekers in Margate, Kent.

Spy centre staff get damages
Compensation is being paid to staff employed at the GCHQ spy centre in Cheltenham to eavesdrop on transmissions and telephone calls, whose hearing was damaged because of inadequate headphones, a spokesman has confirmed.

More than £500,000 has already been paid out, according to the Sunday Telegraph.

Street robber kills pensioner
Catherine McKenzie, an 84-year-old Glasgow pensioner, died this weekend after being robbed of her shopping and less than £100 in cash, police said. Her pelvis and her arm were broken.

Police have launched a murder inquiry.

webTitle: Tracking device will help keep an eye on children

fields.headline: Tracking device will help keep an eye on children
fields.trailText: Missing toddlers and truanting teenagers could soon be things of the past with the development of a revolutionary satellite tracking system to enable parents to keep an eye on their children 24 hours a day.
fields.body:
Missing toddlers and truanting teenagers could soon be things of the past with the development of a revolutionary satellite tracking system to enable parents to keep an eye on their children 24 hours a day.

A tiny gadget called KidBug will enable parents to monitor the movements of their children - and the manufacturer plans to give them to 10m parents before the end of the year in the expectation that many will pay the £10-a-month fee to use them.

The 4cm sq unit, which can be concealed in a child's clothing, will be able to track the precise location of the child to within five feet using the global positioning satellite tracking system (GPS) more usually used to navigate at sea.

Tony Rose, owner of CarBug plc, which makes tracking devices for cars, boats and bicycles, devised the idea after his three-year-old daughter Natanya went missing during a trip to Brent Cross shopping centre in north London.

He said: "My wife and I were looking in shop windows and she disappeared in those few seconds. Any parent would give anything in the world in those few minutes to know where their child is.

"I thought it would be simple to make a tracking device using the same mapping software we already use to track cars, boats and bikes."

The prototype is already developed and Mr Rose is planning to produce 10m KidBugs in Taiwan at a cost of £500m.

Some parents may use KidBug to monitor older children and teenagers suspected of truanting or mixing with the wrong people.

For £10 a month, parents will get a card to place in the gadget and activate the tracking system. The child's location can be shown on a small map on a mobile phone or computer, using satellite navigation and "triangulation" of the mobile phone networks to get locations within buildings.

"Eventually, KidBug will be the size of a wristwatch and every child will wear one."

Mr Rose plans to distribute the gadgets through schools and doctors' surgeries.

webTitle: HRT women reassured after heart warning

fields.headline: HRT women reassured after heart warning
fields.trailText: Women taking hormone replacement therapy were urged not to worry or stop taking their tablets yesterday despite revelations that 27,000 taking part in an HRT trial in the United States have received letters warning of a possible increased risk of heart attack.
fields.body:
Women taking hormone replacement therapy were urged not to worry or stop taking their tablets yesterday despite revelations that 27,000 taking part in an HRT trial in the United States have received letters warning of a possible increased risk of heart attack.

Trials are going on in America and Britain to determine the long-term safety of HRT. Worries surfaced in the American trial when, at one point, it appeared that the number suffering a heart attack, stroke or blood clot in the legs or lungs was above average. Letters were sent out to all the women.

Scientists involved in a similar trial in the UK have enrolled 1,000 women so far. They said yesterday that the increase in the incidents found in the US study was probably due to chance. According to the Medical Research Council, one of the funding bodies, fewer than one in 100 British women had been adversely affected by the end of the first two years - which was below the average for the general population.

"I think that that there isn't sufficient information to justify any change in the plans for the trial and there isn't sufficient information to justify changing anybody's medication," said Madge Vickers, who is leading the British trial.

fields.headline: Mandelson signals Ulster arms shift
fields.standfirst: Fresh government approach indicated to weapons decommissioning as efforts get under way to rescue Good Friday agreement Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, piled pressure on David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, when he signalled a major shift in government approach towards weapons decommissioning, as a new effort began to save the Good Friday agreement, two years old today.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, piled pressure on David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, when he signalled a major shift in government approach towards weapons decommissioning, as a new effort began to save the Good Friday agreement, two years old today.

Jonathan Powell, Downing Street chief of staff, was involved in fresh talks in Dublin over the weekend with Irish officials, as the two governments thrashed out a common approach to return to devolution. Negotiations involving all parties are expected before Easter.

Mr Mandelson angered Unionists when he indicated at the Alliance party conference on Saturday that it was more important to secure clarity from the IRA on its approach to decommissioning rather than a single act. He said: "An unmistakable gesture of their peaceful intentions would be worth a lot more than a one-off gesture of token decommissioning."

Mr Mandelson added: "We must think twice before linking decommissioning directly to the continuance of the institutions and end up getting neither. Decommissioning is most likely to happen in the context of the implementation of the agreement, including the restoration of the institutions."

Sinn Fein, which held its annual conference in Dublin over the weekend, was sceptical. One senior figure said: "He meanders around on decommissioning depending on the day of the week."

The party said it was because of that very linkage that Mr Mandelson, confronted with Mr Trimble's threat to quit, had suspended the power-sharing executive two months ago. It had lasted 72 days.

Ian Paisley, leader of the anti-agreement Democratic Unionist Party, agreed with Sinn Fein's analysis of Mr Mandelson's comments. But he suggested Mr Mandelson was preparing an escape route for republicans.

The agreement aspires to the completion of decommissioning by May 22. Only the fringe Loyalist Volunteer Force has destroyed any weapons.

Mr Paisley said: "That is complete and total surrender. He said 'I am suspending the assembly because they will not decommission and keep to the May date'. Now he says a token decommissioning is not the thing, a statement of intent will do."

Sinn Fein piled pressure on Mr Trimble with a demand he face down his critics in his party. He was told to sell the agreement to his community. Mitchel McLaughlin, Sinn Fein chairman, said Mr Trimble's only chance of survival was to say: "I am going back into the political institutions." Mr Trimble two weeks ago saw off a leadership challenge, sparked after he suggested he would go back into government with Sinn Fein without a prior handover of IRA weapons. But he beat anti-agreement MP Martin Smyth by only 57% to 43%, and remains wounded.

Mr McLaughlin said: "If he continues to procrastinate, then the opponents in his party will destroy him. We say to David Trimble turn up for business, turn up on Monday morning and he will find republicans are ready to do business." Mr Trimble was very important to the agreement, but no more so than Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams or SDLP leader John Hume, and the peace process mattered more than them all.

Mr Adams told the conference Sinn Fein would stick with attempts to save the agreement. But he warned of the dangers of a political vacuum, and said a return to conflict was possible.

But he beat anti-agreement MP Martin Smyth by only 57% to 43%, and remains wounded. Mr McLaughlin said: "If he continues to procrastinate, then the opponents in his party will destroy him. We say to David Trimble turn up for business, turn up on Monday morning and he will find republicans are ready to do business." Mr Trimble was very important to the agreement, but no more so than Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams or SDLP leader John Hume, and the peace process mattered more than them all. Mr Adams told the conference Sinn Fein would stick with attempts to save the agreement. But he warned of the dangers of a political vacuum, and said a return to conflict was possible.

webTitle: English Nature deflects birds at risk

fields.headline: English Nature deflects birds at risk
fields.trailText: It is such a rare bird that no one had seen one in Cambridgeshire before - the pallas's warbler would have attracted twitchers from all over Britain.
fields.body:
It is such a rare bird that no one had seen one in Cambridgeshire before - the pallas's warbler would have attracted twitchers from all over Britain.

But to the embarrassment of English Nature, the government quango which has the job of protecting rarities, the warbler, having flown 4,000 miles from Siberia, was already dead.

It had killed itself hitting the reflective glass which is the cladding for the organisation's headquarters in Peterborough before a single birdwatcher had a chance to spot it.

The warbler was just one of a never ending series of casualties found at the base of the building. Rare firecrests and commoner robins, blue tits, blackbirds and kingfishers, all theoretically protected by English Nature, are being killed.

Now, on the orders of Baroness Young, English Nature's chairman, hundreds of hawk silhouettes have been hung over the outside of the building to frighten the smaller birds away.

Sue Ellis, of English Nature, who works in the three-storey building with 250 conservationists, said: "We have big trees behind the building and the birds must see the reflections and think they're heading for the next tree."

Contractors used hydraulic lifting gear to place three or four silhouettes on each of the 80 upstairs rear windows, at a cost of some £2,000.

"It's not the shape that matters," said Ms Ellis. "It's more to do with breaking up the reflective surface. The building is going to look very odd but it will give the public some idea of what we are trying to do. One of the messages we'd like to send out is the need for better designed buildings."

Casualties of English Nature's windows are sent to the Institute for Terrestrial Ecology for toxicology tests and identification. Staff at a similar nearby building - housing the Joint Nature Conservation Committee - are less fastidious. One specialist likes to take dead woodcock home for the pot.

Tall buildings with reflective glass are a serious worldwide problem for birds. A study funded by the World Wildlife Fund has suggested buildings in North America - skyscrapers particularly - kill between 100m and 1bn birds each year.

Chris Harbard, of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, said songbirds and small migrants such as warblers were the most likely victims.

More may be learned when the new offices of the Greater London Authority are completed. In addition to the new London mayor, the 10-storey building, which will be clad almost entirely in conservation-grade glass, will house the staff of the London Ecology Unit, many of whom are expert birdwatchers.

The building is situated beside the Thames, one of the capital's busiest flyways, and some observers fear casualties may be high.

The WWF study, called Collision Course, found that birds were safe if enough glass was covered to obscure the reflective effect.

Television towers which are proliferating with the spread of digital TV are another hazard. Two years ago, 10,000 Lapland longspurs died during a snowstorm at one Kansas tower in a single night.

webTitle: RUC investigates 'Irish officer who aided IRA killings'

fields.headline: RUC investigates 'Irish officer who aided IRA killings'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Detectives in Northern Ireland are making fresh inquiries into the murder 11 years ago of two RUC officers amid claims that an Irish police officer colluded with the IRA in their deaths.
fields.body:
Detectives in Northern Ireland are making fresh inquiries into the murder 11 years ago of two RUC officers amid claims that an Irish police officer colluded with the IRA in their deaths.

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, has written to the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, demanding that he call a public inquiry into the allegations. Mr Trimble is expected to table an early day motion on the issue in the Commons this week.

The garda, now retired, is also implicated in IRA murders of eight more people, four of them RUC officers.

All were killed after security breaches and he is suspected of passing secret information on their cross-border movements to the IRA, allowing it to plan the assassinations.

Mr Trimble said in his letter: "The IRA mole who would appear to be responsible has never appeared before a court and was not even reprimanded. Instead, when his identity was uncovered - by the RUC - he was merely posted to another garda station. He now lives contentedly on a garda pension in the Republic of Ireland.

"Given that your government has taken a great interest in establishing RUC complicity with loyalist terrorism, I hope you will now accede to a similar public inquiry into the allegations I mention."

The RUC's new inquiries concern the IRA's murder in March 1989 in south Armagh of Chief Superintendent Harry Breen, the most senior of the 302 RUC officers killed during the troubles, and Superintendent Bob Buchanan.

The IRA ambushed them at Jonesborough, just inside Northern Ireland, as they made their way back from a meeting on IRA smuggling with senior gardai at Dundalk in Co Louth.

The RUC initially believed the officers' unmarked Vauxhall Cavalier had been spotted as it arrived at Dundalk police station and that the IRA had quickly put together a team. But there are now suggestions that the security forces discovered a tip-off phone call came from Dundalk police station.

Mr Breen, who had survived an earlier IRA assassination attempt, was in charge of the Armagh area when the SAS had two years earlier shot dead eight IRA men. The IRA viewed him as an important target.

Mr Trimble also listed other IRA killings he believes should be investigated. He has still to receive a reply from Mr Ahern.

Four RUC officers were killed in May 1985 when a garda escort for a security van passed it over to an RUC patrol. The IRA had received precise details of the handover point, and was able to plant a 1,000lb bomb 50 yards further on, just inside Northern Ireland at Killeen.

One of those killed was a 21-year-old woman officer, Tracy Doak. Her dead colleagues were Steven Rodgers, 19, David Baird, 22, and William Wilson, 28.

In July 1988, the IRA wiped out the Hanna family at the same spot, mistaking them for Judge Eoin Higgins and his wife. They were in a car similar to the judge's.

The garda at the centre of the collusion claims is also implicated in the death three years later of Tom Oliver, 37, a father-of-seven, who farmed close to Dundalk. The IRA abducted, tortured and murdered him for passing information to gardai.

webTitle: Lord Alli plans comeback for Crossroads

fields.headline: Lord Alli plans comeback for Crossroads
fields.trailText: Crossroads, the soap with the shaky sets and shakier storylines, is poised to make a comeback. Lord Waheed Alli, the Carlton Television executive, is to put a proposal to ITV for a remake of the show.
fields.body:
Crossroads, the soap with the shaky sets and shakier storylines, is poised to make a comeback. Lord Waheed Alli, the Carlton Television executive, is to put a proposal to ITV for a remake of the show.

It is not clear whether the new version will feature the trademark closing sequence in which the credits criss-crossed the screen above the distinctive theme tune (once arranged by Paul McCartney), but Lord Alli insists it will be recognisably Crossroads.

If accepted by ITV, which will soon have a daily soap slot that needs filling after Channel 5's successful bid for Home and Away, the show will be made at Carlton's studios in Nottingham.

Lord Alli, Carlton's director of productions, said: "I want to do a soap. I very, very badly want to get that slot vacated by Home and Away."

He said the new Crossroads was likely to be set in a hotel, rather than a motel - "I don't think we have motels any more, do we?"

Lord Alli would not reveal whether he would reintroduce classic characters such as Benny, the odd-job man, but said that the new show would be aimed at a young audience - a pledge sure to strike fear into fans of the original, who blamed meddling producers for precipitating its decline.

Dorothy Hobson, author of Crossroads - The Drama of a Soap Opera (now out of print), was delighted. A hotel was ideal for a soap, because it allowed for a good mix of permanent and visiting characters.

Entrances and exits at a legendary motel

It was 4.35pm on November 2, 1964, when, with the immortal lines "Crossroads motel, can I help you?", actress Jane Rossington (aka Jill Richardson/Harvey/Chance) opened one of the most popular shows on British television. Despite questionable storylines and wobbly sets, the series - created in three days for Lew Grade's ATV and pencilled in for 13 weeks - quickly spawned one of television's most loyal band of fans. Some 17 years later, a public outrcy greeted plans to kill off Noele Gordon's character, the actress herself released a tear-jerking statement of shock, death in the inevitable motel inferno was averted, and matriarch Meg Mortimer sailed off on the QE2 instead. Her departure signalled the beginning of the end for the soap, however. Despite (or perhaps because of) a series of facelifts, viewing figures fell and the last episode was broadcast on April 4, 1988. Crossroads' owners Jill and Adam Chance sold up, and the final scene showed them driving off to start a new hotel business in the west country.

The characters

Meg Mortimer (Noele Gordon)
The matriarch of Crossroads. A single parent, bringing up children and running the motel. A star before joining Crossroads, she became the show's leading light. Inexplicably sacked after 17 years in 1981. Asked back when the series was declining in 1985, but was suffering from cancer and never made that triumphant return.

Jill Chance, Meg's daughter (Jane Rossington)
Rossington was the first character to speak when the series began in 1965, and uttered the last line when the end came in 1988. She still lives in the Midlands and appears in theatre productions.

Amy Turtle (Ann George)
George joined after writing to the producers pointing out that the show, although based in the Midlands, had no strong Birmingham voice. She was offered a walk-on part, and hired on the spot. Became the hotel charlady, and resident gossip. In true Crossroads style, disappeared in the mid 1970s without a word of explanation in the storyline. Made a brief and equally unexplained reappearance as Tommy Lancaster's cleaner in 1987. Victoria Wood based the Mrs Overall character in her Crossroads spoof Acorn Antiques - played by Julie Walters - on Turtle.

Benny (Paul Henry)
The woolly-hatted odd-job man with learning difficulties, sufferer of cruel humour, befriended by kitchen hand Miss Luke (played by Kathy Staff, the best-known Crossroads survivor). A resurrection of his character would have to be handled sensitively, given modern sensibilities. After Crossroads ended, his daughter was killed by a drunk driver. Now lives in a Birmingham pub with his wife, and has recently returned to acting.

Diane Lawton/Parker/Hunter - "Miss Diane" to Benny (Susan Hanson)
Long-serving hotel waitress and a tragic figure: suffered one relationship disaster after another. One husband fled across the Atlantic with their child - "little Nicky". Benny's favourite person. Married sixties pop star Carl Wayne, of The Move, and little heard-of since the demise of Crossroads.

webTitle: Police sued over woman's death during 999 call

fields.headline: Police sued over woman's death during 999 call
fields.trailText: The family of a woman who bled to death after the police allegedly stopped paramedics reaching her for nearly an hour are to sue officers for negligence.
fields.body:
The family of a woman who bled to death after the police allegedly stopped paramedics reaching her for nearly an hour are to sue officers for negligence.

Loraine Whiting made a 999 call after being shot by her estranged husband Leonard Carter in Sittingbourne, Kent. While Mrs Whiting, 49, was on the line to emergency operators, Carter shot her again before shooting himself through the head.

A transcript of the 999 call shows Mrs Whiting saying 30 times that her husband was dead and pleading for help.

An ambulance reached the scene within seven minutes of her call, but police stayed outside the house fearing that the gunman could be alive and open fire on them and paramedics if they entered.

The family of Mrs Whiting, who was shot in both ankles and in one thigh, say if police had entered sooner she would have survived.

Lawyers for Mrs Whiting's daughter, Catherine Elvin, 29, said yesterday they would sue Kent police for negligence. They claim Mrs Whiting would have had a 98% chance of survival if officers had entered the house sooner, and that a senior officer ignored her rapidly deteriorating condition.

Mrs Whiting called 999 at 12.26am on March 10 1995.

She told the operator: "I'm dying, I'm shot." She was reassured that help was on the way and a tape of the call records her being shot again. Her husband, who had tricked his way into the house, can then be heard saying, "Kid, I'm going to kill myself," before committing suicide.

By 12.38am she told a police operator who stayed on the line with her that Carter was dead. The operator repeatedly offered comfort and reassured her help was on the way as she lay with her husband's corpse by her side, with police and paramedics outside the house.

Mrs Whiting's last words were. "No one's coming, are they. No one's coming. Please come in."

Mrs Whiting's family have been further angered by Kent police's refusal to hand over documents relating to the incident and a tape of the 999 call.

In a letter the force's solicitor wrote: "The reason this will not be released is that it is an extremely traumatic item to listen to. This then has the potential to cause grave unease, possibly trauma to others for whom the chief constable has responsibility, and even to members of the public, should its contents be published."

Mark Pugash, spokesman for Kent police, yesterday condemned those who criticised the actions of the police officers.

He said: "The only legitimate position to look at this from is that you're outside the house, knowing what the officers knew, and ask yourself hand on heart would you have done anything differently?

"There was no way of determining if the situation Loraine Whiting described is accurate or because someone had put a gun to her head."

An investigation by the police complaints authority cleared officers of wrongdoing.

Desperate plea for help that never came

The call from Loraine Whiting is logged at 00.26 on March 10 1995. It lasts 61 minutes and nine seconds:

Elapsed time: 00.01

BT operator: Which service?

Whiting: Ruins Barn Road, number 48. I've been shot.

Operator: You've been shot?

Whiting: I'm dying - I'm shot.

00.14 Call passed to ambulance operator Anneka West. Whiting names husband Len Carter as gunman. West calls Loraine "Lynn".

00.58 West: Are you all right?

01.04 Whiting: Yeah. He's somewhere in the house.

01.07 West: We've got some one on the way to you - we've got the police on the way too.

01.16 Background noises, then a male voice.

01.18 West: Has it come out or is it still in your leg?

01.19 Whiting (whispering): I can't talk, I can't talk.

01.38 Sounds of footsteps then heavy breathing.

01.51 A bang is heard, possibly from a shotgun. Another is heard a minute later.

01.56 Screaming heard.

02.01 Another bang is heard.

02.21 West: I can hear her breathing.

02.41 Carter: ... Kid... I'm going to kill myself.

03.31 Another bang is heard

12.42 Whiting: I've been shot. He's shot himself.

12.51 West: He's shot himself. You think he's dead?

Whiting: Yeah and I'm dying.

13.27 West: We've got the police and ambulance outside. They'll be into you very shortly - you say he's shot himself? Where's he shot himself?

Whiting: In the head.

13.55 West: Is he in the same room as you Lynn?

Whiting: Yeah.

15.58 Whiting: I'm gonna go in a minute, I know, I know.

West: Keep talking to me, you're not going to die.

20.24 Mrs Whiting's first contact with police. She talks to PC Hillman.

20.32 Whiting: I'm going. I've got no blood in me. Get in here.

22.32 Whiting: I'm not gonna die - I'm not gonna die.

40.19 Whiting repeatedly asks: "Are you coming? Are you coming? Please put me out of my misery, please.

Hillman: You'll be all right.

42.36 Whiting: There's no one else. Please come and kill me.

43.12 Whiting: Just someone come in - he's dead. He put the gun in his mouth.

Hillman: Where is he?

Whiting: In the lounge, by me.

43.21 Hillman: We're coming in sweet. You'll be OK I promise - I'm not going to let you die. You keep talking to me honey.

51.42 Whiting: No one's coming are they. No one's coming. Please come in.
