fields.headline: New crackdown on rowdy pubs
fields.trailText: Rowdy pubs will be closed down under a radical new system in which landlords will have points deducted from a driving licence-style permit, the government will announce today.
fields.body:
Rowdy pubs will be closed down under a radical new system in which landlords will have points deducted from a driving licence-style permit, the government will announce today.

The measure, which will bring relief to local residents plagued by noisy pubs, will be outlined in a white paper that will introduce 24-hour drinking in Britain for the first time.

In the most sweeping changes to licensing laws since the first world war, the home secretary, Jack Straw, will announce a series of measures tightening some laws and liberalising others.

Ministers, who have spent months working out the details of the white paper, believe the law needs to be tightened to clamp down on pubs that are regular centres of trouble.

Under the plans local councils, which are to be handed licensing powers currently held by magistrates, will operate a penalty points system that will disqualify landlords in a system modelled on the way punishments are determined for speeding motorists.

The government believes the licensing laws do not work properly because pubs can only be closed down for breaking their licences. Those that are centres of trouble escape with little more than verbal warnings from police.

A government source said last night: "It is quite difficult to produce sanctions against pubs that are centres of trouble. At the moment it is shut down or nothing."

The most sweeping change in today's white paper, which has been widely trailed, will lead to continental-style 24-hour opening hours.

Mr Straw wants to encourage pubs to adopt staggered closing times to avoid the drunken scenes when pubs close at 11pm. The police have long campaigned for such a move because their resources are stretched when drinkers spill on to the streets at the same time.

Ministers believe that 24-hour drinking is only likely to occur in seaside resorts and town centres, with most pubs closing by midnight or 1am. However, landlords will be allowed to apply for licences that will allow them to remain open all night for special occasions, such as weddings.

The decision to hand licensing powers to local authorities is designed to ensure a better partnership to tackle alcohol-related violence. Ministers have been impressed by a scheme in Cardiff in which local hospitals have liaised with the police to warn of high levels of alcohol abuse at certain pubs in the city centre.

The government believes that local councils, which have recently been given a statutory obligation to deal with crime, are able to respond more effectively than magistrates.

The white paper will also tighten up on under-age drinking by abolishing a series of anomalies. At the moment children as young as five are able to drink in pub gardens. Under the new proposals, nobody under the age of 18 will be able to drink there.

The Brewers' and Licensed Retailers' Association gave a warm welcome to Mr Straw's plans. Rob Hayward, its chief executive, said it was right to reform Britain's "antiquated and ramshackle" licensing laws.

One law that will be abolished is the privilege, dating back to 1382, that allows Cambridge University to grant licences to sell wine.

fields.headline: Blair to help parents adopt
fields.standfirst: Report reveals hundreds trapped in care system
fields.trailText: A national register to link children awaiting adoption with adults approved to be adopters is being considered by ministers following a report that revealed the large number of youngsters languishing for years in the care system.
fields.body:
A national register to link children awaiting adoption with adults approved to be adopters is being considered by ministers following a report that revealed the large number of youngsters languishing for years in the care system.

The idea of a computerised register emerged yesterday as the government published a report showing that 2,400 children in care in England were ready for adoption and awaiting a match with a family. Yet 1,300 approved families were also unmatched.

John Hutton, the social care minister, said he and his colleagues were not prepared to "sit on our bums" while children were left to drift in the care system and were denied the security a permanent family placement could give them.

"Potential adopters can wait a year to begin the process to become a parent. This isn't acceptable," Mr Hutton said.

"While the report shows that there are pockets of good practice on adoption, there is a hard core of local authorities who are lagging behind."

The number of children being adopted from care is rising. In 1998-99, the total increased about 10% to 2,162. This means some 4% of all those in care were adopted during the course of the year.

Performance varied widely across the country, however, Mr Sutton said. Sutton, in south London was achieved an adoption rate of 20% while other London boroughs recorded rates of just 1%.

Social services performance figures, published last year, suggested three London boroughs - Barnet, Lambeth and Ealing, had rates of less than 1% in 1998-99. Four authorities outside London - Bath and North-East Somerset, Reading, Warwickshire and West Berkshire - performed as poorly, though the figures were in many cases disputed.

The new report, details of which were revealed by the Guardian last year, is based on the first UK survey of adoption performance by the social services inspectorate.

The survey, carried out last July and August, found that about 5,000 children in care were considered suitable for adoption, but barely half were matched with a family. Of those waiting, 6% were black and 11% of mixed race.

Officials believe that many of the 1,300 unmatched families are not prepared to take on children with the scale of disabilities and psychological and behavioural problems now common among those in care.

Mr Hutton announced that the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering was being asked to co-ordinate a working group to produce national standards on adoption, to be published for consultation in 2001. Issues would include the recruitment of adopters.

Felicity Collier, the BAAF chief executive, said it was hard to see how progress could be made without a central register of children awaiting adoption and approved, would be adopters.

"It is vital that approved adopters are seen as a national resource rather than, as happens in too many cases, the property of small local authorities which may not have the right children needing new families at a particular time," Ms Collier said.

It is understood that plans for a central register have been discussed in Whitehall. Next month, a report on adoption is due to be submitted by the Cabinet Office's performance and innovation unit, through Mr Hutton, to a ministerial group on adoption led by the prime minister, Tony Blair. Jo Williams, the president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said that while a national register might raise practical problems, a network of regional databases would help in tackling the problem.

"OK, performance is patchy and there are problems where adoption has not been a priority," said Ms Williams, director for Cheshire. "But what we do not want to see is children being railroaded into adoption."

"We run a secure unit and some of our most difficult children are those where a placement has broken down. We must be measured about this."

webTitle: Nasty Tory faction led me to quit, says MP who took Harrods job

fields.headline: Nasty Tory faction led me to quit, says MP who took Harrods job
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Charles Wardle, the former Home Office minister who has accepted a £120,000 directorship from Mohamed Al Fayed, is to stand down from parliament, blaming a "deeply unpleasant faction" which has taken over the party under William Hague's leadership.
fields.body:
Charles Wardle, the former Home Office minister who has accepted a £120,000 directorship from Mohamed Al Fayed, is to stand down from parliament, blaming a "deeply unpleasant faction" which has taken over the party under William Hague's leadership.

In a letter to his Bexhill and Battle Conservative association, Mr Wardle expressed deep regret over his decision, which had not been forced on him by local activists opposed to his decision to join the Harrods board.

"There are better things to do with my life than to scrap with the shrill, deeply unpleasant faction inside and outside Westminster who are in danger of dislocating the party from the wider electorate," Mr Wardle said in his letter announcing that he would not contest the next election despite being renominated in January.

"I have always loved working in the constituency but life has become very drab in the House of Commons and this awful Labour government treats parliament with contempt. In contrast to this, the business challenge at Harrods is interesting and stimulating."

Mr Wardle made the decision to stand down after Mr Fayed told him that he could increase his workload at Harrods if he abandoned the "low life and half men in Westminster".

The former minister, who turned down Mr Fayed's application for British citizenship in 1993, also threatened to sue the Daily Telegraph after it lampooned his decision to accept a £120,000 non-executive Harrods directorship.

Mr Wardle believes he was libelled on Wednesday when the newspaper printed a cartoon of him diving into a giant brown Harrods envelope stuffed with £50 notes.

Mr Fayed is understood to have assured Mr Wardle that he will underwrite his legal expenses if the case goes to court.

Mr Wardle's appointment to the Harrods board, which was cleared with the Tory whips and with the parliamentary standards commissioner, horrified many Tories.

Mr Wardle, who disclosed his new two days a week appointment in last Tuesday's Guardian, insisted that Mr Fayed's business interests were all above board.

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Roseanna's Grave | Jubilee | Bob And Carol And Ted And Alice | Voyager
fields.body:
Voyager

8pm, Sky One

Meanwhile, back in the Delta Quadrant, Voyager is still fending off the advances of fellow lost-in-space travellers USS Equinox whom they met at the end of season five. Their Captain Ransom has ignored the Prime Directive and embarked on a less than Trek-like voyage, killing at will in order to speed his crew's homeward journey. Not the sort of thing that Janeway is likely to let go lightly, particularly after he's left her to fight off a group of vicious aliens, and she's soon tearing after him to refresh his intergalactic protocol.

Bob And Carol And Ted And Alice (Paul Mazursky, 1969)

9.15pm, 3am, Carlton Cinema

Looks not so much dated as prehistoric now, but Mazursky's comic take on the 60s era of free love, and the upper middle-class California scene in particular, is well-acted and funny, and at times it's even touching. Robert Culp and Natalie Wood are the couple learning to swing, but in bed with pals Elliott Gould and Dyan Cannon, no one knows quite what to do. A sort of The Ice Storm played for laughs.

Jubilee (Derek Jarman, 1978)

10.30pm, FilmFour

Despairing view of a punk futureworld as viewed by Queen Elizabeth I (Jenny Runacre), travelling through time to witness the nation's collapse. A harsh punk score and the likes of Little Nell and Toyah Wilcox set the nihilistic tone. It's all ultimately supposed to reflect the grubby present, with the pill sweetened by a certain amount of rather bitter humour.

Roseanna's Grave (Paul Weiland, 1997)

2.15am, Sky Premier

Charming tale of an apparently doomed love. Jean Reno is Marcello, husband of Mercedes Ruehl's Roseanna, who is suffering from a fatal heart condition. Her one wish is to be buried in the village cemetery, so Marcello will have to work wonders keeping the old and ailing villagers alive in order to reserve the only spot left. And there's a dark secret at the centre of this captivating romantic comedy - why does wealthy Capestro (Luigi Diberti) refuse to sell his land for graveyard overspill?

fields.headline: Welcome to hell
fields.trailText: If you didn't get to see Correspondent (BBC2), count yourself lucky. You wouldn't have wanted these images of exquisite pain etched on your retina: bony children lying on stone floors, whimpering like animals; babies rocking in their own sick, cots drenched in urine; teenage girls, who should be doing each other's hair and listening to the Spice Girls, licking the floor like dogs. This was Goya come to half-death. And you wouldn't have wanted to see it. Believe me.
fields.body:
If you didn't get to see Correspondent (BBC2), count yourself lucky. You wouldn't have wanted these images of exquisite pain etched on your retina: bony children lying on stone floors, whimpering like animals; babies rocking in their own sick, cots drenched in urine; teenage girls, who should be doing each other's hair and listening to the Spice Girls, licking the floor like dogs. This was Goya come to half-death. And you wouldn't have wanted to see it. Believe me.

Correspondent Jez Higham joined a group of Belfast men - plumbers, joiners, carpenters - who'd seen the same pictures, taken at an orphanage for girls in Moldavia in 1999, and couldn't stomach their dinner, or any more dinners after that. With compassion guns blazing, they loaded up a lorry with fresh food and teddy bears and headed off to do... something.

At the orphanage, they fixed the heating, burnt old bedding and painted the nursery. The orphanage director, grown fat on selling orphanage food on the black market, waited for the men and their western TV cameras to leave.

Higham, the reporter, shared the Belfast men's anger. What unfolded was a film not just about the complexity of intervening, but about the nature of the correspondent. If their role is no longer to march into a scene of utter human desolation and ask, "Has anyone here been raped and speaks English?", then what is it to be?

Higham decided to play an active part in the story. He interviewed the President of Moldavia (a bigger crook than the orphanage director), demonstrating the chimera of objectivity (most of all, for the correspondent). More depressingly, he showed that we're all complicit in the charade of believing we can do... something. A year on, the food had gone, the bedding was sold. The children were still rocking quietly to themselves in corners. Before the men left, a Moldovian woman asked: what about my children? Pain and suffering are relative, misery can always be contextualised, but this film showed we have to make a stand somewhere. If only for our own selfish sanity.

Alain De Botton continued to search for happiness in the ruins of Athens, finding the site of Epicurus's house on a disused car lot. Philosophy: A Guide To Happiness (C4) made the comforting point that happiness requires very little money. Epicurus boiled it down to three points: (1) friends; (2) an analysed life; (3) self-sufficiency. To illustrate the inverse correlation between money and happiness, De Botton adopted the style of Vision On's mad professor, standing in a field with a graph. "Imagine this side are levels of happiness, and this side, levels of money. For Epicurus, you should be happy about... [draws arbitrary point on graph in big fat marker pen, heavy wind blowing comb-over hair all over place]... here!"

Power Into Art (C4) followed some hard hats round the steel-lattice cathedral of the new Tate, a disused power station (hence the cunning title). The hats were led by Chief Hat, Ian Blake, who gestured upwards. The hats turned en masse to view a girder on the 95th floor, nodding sagely in unison. Ian motioned with his hand and they waddled off in smart new fluorescent smocks like a family of emperor penguins.

Back at Norman Foster's Master Of the Universe offices overlooking the Thames, a nervous Swiss architect explained his "mound solution" to Foster's footbridge. Foster is probably the most intimidating adversary since The Colossus Of Rhodes. Perfectly suited, measured in his use of each syllable, Foster finds 27 ways of saying no, all of them fantastically polite. But each one slowly turning the Swiss architect to dust.

Top Ten New Romantics (C4) gained some unintentional publicity on Friday with Steve Strange's arrest for shoplifting - make-up, some clothes and a Tellytubby (they didn't say which one).

The extraordinary thing about this show (apart from how fantastic it is to be bludgeoned with nostalgia for an hour and a half) is how Terrahawkishly old everyone looks. Boy George looked like Julie Burchill; Philip Salon, wearing pirate pantaloons in his Brent Cross bedsit, looked like Lesley Joseph. Billy Currie now looks like Timothy Spall. Steve was there, of course, looking rather unwell. "I still have a lot of ambitions. I, er, want to achieve... Sorry, I'll do that again." You really wanted to give the guy a break.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Composer Of The Week | Jools Holland
fields.body:
Radio 3's Composer Of The Week (9am) is a place, not a person: The Court Of Dresden. Under Augustus the Strong, Elector of Saxony, this Florence on the Elbe attracted some of Europe's finest painters, architects and, of course, musicians. Augustus was famed for his generous wages, and although Heinichen, Veracini, Pisendel and Zelenka - today's featured composers - will be new to many listeners, Vivaldi who is featured on Friday was also drawn north by Dresden's reputation.

It's a tribute to Jools Holland (Radio 2, 8.30pm) that he can trumpet the 100th edition of Later, his BBC2 show, on the radio without ever seeming too smug. He and producer Mark Cooper reminisce about the days when, despite having no set, only one microphone and one camera, Later gave TV debuts to Portishead and Macy Gray. The two music lovers muse on past triumphs and play some great tracks.

The two music lovers muse on past triumphs and play some great tracks.

fields.headline: Fast-forward
fields.trailText: Despite increased competition between networks bringing more last-minute schedule changes, two peak-time weekday programmes for the BBC1 schedules of spring 2020 and 2021 are already theoretically in place.
fields.body:
Despite increased competition between networks bringing more last-minute schedule changes, two peak-time weekday programmes for the BBC1 schedules of spring 2020 and 2021 are already theoretically in place.

Two months after launching Child Of Our Time - in which Professor Robert Winston follows a group of Y2K children through two decades - BBC1 Controller Peter Salmon now begins 7 Up 2000 (Thursday, 9.35pm, BBC1), a 21st century imitation by producer Julian Farino of Michael Apted's series for Granada, in which a set of current seven-year-olds will be revisited at seven-year intervals.

Though independently made, these series are obviously twin projects in the Controller's mind. Visually they're very similar - factual versions of the long observation technique used by the late novelist Anthony Powell in A Dance To The Music Of Time - and both weight their samples by class, race and location. But the emphases differ. Winston is scientifically assessing the relative importance of environment and genetics. Farino's scope is mainly social. In one sense, his selection already looks polemical. A startling number of his observation squad of 19 children live with only one parent.

This new 7 Up - like the original - is compelling anthropological soap opera but feels less fresh than the Winston. And, given the conventional wisdom that people today are more sophisticated about the media, it would have been intriguing to know about negotiations with the families. Were they greedier than the guardians of Apted's class of '64?

Of course, both fast-forward series are fascinating in terms of BBC psychology. At a time when the future direction and even existence of the BBC have never been in greater doubt, Peter Salmon has committed the Corporation to series stretching beyond the retirement dates of most of those now running it. Perhaps it's a private mind-game, like sending a relative from the intensive care unit to buy you a five-year diary.

webTitle: Brown's tax cut 'favours rich men over poor women'

fields.headline: Brown's tax cut 'favours rich men over poor women'
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown discriminated in favour of rich men at the expense of low paid women in his recent tax cut, the Liberal Democrats claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown discriminated in favour of rich men at the expense of low paid women in his recent tax cut, the Liberal Democrats claimed yesterday.

In a direct challenge to the chancellor's claim to champion the hard-working low-paid, the Lib Dems said that research had found that the tax bill for the average man had fallen, while women in a similar position had seen their bills rise.

Matthew Taylor, the Lib Dem treasury spokesman, said last night: "Gordon Brown pretends he is Robin Hood. But he is more like the Sheriff of Nottingham with his policies hitting the poor or women."

His remarks came after research with the help of the Commons library found that the recent 1p cut in the basic rate of income tax had favoured Britain's richest 10%, who secured a £720m windfall. This compared with virtually nothing for the poorest 10% and £650m for the poorest 60% put together.

As men earned substantially more than women, this meant that men had enjoyed substantial benefits. A third of men earn more than £25,000 a year, compared with 16% of women.

Mr Taylor said that Lib Dems would end the penalisation of low-paid women. He pointed out that, in their alternative budget, they had pledged to cut the new 10p starter tax rate to zero, a move which would help the 1.6m earning less £5,900 a year who only pay this rate. This would be funded through a new 50% tax band for people earning more than £100,000 a year.

Mr Taylor said: "The chancellor claimed his budget was building a fairer Britain, but in fact his tax changes favour top earners and men.

"A 50% tax band on earnings over £100,000 a year would help to cut the 10% rate to zero, delivering big tax cuts to low and middle income earners."

The Lib Dems also rounded on the chancellor for failing to reduce council tax rises - due to be 3.8% above inflation this year - that were hitting poorer families. The research paper said that council tax cost families in the poorest 20% of households 6% of their income, compared to 2% in the richest households.

A Labour spokesman last night dismissed the Lib Dem research. "The national minimum wage, the 10p starting rate, and the working families tax credit are all proof that Labour is working hard for hard-working families who would be hit hard by the Liberel Democrat tax hike. We do not need to take lectures from them."

fields.headline: Vivian Fine
fields.trailText: Vivian Fine, who has died aged 86 after a car accident, was a prolific composer of voice, ballet, orchestra and chamber works, and a concert pianist. The only female member of Aaron Copland's Young Composers' Group, she wrote for choreographers, including Martha Graham.
fields.body:
Vivian Fine, who has died aged 86 after a car accident, was a prolific composer of voice, ballet, orchestra and chamber works, and a concert pianist. The only female member of Aaron Copland's Young Composers' Group, she wrote for choreographers, including Martha Graham.

Fine was born in Chicago, into a family of Russian-Jewish immigrants, and began her piano studies at the age of three. Recognised as a child prodigy, she went on two years later to win a scholarship to the Chicago Musical College. By the age of 11, she was a pupil of Djane Lavoie-Herz. Herz arranged to have one of her other students, Ruth Crawford, give theory lessons to Fine. As an assignment, Crawford asked Fine to write a short piece, and Fine claimed it was the expression on Crawford's face on seeing this first work that led to her becoming a composer.

With her mother's permission, Fine left high school and devoted her energies to furthering her piano and compositional skills. In 1926, she received a scholarship to study counterpoint with Adolph Weidig at the American Conservatory of Music, and made her debut as a composer with a performance of Solo for Oboe (1929) at Carnegie Hall when she was just 16 years old. In 1931, still in her teens, Fine moved to New York, where she quickly established an excellent reputation as a freelance dance accompanist.

She was recognised as an outstanding performer of difficult contemporary works and Aaron Copland invited her to join his Young Composers' Group in 1932, where she was the only woman in the company. Copland also included her in the first Yaddo Festival (1932), where she performed her Four Polyphonic Pieces for piano to critical acclaim. In 1934, she continued her composition studies with Roger Sessions, at what she called the "end of the avant-garde era", and stopped writing experimental music, engaging in a more conventional and consonant style. Fine produced a tremendous repertoire; some of her best known works include Prelude for string quartet (1937), Concertante for piano and orchestra (1943), the witty Guide to the Life Expectancy of a Rose (1956), based on texts from the New York Times garden page; Meeting for Equal Rights 1866 (1975); and Drama for Orchestra (1982), which was nominated for the Pulitzer Prize. She wrote two operas, Women in the Garden (1978), and the autobiographical, multi-media work Memoirs of Uliana Rooney (with librettist Sonya Friedman), both of which explored feminist issues.

She also taught composition at New York University, the Juilliard School, State University Teacher's College at Potsdam, and Bennington College.

Vivian Fine is survived by her husband, sculptor Ben Karp, and two daughters, Peggy and Nina.  Vivian Fine, composer and pianist, born September 28, 1913; died March 22 2000

fields.headline: Truth and nail
fields.standfirst:
Gary Mitchell is that rare thing in Northern Ireland: a loyalist playwright. He talks to Fiachra Gibbons about the struggle, and his latest work

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Gary Mitchell is that rare thing in Northern Ireland: a loyalist playwright. He talks to Fiachra Gibbons about the struggle, and his latest work
fields.body:
Gary Mitchell can handle the knocks on his door from men with notches on their guns wanting a "quiet word" about his plays. The threats in the street from the less subtle local heavies is also something "you have to expect".

What keeps Mitchell awake at night is not the fear of losing a kneecap, but of some sniper in the dark saying he's written a bad play. "It's reviews that scare me," he says. "Someone leaving the theatre saying it's not very good, that I haven't been completely truthful."

Mitchell is a rare beast. He is a playwright from Rathcoole, a sprawling loyalist estate in north Belfast. What is more, he chose to stay put and live among the eejit hoods, unhappy wives and thwarted idealists he writes about. Not for him comfortable anonymity in a middle-class suburb. Not an inch.

His family didn't know what to make of him. "Protestants don't write plays, you see. You must be a Catholic or a Catholic sympathiser, or a homosexual to do that. No one in our community does that because playwriting is a silly pretend thing."

Into this culture of silence and distrust, Mitchell has been lobbing grenade after grenade for 10 years, and with each one his aim has become more sure. In a Little World of Our Own was a raw howl of righteous anger at the "hard men" who warp the values of everyone around them. "People just sat there afterwards in silence, not leaving the theatre," Mitchell recalls. One after-show discussion lasted longer than the play itself. Trust went further, setting loyalties to lovers, tribe and children against one another. Two years ago came As the Beast Sleeps, with paramilitaries turning on each other in the phoney peace of ceasefire - an augury of the internecine warfare now being waged between the UVF and LVF.

Lately, as Mitchell's work has popped up on TV and radio, threats have given way to honking horns and shouts of "Keep the faith, Gary!" One night 90 of Rathcoole's finest trooped into Belfast to see In a Little World of Our Own. "It was great," says Mitchell. "Not having been to a play before, they did all the wrong things - they talked, they rustled their sweets, and they drank. The theatre had to get five extra bar staff in to cope. For the first time they understood what I was at."

That goodwill will be tested by his new play, The Force of Change. For Mitchell is tackling the greatest taboo - collusion between the RUC and loyalist paramilitaries. Even the good cops in the play are finally corrupted by their own prejudice and their instinct to cover up. "If they look into their hearts, no one can deny the truth of my play," insists Mitchell.

Still, this is not what the Unionist people want to hear right now. Collusion is the stick with which nationalists have beaten the police for years, alleging they worked hand in glove with the UVF and the UFF, supplying them with intelligence on republican suspects. For Mitchell to question the RUC at a time when Unionists are fighting plans to change its name and structure will be seen as playing into the enemy's hands. What makes this perceived treachery worse is that Mitchell is a loyalist from a hardline area who flirted with the paramilitaries. He should know the score.

"I grew up completely loyalist, completely Unionist, completely Protestant," says Mitchell. "I believed it all. I was very frightened of this Catholic monster that was raping my community and trying to kill us all. I tried to involve myself in the UDA and find out where the UVF was. I tried to play my part, I wanted to bring the war to them. I did some bad stuff to some people to prove myself but I was racked with guilt. My conscience would never let me go to the levels of criminality you needed to. People put it down to a lack of masculinity. I was full of weakness but those weaknesses I now see as my strengths. I have an inability to break the law. I tried but my conscience kept calling me back, and I question everything."

The Protestant work ethic was the first shibboleth he found wanting. Mitchell, 34, left school at 16 and was unemployed for eight years. What happens to the work ethic when there's no work? "I couldn't get respect, I couldn't get anything that offered me dignity. Without a job in Rathcoole you can't get a girlfriend unless you got involved [in paramilitary politics]."

The truth matters a lot to Gary Mitchell. No one has entirely good motives in his plays. Caroline, the lone woman detective in The Force of Change, should be the heroine as a working mother, but she's too busy using her colleagues' sexism and sectarianism to lever herself up the greasy pole. Truth, Mitchell says, was the first victim of the Troubles. "When things are so obviously fucked up, no one wants to listen to the guy pointing to the sties in everyone's eyes. Everyone wants to keep a lid on things - naturally, they've got to live. But if you're a playwright, that's your job."

With true dissenter steeliness, Mitchell argues you cannot be a true loyalist unless you are "loyal to the truth. I have not let the side down by writing this play. If anybody has let the side down, it is the RUC and those criminal elements within paramilitaries." After Drumcree, when the RUC "stood against its own people" to defend the nationalists of the Garvaghy Road, "it lost the faith of the people. In loyalist eyes, they were supposed to be our defenders."

Still, Mitchell says he has sympathy for grassroots RUC officers. We are asking a lot of them. Not so long ago they thought nationalists were out to kill them; now they are supposed to look after them as if nothing ever happened."

Reforming the police is only the beginning, he says. The whole Unionist identity has to be recast. "There is a fundamental crisis in Protestant culture. We have been going through an extremely depressing loss of identity, loss of culture, and worst of all, loss of a future. The past has been hijacked by the other side. They seem to have this huge mythic past, while the Protestant community has this little crappy one. We're hugely divided. Umpteen churches, umpteen political parties. When you have an enemy who is succeeding on every level, you need a new strategy. While we've been saying 'Not an inch' we have been losing miles.

"We need a new beginning, a reinvention. We have got to recognise our Irishness without giving up our Britishness. The problem of Northern Ireland over the past 30 years has been that the worst of Britishness has clashed with the worst kind of Irishness. No one in Scotland wants to be British, no one in Wales wants to be British any more, and the English never thought of themselves as British in the first place. So you have got us, who are not even in Britain, saying the most important thing to us is to be British. Us and bloody Al Fayed, of course."

Knowing that the southern Irish want their nationalist cousins about as much as the British want the Unionists, Mitchell sees hope only in an independent Ulster where "we will have to get on".

His thinking may be visionary, but Mitchell doesn't look like a prophet about to lead his people to the promised land. He wears a baggy, battered brown leather jacket of a type once briefly fashionable about 15 years ago. There's a softness about him too, a kind of squashed look of someone who has spent his life pushing against an immovable object. His background is straight-down-the-line decent, God-fearing, working-class Prod. His father, Chuck Mitchell, was a country and western singer and semi-professional footballer. Gary, however, is no athlete; as he cheerily admits, his brother, an Elim Pentecostalist preacher, got the lion's share of the handsome showbiz genes.

He started writing after finally getting a job as a civil servant filing compensation claims from the victims of violence. "Bomb damage stuff, personal injury, the usual was mind-bending dull. It nearly broke me. The only good thing was it got me meeting Catholics. One day I decided I was either going to have to shoot myself in the head or do something. I started to improvise life. Which is what plays are, I suppose - improvised life."

That is what Northern Ireland has to do now, he argues. Be creative, take risks. "Often you wonder if anyone is listening. The isolation can be terrible. There are so few people writing from the loyalist, Protestant perspective. There is no space for dissenting voices in Northern Ireland. You're with us or you're not." It's the loneliness of the long-distance visionary. But Mitchell has more company than he thinks.

webTitle: 'Red Oskar' gives Schröder notice he could be back

fields.headline: 'Red Oskar' gives Schröder notice he could be back
fields.trailText: Oskar Lafontaine, whose leftwing convictions propelled him from the German cabinet last year, sent out a clear signal at the weekend that he has not given up his political ambitions.
fields.body:
Oskar Lafontaine, whose leftwing convictions propelled him from the German cabinet last year, sent out a clear signal at the weekend that he has not given up his political ambitions.

In his first high-profile party address since storming out of Gerhard Schröder's government last year, the former finance minister apologised on Saturday for the damage his resignation had done to the Social Democratic party (SPD). But he added: "I would like to make it clear that I have not taken my leave of the SPD and that I am ready to put things right again."

Mr Lafontaine, branded "Red Oskar" by his critics, gave up his seat in the cabinet after losing a longrunning battle with the much less ideological chancellor. He published a critical book, The Heart Beats on the Left, which supplied him with the platform for a comeback. And, with the Social Democrats losing one election after another, a victorious return by Mr Lafontaine could not have been ruled out.

Since last November, however, everything has been going the way of his rivals and critics within the party. The scandal which erupted about the funding of the centre-right Christian Democrat Union (CDU), has drained the main opposition party of support and provided Mr Schröder's government with a freedom to manoeuvre that was previously unthinkable.

In February, despite a programme of government fiscal restraint, the Social Democrats won a comfortable victory in Schleswig-Holstein, where they had once been seen heading for the latest in a string of mid-term defeats.

fields.headline: 19 Marines die in air crash
fields.trailText: A controversial new aircraft which the Pentagon hopes will play the leading role in 21st century expeditionary warfare crashed during a test flight in Arizona on Saturday, killing all 19 passengers and raising fresh doubts about the viability of a project that has been long criticised for its cost and reliability.
fields.body:
A controversial new aircraft which the Pentagon hopes will play the leading role in 21st century expeditionary warfare crashed during a test flight in Arizona on Saturday, killing all 19 passengers and raising fresh doubts about the viability of a project that has been long criticised for its cost and reliability.

The US Marine Corps MV-22 Osprey "convertiplane" - which looks like a cross between a plane and a helicopter - crashed in a fireball while landing at Marana, north-west of Tucson. The plane went down during an exercise in which it and another Osprey were simulating the evacuation of civilians from a war zone.

Witnesses on Saturday evening said that the aircraft headed "straight downward", according to Katy Heiden, a spokeswoman for the local fire service. "It was fully engulfed and there were small explosions," Ms Heiden said.

The dead included four crew members and 15 passengers, all of whom were US marines. The flight was on the first leg of a scheduled return flight from the Marine Corps Air Station near Yuma in western Arizona, around 250 miles away, a marines spokesman said.

Television pictures from the scene of the crash showed smoke rising from the smouldering ruins of the aircraft.

"This terrible loss of life is a reminder of how many men and women in the nation's military put their lives at risk each and every day so that we might be a free people and the cause of peace can be advanced throughout the world," the US president, Bill Clinton, said in a statement from the White House.

This is the third crash - and the second involving fatalities - of the revolutionary Osprey. US military planners hope the aircraft will enable them to deploy more combat-ready troops over a wider range at high speed than the Vietnam era CH-46 helicopters, which it was designed to replace.

In June 1991 a prototype crashed in Delaware during a test, causing injuries to two pilots but no loss of life. A year later, a second Osprey prototype crashed into the Potomac river just short of the marine air corps station runway at Quantico, Virginia. All seven people on board - three marines and four employees of Boeing - were killed.

The Osprey is manufactured by a consortium between Bell Helicopter Textron of Texas and Pennsylvania-based Boeing Helicopters. It flies at twice the speed of sound and can fly at an altitude of up to 25,000 feet. It is designed to carry up to 24 troops or civilian evacuees and can lift external loads of more than six tonnes. Each Osprey comes with a price tag of $40m(£25.3m).

Its most attractive design feature to military planners is its flexibility, combining the vertical flight, take-off and hover capabilities of a helicopter with the speed and range of a propeller-driven plane. The aircraft's main use would be to get more troops quickly into and out of combat zones, and in humanitarian and rescue missions.

In appearance, the Osprey is a turbo-prop plane fitted with rotatable engines on each wing. The Marine Corps has taken delivery of five Ospreys and intends to buy 350 overall, while the air force has plans for a further 50.

However, all plans are likely to be put on hold pending an investigation of the causes of the weekend crash.

webTitle: Anti-globalisation groups plan rerun of battle of Seattle

fields.headline: Anti-globalisation groups plan rerun of battle of Seattle
fields.trailText: Thousands of anti-free trade demonstrators are this week converging on Washington for what is being billed as "Seattle East".
fields.body:
Thousands of anti-free trade demonstrators are this week converging on Washington for what is being billed as "Seattle East".

Their aim is to cause the same disruption to the summit meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank as demonstrators achieved during the World Trade Organisation's gathering in Seattle in November.

"Lots of people were sorry not to have been involved in Seattle, perhaps because they couldn't afford to fly there," said Hilary McQuie, an organiser of this week's protests against globalisation and its effects on the world's poor.

"They were all anxious to play their part in Washington," said Ms McQuie, who also helped organise the Seattle protests.

More than 400 organisations are planning to send demonstrators to the US capital in preparation for the large-scale protests on April 16 and 17. The demonstrations are also known simply as A16.

Mike Dolan, deputy director of Global Trade Watch, said organisers anticipated a turnout the size of the gathering in November, when unconfirmed estimates put the number of protesters at the WTO conference at up to 100,000.

Mr Dolan said many east coast unions, student bodies, environmental groups and civil rights organisations have pledged to attend rallies in the capital. The Ruckus Society, which trains demonstrators in non-violent direct action, has been preparing demonstrators at in Berkeley, California.

Police in Washington have indicated that they are anxious not to be caught out like their colleagues in Seattle, who lost control of the streets.

All leave has been cancelled and the entire force of 3,500 officers will be on duty throughout the week. They have been shown videos of how the Seattle force over-reacted, losing both the public relations battle and control of the WTO conference.

Police in Washington have spent an additional $500,000 (£312,000) on riot control equipment and have the use of 1,500 officers specially trained in dealing with civil disturbances. Some officers will be equipped with shotguns adapted to fire rubber bullets.

In November city authorities imposed a curfew on central Seattle after demonstrators marched on the hall where the opening ceremonies of the WTO talks were due to start. Protesters attacked shops and other commercial premises.

webTitle: Greek rivals head for photo finish in general election

fields.headline: Greek rivals head for photo finish in general election
fields.trailText: Greece was gripped by political drama last night as exit polls put the socialist and conservative main contenders almost equal in the country's general election.
fields.body:
Greece was gripped by political drama last night as exit polls put the socialist and conservative main contenders almost equal in the country's general election.

"We look set for an all-night derby, a thriller in all senses of the word," political analyst Giorgos Sefertdzis told Greek television. Analysts said that whoever won would do so only by a hair's breadth.

A victory for the conservative New Democracy would end eight years of socialist rule under the prime minister, Costas Simitis, who had called the election five months ahead of schedule while riding a wave of popularity.

Successive polls had shown his party, Pasok, which was created out of an anti-junta movement, leading by 2.5% and Mr Simitis enjoying a 10-point lead in popularity ratings over his conservative rival, Costas Karamanlis.

From initial exit polls, Mr Sefertdzis said the biggest winner appeared to be bi-polar politics, with the two main parties gaining substantial support at the expense of Greece's three small leftwing parties.

The prospect of victory for the conservatives, out of office for 16 of the past 19 years, prompted thousands of jubilant, flag-waving supporters to gather outside the party's Athens headquarters.

But Mr Karamanlis, who has been credited with imbuing the New Democracy party with renewed self-confidence, refrained from making any statement.

Analysts said such a close race indicated that the prime minister, who has won praise for his fiscal reforms, had fallen victim to the painful measures that have been the backbone of his own success.

Complacency and allegations of arrogance have marred the socialist campaign. Leading Pasok officials said last night it was "unbelievable" that a party with such widespread support for its economic and foreign policies could have been overtaken by New Democracy.

"It was a botched campaign, one that did not reach out to the youth and did not indicate renewal, which is what our policies have been all about," said one. "Whether we win or lose there will be lots of recriminations."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Joy after Iraqi PoWs released
fields.body:
Joy after Iraqi PoWs released

Relatives hugged their menfolk and wept yesterday when 500 Iraqi prisoners of war arrived home from Iran nearly 12 years after the end of the 1980-88 war that claimed 1m lives on both sides.

Many in the first group of some 2,000 Iraqi prisoners of war whom Iran said on Wednesday it would release looked ill and exhausted. Relatives often had difficulty recognising the freed prisoners, some of whom had spent 18 years as captives.
Reuters, Munthiriya, Iraq

State of siege grips Bolivia

Protests in Bolivia against a potential 35% increase in water prices claimed two lives and injured 10 on Saturday. More than 20 people were jailed after the government declared a state of siege to quell a week of disturbances.

Police said a teacher was shot and killed when the military tried to clear a barricaded highway that runs south from the capital, La Paz, to Oruro, about 150 miles away. A youth was also shot and killed during violent protests in the central city of Cochabamba.
Reuters, La Paz

Public outrage curbs Weizman

The Israeli president, Ezer Weizman, yesterday appeared to bow to public outrage at allegations that he accepted bribes from a French textile tycoon.

In an interview with Israeli radio, Mr Weizman, 75, said he would make a formal announcement after the attorney general gives his report on the scandal.
Suzanne Goldenberg, Jerusalem

Georgia votes for status quo

Georgia's incumbent president, Eduard Shevardnadze, looked set for outright victory in yesterday's elections with about 60% of the vote, according to an exit poll. Some 64% of eligible voters had turned out.
AP, Tbilisi, Georgia

webTitle: Inmate flosses his way to freedom

fields.headline: Inmate flosses his way to freedom
fields.trailText: An Italian mafioso has broken out of a high-security prison and clinched a place in criminal history by sawing through the bars of his cell using nothing but dental floss.
fields.body:
An Italian mafioso has broken out of a high-security prison and clinched a place in criminal history by sawing through the bars of his cell using nothing but dental floss.

Vincenzo Curcio, convicted of one murder and arranging seven others, flossed his way to freedom after discovering that the bars at Vallette prison in Turin were made of ductile iron, which contains no carbon and is softer than steel or normal iron.

He sawed for several days and disposed of the shavings undetected by guards. Then he tied bedsheets together, shimmied to the ground and scaled the jail fence, grateful that the alarm system was out of order.

Bafflement at his success turned to outrage at the weekend when it was revealed, three weeks after the escape, that the bars were to blame.

Mortified officials explained that the prison was built in the 1970s, when fear of terrorists made it more important to design a building to withstand attack from outside, not escape from within.

The revelation piled fresh embarrassment on a judicial system already reeling from blunders.

An investigation is under way into how another mafioso was able to set up a printing press in his cell to forge banknotes.

Another inquiry is examining how 700,000 court cases were filed away in a basement and forgotten for more than 10 years until they were discovered late last year. Major unsolved cases are feared to be buried in the archive, which could take years to sort out.

Feminists gasped last month when it emerged that a Sicilian judge and lawyers had faked a trial in order to trick a new female prosecutor into unknowingly using obscene local slang.

Italy's highest appeals court last week ordered 11 convicted mass murderers, sentenced to life imprisonment, to be released immediately because too much time had passed while they waited for appeals.

fields.headline: The real teen spirit
fields.standfirst: Duncan Campbell on: The next generation | Script errors | The truth about American Beauty
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell on: The next generation | Script errors | The truth about American Beauty
fields.body:
The Wiltern theatre in Los Angeles is a glorious art deco building constructed in 1931 and saved at the last minute from imminent destruction during a bout of planning madness in the 80s. It was, like many of the equally fabulous but run-down buildings on LA's Broadway, once a movie theatre but now mainly used for music (Tracy Chapman is due there this month, giving an airing to her new album).

Having driven past it often, it was a treat to be able to go in and wander around at leisure last weekend during the bar and bat mitzvah ceremonies for two 14-year-old boys and one 13-year-old girl. One of the boys being the son of a friend.

It was, I was assured, not a typical LA bar mitzvah because the three were all part of something called the Sholem Educational Institute, which was one of the first secular Jewish groups to develop the concept of bar/bat mitzvahs in keeping with what they describe as "a humanist approach to Jewish identity".

Part of the ceremony involved the three teenagers delivering speeches on a subject of their choice. Since American teenagers usually only feature in the British media when they have shot a classmate in high school, it is perhaps worth recording what they talked about.

Casey, the 13-year-old girl, delivered a history of the Hollywood 10, the writers and directors blacklisted for their supposed communist sympathies in the 50s, describing each one of them and reflecting on how it was that people were persecuted for their political beliefs and whether it could happen again.

Sam, my friend's son, spoke about the relationship between blacks and Jews in the civil rights movement in the 60s, saying that the US at the time could have been described as "the land of the free - for whites". He drew attention to the fact that a disproportionate number of the young students who marched alongside the black civil rights marchers were Jewish, as were many of the lawyers who later defended those arrested in court.

Max spoke about resistance to fascism, using the stories of three elderly relatives who turned out to be sitting near the front of the theatre. All three presentations, which they had written themselves, raised the issue of people taking action against oppression. At a time when much is made of the rifts between black and Jewish communities over the anti-Semitic statements made by some members of the Nation of Islam, it was good to be reminded of the countless battles fought in common, rather than of the divisions.

This was accompanied by music the trio had chosen, including Oh, Freedom and the Partisan Hymn, as well as the more traditional tributes from relatives.

What emerged from all this was a sort of potted history of radicalism within the Jewish community in LA, stretching back to the times of the International Workers Organisation, the fight against McCarthyism and the early union battles. Unions are back to being big news in LA again, with the mainly Latino janitors who clean all the corporate buildings in downtown now on a series of rolling strikes to improve their appalling wages.

In his tribute to his son, one of the bar mitzvah boys' fathers, who had emigrated to LA from the east coast, explained that he had been so frightened of his children becoming Californian beach bunnies that he had subscribed to every publication that had the words New York in the title, and that this had clearly had the desired effect on his son, who gave, as did all three of them, the sort of historical analysis of their subjects of which any graduate student would have been proud.

At the end of the ceremony, their contemporaries announced that they were making donations in their name to charities which included an organisation that works jointly with Palestinian and Israeli children, and a law centre in LA that acts pro bono for undocumented workers. All that and a piece of LA's art deco history, too.

The sun seemed a bit brighter on Western Avenue when I emerged at the end of the afternoon.

A dance to the music of time

The old cliche has it that the difference between the UK and the US is that, in Britain, 100 miles is a long distance and, in America, 100 years is a long time.

I had this confirmed for me recently when I was walking down the street to my local store and was stopped by a stranger, an agitated woman carrying a script in her hand. Do you, she asked me, know much about "really old music"? There was a musical reference in the script but she was not sure what is was.

Well, I have seen a couple of performances of the work of the 12th-century German mystic and composer Hildegard of Bingen but I was not sure if that qualified me to be an expert and said so. I suggested she try a local coffee house, Abbot's Habit, which is usually full of people with unfinished scripts, as I thought someone there might be into madrigals and medieval music.

I bumped into her later. Had she discovered the provenance of the old piece of music her character needed to know about? Oh, yes, someone in Abbot's Habit had turned out to be an "old" music expert. They had explained that the music was a song performed by the heavy metal band Motorhead in 1972.

Since 1993, one of west Hollywood's most entertaining nights out has been the Uncabaret at Lunar Park on a Sunday night. Under the watchful eye of Beth Lapides and Greg Miller, comedians, writers, actors and performers talk about recent events in their lives rather than just telling jokes, with Lapides periodically breaking into their monologues on a remote mic with a helpful query or two.

On the night we went, the actor Tim Bagley, who is in the film Happy Texas, was talking about American Beauty, which his parents, who lived in a conservative state, had been to see on his recommendation. (People who have still not seen the film and who don't want to know the end, stop reading.) They remarked on the moment in the plot when the real estate agent played by Annette Bening had killed her husband, played by Kevin Spacey. No, no, said Bagley, Spacey had been killed by the ex-marine, Colonel Fitts, after the latter's repressed homosexual advance had been rebuffed.

Nonsense, his parents told him, there was none of that homosexual stuff in the version they saw. They suggested to him in all seriousness that maybe a special version of the film with all these sexual undertones was shown only in decadent places such as California. Perhaps they have stumbled across a wonderful idea whereby different endings of films can be made to cater to different parts of the country. Trainspotting would have had to run as a short in Miami.

What emerged from all this was a sort of potted history of radicalism within the Jewish community in LA, stretching back to the times of the International Workers Organisation, the fight against McCarthyism and the early union battles. Unions are back to being big news in LA again, with the mainly Latino janitors who clean all the corporate buildings in downtown now on a series of rolling strikes to improve their appalling wages. In his tribute to his son, one of the bar mitzvah boys' fathers, who had emigrated to LA from the east coast, explained that he had been so frightened of his children becoming Californian beach bunnies that he had subscribed to every publication that had the words New York in the title, and that this had clearly had the desired effect on his son, who gave, as did all three of them, the sort of historical analysis of their subjects of which any graduate student would have been proud. At the end of the ceremony, their contemporaries announced that they were making donations in their name to charities which included an organisation that works jointly with Palestinian and Israeli children, and a law centre in LA that acts pro bono for undocumented workers. All that and a piece of LA's art deco history, too. The sun seemed a bit brighter on Western Avenue when I emerged at the end of the afternoon. A dance to the music of time The old cliche has it that the difference between the UK and the US is that, in Britain, 100 miles is a long distance and, in America, 100 years is a long time. I had this confirmed for me recently when I was walking down the street to my local store and was stopped by a stranger, an agitated woman carrying a script in her hand. Do you, she asked me, know much about "really old music"? There was a musical reference in the script but she was not sure what is was. Well, I have seen a couple of performances of the work of the 12th-century German mystic and composer Hildegard of Bingen but I was not sure if that qualified me to be an expert and said so. I suggested she try a local coffee house, Abbot's Habit, which is usually full of people with unfinished scripts, as I thought someone there might be into madrigals and medieval music. I bumped into her later. Had she discovered the provenance of the old piece of music her character needed to know about? Oh, yes, someone in Abbot's Habit had turned out to be an "old" music expert. They had explained that the music was a song performed by the heavy metal band Motorhead in 1972. Since 1993, one of west Hollywood's most entertaining nights out has been the Uncabaret at Lunar Park on a Sunday night. Under the watchful eye of Beth Lapides and Greg Miller, comedians, writers, actors and performers talk about recent events in their lives rather than just telling jokes, with Lapides periodically breaking into their monologues on a remote mic with a helpful query or two. On the night we went, the actor Tim Bagley, who is in the film Happy Texas, was talking about American Beauty, which his parents, who lived in a conservative state, had been to see on his recommendation. (People who have still not seen the film and who don't want to know the end, stop reading.) They remarked on the moment in the plot when the real estate agent played by Annette Bening had killed her husband, played by Kevin Spacey. No, no, said Bagley, Spacey had been killed by the ex-marine, Colonel Fitts, after the latter's repressed homosexual advance had been rebuffed. Nonsense, his parents told him, there was none of that homosexual stuff in the version they saw. They suggested to him in all seriousness that maybe a special version of the film with all these sexual undertones was shown only in decadent places such as California. Perhaps they have stumbled across a wonderful idea whereby different endings of films can be made to cater to different parts of the country. Trainspotting would have had to run as a short in Miami.

fields.headline: Livingstone, I consume
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: I have spent most of the week in pursuit of a T-shirt. I stalk possessions like other people stalk celebrities. I seek out new brands like cults seek out lonely, socially inadequate undergraduates. There are, clearly, better things I should be doing with my time, but I find consumerism fills the aching void disaffected middle youth has hollowed out of me. At least for a short while.
fields.body:
I have spent most of the week in pursuit of a T-shirt. I stalk possessions like other people stalk celebrities. I seek out new brands like cults seek out lonely, socially inadequate undergraduates. There are, clearly, better things I should be doing with my time, but I find consumerism fills the aching void disaffected middle youth has hollowed out of me. At least for a short while.

So: the T-shirt. It was a twisted reworking of the classic Che Guevara image: a face, made up of black lines and shadows, superimposed on a red background. But Che's face had been replaced with Ken Livingstone's. And where the original read: CHE, it now bore the legend KEN. I loved its ambiguous, multi-layered politics, I loved its naivety, I loved its undertones of studenty idealism cut with grown-up cynicism

I staked out Portobello market for a while, because that seemed a likely enough fashion arena, but it wasn't there. I called Ken's campaign office, who immediately knew what I was talking about, said the T-shirt had nothing to do with them, but thought maybe I could find them somewhere in Covent Garden. "Though I don't think they're cheap," she added disapprovingly. I scoured Covent Garden, but came away with a Coffee Republic skinny latte. Finally, I posted a message on The Big Breakfast website, because that was where I originally spotted the T-shirt, clutched to Wayne Hemingway's breast.

I said: Subject - Red Ken's T-shirt. Does anyone know where I could get myself one of those Ken/Che Guevara T-shirts, as modelled by Wayne on last week's show?

After 48 hours, a Big Breakfast fan broke away from frantically debating Liza Tarbuck (was she crap, or THE BEST LADY TV PRESENTER IN THE WORLD, EVER?) to tell me they thought I could get said garment from The Dispensary in Notting Hill. Which I did. It set me back £18, which I didn't think was unreasonable.

Ken's book, Livingstone's London, is proving even more elusive. Though not quite as covetable as the T-shirt (because you can't wear it and thus alert the entire world to your wry political perspective, your general awareness, your biting wit) it's still got a considerable amount of coffee-table cachet. I could pop it on my bookshelf next to Nigella Lawson's How To Cook, and friends would see them both and know I was trying to be a better person.

Preliminary inquiries revealed that not only had the publication date been postponed (from last Thursday, to the end of the month), but, in the meantime, absolutely nothing was known about the oeuvre. There were no unbound proofs, no front covers, no writer's note, no hint of what, exactly, Livingstone meant by His London.

Was it, like, a list of his favourite pie and liquor shops? I asked the publisher's press officer. "I really, don't know," she said. Well, was it his London musings and philosophies, then? "Shall I read to you from my computer screen?" she asked. I said that would be nice. "It's an account of his personal experience of the city... combined with his manifesto... part autobiography, part polemic... lifetime of passion and personal vision for the future. And that's really all I know," she said, before sighing and promising to call back in a fortnight.

So, Ken's merchandise is proving thrilling in principle, but difficult to pin down in practice. Symbolism, maybe? Well no, actually, and anyway, that's not the point. The point is, Ken has desirable merchandise in the first place.

It takes relevance and a strong basic product to make your gimmicks and spin-offs recherché. Think Star Wars, Buzz Lightyear, Che Guevara and communism Cuban style. Ken's viability as merchandise says a great deal about his relevancy as a potential mayor. Dobson knick-knacks couldn't work in the same way. I do not ache for Dobbo's salad dressing, or for Frankie Says vest tops. The metaphor is staggeringly literal: I buy Ken. (Well, I would if I could track down his goodies.)

I suppose there's a certain amount of irony in the selling of Ken Livingstone. Merchandise does not coexist comfortably with socialist firebrand tendencies. It's a kind of a swizz in essence - advertising you get the people you are trying to advertise to, to pay for. But still, he must take comfort from the subtext - that, in London's eyes, Ken has an undeniable touch of Yoda, a trace of Che, a glimmer of Ali G about him.

A final word on the elusive merchandise front. During a recent trip to Havana, I raided all available souvenir shops for trashy Che articles. A surprising amount of my friends had asked me to seek out Guevara snowshakers for them. But it was entirely in vain. Bookmarks were your limit. The best I got was a fridge magnet. So maybe that's just the way with truly desirable merchandise.

webTitle: Tobin's tax plan finds favour only with the Finns

fields.headline: Tobin's tax plan finds favour only with the Finns
fields.trailText:
What is a Tobin tax?
It's a small tax on currency trading designed to stop countries being overwhelmed by hot money flows - waves of short-term capital of the kind which swamped the former tiger economies of South-east Asia in the 1990s.
fields.body:
What is a Tobin tax?
It's a small tax on currency trading designed to stop countries being overwhelmed by hot money flows - waves of short-term capital of the kind which swamped the former tiger economies of South-east Asia in the 1990s.

The idea was dreamed up by the Nobel prize-winning economist James Tobin in 1972 as a way of discouraging speculation by throwing "sand in the wheels" of forex trading. When Tobin invented his tax, $18bn a day changed hands in the world's foreign exchange dealing rooms. Today that has risen to $1.3trillion - and according to some estimates, a Tobin tax set at just 0.25% could raise $250bn a year.

Who would get the money?
Development agencies say it should go to the international development organisations to be spent on helping the world's poor. Just $8bn a year would buy universal primary education, says Oxfam.

Alleviating the worst forms of poverty would cost around $80bn. That would leave some spare change for international environmental problems.

Sounds a great idea, which governments are in favour ?
Apart from the Finns, no government has officially signed up to the tax. And that's the problem, because everybody more or less has to agree, otherwise the money dealers will simply move to a jurisdiction which doesn't levy the tax.

The argument over the witholding tax is an example of how sensitive financial centres, like the City of London, are to taxes which they fear could erode their competitiveness. The opponents of a Tobin tax argue that if just one offshore financial centre were to refuse to levy it, the world's banks would relocate en masse.

Is this likely?
It's somewhat exaggerated. There are other reasons for banks to have headquarters in London and there would be ways of disciplining rogue states. A more fundamental objection is that the tax is unlikely to stop the most destabilising forms of speculation.

When the markets sense that they are onto a one-way bet - for example a currency crisis such as the one which blew sterling out of the exchange rate mechanism back in 1992 - the rewards are so great that a small tax is unlikely to stop them. It could also make long-term investment, which most people agree is good for economies, less attractive.

In that case how do we stop speculation?
It's an unfashionable idea, but direct capital controls - such as those which were introduced by Malaysia during the East Asian crisis - could be one solution for developing countries. China still has capital controls and does not seem to have any problems attracting long-term investment while keeping the speculators at bay.

webTitle: Irish need more than a tenner to cure hangover

fields.headline: Irish need more than a tenner to cure hangover
fields.trailText: The rollicking progress of Ireland's economic miracle has British observers tut-tutting in a done-that sort of way and murmuring about "Nigel O'Lawson".
fields.body:
The rollicking progress of Ireland's economic miracle has British observers tut-tutting in a done-that sort of way and murmuring about "Nigel O'Lawson".

Actually, they've got the wrong man. With recent strikes paralysing the nation's public transport and the economy being run at reckless speed largely for foreign policy reasons, the obvious villain of the piece (if villain he be) has to be a Gaelic reincarnation of our long-ago but unforgettable demon chancellor, "Antaine Barber".

In the year to the end of February, lending to Irish residents ballooned by 35%, and house prices are predicted to rise a fifth during 2000 - which is not bad going for a country that's empty by English standards.

Having thrown away the option of higher interest rates (courtesy of the single currency), the authorities have put their faith in a latter day social contract, the "programme for prosperity and fairness".

This is the sort of meaningless, Heathite, feel-good handle that makes you long for someone bold enough to come forward and suggest a programme for pauperisation and gross iniquity. In the true spirit of the 70s, the programme has set a 5.5% pay norm and the transport disputes centred on claims nearly four times higher.

On March 29, the Irish central bank declared all to be right with the world. Just 24 hours later, Ireland's real central banker, Wim Duisenberg, poured cold water on such Panglossian patter and ordered this province of his monetary empire to get its inflationary house in order double quick.

Meanwhile, investors - deprived of the chance to sell a national currency - have cleared out of the stock market instead, which is currently one of the worst performing in Europe.

Surprisingly, the BBC - so eager recently to showcase the Irish miracle as a wonderful advertisement for joining the euro - hasn't had much space to devote to these difficulties. Doubtless lengthy coverage will be granted in due course.

Many, perhaps most, residents can see a property crash coming, but put their faith, post-crash, in the sort of social solidarity which was summed up by one retired customs officer only last week: "Everyone'll put a tenner in".

Maybe. In fact, there may be a case for suggesting that - even with the morning-after taken into account - manic upswings of this type may be no bad thing.

Our own wild party in 1971-1973 left a lot of debris in its wake, but it left also mass ownership of items, such as colour television sets, deep freezes, dishwashers and stereo systems, which had hitherto been regarded as luxuries .

Come the hangover of the late 1970s and early 1980s, these items were not confiscated by some sort of economic payback squad, and a good thing too. In Britain, as in Ireland or anywhere else, such goods - along with cars, houses, holidays and plentiful food - are desirable in themselves.

As for "aesthetic" objections to a booming economy, these usually emanate from those who are happily spared the grind of having to earn a living and are pretty well beneath contempt.

The snag comes for those who pay the ultimate bill. When the above thesis regarding the glories of the Barber boom was tried out recently on someone who was of primary school age at the time, her reply was uncomplicated: "Were you trying to find a job in 1984?"

Ah, yes. Quite.
